courses.title: Animal Health & Disease
courses.desc: Basic concepts of animal immunology, microbiology, parasitology, epidemiology, vaccination, and how the knowledge can be used to improve animal health and prevent animal infection & disease. Includes relevant health and disease issues.

courses.title: Ethics of Animal Use
courses.prereqs: Any basic course in composition or speech, or completion of college English requirement.
courses.desc: Ethical issues relating to animal use in contemporary society. Integration of philosophical theories with scientific evidence relating to animal behavior, mentality, and welfare. Uses of animals in agriculture, research, and as companions. Ethical responsibilities regarding wildlife and the environment.

courses.title: Undergraduate Honors Thesis in Animal Science
courses.prereqs: (NPB 101 or ANS 100);  (ABI 103 or BIS 103);  and Consent of Instructor.  Minimum cumulative GPA of 3.200 and selection by the Honors Selection Committee.
courses.desc: Carry out a research project (chosen from faculty-suggested or approved proposals) during the academic year under the guidance of a faculty member. Upon completion, write a thesis and present a public seminar describing his/her research.

courses.title: Undergraduate Honors Thesis in Animal Science
courses.prereqs: (NPB 101 or ANS 100);  (ABI 103 or BIS 103);  and Consent of Instructor.  Minimum cumulative GPA of 3.200 and selection by the Honors Selection Committee.
courses.desc: Carry out a research project (chosen from faculty-suggested or approved proposals) during the academic year under the guidance of a faculty member. Upon completion, write a thesis and present a public seminar describing his/her research.

courses.title: Undergraduate Honors Thesis in Animal Science
courses.prereqs: (NPB 101 or ANS 100);  (ABI 103 or BIS 103);  and Consent of Instructor.  Minimum cumulative GPA of 3.200 and selection by the Honors Selection Committee.
courses.desc: Carry out a research project (chosen from faculty-suggested or approved proposals) during the academic year under the guidance of a faculty member. Upon completion, write a thesis and present a public seminar describing his/her research.

courses.title: Strategies in Animal Production
courses.desc: Examines the forces and issues in animal agriculture through the strategic management process.

courses.title: Models in Agriculture & Nutrition
courses.desc: Basic model building principles and techniques for statistical and systems simulation models. Optimization techniques for non-linear experimental designs and management models are presented. Quantitative analysis and evaluation of linear and non-linear equations used in agriculture and nutrition.

courses.title: Group Study
courses.desc:
Lectures and discussions of advanced topics in the animal sciences.

(Sect. 1, 2, 3-letter grading; from Sect. 4 on-S/U grading only.)

courses.title: Human Evolutionary Biology
courses.desc: Processes and course of human evolution; primatology; biological and social diversity within Homo sapiens; human paleontology.

courses.title: Cultural Anthropology
courses.desc: Introduction to cultural diversity in its many forms and methods used by anthropologists to account for it. Relational dynamic of culture, history, and power in constituting "social facts" and "realities." Critical thinking of contemporary concerns.

courses.title: Introduction to Archaeology
courses.desc:
Development of archaeology as an anthropological study; objectives
and methods of modern archaeology.

courses.title: Introduction to Anthropological Linguistics
courses.desc: Exploration of the role of language in social interaction and world view, minority languages and dialects, bilingualism, literacy, the social motivation of language change. Introduction of analytical techniques of linguistics and demonstration of their relevance to language in sociocultural issues.

courses.title: Scientific Method in Physical Anthropology
courses.desc: Skills for scientific thinking; designing, implementing, analyzing, interpreting, presenting, and criticizing research. Collection and analysis of original data. Basic statistical methods.

courses.title: From Birth to Death: The Evolution of the Human Life Cycle
courses.desc: Introduction to the biology of birth, childhood, marriage, the family, old age, and death. Examines comparative characteristics of nonhuman primates and other animals as well as cross-cultural variation in humans by study of selected cases.

courses.title: Comparative Cultures
courses.desc:
Introduction to the anthropological study of cultural diversity. Case
studies of eight societies will be presented to illustrate and compare the distinctive features of major cultural regions of the world. Concludes with a discussion of modernization.

courses.title: Zombies
courses.desc: Figure of the zombie as window into ideas about race, economic exploitation, and what it means to be human. Zombie lore in the Afro-Atlantic world and its re-imagining in contemporary pop culture.

courses.title: Introduction to World Prehistory
courses.desc: Broadly surveys patterns and changes in the human species' physical and cultural evolution from earliest evidence for "humanness" to recent development of large-scale complex societies or "civilizations." Lectures emphasize use of archaeology in reconstructing the past.

courses.title: Ancient Crops & People
courses.desc: The archaeological evidence for domestication of plants and the origins of agricultural societies. Anthropological context of agriculture and the effects on sexual division of labor, social inequality, wealth accumulation, warfare, human health, and sedentism.

courses.title: Ancient Animals & People
courses.desc: History of human and animal relationships and how animals have influenced social and economic structures of past societies. Why, when and how humans used animals in the context of hunting, domestication, secondary products, ritual, companionship, and conservation.

courses.title: Mummies of the Ancient World
courses.desc: Archaeological approaches for studying mummies and the process of mummification in the ancient world. Analytical techniques used, environmental factors promoting mummification, and archaeological conservation of mummified bodies.

courses.title: Great Adaptations: Genetic & Cultural Evolution in the Spread of Humanity
courses.desc: How humans adapted to diverse ecologies through cultural and genetic changes. Illustrations include evolution in response to disease, dietary, social, and communication challenges.

courses.title: Prehistoric Origins of Art
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary look at the earliest evidence for art and symbolic behavior. Method and techniques to investigate Prehistoric art. Interpretative framework and relevance for understanding the role of symbolic activities in traditional societies.

courses.title: Vikings
courses.desc: History of the Vikings through the Slavic and Mediterranean regions in the East and across the vast North Atlantic region to the west. Emphasis on archaeology and sagas to understand Viking culture from the 8th to 11th centuries.

courses.title: Sexualities
courses.desc: Introduction to the study of sexuality, particularly to the meanings and social organization of same-sex sexual behavior across cultures and through time.  Biological and cultural approaches will be compared, and current North American issues placed in a wider comparative context.

courses.title: Drugs, Science & Culture
courses.desc: Drugs, politics, science, society in a cultural perspective: emphasis on roles of science, government and the media in shifting attitudes toward alcohol, marijuana, Prozac and other pharmaceuticals; drug laws, war on drugs and global trade in sugar, opium, cocaine.

courses.title: Cultures of Consumerism
courses.desc: Aspects of modern consumer cultures in capitalist and socialist countries. Transformations of material cultures over the past century. Case studies on the intersections of gender, class, and culture in everyday consumption practices.

courses.title: Star Trek as Social Theory
courses.desc: Introduction to core concepts in anthropological and social theory using Star Trek as a teaching vehicle. Emphasis on thinking anthropologically about everyday life and popular culture.

courses.title: Introduction to Primatology
courses.desc: Basic survey of the primates as a separate order of mammals; natural history and evolution of primates; consideration of hypotheses for their origin.

courses.title: Introduction to Forensic Anthropology
courses.desc: Survey of anthropological techniques as applied within the legal system, including scene documentation and recovery, human identification, and trauma analysis. Examination of error and uncertainty, ethics, and human rights in forensic anthropology.

courses.title: Theory in Social-Cultural Anthropology
courses.desc: Discussion of the theoretical and philosophical developments in cultural anthropology from the 19th century to the present.

courses.title: Ecology, Nature, & Society
courses.prereqs: ANT 001 or ANT 002 or ESP 030 or EVE 100 or BIS 101 recommended.
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary study of diversity and change in human societies, using frameworks from anthropology, evolutionary ecology, history, archaeology, psychology, and other fields. Topics include population dynamics, subsistence transitions, family organization, disease, economics, warfare, politics, and resource conservation.

courses.title: Indigenous Peoples & Natural Resource Conservation
courses.prereqs: ANT 002 or GEL 001 or ESP 030 recommended.
courses.desc: Integration of the interests of resident and indigenous peoples with the conservation of natural resources and ecosystems, using case study examples from both the developing and developed world.

courses.title: Cultural Politics of the Environment
courses.desc: Political economy of environmental struggles. Relationship between social inequality (based on race, class and/or gender) and ecological degradation. Articulation of local peoples, national policy, and the international global economy in the contestation over the use of environmental resources.

courses.title: Law, Power, Violence
courses.desc: Cultural dimensions of law and political power.  Colonial and postcolonial legal regimes, bureaucratic reason, legalized violence, sovereign power, and human rights.

courses.title: Visualization in Science: A Critical Introduction
courses.prereqs: ANT 002 or STS 001 or STS 020 recommended.
courses.desc: Anthropological approaches to scientific visualization techniques, informatics, simulations. Examination of different visualization techniques toward understanding the work involved in producing them, critical assessment of their power and limits, especially when visualizations are used socially to make claims.

courses.title: Language and Society
courses.prereqs: ANT 004 or LIN 001 recommended; ANT 002 recommended.
courses.desc: Consideration of language in its social context. Methods of data collection and analysis; identification of socially significant linguistic variables. Contributions of the study of contextualized speech to linguistic theory.

courses.title: The Ethnographic & Literary Imagination
courses.desc: The ethnographic and literary imagination. Relationship between fiction & anthropology, narrative form, modalities of ethnographic encounter, social & historical phenomena, aesthetics, poetics, language, and the question of representation.

courses.title: Language & Culture
courses.prereqs: ANT 004 or LIN 001 recommended; ANT 002 recommended.
courses.desc: Culture, cognition, meaning, and interpretation; language and the classification of experience; communication and learning in crosscultural perspective.

courses.title: Special Topics in Medical Anthropology
courses.desc: Introduction to critical medical anthropology. Topics include anthropological analysis of bio-medicine, psychiatry, systems of knowledge and healing, the body, emotions, and clinical encounters in a cross-cultural perspective.

courses.title: Economic Anthropology
courses.desc: The varieties of production, exchange, and consumption behavior in precapitalist economies, their interaction with culture and social-political organization, and the theories that account for these phenomena.  The effects of capitalism on precapitalist sectors.

courses.title: Anthropology & Political Economy
courses.desc: Survey of anthropological approaches to the study of political organizations; inter-relationships among political institutions, economic infrastructures and cultural complexity.

courses.title: Capitalism & Power
courses.desc: Theorizations of economy and society. The rise of modern capitalism and new social and political formations. Relationships between value and violence, subjectivity, the unconscious, money, imperialism and different understandings of exchange and the political.

courses.title: Resistance, Rebellion, & Popular Movements
courses.desc: Analysis of popular protest in Third World and indigenous societies ranging from covert resistance to national revolts. Comparative case studies and theories of peasant rebellions, millenarian movements, social bandits, Indian "wars", ethnic and regional conflicts, gender and class conflicts.

courses.title: Religion in Society & Culture
courses.desc: Discussion of anthropological theories of religion with emphasis on non-literate societies. Survey of shamanism, magic and witchcraft, ritual and symbols, and religious movements. Extensive discussion of ethnographic examples and analysis of social functions of religious institutions.

courses.title: Structuralism & Symbolism
courses.desc: Survey of anthropological approaches to understanding the logic of structuralism and symbolism in cultural analysis. Focus on how structural and symbolic interpretations relate to cultural and linguistic universals and to the philosophical basis of relativism in the social sciences. (Former ANT 125.)

courses.title: Postmodernism(s) & Culture
courses.desc: Crucial theories of modernity and post-modernity. How postmodernism is distinct from modernism, why it is related to the collapse of certainty about our collective reality and what it reveals about the status of reason, the self, and collective experience. Readings draw from various philosophical-theoretical, artistic and political literatures.

courses.title: Anthropology of Development
courses.desc: Theories of development and current critiques. Colonial legacies and post-colonial realities. Roles of the state and NGOs, population migrations, changing gender identities, cash-earning strategies, and sustainability issues. Stresses importance of cultural understandings in development initiatives. Case studies emphasizing non-industrial societies.

courses.title: Women & Development
courses.desc: Current Third World and Western development issues concerning women in agriculture, industry, international division of labor, political movements, revolutions, politics of health, education, family and reproduction. Impact of colonialism, capitalism, the world system, and international feminism on women and development.

courses.title: Urban Anthropology
courses.desc:
Survey of approaches to urban living: political structures, organization
of labor, class relations, world views. The evolution of urban life and its contemporary dilemmas. Cross-cultural comparisons discussed through
case studies.

courses.title: Kinship & Social Organization
courses.desc: Comparative examination of personal kinship, descent, marriage, household and family organizations; the theories that account for variation, and recent advances in the treatment of these data.

courses.title: Self, Identity, & Family
courses.desc: Exploration of self, identity, and family systems cross-culturally. Impact of class, gender, race, ethnicity, ruralization, urbanization, and globalization on notions of selfhood in different social/cultural systems.

courses.title: Health & Medicine in a Global Context
courses.desc: Recent works in medical anthropology and the science studies of medicine dealing with social and cultural aspects of global health issues such as AIDS, pandemics, clinical trials, cultural differences in illnesses, diabetes, organ trafficking, medical technologies, illness narratives, and others.

courses.title: Cultural Dimensions of Globalization
courses.desc: Cultural dimensions of recent economic and political developments frequently termed "globalization."

courses.title: Migration & the Politics of Place & Identity
courses.desc: Internal and international migration from an anthropological perspective, including causes, processes, and political, economic, and cultural effects of spatial mobility and displacement.  Emphasizes the interplay of identity, place, and power in diverse cultural and historical contexts.

courses.title: Ecology & Politics
courses.desc: Analysis of the complex interactions between ecological dynamics and political processes employing the emerging approach of political ecology. Case studies of environmental degradation (e.g., desertification, logging, mineral extraction, petroleum, water) from various cultural and geographic regions.

courses.title: Psychological Anthropology
courses.desc: History of the relationship between anthropology and psychoanalysis. Exploration of anthropology of emotions, colonial psychology, contemporary ethno-psychiatry, studies on personhood, possession, magic, altered states, subjectivity, and definitions of the normal and the pathological in different contexts and cultures.

courses.title: Anthropology of Ocean Worlds
courses.desc: Exploration of various oceanic cultures and their engagement with the sea. Piracy, smuggling, exchange, maritime legal regimes, offshore policing, media infrastructures, and ocean ecologies.

courses.title: Buddhism in Global Culture
courses.desc: Buddhist meditation and ritual as a cultural system that adapts to global and local forces of change. Anthropological theory and method in understanding global culture transmission, including Buddhist reform movements in Asia and Buddhist practice in the West.

courses.title: Media Anthropology
courses.desc: Examining human practices through their inscription in old and new media; evaluating the emergent fields of “cyber” and “digital” anthropology; and problematizing terms and concepts routinely deployed in studies of media worlds—platform, social media, hologram, algorithm, remediation, curation, animation.

courses.title: Ethnographic Film
courses.desc: Overview of the use of film in anthropology and its advantages and limitations in comparison to written ethnographic descriptions. Essential features of ethnographic films. Film production in anthropological research and problems encountered in producing films in the field.

courses.title: Meditation & Culture
courses.desc: Study and practice of the relation between meditation and cultural conditioning; comparison of Buddhist practice with other cultural constructions of mind, body, brain, thought, emotion, and self.

courses.title: Ethnographic Research Methods in Anthropology
courses.desc: Basic concepts in and approaches to ethnographic field research. Problem formulation, research design, qualitative and quantitative data collection procedures, and techniques for organizing, retrieving, and analyzing information. Ethnographic description and constructed inference. Students will organize and conduct individual research projects.

courses.title: Race, Class, Gender Systems
courses.desc: Comparative analysis of class/race/gender inequality, concentrating on the ways in which beliefs about descent, "blood," and biological difference interact with property and marital systems to affect the distribution of power in society.

courses.title: Gender & Sexuality
courses.desc: Gender and sexuality in foraging bands, horticultural and pastoral tribes, agricultural and industrial states. Debates on cultural evolution and distribution of gender hierarchies. Impact of politics, economics, religion, social practices, women's movements on gender and sexuality. Culture, nature and sexuality.

courses.title: Cultures & Societies of West & Central Africa
courses.desc: Ethnographic survey of West Africa and Congo Basin with analyses of representative societies which illustrate problems of general theoretical concern. Major consideration will be the continuities and discontinuities between periods prior to European contact and the present.

courses.title: Cultures & Societies of East & South Africa
courses.desc: Ethnographic survey of Eastern and Southern Africa with analyses of selected societies which illustrate problems of interest to anthropologists. Major consideration will be given to continuities and discontinuities between periods prior to European contact and the present.

courses.title: People of the Arctic: Contemporary & Historic Cultures of the Circumpolar Region
courses.desc: Social, economic, political, and religious lives of Russian, American, Canadian, and Greenlandic Arctic people (Yup'ik, Iñupiat, Inuit). Topics include Arctic ecosystems, archaeological record of human occupation, ethnohistorical and ethnographic accounts, arctic people in popular culture, and contemporary issues.

courses.title: Peoples of the Middle East
courses.desc: Peoples of the Middle East (including North Africa). Discussions of class relations, kinship organization, sex/gender systems, religious beliefs and behavior, ethnic relations, political systems. Impact of world systems, political and religious movements and social change. (Former ANT 136.)

courses.title: Ethnology of Southeast Asia
courses.desc: Patterns of culture and social organization from prehistory to the present, in the context of historical, ecological, economic, and political settings. Emphasis on the relation of ethnic minorities to national states.

courses.title: Contemporary Societies & Cultures of Latin America
courses.desc: Introduction to contemporary social structure of Latin America. Origins, maintenance and changes in inequality: economic responses to poverty, sociocultural responses to discrimination, and political responses to powerlessness.

courses.title: Performance, Embodiment, & Space in South Asia
courses.desc: South Asian cultures and societies with a focus on performance, embodiment, and space from several disciplinary fields. Topics may include colonialism, nationalism, religious traditions, media, popular culture, cities, social movements, modernity, body-cultures, identity, gender, and diasporas.

courses.title: Topics in the Anthropology of Europe
courses.desc: Recent ethnographies of different nation-states and socio-political spaces in Europe. Topics include the question of old and new boundaries, historical and contemporary constructions of Europe, migration and ethnicity, citizenship, belonging, multiculturalism, and post/socialisms.

courses.title: Modern South Asia Cinema
courses.prereqs: Upper division standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: South Asian cinema of last 100 years in the context of cultural, social, and political changes. South Asian history, Independence, Partition, urban life, class, migration, postcolonial identity, diaspora, gender, sexuality, religion, sport, performance, etc.

courses.title: Culture & Political Economy in Contemporary China
courses.desc: Examining contemporary Chinese culture and political economy through reading ethnographic studies on recent transformations in rural and urban Chinese society. Special attention is given to state power, popular culture, spatial mobility, city space, and gender.

courses.title: Primate Evolution
courses.prereqs: ANT 001 or BIS 002B or BIS 002C or EVE 010 recommended.
courses.desc: Origin and relationships of the prosimians, monkeys, and apes.

courses.title: Human Evolution
courses.desc: Nature and results of the evolutionary processes involved in the formation and differentiation of humankind.

courses.title: Human Genetics: Mutation & Migration
courses.prereqs: BIS 002B C- or better or MCB 010 C- or better.
courses.desc: Introduction to human genetics. Principles of inheritance, the human genome, population genetics, mutation, genetic diversity, using DNA to study ancient human history, personal genomics. Human genetics as a tool to understand the patterns and processes of human migration. Introduction to the major concepts in human genetic and genomic research.

courses.title: The Evolution of Primate Behavior
courses.prereqs: ANT 001 or ANT 054 or EVE 010 recommended.
courses.desc: Examines ecological diversity and evolution of social systems of prosimians, monkeys, and apes, placing the social behavior of the primates in the context of appropriate ecological and evolutionary theory.

courses.title: Primate Evolutionary Ecology
courses.desc: Examination of the ecology of primates within an evolutionary framework. Theoretical concepts in individual, population, and community ecology, illustrated with primate (and other vertebrate) examples, with additional discussion of primate and rainforest conservation.

courses.title: Primate Behavior: Methods & Experimental Design
courses.prereqs: (ANT 054 or ANT 154A or ANT 154B or NPB 102);  (STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 032 or STA 100 or SOC 046B);  ANT 154CL (can be concurrent).
courses.desc: Scientific methods of studying, describing and analyzing the behavior and ecology of primates.

courses.title: Primate Conservation Biology
courses.desc: Study of the taxonomic, ecological and cultural diversity of Primates and how human activities impact tropical ecosystems. Emphasis on case studies and applied research methods. Includes discussion about career opportunities in conservation.

courses.title: Human Osteology
courses.desc: Human skeleton from archaeological, forensic, and paleontological perspectives, including anatomical nomenclature, variation with sex and age, function, evolution, growth, and development of bones and teeth. Hands-on study and identification of human skeletal remains.

courses.title: Advanced Human Osteology
courses.desc: Human skeletons from archaeological, forensic, and paleontological contexts. Bone and tooth structure, growth, and development; measurement, statistics, and biomechanics; assessment of age, sex, weight, height, and ancestry; and indicators of illness, injuries, diet, and activities.

courses.title: Advanced Human Genetics
courses.prereqs: ANT 153 or BIS 101 or EVE 102 or EVE 131 or EVE 175 or MCB 162 or MCB 182.
courses.desc: Advanced concepts in human genetics and genomics. Identification of genes underlying human health and disease. Use of genomic data in clinical settings and examination of biases associated with 'personalized medicine." Emphasis on current human genomic technology and critical reading of scientific papers.

courses.title: Evolution of Females & Males: Biological Perspective
courses.desc: Current theoretical frameworks for explaining the evolution of sex differences and for understanding the interrelationship between biological processes and cultural construction of gender roles.

courses.title: Neandertals & Modern Human Origins
courses.prereqs: ANT 001 or ANT 001Y or equivalent recommended.
courses.desc: Origins, evolution, and disappearance of Neandertals. Emergence of humans like us in both anatomy and behavior. Interpretation of the fossil and archaeological records of Europe and Africa. Genetics of living and fossil humans.

courses.title: Archeological Theory & Method
courses.desc: Introduction to history and development of archeological theory and method, with particular emphasis on the basic dependence of the latter on the former. Stress is on historical development of archaeology in the New World.

courses.title: New World Prehistory: The First Arrivals
courses.desc: Survey of data relating to the peopling of the New World. Cultural adaptation and development of early inhabitants of North and South America.

courses.title: European Prehistory
courses.desc: Survey of the prehistory of Europe from its earliest human inhabitants, to the Neandertals and first modern humans, and through early agricultural and complex societies. Analysis and interpretation of the European archaeological record for understanding human dispersals into Europe.

courses.title: Andean Prehistory: Archaeology of the Incas & Their Ancestors
courses.desc: Prehistory of the Andean region, especially Peru, from the earliest hunting and gathering societies through the Inca. Focus on the use of archaeological data to reconstruct ancient human adaptations to the varied Andean environments.

courses.title: Prehistory of California & the Great Basin
courses.desc: Description and analysis of the prehistoric peoples of California and the Great Basin from earliest times to European contact.

courses.title: African Prehistory
courses.desc: Survey of prehistory of Africa from early human ancestors, through modern human origins, and into early agricultural and complex societies and the Bantu expansion.  Analysis and interpretation of the African archaeological record, incorporating human paleontology and genetics.

courses.title: Hunter-Gatherers
courses.desc: Study and interpretation of the ancient and modern lifeway in which peoples support themselves with primitive technologies and without benefit of domesticated plants and animals.

courses.title: Asian Prehistory
courses.desc: Survey of the prehistory of Asia from the earliest human occupations to the rise of complex societies. Special focus on fossil and archeological records.

courses.title: Zooarchaeology
courses.desc: Theories and methods for studying animal skeletal remains from archaeological sites. Identification and quantification of zooarchaeological material, cultural and natural processes affecting animal bones pre- and postburial, and use of faunal remains for determining past human diets and past environments.

courses.title: Archaeological Field Methods
courses.desc: Survey of archeological field methods and techniques. Strategies for survey and site location, mapping of artifacts and features, geophysical techniques, and hand excavation and analysis of stratigraphy.

courses.title: Archaeometry
courses.desc: Scientific techniques used to study the chemical and physical properties of archaeological materials. Types of anthropological questions that can be addressed with different methods. Preparation and analysis of archaeological materials.

courses.title: Laboratory in Archeological Analysis
courses.desc: Museum preparation, advanced field investigation, and guidance in preparation of museum material for publication.

courses.title: Prehistoric Technology: The Material Aspects of Prehistoric Adaptation
courses.desc: Examination of the role of lithic, ceramic, textile and wooden implements as elements in prehistoric survival and development. Emphasis is descriptive, but the significance of material resources as factors in prehistoric adaptation, settlement patterns, and culture change are discussed.

courses.title: Lithic Analysis
courses.desc: Basic concepts of lithic analysis. General introduction on the place of stone tool technology in the archeological record. Physics, terminology and methodological concepts behind the study of stone tools. Review of the development of stone tool technology from its emergence.

courses.title: Museum Studies: Analysis of Native American Basketry
courses.desc: Study of ethnographic and prehistoric basketry from North America, especially California and Oregon, in a multidisciplinary anthropological context. Techniques for basketry attribution and textile analysis.

courses.title: Cultural Resource Management in Archaeology
courses.prereqs: ANT 003;  or Consent of Instructor.  ANT 170 recommended.
courses.desc: Examination of legal foundations and goals of cultural resource management in the United States, with a focus on archaeological resources. Review of state and federal regulations, guidelines for assessing eligibility for listing in the National Register of Historic Places, professional practices to preserve and mitigate damage to resources, and public outreach practices.

courses.title: History of Anthropology
courses.desc: Historical development of socio-cultural theory within anthropology, from mid-19th to mid-20th centuries. Focus on original theory texts in context of historical developments in the field as a whole.

courses.title: Political Ecology
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary seminar evaluating contributions from ecological anthropology, political economy, cultural constructivism, postmodernism, and feminism towards development of theories of political ecology. Historical relationships between local/global power structures, environmental degradation, and resistance movements. Case studies of desertification, deforestation, mining, conservation, development.

courses.title: Quantitative Modeling in Archaeology
courses.desc: Examination of the nature of archaeological data with a focus on the quantitative and statistical techniques available to model, analyze, display, and make sense of such data.

courses.title: Family Systems & Reproduction: Theory & Comparisons
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing in one of the social sciences including History.
courses.desc: Comparative examination of family systems in historical context and of reproductive behaviors and strategizing. A major theme is how family-system norms specify the relative desirability of differently configured offspring sets. Cases are drawn from Western Europe and South and East Asia.

courses.title: Modeling the evolution of social behavior
courses.prereqs: MAT 016C;  or Consent of Instructor.  Or equivalent of MAT 016C.
courses.desc: Tools and topics in modeling the evolution of social behavior in humans and other animals. Game theory, basic population genetics, animal conflict, altruism, reciprocity, signaling, and group selection.

courses.title: Comparative Vertebrate Organology
courses.desc: Functional anatomy of major organ systems in vertebrates. Each system examined from cellular to gross level in fish, birds, and mammals. Emphasis on how differentiated cell types are integrated into tissues and organs to perform diverse physiological functions.

courses.title: Basics of Microscopy & Cellular Imaging
courses.desc: Practical applications of basic microscope techniques used to image cells and tissues with the goal of using these techniques to generate publication quality images. Principles of light, epifluorescent, confocal and electron microscopy, their applications and limitations.

courses.title: Elementary Arabic 1
courses.desc: Introduction to basic Arabic. Interactive and integrated presentation of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills, including the alphabet and basic syntax. Focus on standard Arabic with basic skills in spoken Egyptian and/or one other colloquial dialect.

courses.title: Accelerated Intensive Elementary Arabic
courses.desc: Special 12-week accelerated, intensive summer session course that combines the work of courses ARB 001, 002, and 003. Introduction to Modern Standard Arabic through development of all language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communicative proficiency.

courses.title: Elementary Arabic 2
courses.desc: Continuation of basic Arabic from ARB 001. Interactive and integrated presentation of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills, including syntax. Focus on standard Arabic and limited use of spoken Egyptian and/or one other colloquial dialect.

courses.title: Elementary Arabic 3
courses.desc: Continuation of introduction to basic Arabic from ARB 001 and ARB 002. Interactive and integrated presentation of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills, including syntax. Focus on standard Arabic with limited use of spoken Egyptian and/or one other colloquial dialect.

courses.title: Intermediate Arabic 21
courses.desc: Builds on courses ARB 001, ARB 002, and ARB 003. Interactive and integrated presentation of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills, including idiomatic expression. Focus on standard Arabic with limited use of Egyptian and/or one other colloquial dialect.

courses.title: Accelerated Intensive Intermediate Arabic
courses.desc: Special 12-week accelerated, intensive summer session course that combines the work of courses ARB 021, ARB 022, and ARB 023. Modern Standard Arabic through development of all language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communicative proficiency.

courses.title: Colloquial Egyptian Arabic
courses.desc: Continuation of the Colloquial Egyptian Arabic covered in the first year of Arabic; ARB 001, ARB 002, and ARB 003.

courses.title: Colloquial Levantine Arabic
courses.desc: Continuation of colloquial Levantine Arabic presented in ARB 001, ARB 002 and ARB 003. Integrated presentation of speaking and listening skills in colloquial Levantine Arabic, with reading and writing in Modern Standard Arabic that is related to Levantine cultural production and social life.

courses.title: Intermediate Arabic 22
courses.desc: Continuation of ARB 021. Interactive and integrated presentation of listening, speaking, reading, and writing, including idiomatic expression. Focus on standard Arabic with limited use of Egyptian and/or one other colloquial dialect.

courses.title: Colloquial Egyptian Arabic
courses.desc: Continuation of the Colloquial Egyptian Arabic covered in first year of Arabic; courses ARB 001, ARB 002, and ARB 003 and the first quarter of Colloquial Arabic ARB 021C.

courses.title: Colloquial Levantine Arabic
courses.desc: Continuation of colloquial Levantine Arabic presented in ARB 021L. Integrated presentation of speaking and listening skills in colloquial Levantine Arabic; reading and writing in Modern Standard Arabic related to Levantine social life.

courses.title: Intermediate Arabic 23
courses.desc: Continuation of ARB 021 and ARB 022. Interactive and integrated presentation of Arabic listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills, including idiomatic expression.

courses.title: Colloquial Egyptian Arabic
courses.desc: Continuation of Colloquial Egyptian Arabic covered in ARB 022C.

courses.title: Colloquial Levantine Arabic
courses.desc: Continuation of colloquial Levantine Arabic presented in ARB 022L. Integrated presentation of speaking and listening skills in colloquial Levantine Arabic; reading and writing in Modern Standard Arabic related to Levantine social life.

courses.title: Advanced Arabic
courses.desc: Review, refinement, and development of skills learned in intermediate Arabic through work with texts, video, and audio on cultural and social issues. Integrated approach to reading, writing, listening, speaking primarily standard Arabic, with limited use of one colloquial dialect.

courses.title: Advanced Arabic
courses.desc: Continuation of ARB 121. Further development of advanced skills in reading, listening, writing, and speaking standard Arabic through work with texts, video, and audio on cultural and social issues. Limited use of one colloquial dialect.

courses.title: Advanced Arabic
courses.desc: Continuation of ARB 122. Further development of advanced skills in reading, listening, writing, and speaking standard Arabic through work with texts, video, and audio on cultural and social issues. Limited use of one colloquial dialect.

courses.title: A Story for a Life: The Arabian Nights
courses.desc: In-depth exploration of The Arabian Nights, the best-known work of pre-modern Arabic literature and a major work of world literature. Analysis of the work in its historical context and in comparison to other frame tales in world literature.

courses.title: Readings in Modern Arabic Literature
courses.desc: Readings of modern Arabic poetry and fiction in original format, assisted by instructor-prepared glossaries and other supplementary material. Readings to be followed by class discussion and short writing assignments in Arabic. Open to students at advanced proficiency in Arabic.

courses.title: Economic Basis of the Agricultural Industry
courses.desc:
Agriculture and man; the agricultural industry in U.S. and world economies; production and supply, marketing and demand; agricultural
land, capital and labor markets; economic and social problems of agriculture in an urban and industrialized economy emphasizing California.

courses.title: Economic Basis of the Agricultural Industry
courses.desc: Agriculture and man; the agricultural industry in Australia and world economies; production and supply, marketing and demand; agricultural land, capital and labor markets; economic and social problems of agriculture in an urban and industrialized economy emphasizing Australia. May be taught abroad in Australia under the supervision of a UC Davis faculty member.

courses.title: Population, Environment & World Agriculture
courses.desc: Economic analysis of interactions among population, environment, natural resources and development of world agriculture. Introduces students to economic thinking about population growth, its causes and consequences for world food demand, and environmental and technological limits to increasing food supplies.

courses.title: Business Law
courses.desc: General principles of business law in the areas of contracts, business organization, real property, uniform commercial code, sales, commercial paper, employment relations, and creditor-debtor against a background of the history and functioning of our present legal system.

courses.title: Intermediate Microeconomics: Theory of Production & Consumption
courses.prereqs: ((ECN 001A C- or better or ECN 001AV C- or better);  ECN 001B C- or better);  ((MAT 016A C- or better,  MAT 016B C- or better,  MAT 016C C- or better) or (MAT 017A C- or better,  MAT 017B C- or better) or (MAT 021A C- or better,  MAT 021B C- or better)).
courses.desc: Theory of individual consumer and market demand; theory of production and supply of agricultural products, with particular reference to the individual firm; price determination, and employment of resources under pure competition.

courses.title: Intermediate Microeconomics: Imperfect Competition, Markets & Welfare Economics
courses.prereqs: ARE 100A C- or better;  ((ECN 001A C-  or better or ECN 001AV C- or better);  ECN 001B C- or better);  ((MAT 016A C- or better,  MAT 016B C- or better,  MAT 016C C- or better) or (MAT 017A C- or better,  MAT 017B C- or better) or (MAT 021A C- or better,  MAT 021B C- or better)).
courses.desc: Price determination, and employment of resources under conditions of monopoly, oligopoly, and monopolistic competition.

courses.title: Econometric Theory & Applications
courses.prereqs: ARE 100A C- or better;  (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better);  STA 103 C- or better.
courses.desc: Statistical methods for analyzing data to solve problems in managerial economics. Topics include the linear regression model, methods to resolve data problems, and the economic interpretation of results.

courses.title: Econometrics for Business Decisions
courses.prereqs: ARE 100A C- or better;  ARE 106 C- or better;  (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better);  STA 103 C- or better.
courses.desc: Covers state-of-the art econometric and statistical methods for causal and predictive modeling with applications to finance and marketing.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Organization Management
courses.desc: Role of organizational design and behavior in business and public agencies. Principles of planning, decision making, individual behavior, management, leadership, informal groups, conflict and change in the organization. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Marketing Management
courses.prereqs: ECN 001A or ECN 001AV;  For non-majors only.
courses.desc: Nature of product marketing by the business firm. Customer-product relationships, pricing and demand; new product development and marketing strategy; promotion and advertising; product life cycles; the distribution system; manufacturing, wholesaling, retailing. Government regulation and restraints.

courses.title: Economic Development
courses.desc:
Major issues encountered in emerging from international poverty, problems of growth and structural change, human welfare, population
growth and health, labor markets and internal migration. Important issues of policy concerning international trade and industrialization.

courses.title: Economic Development
courses.desc: Macroeconomic issues of developing countries. Issues include problems in generating capital, conduct of monetary and fiscal policies, foreign aid and investment. Important issues of policy concerning international borrowing and external debt of developing countries.

courses.title: Economic Development
courses.desc: Macroeconomic issues of developing countries. Problems in generating capital, conduct of monetary and fiscal policies, foreign aid and investment.  Issues of policy concerning international borrowing and external debt of developing countries.

courses.title: Tax Accounting
courses.desc: Development and application of a framework to understand the tax effects of typical management decisions on both entities and their owners. Impacts that different methods of taxation have on business entities with emphasis on tax planning, using income and deduction strategies, retirement plans, and choice of business entity for tax minimization.

courses.title: Intermediate Managerial Accounting
courses.desc: Use of accounting information by mangers in decision making, planning, directing and controlling operations. Focuses on managerial/cost accounting theory and practice. Covers costing systems, budgeting, and financial statement analysis.

courses.title: Agricultural Policy
courses.desc: Analytical treatment of historical and current economic problems and governmental policies influencing American agriculture. Uses of economic theory to develop historical and conceptual understanding of the economics of agriculture; how public policy influences the nature and performance of American agriculture.

courses.title: Agricultural Policy
courses.desc: Analytical treatment of historical and current economic problems and governmental policies influencing agriculture. Uses of economic theory to develop historical and conceptual understanding of the economics of agriculture; how public policy influences the nature and performance of agriculture. May be taught abroad in Australia under the supervision of a UC Davis faculty member.

courses.title: Economics of Agricultural Sustainability
courses.prereqs: ECN 001A C- or better or ECN 001AV C- or better.
courses.desc: Application of economic concepts to agro-environmental issues relevant to agricultural sustainability. Topics include market efficiency, production externalities, government policies, agricultural trade, product differentiation, all linked to sustainability issues. Case studies include biofuels, genetically modified foods and geographically differentiated products.

courses.title: Agricultural Markets
courses.prereqs: ARE 106 C- or better;  ARE 100A C- or better;  (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better);  STA 103 C- or better.
courses.desc: Nature, function, organizational structure, and operation of agricultural markets; prices, costs, and margins; market information, regulation, and controls; cooperative marketing.

courses.title: Cooperative Business Enterprises
courses.prereqs: (ECN 001A C- or better or ECN 001AV C- or better);  (UWP 104A or UWP 104AY or UWP 101).
courses.desc: Study of cooperative business enterprise in the United States and elsewhere; economic theories of behavior, principles of operation, finance, decision-making, and taxation.

courses.title: Introduction to Behavioral Economics
courses.prereqs: (ECN 001A C- or better or ECN 001AV C- or better);  (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better).
courses.desc: Inclusion of non-economic factors such as psychological principles in economic decisions and model predictions. Emphasis on behavioral principles, resulting strategies and implications for diverse market settings.

courses.title: Agribusiness Marketing Plan Development
courses.desc:
Fundamental components required to develop a marketing plan. Appreciation of the concept of marketing plans, appropriate research
required, including the use of library, Internet, survey and interview instruments, government documents, market analysis, business proposition, action planning, financial evaluation and monitoring.

courses.title: Managerial Marketing
courses.prereqs: ARE 100B C- or better;  ARE 106 C- or better;  ARE 100A C- or better;  (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better);  STA 103 C- or better.
courses.desc: Application of economic theory and econometrics to the study of marketing and consumer research. Emphasis on industry structure, history, regulatory aspects, integrated brand promotion, market segmentation, optimal product mix, message placement.

courses.title: International Commodity & Resource Markets
courses.prereqs: ARE 100A C- or better;  ARE 100B C- or better.
courses.desc: Basic nature and scope of international trade in agricultural commodities, agricultural inputs, and natural resources. Market dimensions and policy institutions. Case studies to illustrate import and export problems associated with different regions and commodities.

courses.title: Futures & Options Markets
courses.prereqs: ARE 100A C- or better;  (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better);  STA 103 C- or better.
courses.desc: History, mechanics, and economic functions of futures and options markets; hedging; theory of inter-temporal price formation and behavior of futures and options prices; price forecasting; futures and options as policy tools.

courses.title: Farm Management
courses.prereqs: ECN 001A C- or better or ECN 001AV C- or better.
courses.desc: Farm organization and resources; economic and technological principles in decision making; analytical techniques and management control; problems in organizing and managing the farm business.

courses.title: Personal Finance
courses.desc: Management of income and expenditures by the household. Use of consumer credit, savings, and insurance by households. Principles of tax, retirement, and estate planning.

courses.title: Investments
courses.desc: Survey of investment institutions, sources of investment information, and portfolio theory. Analysis of the stock, bond and real estate markets from the perspective of the investor.

courses.title: Real Estate Economics
courses.desc: Economic theory, analysis, and institutions of real estate markets and related financial markets. Techniques for appraising property values. Cases drawn from the raw land, single family, multifamily, industrial and office real estate markets.

courses.title: Farm & Rural Resources Appraisal
courses.desc: Principles and procedures of the valuation process with emphasis placed on rural real estate. Includes identification of the major physical and economic determinants of value, the three primary appraisal approaches to valuation, discussion of appraisal activity and practice.

courses.title: Business, Government Regulation, & Society
courses.prereqs: ARE 100A C- or better;  ARE 100B C- or better.
courses.desc: Variety, nature and impact of government regulation: anti-trust laws and economic and social regulation. Nature of the legislative process, promulgation of regulations, and their impact, especially as analyzed by economists.

courses.title: Resource & Environment Policy Analysis
courses.desc: Natural resource use problems with emphasis on past and current policies and institutions affecting resource use; determinants, principles, and patterns of natural resource use; property rights; conservation; private and public resource use problems; and public issues.

courses.title: Resource & Environmental Policy Analysis
courses.desc: Natural resource use problems with emphasis on past and current policies and institutions affecting resource use; determinants, principles, and patterns of natural resource use; property rights; conservation; private and public resource use problems; and public issues.

courses.title: Agricultural Labor
courses.desc: Analysis of labor markets with focus on U.S. and world agriculture. Labor supply, demand, market equilibrium; why farm labor markets are different; global trends in farm labor; U.S. farm labor history; unions and collective bargaining; immigration policy.

courses.title: Operations Research & Management Science
courses.prereqs: ARE 100A C- or better;  (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better);  STA 103 C- or better.
courses.desc: Introduction to quantitative methods used to analyze business and economic processes: decision analysis for management, mathematical programming, competitive analysis, and other methods.

courses.title: Introduction to Mathematical Economics
courses.prereqs: ARE 100B;  ARE 155;  ARE 100A C- or better;  (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better);  STA 103 C- or better.
courses.desc: Linear algebra for economists; necessary and sufficient conditions in static optimization problems; implicit function theorem; economic methodology and mathematics; comparative statics; envelope theorem; Le Chatelier principle; applications to production and consumer models.

courses.title: Analysis for Operations & Production Management
courses.prereqs: ARE 155;  ARE 100A C- or better;  (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better);  STA 103 C- or better.
courses.desc: Application of economic theory and quantitative methods to analyze operations and production management problems including process strategy, quality management, location and plant layout, and inventory management.

courses.title: Emerging Economies & Globalization
courses.prereqs: ARE 100A C- or better;  ARE 115A;  ARE 115B;  Completion of ARE 106 & ECN 162 strongly recommended.
courses.desc: Economic drivers and policy challenges in the major emerging markets, with an emphasis on the effects of rising incomes, population growth, urbanization, and relative wages on world markets and natural resources.

courses.title: Economics of Global Poverty Reduction: What Works & Why
courses.prereqs: (ARE 100B or ECN 100 or ECN 100B);  (ARE 106 or ECN 140);  (ARE 115A or ECN 115A).
courses.desc: Application of microeconomic theory and econometrics to understand causes of poverty and critically evaluate poverty alleviation policies in low income countries.

courses.title: Principles of Finance
courses.prereqs: ARE 100A C- or better;  ARE 106 C- or better;  MGT 011A;  MGT 011B.
courses.desc: Principles of corporate financial management. Time value of money, interest rates, principles of valuation, NPV, risk and return, and cost of capital.

courses.title: Financial Management of the Firm
courses.prereqs: (ARE 171A or ARE 171);  ARE 106 C- or better;  ARE 100A C- or better;  MGT 011A;  MGT 011B.
courses.desc: Financial analysis at the firm level: optimizing capital structure; minimizing the cost of capital; dividend policies; mergers and acquisitions; real options; and risk management.

courses.title: Capital Markets
courses.prereqs: (ARE 171A or ARE 171);  ARE 106 C- or better;  ARE 100A C- or better;  MGT 011A;  MGT 011B.
courses.desc: Introduction to asset pricing. Valuation and risk characteristics of financial assets, including stocks, bonds, futures, and options. Investors’ attitudes toward risk, capital allocation, portfolio selection, the capital asset pricing model, and the efficient market hypothesis.

courses.title: Natural Resource Economics
courses.prereqs: ARE 100A C- or better or ECN 100A C- or better or ECN 100 C- or better.
courses.desc: Economic concepts and policy issues associated with natural resources, renewable resources (ground water, forests, fisheries, and wildlife populations) and non-renewable resources (minerals and energy resources, soil).

courses.title: Environmental Economics
courses.prereqs: ARE 100A C- or better or ECN 100A C- or better or ECN 100 C- or better.
courses.desc:
Role of the environment in economic activity and methods for protecting
and enhancing environmental quality; implications of market failures for public policy; design of environmental policy; theory of welfare measurement; measuring the benefits of environmental improvement.

courses.title: Topics in Managerial Economics
courses.prereqs: ARE 100A;  STA 103;  and Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Selected topics in managerial economics, focusing on current research.

courses.title: Microeconomic Theory
courses.desc: Linear and non-linear optimization theory applied to develop the theory of the profit-maximizing firm and the utility-maximizing consumer.

courses.title: Microeconomic Theory
courses.desc: Characteristics of market equilibrium under perfect competition, simple monopoly and monopsony. Emphasis on general equilibrium and welfare economics; the sources of market success and market failure.

courses.title: Microeconomic Theory
courses.desc: Uncertainty and information economics. Individual decision making under uncertainty. Introduction to game theory, with emphasis on applications to markets with firms that are imperfect competitors or consumers that are imperfectly informed.

courses.title: Introduction to Applied Research Methods
courses.desc: Study of philosophy and methodology of applied research in agricultural economics. Methods of conceptualization of researchable topics. Method of communication and constructive criticism.

courses.title: Applied Microeconomics: Consumer & Producer Behavior
courses.desc: Application of consumer and producer theory in models of individual behavior and market-level phenomena. Implications of consumer and producer theory for specification of empirical models of supply and demand for inputs and outputs and market equilibrium displacement models.

courses.title: Research Design for Applied Microeconomics
courses.desc: Third of three courses in the Ph.D. level applied microeconomics sequence. Examines the design of empirical research and the application of econometric theory.

courses.title: Microeconomic Analysis I
courses.prereqs: ARE 100B or ECN 100;  Advanced undergraduates with consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Behavior of consumers and producers and their interactions; tools and methods needed to analyze economic behavior in the marketplace.  Application of those methods to real-world problems.

courses.title: Microeconomic Analysis II
courses.desc: Behavior in imperfectly competitive markets–monopoly and price discrimination; oligopoly. Introduction to noncooperative game theory.  Analysis of decisions made under risk and uncertainty and imperfect information. The economics of externalities and public goods.

courses.title: Development Economics
courses.prereqs: ARE 100A;  ARE 100B;  ECN 101;  ARE 204A and ECN 160A, ECN 160B recommended.
courses.desc: Review of the principal theoretical and empirical issues whose analysis has formed development economics. Analysis of economic development theories and development strategies and their application to specific policy issues in developing country contexts.

courses.title: Microdevelopment Theory & Methods I
courses.desc: Agricultural development theory, with a focus on microeconomics. Agricultural household behavior with and without imperfections and uncertainty. Analysis of rural land, labor, credit and insurance markets, institutions, and contracts.

courses.title: Open Macroeconomics of Development
courses.prereqs: (ARE 200A or ARE 204A);  (ARE 214 or ARE 215A);  (ARE 200D or ARE 205).
courses.desc: Models and policy approaches regarding trade, monetary and fiscal issues, capital flows and debt are discussed in the macroeconomic framework of an open developing country. Basic analytical focus is real exchange rate and its impact on sectoral allocation of resources.

courses.title: Microdevelopment Theory & Methods II
courses.desc: Extension of development theory and microeconomic methods. Agricultural growth and technological change; poverty and income inequality; multisectoral, including village and regional models. Computable general equilibrium methods and applications.

courses.title: Environmental & Economic Development
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary course drawing on theoretical and empirical research on interactions between environmental resource use and economic development processes. Analysis of issues emerging at the interface of environmental and development economics.

courses.title: International Agricultural Trade & Policy
courses.prereqs: (ARE 100B or ARE 204A);  ECN 160A;  Or the equivalent of ECN 160A.
courses.desc: Analysis of country interdependence through world agricultural markets. Partial equilibrium analysis is used to study the impacts of national intervention on world markets, national policy choice in an open economy and multinational policy issues.

courses.title: Economics of Agriculture
courses.prereqs: ARE 204A (can be concurrent);  ARE 256A (can be concurrent);  Or equivalent course(s) completed or concurrent required.
courses.desc: Analytic treatment of the historical development and contemporary role of agriculture in the global, U.S. and California economies. Uses economic reasoning and evidence to develop historical and conceptual understanding of the economics of agriculture, agricultural issues, and related government policies.

courses.title: Supply & Demand for Agricultural Products
courses.prereqs: ARE 200A;  ARE 202A;  ARE 240A;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Analysis of supply and demand for agricultural commodities emphasizing the effective use of microeconomic theory with econometric methods, and other empirical procedures, in conducting applied analysis of supply and demand at the firm and industry level.

courses.title: Agricultural Commodity Markets
courses.prereqs: ARE 200A;  ARE 202A;  ARE 240A;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Economic analysis of industries that produce, market, transport, store, and process basic commodities. Analysis of market equilibrium under perfect and imperfect competition, with and without government involvement.

courses.title: Agricultural Policy
courses.prereqs: ARE 200A;  ARE 202A;  ARE 240A;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc:
Nature, formation, evolution, and institutions of economic policy applied to food, agricultural, and rural issues. Examples for detailed
consideration include food security, commodity issues, and trade policy. Analytical approaches include static and dynamic welfare analysis, policy design, and political-economic analysis.

courses.title: Econometric Foundations
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Prepares students for econometric theory and empirical work by examining the statistical foundation of econometrics. Special attention is paid to problems specific to non-experimental data common to social sciences. Topics from matrix algebra are also covered.

courses.title: Econometric Methods
courses.desc: Least squares, instrumental variables, and maximum likelihood estimation and inference for single equation linear regression model; linear restrictions; heteroskedasticity; autocorrelation; lagged dependent variables.

courses.title: Econometric Methods
courses.desc: Topics include asymptotic theory and instrumental variables, pooled time-series cross-section estimation, seemingly unrelated regression, classical hypothesis tests, identification and estimation of simultaneous equation models, cointegration, errorcorrection models, and qualitative and limited dependent variable models.

courses.title: Time Series Econometrics
courses.desc: Probability theory; estimation, inference and forecasting of time series models; trends and non-standard asymptotic theory; vector time series methods and cointegration; time series models for higher order moments and transition data; state-space modeling; the Kalman filter.

courses.title: Cross Section Econometrics
courses.desc: Estimation and inference for nonlinear regression models for cross-section data; models for discrete data and for limited dependent variables; models for  panel data; additional topics such as bootstrap and semiparametric regression.

courses.title: Topics in Time Series Econometrics
courses.desc: Modern econometric techniques for time series data. Expand on topics covered in ECN 240A, ECN 240B and ECN 240C. Contents vary from year to year.

courses.title: Topics in Cross Section Econometrics
courses.desc: Modern econometrics techniques for cross-section data. Expand on topics covered in ECN 240A, ECN 240B and ECN 240D. Contents vary from year to year.

courses.title: Optimization with Economic Applications
courses.desc: Microeconomic topics in the framework of mathematical programming.

courses.title: Dynamic Optimization Techniques with Economic Applications
courses.prereqs: Elementary knowledge of ordinary differential equations.
courses.desc: Necessary and sufficient conditions in the calculus of variations and optimal control, economic interpretations, the dynamic envelope theorem and transversality conditions, infinite horizon problems and phase diagrams, local stability and comparative statics of the steady state, comparative dynamics.

courses.title: Applied Dynamic Structural Econometric Modeling
courses.desc: Covers structural econometric models of static games of incomplete information, single-agent dynamic optimization problems and multi-agent dynamic games, with a focus on applications to issues relevant to the environment, energy, natural resources, agriculture, and development.

courses.title: Applied Econometrics I
courses.prereqs: ARE 106 or ECN 140;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: First of two courses in the Masters-level econometrics sequence. The linear regression model and generalizations are applied to topics in applied economics. Tools for empirical research for problems requiring more sophisticated tools than standard regression models are emphasized.

courses.title: Applied Econometrics II
courses.desc: Second of two courses in the Masters-level econometrics sequence. The linear regression model and generalizations are applied to a variety of topics in applied economics. Tools for empirical research for problems requiring more sophisticated tools than standard regression models are emphasized.

courses.title: Demand & Market Analysis
courses.prereqs: ARE 204B;  ARE 256B;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Application of theoretical material covered in ECN 204A and ECN 204B, with particular focus on production theory/factor demand and imperfect competition/market power. Use of theoretical models as a foundation for empirical economic analysis, and empirical exercises. Independent research on chosen topics, with empirical application.

courses.title: Financial Economics
courses.desc: Risk, aversion, choice under uncertainty. Arrow-Debreu securities. Valuation and risk characteristics of financial assets, capital allocation, portfolio selection, Capital Asset Pricing Model, efficient market hypothesis. Applications to topics in agricultural, resource and development economics.

courses.title: Economic Analysis of Resource & Environmental Policies
courses.desc: Development of externality theory, market failure concepts, welfare economics, theory of renewable and non-renewable resource use, and political economic models. Applications to policy issues regarding the agricultural/environment interface and managing resources in the public domain.

courses.title: Environmental Economics: Externalities
courses.prereqs: Students should have completed the first year graduate level sequence in microeconomics and econometrics.
courses.desc: Introduces fundamental and recent research in environmental economics, focusing on the design, implementation and evaluation of environmental policy instruments to correct market failures. Exposure to economic theories and empirical techniques frequently used in this field.

courses.title: Environmental Economics: Non-Market Valuation
courses.prereqs: Students should have completed the first year graduate level sequence in microeconomics and econometrics.
courses.desc: Second Ph.D. field course in environmental economics, covering theory and econometrics of methods for valuing non-market goods and environmental quality changes. Topics include revealed preference (travel cost, hedonics, sorting equilibrium) and stated preference (contingent valuation, choice experiments, conjoint analysis) techniques.

courses.title: Natural Resource Economics
courses.desc: Application of capital theory and dynamic methods to issues of optimal use of renewable and nonrenewable resources. Examination of policy issues associated with forests, fisheries, groundwater, energy resources, watersheds, soil, global climate, and wildlife.

courses.title: Topics in Agricultural & Resource Economics
courses.desc: Selected topics in agricultural and resource economics, focusing on current research.

courses.title: Analysis of California Agriculture & Resources
courses.desc: Review and analysis of production, marketing, and resource issues facing agricultural firms in California. Application of economic theory and measurement to individual firm and industry decisions in an applied setting. Fieldwork-45 hours total, including one five-day summer field trip.

courses.title: Fine Art Appreciation
courses.desc: Survey of contemporary artists since 1970. Topics explore contemporary thought within the visual arts using the forms and strategies of painting, sculpture, installation, performance, photography, and video in collaborative, ephemeral and multimedia approaches. Intended for Art and non-Art majors.

courses.title: Contemporary Art Appreciation
courses.desc: Survey of contemporary art since 1960; includes discussion. Explores contemporary thought within the visual arts using forms and strategies of painting, sculpture, installation, performance, photo and video in collaborative, ephermeral and multimedia approaches. For Art and non-Art majors.

courses.title: Contemporary Art Appreciation
courses.desc: Survey of contemporary art since 1960; includes fieldwork. Explores contemporary thought within the visual arts using forms and strategies of painting, sculpture, installation, performance, photo and video in collaborative, ephermeral and multimedia approaches. For Art and non-Art majors.

courses.title: Introduction to Experimental Video & Film
courses.desc: Evolution of moving image technologies. Shifts within avant-garde artistic practices. Conceptual and historical differences between film and video. Relationship of film and video to fine arts.

courses.title: Introduction to Contemporary Visual Culture
courses.desc: Establishing visual literacy across the media of fine art, photography, advertising, television and film; media culture; focus on critical decoding of contemporary visual culture.

courses.title: Theory & Criticism of Photography
courses.desc: Development of camera vision, ideas, and aesthetics and their relationship to the fine arts from 1839 to the present.

courses.title: Theory & Criticism: Painting & Sculpture
courses.desc: Study of forms and symbols in historic and contemporary masterpieces.

courses.title: Introduction to Critical Theory
courses.desc: Overview of 20th-century critical theories of culture and their relation to visual art and mass media culture.

courses.title: Theory & Criticism of Electronic Media
courses.desc: Study of electronic media, focusing on critique, application, and relationship to art practice. Analysis of the conceptual basis of electronic media as an artistic mode of expression.

courses.title: Expanded Field: Artist Lecture Series
courses.desc: Exploration of the expanded field of practice, theory and criticism in the visual arts. Presentations and discussions with professional practitioners in the field.

courses.title: Historical Experience of Asian Americans
courses.desc: Introduction to Asian American Studies through an overview of the history of Asians in America from the 1840s to the present within the context of the development of the United States.

courses.title: Contemporary Issues of  Asian Americans
courses.desc: Introduction to Asian American Studies through the critical analysis of the impact of race, racism, ethnicity, imperialism, militarism, and immigration since post-World War II on Asian Americans.  Topics may include sexuality, criminality, class, hate crimes, and inter-ethnic relations.

courses.title: Social & Psychological Perspectives of Asian Americans
courses.desc: Major psychosocial issues of Asian Americans. Theories and empirical research that address cultural values, behavioral norms, ethnic stereotypes, racism, acculturation, ethnic identity development, family communication, stressors and social support systems, academic achievement, interpersonal effectiveness, and psychopathology.

courses.title: Asian American Cultural Studies
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary course examines the multiple ways in which race, class, sexuality and gender, as well as the recent turn to transnationalism and postcolonial theory, have changed the ways we read Asian American literature and see art, theater and film.

courses.title: Directed Group Study
courses.desc: Primarily intended for lower division students.

courses.title: Asian American Communities
courses.desc: Survey and analysis of Asian American communities within both historical and contemporary contexts. Presentation of the analytical skills, theories, and concepts needed to describe, explain, and understand the diversity of Asian American communities within the larger, dominant society.

courses.title: Theoretical Perspective in Asian American Studies
courses.prereqs: ASA 001 or ASA 002 or ASA 003 or ASA 004;  or Consent of Instructor.  Upper division standing.
courses.desc: Explores major theories of race and its intersections with class, gender, and sexuality from interdisciplinary perspective. Introduces key theoretical developments, issues, debates. Through case studies, analyzes ways various theoretical frameworks and perspectives have been incorporated into range of scholarship.

courses.title: Asian American Women
courses.desc:
Experiences of Asian American women from major ethnic subgroups
comparatively examined in their social, economic and historical contexts using theoretical perspectives from social sciences, humanities/arts: identity, racialization, immigration, gender, sexuality, labor, socialization, cultural expression, social movements and feminist theorizing.

courses.title: Asian Diasporas
courses.desc: Asian diasporic communities and the experiences of its members in the United States and internationally. Community building, cyberspace, gender issues, labor, transnational practices, effects of globalization, political organizing, homeland politics, humanitarian projects, citizenship and nationalism.

courses.title: Multiracial Asian Pacific American Issues
courses.desc: Introduction to the experiences of biracial and multiracial Asian Pacific people in the U.S., concentrating on theories of race, racial identity formation, culture, media, and anti-racist struggles. Critical approaches to the analysis of popular media and academic representations.

courses.title: Asian American Youth
courses.desc: Social experiences of diverse groups of Asian American youth. Ways in which youth themselves actively create cultural expressions and political interventions.

courses.title: Asian American Performance
courses.desc: Performance work by, for, and/or about Asian Pacific Americans including dramatic literature, performance art, dance, and film. Ethnicity, gender and sexuality, class and age as they intersect with Asian Pacific American identities in and through dramatic performance.

courses.title: Asian American Literature
courses.desc: Works of Asian American literature by writers from the major ethnic subgroups, examined in their social, economic and historical contexts. Intertextual analysis of their thematic and formal elements to form an understanding of Asian American literary traditions.

courses.title: Ethnicity, Culture, & the Self
courses.desc: Cultural and social psychological influences on Asian Americans focusing on the individual.

courses.title: Health Issues Confronting Asian Americans & Pacific Islanders
courses.desc: Health issues confronting Asian Americans & Pacific Islanders.

courses.title: Asian Americans & the Political Culture of Fashion in the U.S. & Asia
courses.desc: Historical, cultural and sociopolitical development of fashion in Asia and the U.S. as it relates to the Asian Diasporas. Specific aspects of material culture: textiles, clothing and fashion.

courses.title: Japanese American Experience
courses.desc: Different analytical approaches to understand Japanese American history, culture and society.

courses.title: Chinese American Experience
courses.desc: Survey of the historical and contemporary experiences of Chinese in the United States, starting with the gold rush era and concluding with the present-day phenomenon of Chinese transnational movement to the United States and its diasporic significance.

courses.title: Korean American Experience
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary survey of the historical and contemporary experiences of Koreans in the United States from the late-19th century to the present.

courses.title: Southeast Asian American Experience
courses.desc: Historical survey of Southeast Asian experiences with special focus on United States involvement and post 1975 migrations. Defines international and transnational conditions that led up to the large exodus and resettlement of Southeast Asians.

courses.title: South Asian American History, Culture, & Politics
courses.desc: South Asian American experiences, focusing on the histories, cultures, and politics of Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi, and Sri Lankan communities in the U.S. Interdisciplinary approaches to migration, labor, gender, racialization, ethnicity, youth, community mobilization.

courses.title: Asian American Legal History
courses.desc: Legal history of Asian Americans, from the mid-19th century to present. Laws and administrative policies affecting Asian American communities, including those governing immigration, social and economic participation, WWII internment, and affirmative action.

courses.title: Topics in Asian American Studies: History
courses.desc: Intensive treatment of a topic in Asian American Studies; history.

courses.title: Topics in Asian American Studies: Culture
courses.desc: Intensive treatment of a topic in Asian American Studies; culture.

courses.title: Topics in Asian American Studies: Physical & Mental Health
courses.desc: Intensive treatment of a topic in Asian American Studies; physical and mental health.

courses.title: Topics in Asian American Studies: Policy & Community
courses.desc: Intensive treatment of a topic in Asian American Studies: policy and community.

courses.title: Topics in Asian American Studies: Comparative Racial Studies
courses.desc: Intensive treatment of a topic in Asian American Studies: comparative racial studies.

courses.title: Topics in Asian American Studies: Asian Studies & Asian American Studies
courses.desc: Intensive treatment of a topic in Asian American Studies: asian studies and asian american studies.

courses.title: Topics in Asian American Studies: Race, Class, Gender, & Sexuality
courses.desc: Intensive treatment of a topic in Asian American Studies: race, class, gender, and sexuality.
