courses.desc: Medicine in ancient Greece and Rome; physiological conceptions of the body within scientific and social frameworks; exploration of sanitation technology and health in antiquity; medical treatment of the female body; medicine and the economy.

courses.title: Topics in Ancient Mediterranean Civilizations
courses.prereqs: A lower division Classics (CLA) course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Topics may be ordered by time or place (e.g. Hellenistic Egypt) or by theme or genre (e.g. slavery in the ancient world).

courses.title: Topics in Greek Civilization
courses.prereqs: A lower division Classics (CLA) course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Topics may be ordered by time or place (e.g. the world of Homer) or by theme or genre (e.g. the Greek art of war).

courses.title: Topics in Roman Civilization
courses.prereqs: A lower division Classics (CLA) course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Topics may be ordered by time or place (e.g. Julius Caesar and his age) or by theme or genre (e.g. gladiators: blood in the arena).

courses.title: Topics in Classical Receptions
courses.prereqs: A lower division Classics (CLA) course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Topics in classical reception from late antiquity to the present. Topics may be ordered by time or place (e.g. the classical tradition in Washington, D.C.) or by theme or genre (e.g. cinematic representations of the ancient world).

courses.title: Topics in Ancient Science
courses.prereqs: CLA 050 or CLA 051;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Topics may be ordered by discipline (e.g. ancient medicine), historical figure (e.g. Galen) or topic (e.g. science and the economy).

courses.title: Film & the Classical World
courses.prereqs: A lower division Classics (CLA) course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Classical World as portrayed in films. Viewings and discussions of modern versions of ancient dramas, modern dramas set in the Ancient Mediterranean world, and films imbued with classical themes and allusions. Supplementary readings in ancient literature and mythology.

courses.title: Love & Beauty in the Ancient World
courses.desc: Philosophical and literary traditions connecting love, beauty, and goodness in ancient thought. Moral and ethical implications, ideologies of sexuality and gender; transmission into the medieval and modern world.

courses.title: Theory & Practice of Greek & Roman Mythology
courses.prereqs: A lower division Classics (CLA) course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Thematically focused study of mythological narratives. Emphasis on the historical development of myths and the variety of theoretical approaches for the study of myth.

courses.title: Origins of Rhetoric
courses.prereqs: A lower division Classics (CLA) course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Issues in the development of rhetoric from its origins in ancient Greece to A.D.430. Special attention  to works of Plato, Aristotle, Cicero, and Quintilian. Role of grammar and rhetoric in schools of Roman Empire. The Christian rhetoric of Saint Augustine.

courses.title: Greek & Roman Historiography
courses.prereqs: A lower division Classics (CLA) course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Survey of Greek and Roman historical writing in English translation. Authors to be read may include Herodotus, Thucydides, Sallust, Livy, and Tacitus. Focus on the development of historical writing as a literary genre.

courses.title: Roman Political Thought
courses.prereqs: A lower division Classics (CLA) course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Survey of Roman thinking about politics, as expressed both in formal theorizing and in a variety of other contexts, including oratory, historiography, and epic. Study of Roman political reflection in its historical, cultural, and literary context.

courses.title: Homer & Ancient Epic
courses.prereqs: A lower division Classics (CLA) course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Reading of the classical epics of Homer (Iliad, Odyssey) and Virgil (Aeneid) in English. Discussion of techniques of composition, the beliefs and values of their respective societies, and the generic tradition of ancient epic.

courses.title: Greek & Roman Comedy
courses.prereqs: A lower division Classics (CLA) course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Readings in Aristophanes, Menander, Plautus, and Terence; lectures on the development of ancient comedy.

courses.title: Greek & Roman Novel
courses.prereqs: A lower division Classics (CLA) course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Examination of the ancient Greek romances and their development into the grotesque realism of Petronius' Satyricon, and the religious mysticism of Apuleius' The Golden Ass.

courses.title: Greek Tragedy
courses.prereqs: A lower division Classics (CLA) course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Reading in English of selected plays of Aeschylus, Sophocles, and Euripides. Discussion of the development and influence of Athenian tragedy.

courses.title: Socrates & Classical Athens
courses.prereqs: A lower division Classics (CLA) course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Study of the major sources of our knowledge of Socrates, assessment of his role in the politics and culture of ancient Athens, his method of teaching, and his place in Western thought.

courses.title: Cultural Interactions in the Ancient Mediterranean World
courses.desc: Exploration of the role of colonial encounters in the spread of ideas throughout the ancient Mediterranean from an archaeological and artistic perspective. Emphasis on material and literary expressions of culture, trade routes, and theories pertaining to culture contact.

courses.title: Mediterranean Bronze Age Archaeology
courses.prereqs: A lower division Classics (CLA) course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Archaeological monuments of the ancient Near East, including Egypt and Mesopotamia, and of Greece and Crete during the Bronze Age. Special emphasis on the problems of state formation and on the co-existence and collapse of Bronze Age societies.

courses.title: Early Greek Art & Architecture
courses.desc: Examination of the origin and development of the major monuments of Greek art and architecture from the 8th century to the mid-5th century B.C.

courses.title: Later Greek Art & Architecture
courses.desc: Study of the art and architecture of later Classical and Hellenistic Greece, from the mid-5th century to the 1st century B.C.

courses.title: Roman Art & Architecture
courses.desc: Art and architecture of Rome and the Roman Empire, from the founding of Rome through the 4th century C.E.

courses.title: Greek Religion & Society
courses.prereqs: A lower division Classics (CLA) course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Cults, festivals, and rituals of Greek religious practice and their relationship to Greek social and political institutions, and to Greek private life. Includes discussion of major sanctuaries at Olympia, Delphi, Athens, and others.

courses.title: Architecture & Urbanism in Mediterranean Antiquity
courses.desc: Architecture and urban development in the ancient Near East, Greece, and Rome. Special emphasis on the social structure of the ancient city as expressed in its architecture, and on the interaction between local traditions and the impact of Greco-Roman urbanism.

courses.title: Roman Religions
courses.desc: Roman religion from republic to empire. Gods, rituals, and festivals at Rome; sacrifice, sacred places, magic. Gender roles, social status, national identity. Influences from other cultures, especially Egypt and the eastern Mediterranean.

courses.title: Introduction to Translational Research
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  One of the following degrees: MD, DDS, DMD, OD, ND, DO, PharmD, DVM, PhD or DNS in nursing; application and acceptance into the Clinical Research Graduate Group, K30 program or other SOM/CTSC training programs.
courses.desc: Introduction to the CRGG program and overview of major clinical research topics. Overview of basic clinical skills needed to accomplish CRGG mentored research project.

courses.title: Strategies for Grant Writing
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Completed one of the following degrees: MD, DDS, DMD, OD, ND, DO, PharmD, DVM, PhD or DNS in nursing. Application and acceptance into the Clinical Research Graduate Group, K30 program or other SOM/CTSC training program.
courses.desc: Practical skills and strategies to create successful grant proposals in NIH style/format. Generating ideas, identifying and accessing research resources, grant components, specific aims, background and significance, preliminary studies, budgets, and bios. Matriculation through UC system, and resubmissions. (Former MDS 461CR.)

courses.title: Introduction to Clinical Research
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Completed one of the following degrees: MD, DDS, DMD, OD, ND, DO, PharmD, DVM, PhD or DNS in nursing; application and acceptance into the Clinical Research Graduate Group, MRCTP program, Clinical Research Certificate or other SOM/CTSC training programs.
courses.desc: Anatomy and physiology of conducting clinical epidemiologic research. Familiarity with three basic study designs: cross-sectional, case-control, and cohort. Discussion of principles of measurements in clinical epidemiological studies, basic methods for analyzing data, and ethical issues involved in conducting research.

courses.title: Methods in Clinical Research
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Completed one of the following degrees: MD, DDS, DMD, OD, ND, DO, PharmD, DVM, PhD or DNS in nursing; application and acceptance into the Clinical Research Graduate Group, K30 program or other SOM traing programs.
courses.desc: Overview of major approaches to clinical research, including health services research techniques, informatics, GCRC, and preclinical methodologies to enhance clinical projects. Overview of UC Davis clinical research support infrastructure. Methodologies applicable to clinical research and its multi-disciplinary perspective.

courses.title: The Ethics of Research
courses.desc: Acquire information about ethical responsibilities; Explore major questions in ethics; Apply ethical principles, concepts and values; Gain an appreciation of the role of trust in scientific research. Recommend three quarters of CLH204. Must enroll in Fall to continue through Spring.

courses.title: Team Science
courses.prereqs: Participation in CTSC Research Education and Training Programs, or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Today’s scientific challenges necessitate cross-disciplinary engagement and high collaboration levels. Offers guidance on how best to engage in team science to pursue complex questions, work effectively with team members, and produce high impact research that meets society’s needs.

courses.title: Introduction to Grant Writing, I
courses.desc: First in a two-quarter series. Scholars are encouraged to enroll in both classes. The two-course sequence provides training in practical aspects of competitive grant writing. The focus is NIH, but information will apply to other funding agencies.

courses.title: Introduction to Grant Writing, II
courses.desc: Second in a two-quarter series. Two-course sequence provides training in practical aspects of competitive grant writing.

courses.title: Critical Assessment of the Biomedical Literature
courses.desc: Exposure to topical issues and controversies in the design of interdisciplinary translational research, with an emphasis on critical assessment of the biomedical and health sciences literature. Extends students’ knowledge of study design through practical application.

courses.title: Introduction to Stem Cell Biology
courses.desc: Introduction to Stem Cell Biology. Each week will focus on different aspects of stem cells, including general concepts, stem cells in lower organisms, embryonic stem cells and cellular reprogramming.

courses.title: Biodesign I
courses.desc: Focuses on the principles of needs identification and invention of biomedical technologies. Two part course provides a basic understanding of the elements of the innovation process and how to translate these principles into biomedical device design.

courses.title: Biodesign II
courses.desc: Focuses on the implementation of biomedical technologies and translational process. Two part course provides a basic understanding of the elements of the innovation process and how to translate these principles into biomedical device design.

courses.title: Basics of Stem & Progenitor Cells
courses.prereqs: MCP 200L;  MCP 200; Consent of Intructor; Graduate standing.
courses.desc: Lecture designed for graduate students who have experience in cell culture techniques. Designed to give a broad overview of the field and current cells of interest to the greater research community.

courses.title: Ethical Issues in Stem Cell Biology
courses.desc: Critical presentation and analysis of recent articles in stem cell biology and small group discussions of the ethical issues surrounding this area of research.

courses.title: Stem Cell Biology & current Good Manufacturing Practice
courses.prereqs: Must have foundational knowledge of biology and chemistry; graduate students preferred, other students upon instructor’s consent.
courses.desc: Introduction to human stem cell biology; development of cellular therapeutics based on human stem cells for the treatment of currently incurable diseases; introduction to current Good Manufacturing Practice (cGMP), and theoretical & practical exploration of cGMP to manufacture such cellular therapies.

courses.title: Congestive Heart Failure, Mechanism of Disease
courses.desc: Underlying mechanisms of cardiomyopathy and heart failure.  Presentation of fundamental knowledge of and recent basic research on heart failure.   Student team projects: investigation and presentation of a research topic and bench research project to advance research in the same area.

courses.title: Current Techniques in Clinical Research
courses.prereqs: CLH 250;  and Consent of Instructor.  Graduate standing.
courses.desc: Current techniques used in clinical research such as electrophysiology, cardiovascular surgery, cardiac catheterization and echocardiography, team science, and patient management. Lectures are presented by experts on each technique, with an emphasis on use in translational research.

courses.title: Molecular Mechanisms of Disease:  Cancer
courses.desc: Cutting edge of research on underlying mechanisms of cancer development, progression and prevention—clinical trials/drug development, signaling pathways and molecular mechanisms of cancer development, recent basic research on cancer stem cells, genetics and epigenetic events and animal models used.

courses.title: Introduction to Medical Statistics
courses.desc: Introduction to statistical methods and software in clinical, laboratory and population medicine. Graphical and tabular presentation of data, probability, binomial, Poisson, normal, t-, F-, and Chi-square distributions, elementary nonparametric methods, simple linear regression and correlation, life tables.

courses.title: Biostatistics for Biomedical Science
courses.prereqs: CLH 244 or SPH 244;  Consent of Instructor.  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Analysis of data and design of experiments for laboratory data.

courses.title: Biostatistics for Clinical Research
courses.desc: Emphasizes critical biostatistics for clinical research and targets biomedical audience. Students will develop understanding for basic planning and analysis of clinical studies and learn to develop collaborations with biostatisticians.

courses.title: Statistical Analysis for Laboratory Data
courses.desc: Statistical methods for experimental design and analysis of laboratory data including gene expression arrays, RNA-Seq, and mass spec.

courses.title: Integrating Medicine Into Basic Science
courses.desc: Four-week summer institute consisting of didactic lectures, reading assignments, group discussions, and clinical rotations to acculturate students to the human medical environment; integrate medical principles, physiology and pathophysiology into basic research; introduce high-impact clinical studies related to medicine and health.

courses.title: Introduction to Public Speaking
courses.desc: Practice in the preparation and delivery of speeches based on principles and strategies of informing and persuading audiences drawn from the social sciences and humanities.

courses.title: Interpersonal Communication Competence
courses.desc: Communication competence in professional settings. Managing face-to-face and virtual teams. Leadership, conflict management and negotiation skills. Communication in diverse organizations. Leveraging communication networks. Effective interviewing.

courses.title: Global English & Communication
courses.desc: English as a global language and its uses in intercultural communication. Cultural, historical, and political dimensions of varieties of English spoken around the world. Experiential grounding in strategies for increasing interpretive and verbal communicative competence for a globalized world.

courses.title: Data Visualization in the Social Sciences
courses.desc: Introduction to quantitative data across the social sciences (Communications, Political Science, Psychology, Sociology, and other disciplines). Transforming data, describing data, producing graphs, visual reasoning, and interpretations.

courses.title: Video Games & Virtual Environments
courses.desc: Impact of video games on players and society. Topics include motivations for playing games; cognitive, emotional, and behavioral effects, including violence and addiction; interpersonal and group processes in online games; virtual communities; and video games for education.

courses.title: Communication Theories
courses.desc: Forms, functions, development, and testing of communication theory, with emphasis on social scientific approaches. Survey and comparison of significant micro and macro theories and models of face-to-face and mediated communication. Application of theories to real-world problems.

courses.title: Empirical Methods in Communication
courses.prereqs: STA 013 or STA 013Y;  Or equivalent of STA 013.
courses.desc: Social scientific research methods employed in Communication. Topics include research design, measurement, sampling, questionnaire construction, survey research, experimental design, content analysis and qualitative field methods.

courses.title: Communication Networks
courses.desc: Theoretical approaches to communication networks, practical applications of network studies, and network analysis tools. Friendship, political discussion, social support, organizational, social media, and disease transmission networks are examined. Impact of emerging technologies on network creation, maintenance, and expansion.

courses.title: Gender Differences in Communication
courses.desc: Examination of communication differences between men and women as sources of male/female stereotypes, misunderstandings, dilemmas, and difficulties (real and imagined). Treatment of genders as cultures. Topics include male/female differences in discursive practices and patterns, language attitudes, and relationship dynamics.

courses.title: Theories of Persuasion
courses.desc: Theories and models of persuasion that account for the effects of source, channel and audience factors on message recipients. Examination of message strategies for altering attitudes and gaining compliance. Contexts of application include interpersonal relationships, advertising, politics, and health.

courses.title: Communication & Cognition
courses.desc: Relationship between communication and cognition in interpersonal and mediated contexts. Discourse comprehension and production, impact of language attitudes on social judgments, the effects of information processing on decision making.

courses.title: Interpersonal Communication
courses.desc: Theories and principles of interpersonal communication related to perception, verbal and nonverbal channels, mutual understanding, and relationship development. Communication processes in face-to-face and technologically-mediated encounters. Consideration of different relationship contexts, including friendships, dating and family relationships, and the workplace.

courses.title: Language Use in Conversation
courses.desc: Examination of how people use language in social interaction, how they exchange meaning during conversation, and how their use of language plays a central role in turn-taking, speech acts, attitude formation, figurative speech, politeness, and other aspects of conversation.

courses.title: Nonverbal Communication
courses.desc: Examination of the interaction between nonverbal communication and verbal communication channels in influencing outcomes in interpersonal relationships. Underlying functions served by nonverbal communication are considered.

courses.title: Family Communication
courses.desc: Theories and research on family communication. Communication in courtship, marriage, and relational dissolution. Processes and outcomes of parent-child, sibling, family roles, and inter-generational communication. Interaction patterns associated with marital/family satisfaction, maintenance, divorce, and dysfunction. Cultural influences on family communication.

courses.title: Group Communication
courses.desc: Communication processes in the development and maintenance of effective groups and teams in organizations. Examination of both face-to-face and computer-mediated group interaction. Topics include group development, power, norms, cohesion, decision making, problem solving, creativity, conflict management, working remotely, and leadership.

courses.title: Strategic Communication in Public Relations
courses.desc: Principles, evolution, and professional practice of public relations. Planning and execution of effective, ethical communication strategies and campaigns. Distribution of messages through traditional and new media, including social media. Cultivation of relationships between organizations and their publics. Crisis communication management.

courses.title: Social Media for Public Relations
courses.desc: Uses of social media technologies in contemporary public relations practice. Social and behavioral theories of social media processes and effects. Strategies and tools for authoring content that builds relationships and creates conversations with key publics.

courses.title: Organizational Communication
courses.desc: Organizational communication theory and practice is examined with an emphasis on the use of effective communication strategies for achieving organizational goals.

courses.title: Advanced Organizational Communication
courses.desc: Communication processes within and among social organizations. Examines formal organizations as information processing systems. Topics include general systems theory, input-output analysis, structural-functionalism, cybernetics, organizational network analysis, organization environments, organizations as cultures, organizational learning, information technologies, and communication diagnostic/auditing strategies.

courses.title: Introduction to Mass Communication
courses.desc: History of mass media and media research traditions. Organization and economics of the media industry. Media policy, law, regulation and ethics.  Impact of the media on individuals and society. Traditional, new and emerging communication technologies.

courses.title: Media Effects: Theory & Research
courses.desc: Social scientific studies of the effects of mass media messages on audience members' actions, attitudes, beliefs, and emotions. Topics include the cognitive processing of media messages, television violence, political socialization, cultivation of beliefs, agenda-setting, and the impact of new technologies.

courses.title: Newsmaking
courses.desc: The making of news. How journalists construct news and how consumers and newsmakers use it.  Effects of news, technology’s challenges to journalism, and the relationship of news to other institutions.

courses.title: Analysis of Media Messages
courses.desc: Examination of alternative approaches to the analysis, interpretation, and evaluation of media messages, including those disseminated through broadcasting, print, and new technologies.

courses.title: Media Entertainment
courses.desc: Effects and appeal of media entertainment, emphasizing emotional reactions. Topics include key concepts of entertainment research such as mood management, and the respective features and emotional/social-psychological effects of genres such as comedy, mystery, thriller, sports, music, horror, and erotica.

courses.title: Political Communication
courses.desc: Relationships among the mass media, citizens, and politics, production of political news, campaign strategies, and citizens’ attitudes and behaviors. Frameworks for mediated politics, the news, and elite discourse and campaign messages.

courses.title: Communication Campaigns
courses.desc: Strategic uses of media and interpersonal communication channels in health, environmental advocacy, and political campaigns. Emphasis on general principles relevant to most campaign types, including public information, social marketing, and media advocacy campaigns.

courses.title: Children, Adolescents, & the Media
courses.desc: Research on the adaptive and maladaptive effects of media (e.g., television, movies, video games, social media) on the social, emotional, cognitive, and physical development of youth, considering the protective role of parents, teachers, ethics, and policy.

courses.title: Contemporary Trends In Media
courses.desc: Global trends in media, including media and globalization, impacts of the new media economy, media and security, and effects of ownership on media content and culture.

courses.title: Race & Media
courses.desc: Examines how race and ethnicity as social categories are shaped by mass media. Focuses on the impact of race and ethnicity role portrayals in content and style of news, television and cinema.

courses.title: Simulating Communication Processes
courses.desc: Simulations of communication and sociality using agent-based models. Focus on strategic behavior, cooperation, coordination, self-organization, information diffusion, and other communication phenomena. No programming skills assumed.

courses.title: Health Communication
courses.desc: Health communication theories and research. Health literacy, social support and coping, doctor-patient interaction, health communication campaigns, media influences on health, and applications of new technologies in health promotion.

courses.title: Media & Health
courses.desc: Content and effects of health messages in the media. Topics include health news reporting; portrayals of disease, disability, death and health-related behaviors; promotion of drugs and other health products; and tobacco and alcohol advertising.

courses.title: Digital Technology & Social Change
courses.desc: Conceptual understanding of how digital communication technologies transform our lives through social media, mobile connectivity, globalization, and big data. Contexts include education, health, entrepreneurship, democracy, and poverty.

courses.title: Interpersonal Technologies
courses.desc: Theories and research findings on how people use technologies for interpersonal and relational purposes, including impression formation, self-presentation, deception, anonymity, friendship maintenance, online dating, and emotional expression.

courses.title: Social Media
courses.desc: Application of communication theories to the study and design of social media. Examination of social media in contexts such as political activism and collaboration. Topics include online credibility, participatory culture, viral media and privacy.

courses.title: Video Games Theory & Research
courses.desc: Communication theory and research on the uses and effects of video games. Research methods available for investigating game use and the impact of games on behavior. Application of those methods in a research project.

courses.title: Persuasive Technologies
courses.desc: Designing and testing ethical, technology-based communication interventions in the domains of health, marketing, education, and environment. Social media, mobile apps, wearable devices, recommendation systems, serious games, and augmented reality.

courses.title: Current Topics in Communication
courses.prereqs: CMN 101;  CMN 102;  Or a research methods course equivalent to CMN 102.
courses.desc: Group study of a special topic in communication.

courses.title: Theoretical Perspectives on Communication
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Graduate standing in Communication.
courses.desc: Social scientific study of Communication. Research on interpersonal, organizational, mass, political, and health communication; communication technologies (e.g., video games, social media, persuasive technologies); and communication network analysis.

courses.title: Biological Foundations of Communication
courses.desc: Communibiological, evolutionary, neuroscience, and neurophysiological perspectives on communication. Methodologies for examining human physiological responses to messages, such as heart rate, skin conductance, electromyography, and cortical activity.

courses.title: Experimental Methods & Analysis in Communication
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Graduate standing; one course in inferential statistics.
courses.desc: Experimental designs in communication. Topics include: causation; threats to validity; conceptualization, operationalization, and measurement; hypothesis testing; ethics; data analysis software focusing on the analysis of variance and planned contrasts; and the practical and effective implementation and writing of experiments.

courses.title: Web Science Research Methods
courses.desc: Applications of data science to web-based communication research. Design, implementation, analysis, and reporting of studies using online data. Use of Python to scrape, organize, analyze, and visualize web data.

courses.title: Simulation Methods in Communication Research
courses.desc: Simulation methods for modeling human communication. Single and multiple agent approaches to developing process theories of cooperation, coordination, strategic behavior, information and innovation diffusion, and other aspects of sociality.

courses.title: Analysis of Communication Networks
courses.desc: Theoretical and analytic issues pertaining to network perspectives on communicating and organizing. Consideration of structural and dynamic features of communication networks. Introduction to network analysis software and various analysis techniques.

courses.title: Persuasive Technologies for Health
courses.desc: Theorizing, designing and evaluating ethical technology-based health communication interventions. Uses of social media, mobile communication apps, wearable devices, computer-generated tailored messages, educational games, and computational approaches in health promotion and healthcare delivery.

courses.title: Health Communication Campaigns
courses.desc: Principles of health communication campaign planning, implementation and evaluation. Strategies for changing health behaviors, shaping policy, and improving healthcare organizations’ relations with stakeholders.

courses.title: Children, Adolescents, & the Media
courses.desc: Theory and research on the uses and effects of traditional and new media on children and adolescents, emphasizing social, emotional, cognitive, and physical development. Methodological approaches and ethical issues in studies of underage populations. Parent and family mediation of effects.

courses.title: Political Communication
courses.desc: Theories and research on the connections between media, politics, and citizens in the digital age. Critical framework for understanding the nature of mediated politics by assessing inter-relationships between production of news, political elites’ campaign strategies, and behaviors of citizens.

courses.title: Special Topics in Political Communication
courses.desc: Reading, discussion, research, and writing on a selected topic in the specialty of political communication.

courses.title: Consumer Behavior
courses.prereqs: Preparation in areas of psychology or sociology and economics recommended.
courses.desc: Provides a set of behavioral concepts and theories useful in understanding consumer behavior on the part of the individual, business, and social organizations. Conceptual models to help guide and understand consumer research will be presented.

courses.title: Major Works of the Ancient World
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Introduction, through class discussion and frequent written assignments, to some of the major works of the ancient world (up to 5th century CE) such as The Odyssey, the Bible, Augustine's Confessions, and works by Plato and Confucius. Examined genres include religious texts, the epic, philosophy, drama, poetry.

courses.title: Major Works of the Medieval & Early Modern World
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Introduction, through class discussion and frequent written assignments, to some of the major works of the medieval and early modern worlds (6th century to the mid-17th century) such as Dante’s Comedy, 1001 Nights, The Tale of Genji, and Elizabethan/Jacobean plays. Examined genres include framed narratives, courtly literature, and early modern drama.

courses.title: Major Works of the Modern World
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Introduction, through class discussion and frequent written assignments, to some of the major works of the modern world (mid-17th to the mid-20th centuries) such as those by Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Flaubert, Woolf, Lu Xun, Borges and Yeats. Examined genres include realist fiction, modernist fiction, and modernist poetry.

courses.title: Major Works of the Contemporary World
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Comparative study of selected major Western and non-Western texts composed in the period from 1945 to the present. Intensive focus on writing about these texts, with frequent papers written about these works.

courses.title: Major Works of the Contemporary World
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Comparative study of selected major Western and non-Western texts composed in the period from 1945 to the present. Intensive focus on writing about these texts, with frequent papers written about these works.

courses.title: Fairy Tales, Fables, & Parables
courses.desc: Introduction to fairy tales, fables, and parables as recurrent forms in literature, with such readings as tales from Aesop & Grimm, Chaucer & Shakespeare, Kafka & Borges, Buddhist & Taoist parables, the Arabian Nights, and African American folklore.

courses.title: Myths & Legends
courses.desc: Introduction to the comparative study of myths and legends, with readings selected from Near Eastern, Teutonic, Celtic, Indian, Japanese, Chinese, African and Native American literary sources.

courses.title: Literature of Fantasy & the Supernatural
courses.desc: Role of fantasy and the supernatural in literature: tales of magic, hallucination, ghosts, and metamorphosis, including diverse authors such as Shakespeare, P'u Sung-Ling, Kafka, Kawabata, Fuentes, and Morrison.

courses.title: Utopias & Their Transformations
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Consideration, in literary works from different ages, of visionary and rational perceptions of a lost paradise, Golden Age, or Atlantis-and of the inhuman nightmares that can result from perversions of the utopian dream of perfection.

courses.title: The Short Story & Novella
courses.desc: Introduction to shorter forms of prose fiction by major authors of different countries, with special emphasis on the modern period.

courses.title: Master Authors in World Literature: Gilgamesh, Ramayana, Beowulf, Nibelungenlied
courses.desc: Designed primarily to acquaint the non-literature major with a cross-section of writings by the world’s most important authors; readings in English translation. Content alternates among the following segments: Gilgamesh, Ramayana, Beowulf, Nibelungenlied.

courses.title: Master Authors in World Literature: Metamorphoses, Decameron, Arabian Nights, Canterbury Tales
courses.desc: Designed primarily to acquaint the non-literature major with a cross-section of writings by the world’s most important authors; readings in English translation. Content alternates among the following segments: Metamorphoses, Decameron, Arabian Nights, Canterbury Tales.

courses.title: Master Authors in World Literature: Chanson de Roland, El Cid, Igor’s Campaign, Morte D’Arthur
courses.desc: Designed primarily to acquaint the non-literature major with a cross-section of writings by the world’s most important authors; readings in English translation. Content alternates among the following segments: Chanson de Roland, El Cid, Igor’s Campaign, Morte D’Arthur.

courses.title: Master Authors in World Literature: Sakuntala, Tristan & Isolde, Aucassin and Nicolette, Gawain & the Green Knight
courses.desc: Designed primarily to acquaint the non-literature major with a cross-section of writings by the world’s most important authors; readings in English translation. Content alternates among the following segments: Sakuntala, Tristan and Isolde, Aucassin and Nicolette, Gawain and the Green Knight.

courses.title: Master Authors in World Literature: Swift, Rabelais, La Celestina, Simplicissimus
courses.desc: Designed primarily to acquaint the non-literature major with a cross-section of writings by the world’s most important authors; readings in English translation. Content alternates among the following segments: Swift, Rabelais, La Celestina, Simplicissimus.

courses.title: Master Authors in World Literature: Cervantes, Saikaku, Fielding, Voltaire
courses.desc: Designed primarily to acquaint the non-literature major with a cross-section of writings by the world’s most important authors; readings in English translation. Content alternates among the following segments: Cervantes, Saikaku, Fielding, Voltaire.

courses.title: Master Authors in World Literature: Machiavelli, Shakespeare, Lope de Vega/Calderón, Molière/Racine, Lessing/Schiller (2)
courses.desc: Designed primarily to acquaint the non-literature major with a cross-section of writings by the world’s most important authors; readings in English translation. Content alternates among the following segments: Machiavelli, Shakespeare, Lope de Vega/Calderón, Molière/Racine, Lessing/Schiller.

courses.title: Master Authors in World Literature: Goethe, Byron, Stendhal, Pushkin, Lermontov
courses.desc: Designed primarily to acquaint the non-literature major with a cross-section of writings by the world’s most important authors; readings in English translation. Content alternates among the following segments: Goethe, Byron, Stendhal, Pushkin, Lermontov.

courses.title: Master Authors in World Literature: Hoffmann, Gogol, Poe, Hawthorne, Maupassant, Chekhov, Melville
courses.desc: Designed primarily to acquaint the non-literature major with a cross-section of writings by the world’s most important authors; readings in English translation. Content alternates among the following segments: Hoffmann, Gogol, Poe, Hawthorne, Maupassant, Chekhov, Melville.

courses.title: Master Authors in World Literature: Flaubert, Twain, Turgenev, Galdós, Ibsen
courses.desc: Designed primarily to acquaint the non-literature major with a cross-section of writings by the world’s most important authors; readings in English translation. Content alternates among the following segments: Flaubert, Twain, Turgenev, Galdós, Ibsen.

courses.title: Master Authors in World Literature: Balzac, Dostoevski/Tolstoi, Hardy, Shaw, Strindberg
courses.desc: Designed primarily to acquaint the non-literature major with a cross-section of writings by the world’s most important authors; readings in English translation. Content alternates among the following segments: Balzac, Dostoevski/Tolstoi, Hardy, Shaw, Strindberg.

courses.title: Master Authors in World Literature: Unamuno, Svevo, Conrad, Gide, Kafka, Faulkner
courses.desc: Designed primarily to acquaint the non-literature major with a cross-section of writings by the world’s most important authors; readings in English translation. Content alternates among the following segments: Unamuno, Svevo, Conrad, Gide, Kafka, Faulkner.

courses.title: Master Authors in World Literature: Rilke/Yeats, Joyce/Woolf, Mann/Céline, Bulgakov/Tanizaki, O’Neill/Brecht, Lorca/Pirandello
courses.desc: Designed primarily to acquaint the non-literature major with a cross-section of writings by the world’s most important authors; readings in English translation. Content alternates among the following segments: Rilke/Yeats, Joyce/Woolf, Mann/Céline, Bulgakov/Tanizaki, O’Neill/Brecht, Lorca/Pirandello.

courses.title: Master Authors in World Literature: Camus/Sartre, García Márquez/Grass, Borges/Sarraute, Bellow/Nabokov, Beckett/Pinter, Genet/Dürrenmatt
courses.desc: Designed primarily to acquaint the non-literature major with a cross-section of writings by the world’s most important authors; readings in English translation. Content alternates among the following segments: Camus/Sartre, García Márquez/Grass, Borges/Sarraute, Bellow/Nabokov, Beckett/Pinter, Genet/Dürrenmatt.

courses.title: Travel & the Modern World
courses.desc: Examination of travel as a quintessential human activity and experience of global modernity and cross-cultural encounters from the 18th to the 21st century with an emphasis on German-speaking culture. Travelogues, literature, art, memoirs, and films in English translation.

courses.title: Introduction to Women Writers
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Survey of fiction, drama, and poetry by women writers from all continents. Concerns of women compared in light of their varied social and cultural traditions. Literary analysis of voice, imagery, narrative strategies and diction.

courses.title: Dramatic Literature
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Introduction, through careful reading of selected plays, to some of the major forms of Western drama, from the earliest tragedies of ancient Greece to the contemporary American theater.

courses.title: Introduction to Poetry
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Comparative study of poetry in a variety of lyric and other poetic forms from different historical periods and different linguistic, national, and cultural traditions.

courses.title: Humans & the Natural World
courses.desc: Changing relationship between humans and the natural environment in ancient and modern authors as Virgil, Li Po, Basho, Darwin, and Thoreau.

courses.title: Literature of the Abnormal Psyche
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Representations of the human psyche in literature and other media (film, visual arts, music) spanning cultures and historical contexts. Depictions of abnormal psychological states, including madness, obsession, and self-fragmentation. Textual interpretation informed by psychological theories. Rhetorical persuasion and nuanced argumentation.

courses.title: Animals in Literature
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Study of literary texts from various periods and cultures whose theme is the representation of animals.

courses.title: Ethnic Minority Writers in World Literature
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Consideration of a broad range of writers who speak from an ethnic perspective different from the nominally or politically dominant culture of their respective countries and who explore the challenges faced by characters significantly affected by their ethnic minority status.

courses.title: Literature of East Asia
courses.desc:
Introduction to representative masterpieces of East Asia with readings
from such works as The Story of the Stone, The Peach Blossom Fan, T'ang and Sung poetry, classical Japanese poetry, drama, and travel diaries, and The Tale of Genji.

courses.title: Literature of South Asia
courses.desc:
Introduction to representative masterpieces of South Asia with readings
from such works as the Mahabharata and Ramayana, The Cloud Messenger, Shakuntala, The Little Clay Cart, and the stories and poems of both
ancient and modern India and Southeast Asia.

courses.title: Literatures of the Islamic World
courses.desc: Introduction to classical Islamic culture through translations of literature primarily from Arabic and Persian, as well as other languages. Topics include the concept of the self, society and power, spirituality, the natural world, the cosmos, and the supernatural.

courses.title: World Cinema
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR), upper division standing, or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Comparative, cross-cultural study of a topic, theme, or movement in world cinema beyond the boundary of a single national tradition. Topics may include "postsocialist cinemas in East Europe and Asia," "cinema and globalization," and "popular Asian cinemas."

courses.title: Hong Kong Cinema
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR), upper division standing, or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Hong Kong cinema, its history, industry, styles, genres, directors, and stars. Special attention to its polyglot, multicultural, transnational, colonial, and postcolonial environment.

courses.title: Japanese Cinema
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Or upper-division standing.
courses.desc: Introduction to Japanese cinema from early silent films to the present. Explores important directors, genres, stars, themes and techniques in relation to specific historical and cultural contexts. Lectures and readings in English. Films in Japanese with English subtitles.

courses.title: Writing Nature: 1750 to the Present
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Study of representations, descriptions, and discussions of humankind's problematical relationship with the non-human world in texts written in a variety of European and American traditions between 1750 and the present.

courses.title: Women Writers
courses.desc: Exploration of women's differing views of self and society as revealed in major works by female authors of various times and cultures. Readings, principally of fiction, will include such writers as Lady Murasaki, Mme de Lafayette, and Charlotte Bronte.

courses.title: Gender & Interpretation in the Renaissance
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Critical analysis of Renaissance texts with primary focus on issues such as human dignity, education and gender politics; "high" and "low" culture and its relation to literary practices.

courses.title: Shakespeare & the Classical World
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Shakespeare's representations of the classical world in the light of selected ancient texts and Renaissance conceptions of Antiquity, with special attention to the depiction of politics and history.

courses.title: Thematic & Structural Study of Literature
courses.desc: Interpretation of selected works illustrating the historical evolution of themes, as well as of formal and structural elements.

courses.title: Introduction to Critical Theoretical Approaches to Literature & Culture
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Introduction to critical theory and its use for interpreting literary texts, film, and media forms in global culture.

courses.title: Critical Reading & Analysis
courses.desc: Close reading of selected texts; scrutiny of very limited amount of material, with attention to the problems of texts in translation.

courses.title: The Grotesque
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Study of the "grotesque" in selected texts from the Renaissance to the 20th century, with attention to the "grotesque" as a means of social, cultural, and political commentary, as well as of aesthetic innovation.

courses.title: Representations of the City
courses.desc: Exploration of the representation of the city in major translated literary texts from a variety of literary traditions and periods. Emphasis on the diversity of urban experience in literature. Topics include public and private space, memory, and gender.

courses.title: Myth in Literature
courses.desc: Comparative study of different versions of one or more central myths, with attention to their cultural settings, artistic and literary forms of representation, as well as to their psychological dimensions.

courses.title: Modern Jewish Writers
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Problems of the modern Jewish experience from the perspective of the writer's construction of the self in relation to the future and to the non-Jew. Draws upon Russian, German, Yiddish, and American traditions.

courses.title: Mystical Literatures of South Asia & the Middle East
courses.desc: Exploration of the comparative mystical literatures of major religious traditions, with a focus on those produced in South Asia and the Middle East, although including other traditions.

courses.title: Colonial & Postcolonial Experience in Literature
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Literary introduction to the cultural issues of colonialism and postcolonialism through reading, discussing and writing on narratives which articulate diverse points of view.

courses.title: Literature of the Americas
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Study of the various stylistic, historical, social and cultural factors that contribute to a hemispheric vision of American literature, encompassing works by Canadian, United States, Caribbean, Brazilian, and Spanish-American writers.

courses.title: Literature of the Americas (Taught in Latin America)
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Various stylistic, historical, social, and cultural factors that contribute to a hemispheric vision of American literature, encompassing works by Canadian, United States, Caribbean, Brazilian, and Spanish-American writers. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: The Forms of Asian Literature
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Introduction to distinctive Asian literary forms, such as haiku, noh, the Chinese novel and tale, through reading of major works. Comparison with Western genres and study of native and Western critical traditions.

courses.title: African Literature
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Colonial and post-colonial sub-Saharan African literature and the African oral traditions from which it emerged. Genres and themes of African literature from the 19th century to the present.

courses.title: Classical Literatures of the Islamic World 600-1900
courses.desc: Major texts from Arabic, Persian, Ottoman Turkish and Urdu literature with attention to historical and cross-cultural context. Includes epic, romance, various genres of lyric poetry, fairy tales, historical and religious stories, mystical and philosophical narratives, and essays.

courses.title: The Ramayana
courses.desc: Exploration of the Indian epic, Ramayana, through the lens of literature, performance, and visual art. Emphasis on the text's diversity and its contemporary global relevance. Topics include Ramayanas in Southeast Asia, and in various South Asian diaspora communities.

courses.title: War & Peace in Literature
courses.prereqs: COM 001 or COM 002 or COM 003;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Through study of a few major works from Western and non-Western literature, illuminates the way in which literature from antiquity to the present has dealt with the antinomy peace/war through the ages.

courses.title: The Detective Story as Literature
courses.desc:
Study of the origins, literary and social background, development and
implications of the literature of detection in a comparative context.

courses.title: Women in Literature
courses.prereqs: COM 001, COM 002, COM 003, or COM 004 or the equivalent recommended.
courses.desc: Portrayals of women in literature, comparing selected heroines who represent a particular theme, period, or genre. Texts range around the globe and from ancient to modern works, such as Lysistrata, Emma, Hedda Gabler, The Makioka Sisters, and Top Girls.

courses.title: The Modern Novel
courses.desc: The changing image of man and his world as seen in novels by such writers as Joyce, Proust, and Mann.

courses.title: The Modern Drama
courses.desc: Readings in representative authors such as Ibsen, Strindberg, Chekhov, Pirandello and Brecht.

courses.title: Tragedy
courses.desc: Persistent and changing aspects of the tragic vision in literature from ancient times to the present.

courses.title: Comedy
courses.desc: Comic attitudes towards life in literary works of different ages.

courses.title: Writing Love & War in South Asia
courses.desc: Comparative study of the themes and motifs of love and war in the literature of South Asia. Includes a discussion of Sanskrit epics, classical erotic court poetry, medieval heroic poetry, mystical compositions and colonial and post-colonial fiction.

courses.title: Biography & Autobiography
courses.desc: Portrayals of a human life in biographies and/or autobiographies of different countries and ages.

courses.title: The European Middle Ages
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Medieval literary genres as the foundation for modern literary forms. Topics and themes as love, God, vision, nature, history and politics, and sign theory.

courses.title: The Renaissance
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Literature, new science, gender, politics, and exploration in European Renaissance. Readings in Petrarch, Machiavelli, Montaigne, Tasso, Ariosto, Stampa, Shakespeare, Labé and Aphra Behn.

courses.title: Baroque & Neoclassicism
courses.desc: Readings in major authors such as Calderón, Corneille, Pascal, Racine, Milton, and Grimmelshausen, with consideration of the tension between the expansive energies of the "baroque" and the restraints of dogma and reason.

courses.title: The Enlightenment
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Enlightenment writers such as Swift, Voltaire, Sterne, Rousseau, Wollstonecraft, and Kant. Emphasis on the revolutionary impact of 18th-century philosophical ideas and literary forms on modern political, social, and aesthetic culture.

courses.title: Caribbean Literatures
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Comparative approach to the multi-lingual, multi-cultural literatures of the Caribbean. Works from English, French, and Spanish speaking regions with special attention to problems of identity, diaspora and resistance, class, gender, race.

courses.title: Caribbean Literatures
courses.desc: Comparative approach to the multi-lingual, multi-cultural literatures of the Caribbean. Works from English, French, and Spanish speaking regions with special attention to problems of identity, diaspora and resistance, class, gender, race. May be taught abroad at the University of Havana, Cuba.

courses.title: Literatures of the Modern Middle East
courses.desc: Major translated works in modern Middle Eastern and North African Literature, including Arabic, Hebrew, Persian, and Turkish. Social and historical formation, with topics such as conflict and coexistence, journeys, and displaced people, gender and family.

courses.title: The Epic
courses.desc: Study of various forms of epic poetry in both the oral and literary traditions.

courses.title: The Novel
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: The novel as global genre: picaresque, epistolary, Bildungsroman, historical novel, contemporary forms.

courses.title: Comparative Study of Major Authors
courses.desc: Pivotal works of artists in the Western mainstream, such as Dante, Shakespeare, Cervantes, Goethe, Tolstoi, Proust, and Joyce.

courses.title: The Avant-Garde
courses.desc: Studies in movements such as surrealism, expressionism and the absurd.

courses.title: The Contemporary Novel
courses.desc:
Study of important novels from different parts of the world, including
Asia, Africa, Latin America, Europe, and the United States, in the period from the Second World War to the present.

courses.title: Partition Literature: South Asia
courses.desc: An exploration of novels, short stories, plays, and films in translation and in English, produced about the Partition of India in 1947.

courses.title: A Story for a Life: The Arabian Nights
courses.desc: In-depth exploration of The Arabian Nights, the best-known work of pre-modern Arabic literature and a major work of world literature. Analysis of the work in its historical context and in comparison to other frame tales in world literature.

courses.title: Shahnameh: The Persian Book of Kings
courses.desc: In-depth analysis of the Persian Book of Kings (Shahnameh) by Abu al-Qasim Ferdowsi (d. 1020 CE) in its historical context with a comparative perspective on the role of this work in Persian and world literature.

courses.title: Selected Topics in Comparative Literature
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR); at least one course in literature.
courses.desc:
Study of a selected topic or topics appropriate to student and faculty
interests and areas of specialization of the instructor.

courses.title: Selected Topics in Comparative Literature (Taught Abroad)
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR); at least one course in literature or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Study of selected topics appropriate to student and faculty interests and areas of specialization of the instructor. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Proseminar: Comparative Literature: Past, Present, Future
courses.desc: History, theory, and methodology of comparative literature. Issues of national literature, world literature, and comparative literature. Relation of comparative literature to other disciplines and diverse expressions. Discussion of current problems in teaching and research in comparative literature. Required of M.A. and Ph.D. candidates.

courses.title: Teaching Comparative Literature in College
courses.prereqs: Appointment as a Comparative Literature Associate Instructor or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Discussion of the theory and practice of teaching composition at the college level in a department of comparative literature in relation to the major cultural and social developments and with specific application to the introductory COM 001, COM 002, COM 003, COM 004.

courses.title: The Community
courses.desc:
Basic concepts of community analysis and planned social change. The dynamics of community change through case studies of communities including peasant, urban ghetto, suburban mainline, and California
farm workers.

courses.title: Ethnicity & American Communities
courses.desc: Historical and cultural survey of the role of various ethnic groups in the development of American communities. Examines ethnicity as a cultural factor, ethnicity as power and issues related to selected American ethnic groups.

courses.title: Food Systems
courses.desc: Social aspects of agri-food systems. Social science perspectives applied to food and agricultural sustainability in relation to ecology, knowledge, technology, power, governance, labor, social difference, and social movements. Social and environmental effects of commodity chains in comparative global context.

courses.title: Technology & Society
courses.prereqs: CRD 001 or CRD 002 or SOC 001 or ANT 002.
courses.desc: Impact of technology on labor relations, employment, industrial development and international relations. Internal relations of technology development and deployment.

courses.title: Dynamics of Regional Development
courses.prereqs: CRD 001 or CRD 002 or SOC 001 or ANT 002.
courses.desc: Industrial cluster formation and institutions. Technology, labor relations and interfirm linkages in global value chains. California and other regions are used as case studies.

courses.title: Organization of Economic Space
courses.prereqs: CRD 001 or CRD 002 or SOC 001 or ANT 002.
courses.desc: Globalization and technological restructuring of economic activity focusing on new spatial patterns of production and circulation and their implications for workers, communities and societies, both in the U.S. and around the globe.

courses.title: Rural Change in the Industrialized World
courses.prereqs: SOC 001 or CRD 001 or CRD 002 or ANT 002.
courses.desc: Geography of rural environment with emphasis on rural restructuring. Demographics, community, economy, governance, agriculture, and environmental conservation in rural areas of industrialized world. Case studies from and comparisons drawn between North America, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, and Japan.

courses.title: Community Youth Development
courses.desc: Community influences on youth well-being, youth as agents of community change, and policies to support healthy communities for young people. Special emphasis on disparities in youth well-being related to race, class, immigration status, gender, sexual-orientation.

courses.title: Community Development Perspectives on Environmental Justice
courses.desc: Environmental justice social movements; inequitable distribution of pollution on low-income communities of color; histories, policies, and innovations associated environmental justice movements in the United States and around the world.

courses.title: Quantitative Methods in Community Research
courses.prereqs: SOC 046B or STA 013 or STA 032;  Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Introduction to statistical analysis of social data relevant to community research, planning and assessment, emphasizing data sources and acquisition, descriptive and inferential analysis techniques, and data interpretation and presentation. Emphasis on spatial data and methods, focusing on the sources, processing, analysis, and presentation of spatial data in a community assessment context.

courses.title: Community Field Research: Theory & Analysis
courses.prereqs: CRD 001;  (STA 013 or STA 013Y or SOC 046B);  any upper division Community & Regional Development (CRD) course recommended.
courses.desc: Design and analysis of community research considering the relationship between theory and practice. Community research methods, including elite interviewing, ethnographic approaches, and statistical methods, descriptive statistics and OLS regression. Requires design and completion of field research project.

courses.title: Community Development
courses.prereqs: CRD 001 or CRD 151 or SOC 002 or ANT 002 or ASA 100 or CHI 132 or AAS 101.
courses.desc: Principles and strategies of community organizing and development. Social change from the grassroots organizing perspective to the formalized public participation process involved in general plan revisions. Practical experience in conducting charrettes, visioning and community needs assessments.

courses.title: Community Development
courses.prereqs: CRD 001 or CRD 151 or SOC 002 or ANT 002 or ASA 100 or CHI 132 or AAS 101.
courses.desc: Introduction to principles and strategies of community organizing and development. Examination of non-profit organizations, citizen participation, poverty reduction, community needs assessment, and regional development strategies. Comparison of community development approaches of the U.S.A./California with other western and non-western societies.

courses.title: International Community Development: Europe
courses.prereqs: ANT 002 or IAD 010 or CRD 001 or CRD 002 or SOC 001 or SOC 002 or POL 001.
courses.desc: Examination and analysis of community development efforts in Europe and the impact of global forces in different settings. Alternative strategies with emphasis on self-reliance and locally controlled development. Based in Freiburg, Germany, including field trips to France and Switzerland; taught abroad.

courses.title: International Community Development: Africa
courses.prereqs: CRD 001 or CRD 002 or ANT 002 or IAD 010 or SOC 001 or SOC 002 or POL 001.
courses.desc: Examination and analysis of community development efforts in Africa and the impact of global forces in urban and rural settings. Focus on strategies that promote self-reliance and locally controlled development. Based in South Africa; includes field trips.

courses.title: Social Theory & Community Change
courses.prereqs: CRD 001 or SOC 001 or ANT 002;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Comparative overview of the dominant social science paradigms for the study of community development and change. Among the paradigms discussed are functionalism, conflict theory/Marxism, structuralism, community capitals, social exchange, post-positivism, feminist theories and social constructivism.

courses.title: Community Economic Development
courses.prereqs: CRD 152 or PLS 021 or ECS 015;  and Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: How government and community organizations help firms grow and create jobs through local economic development corporations, small business centers, revolving loan funds, incubators, and other programs. Techniques to analyze community economic potential and identification of appropriate intervention tools. Group project.

courses.title: Politics & Community Development
courses.desc: Analyzes political, economic and sociocultural forces shaping the form and function of local communities in the U.S. Considers theories of the state, the community and social change and case studies of actual community development in comparative historical perspective.

courses.title: Community Governance
courses.desc: Governing institutions and political processes at the local level. Local government organization, community autonomy, leadership, political change, policy development, and select policy issues including public finance. Topics change depending on student interest. Field research on coalition building or policy issues in select communities.

courses.title: People, Work & Technology
courses.prereqs: CRD 001 or SOC 001 or ANT 001;  Upper division standing recommended.
courses.desc: Analysis of the relationship between work, technology, and the human experience. Theories of the causes and consequences of labor process, changes under capitalism and globalization, impacts of race/ethnicity, class, gender, and citizenship status on work in the United States and globally; responses of workers, communities, and policy-makers to workplace changes.

courses.title: Theories of Organizations & Their Role in Community Change
courses.prereqs: (STA 013 or STA 013Y or SOC 046B);  (CRD 001 or CRD 002 or SOC 001 or ANT 002).
courses.desc: Planned change within and through community organizations. Private voluntary organizations, local community associations, and local government. Relationship between community organizations and social capital. Collaborative original data gathering and professional report writing.

courses.title: Housing & Social Policy
courses.desc: Social impact, economics, and politics of housing in the United States. Special attention given to federal, state, and local policy and program strategies to produce and preserve affordable housing and inclusive neighborhoods.

courses.title: Social Inequality: Issues & Innovations
courses.prereqs: CRD 001 or CRD 002 or SOC 001 or ANT 002;  Upper division standing recommended.
courses.desc: Focus on the dimensions, causes, and means of alleviating social inequality in the U.S. Examination and analysis of major theories and forms (class, race/ethnicity, gender, and citizenship status) of inequality. Policy-based and grassroots approaches to change.

courses.title: Comparative Ethnicity
courses.prereqs: CRD 001 or CRD 002 or SOC 001 or ANT 002;  Upper division standing recommended.
courses.desc: Role of ethnicity in shaping social systems and interaction. Analytical approaches to and issues arising from the study of ethnicity, through utilization of data from a range of different societies.

courses.title: Transnational Community Development
courses.desc: The effects of grassroots, non-state, non-corporate actors from abroad on local, national and international development. Socioeconomic, political, and cultural implications of transnational actions undertaken by international non-governmental organizations, individual migrants, and migrant grassroots civic organizations.

courses.title: Planning for Health
courses.desc: Focused on the intersection of city planning and public health. The health of an individual or community is determined not only by the health care they receive, but also by the natural, social, physical, economic, and political environment. Covers topics such as food access, air quality, water quality, waste and energy infrastructure, community engagement, and the planning process. Provides an overview of available public spatially explicit data.

courses.title: Spatial Methods in Community Research
courses.desc: Spatial analysis of social data relevant to community research, with focus on neighborhoods as units of analysis. Clustering, segregation, geodemographic modelling, spatial regression, mulitlevel models, spatial data management, accessibility.

courses.title: Community Development Theory
courses.desc: Introduction to theories of community development and different concepts of community, poverty, and development. Emphasis on building theory, linking applied development techniques to theory, evaluating development policy, and examining case studies of community development organizations and projects.

courses.title: Political Ecology of Community Development
courses.desc: Community development from the perspective of geographical political ecology.  Social and environmental outcomes of the dynamic relationship between communities and land-based resources, and between social groups. Cases of community conservation and development in developing and industrialized countries.

courses.title: The Political Economy of Urban & Regional Development
courses.desc: How global, political and economic restructuring and national and state policies are mediated by community politics; social production of urban form; role of the state in uneven development; dynamics of urban growth and decline; regional development in California.

courses.title: The Political Economy of Transnational Migration
courses.desc: Theoretical perspectives and empirical research on social, cultural, political, and economic processes of transnational migration to the U.S. Discussion of conventional theories will precede contemporary comparative perspectives on class, race, ethnicity, citizenship, and the ethnic economy.

courses.title: Transformation of Work
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing in history or social science degree program or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Exploration of the ways that the experience, organization, and systems of work are being reconfigured in the late-20th century. The impacts of economic restructuring on local communities and workers.

courses.title: Professional Skills for Community Development
courses.desc: Help develop the practical skills needed to work professionally in organizations that are involved in community development. Provides an overview of community development planning, project management, and consultation skills.

courses.title: Community Development Graduate Proseminar
courses.prereqs: Enrollment in Community Development graduate group.
courses.desc: Introduction to graduate training in Community Development. Seminar designed to introduce students entering graduate work in the Community Development Graduate Group to its ongoing activities.

courses.title: Introduction to Critical Theoretical Approaches to Literature & Culture
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Introduction to critical theory and its use for interpreting literary texts, film, and media forms in our present global culture.

courses.title: Visual Culture
courses.desc: Analysis of image production in the contemporary world (photography, film, television, advertising, etc.) and their effects on individual subjectivities and collective social identities.

courses.title: Histories of Cultural Studies
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor required. Undergraduate coursework in the humanities or social sciences recommended.
courses.desc: Histories and traditions of cultural studies internationally;  multiple legacies of cultural studies as a field of inquiry in various geographical contexts; foregrounds important critical perspectives resulting from social and intellectual movements world-wide.

courses.title: Theories of Cultural Studies
courses.desc: Definitions of "critical" scholarship and examination of various contexts in which cultural studies theory has emerged worldwide. Both mainstream and alternative theoretical traditions, such as those developed by people of color and by other minoritized groups.

courses.title: Practices of Cultural Studies
courses.prereqs: CST 200A;  CST 200B;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Methodological and practical applications of cultural studies research. Critical analyses of ethnography, textual analysis, social change, community development, and identity formation. Emphasis given to students' unique versions of cultural studies practices.

courses.title: History & Theory of Sexualities
courses.prereqs: CST 200A (can be concurrent);  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Studies of sexuality in feminist, literary, historical, and cultural studies research, specifically examining the emergence of "sexuality" as a field of research and the relationship of sexuality studies to cultural forms, subjectivity, and social relations generally.

courses.title: Studies in Race Theory
courses.prereqs: CST 200A (can be concurrent);  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Theoretical framework for the critical study of race, drawing on contemporary cultural studies and postcolonial scholarship in order to understand the social production of "race" as a category for organizing social groups and determining group processes.

courses.title: Studies in Nationalism, Transnationalism, & Late Capitalism
courses.prereqs: CST 200A (can be concurrent);  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Contemporary theories of nation, nationalism, postcolonialism, and transnationalism. Specific attention to the relationship between cultural production and the formation of ideas about nation and nationalism, including examination of both "legitimizing" and resistant discourses.

courses.title: Studies in the Rhetorics of Culture
courses.prereqs: CST 200A (can be concurrent);  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Survey of critical and analytical approaches to the study of texts.  Examination of multi-mediated objects to understand their cultural import by focusing on discursive production, dispersal, and reception processes, and related shifts in power relations.

courses.title: Studies in Political & Cultural Representations
courses.prereqs: CST 200A (can be concurrent);  Consent of graduate advisor required.
courses.desc: Framework for the analysis of political and popular cultural representations.  Emphasis on concepts, theories, and methodologies illuminating dominant and vernacular cultural representation, appropriation, and innovation in transnational contexts.

courses.title: Colloquium
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Designed to provide cohort identity and faculty student exchange.  Opportunity to present papers, hear guest lecturers, and see faculty presentations, gather for organizational and administrative news, exchange information, and make announcements.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Special topics courses offered according to faculty and student interests and demands.

courses.title: Introduction to Media Computation
courses.desc: Introduction to key computational ideas necessary to understand and produce digital media.  Fundamentals of programming are covered as well as analysis of how media are represented and transmitted in digital form. Aimed primarily at non-computer science students.

courses.title: Media History 1, Guttenberg to Oppenheimer
courses.desc: History of Media to 1945, with particular focus on mechanically reproduced mass media technologies including the printing press, the newspaper, photography, cinema, radio and early computing technology. Analysis of inter-related cultural and political topics.

courses.title: Media History 2 1945-Present
courses.desc: History of media from 1945 to present, with particular focus on the development of the computer, digital network and Internet technologies in the context of other media infrastructures like radio, television and satellite networks. Analysis of inter-related cultural/political topics.

courses.title: History of Cinema from 1945 to the present
courses.desc: Examination of cinema in the postwar period. Study of world cinema trends and the economic and socio-political conditions enabling innovative work in the film industry.

courses.title: Design on Screen
courses.desc: Analysis of the contribution of outstanding designers for cinema, television and filmed entertainment. Study of diverse aesthetic theories of production design and art direction, costume design, or cinematography. Introductory principles and practice, history.

courses.title: Costume Design for Film
courses.desc: Theory and practice of the art and business of film costume design. Script analysis, costume research, developing design concepts, budgeting, and current production practices and methods. Execution of designs for period and contemporary films. Viewing of current films.

courses.title: Modern Iranian Cinema
courses.prereqs: Upper division standing, or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Iranian cinema of the 20th century in the context of profound cultural and social changes in Iran especially since the Iranian Revolution. Productions by representative directors such as Kiarostami, Makhmalbaf, Bahram Beizaie are included. Knowledge of Persian not required.

courses.title: Modern South Asia Cinema
courses.prereqs: Upper division standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: South Asian cinema of last 100 years in the context of cultural, social, and political changes. South Asian history, Independence, Partition, urban life, class, migration, postcolonial identity, diaspora, gender, sexuality, religion, sport, performance, etc.

courses.title: Chinese Film
