courses.title: Special Topics in Electrical Engineering & Computer Science: Electromagnetics
courses.desc: Special topics in Electromagnetics.

courses.title: Special Topics in Electrical Engineering & Computer Science: Opto-Electronics
courses.desc: Special topics in Opto-Electronics.

courses.title: Navigating Graduate School
courses.prereqs: First-year Electrical & Computer Engineering graduate student, Electrical & Computer Engineering transfer student, or instructor approval.
courses.desc: Practical and non-technical skills necessary for first-year students in the Electrical & Computer Engineering Graduate Group. Mentorship, time management, research ethics, science communication, intellectual property.

courses.title: Digital Signal Processing
courses.prereqs: EEC 150B;  STA 120 or MAT 131 or MAT 167 recommended.
courses.desc: Theory and design of digital filters. Classification of digital filters, linear phase systems, all-pass functions, FIR and IIR filter design methods and optimality measures, numerically robust structures for digital filters.

courses.title: Computational Methods in Biomedical Imaging
courses.desc: Analytic tomographic reconstruction from projections in 2D and 3D; model-based image reconstruction methods; maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods; applications to CT, PET, and SPECT.

courses.title: Digital Image Processing
courses.desc:
Two-dimensional systems theory, image perception, sampling and quantization, transform theory and applications, enhancement, filtering
and restoration, image analysis, and image processing systems.

courses.title: MOS Analog Circuit Design
courses.desc: Analysis and design of MOS amplifiers, bias circuits, voltage references and other analog circuits. Stability and compensation of feedback amplifiers. Introduction to noise analysis in MOS circuits.

courses.title: Advanced Analog Circuit Design
courses.desc: Noise and distortion in electronic circuits and systems. Application to communication circuits. Specific applications include mixers, low-noise amplifiers, power amplifiers, phase-locked loops, oscillators and receiver architectures.

courses.title: Analog MOS IC Design for Signal Processing
courses.desc: Analysis and design of analog MOS integrated circuits. Passive components, Single-ended and fully differential op amps, Sampled-data and continuous-time filters.

courses.title: Data-Conversion Techniques & Circuits
courses.desc: Digital-to-analog and analog-to-digital conversion; component characteristics and matching; sample-and-hold, comparator, amplifier, and reference circuits.

courses.title: Circuits for Digital Communications
courses.prereqs: EEC 150B;  EEC 210 (can be concurrent);  EEC 165, EEC 166, or EEC 265 recommended.
courses.desc: Analog, digital, and mixed-signal CMOS implementations of communication-circuit blocks: gain control, adaptive equalizers, sampling detectors, clock recovery.

courses.title: Low Power Digital Integrated Circuit Design
courses.desc: Integrated circuit design for low power and energy consumption. Low power architectures, logic styles and circuit design. Variable supply and threshold voltages. Leakage management. Power estimation. Energy sources, power electronics, and energy recovery. Applications in portable electronics and sensors. Thermodynamic limits.

courses.title: Radio Frequency & Microwave Filter Design
courses.desc: Design of radio frequency and microwave filters including filter specification and approximation theory. Passive LC filter design covers doubly-terminated reactance two-port synthesis and coupling matrix based synthesis. Active filter design includes sensitivity, op-amp building blocks, and cascade filter design.

courses.title: RF IC Design
courses.desc: Radio frequency (RF) solid-state devices, RF device modeling and design rules; non-linear RF circuit design techniques; use of non-linear computer-aided (CAD) tools; RF power amplifier design.

courses.title: RF Integrated Circuits for Wireless Communications
courses.desc: Integrated RF front end circuit design of receivers and synthesizers for wireless communications, such as LNA, mixers, PLL; noise and linearity analysis and specifications; theory and working mechanism of synthesizers and phase noise analysis.

courses.title: Terahertz & mm-Wave Integrated Circuit Design
courses.prereqs: EEC 132A;  EEC 112;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Fundamental theory of RF transmitter and receiver, including noise analysis, transceiver architectures, and antenna arrays. Fundamental limitations, theory and design of amplifiers, oscillators and signal sources at THz and mm-wave frequencies

courses.title: Advanced Microwave Circuit & Device Design Techniques
courses.desc: Theory, design, fabrication, analysis of advanced microwave circuits and devices. Wideband transformers, stripline/microstripline broadband couplers. Lumped and distributed filter synthesis. Broadband matching theory applied to microwave devices. Wideband and low noise FET/HEMT amplifiers. Advanced microwave oscillator theory. Phase noise analysis.

courses.title: RF-MEMS & Adaptive Wireless Frontends
courses.desc: Focuses on the modeling, design, fabrication, and characterization of RF-MEMS while providing a thorough introduction to the technology with an emphasis on how it will benefit the design of adaptive RF/microwave wireless systems.

courses.title: Electromagnetics
courses.desc: Maxwell's equations, plane waves, reflection and refraction, complex waves, waveguides, resonant cavities, and basic antennas.

courses.title: Plasma Physics & Controlled Fusion I
courses.desc: Equilibrium plasma properties; single particle motion; fluid equations; waves & instabilities in a fluid plasma; plasma kinetic theory & transport coefficients; linear & nonlinear Vlasov theory; fluctuations, correlations & radiation; inertial & magnetic confinement systems in controlled fusion.

courses.title: Plasma Physics & Controlled Fusion II
courses.desc: Equilibrium plasma properties; single particle motion; fluid equations; waves & instabilities in a fluid plasma; plasma kinetic theory & transport coefficients; linear & nonlinear Vlasov theory; fluctuations, correlations & radiation; inertial & magnetic confinement systems in controlled fusion.

courses.title: Plasma Physics & Controlled Fusion III
courses.desc: Equilibrium plasma properties; single particle motion; fluid equations; waves & instabilities in a fluid plasma; plasma kinetic theory & transport coefficients; linear & nonlinear Vlasov theory; fluctuations, correlations & radiation; inertial & magnetic confinement systems in controlled fusion.

courses.title: Advanced Applied Electromagnetics I
courses.desc: The exact formulation of applied electromagnetic problems using Green's functions. Applications of these techniques to transmission circuits.

courses.title: Advanced Applied Electromagnetics II
courses.desc: An advanced treatment of electromagnetics with applications to passive microwave devices and antennas.

courses.title: High Speed Signal Integrity
courses.desc: Design and analysis of interconnects in high-speed circuits and sub-systems; understanding of high-speed signal propagation and signal integrity concepts; electromagnetic modeling tools and experimental techniques.

courses.title: Physics & Technology of Microwave Vacuum Electron Beam Devices I
courses.prereqs: B.S. degree in physics or engineering or the equivalent background or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Physics & technology of electron beam emission, flow and transport, electron gun design, space charge waves & klystrons with applications to accelerator systems, RF power sources for radar & communication systems, thermionic energy conversion, and electric space propulsion. Recent advances in materials & manufacturing technologies are also reviewed.

courses.title: Physics & Technology of Microwave Vacuum Electron Beam Devices II
courses.desc: Theory, modeling, & experimental design of traveling wave tubes, backward wave oscillators, and extended interaction oscillators employed in satellite commutations, plasma imaging, and underground imaging systems.

courses.title: Physics & Technology of Microwave Vacuum Electron Beam Devices III
courses.desc: Physics & technology of gyrotrons, gyro-amplifiers, free electron lasers, magnetrons, cross-field amplifiers, and relativistic devices employed in plasma fusion reactors, microwave heating, and high power microwave applications.

courses.title: Photonics
courses.desc: Optical propagation of electromagnetic waves and beams in photonic components and the design of such devices using numerical techniques.

courses.title: Nonlinear Optical Applications
courses.desc: Nonlinear optical interactions in optical communication, optical information processing and integrated optics.  Basic concepts underlying optical nonlinear interactions in materials and guided media.

courses.title: Lasers
courses.prereqs: EEC 235;  EEC 130B;  Or the equivalent of EEC 130B.
courses.desc: Theoretical and practical description of lasers. Theory of population inversion, amplification and oscillation using semiclassical oscillator model and rate equations. Description and design of real laser system.

courses.title: Laser Physics II
courses.desc: Oscillation threshold. Coupled cavity/atomic rate equations, Linear pulse propagation; dispersion, broadening, compression. Nonlinear pulse propagation. Energy extraction. Optical beams, resonators, eigenmodes, axial/transverse modes. Paraxial ray optics, resonator stability, ABCD matrices. Laser dynamics; transients, spiking, Q-switching, active and passive modelocking.

courses.title: Semiconductor Lasers & Photonic Integration
courses.desc: Understanding of fundamental optical transitions in semiconductors and quantum-confined systems are applied to diode & unipolar lasers and selected photonic devices. The importance of radiative and non-radiative recombination, simulated emission, excitons in quantum wells, and strained quantum layers are considered. Photonic integrated circuits based on active (with optical gain) and passive (without optical gain).

courses.title: Optical Communication Technologies  for High-Speed Data Networking
courses.desc: Enabling technologies for optical fiber communication and data center networks. Physical layer issues for component and system technologies in high-speed data optical communications. High-capacity data multiplexing technologies including wavelength-division-multiplexing, time-division-multiplexing, and advanced coherent modulation. Optical signal transmission, optical amplification, and optical switching for telecom and data center networks.

courses.title: High-Capacity Optical Data Systems & Networks
courses.desc: High-capacity optical data systems and networks, built-on modern optical communication technologies. Technologies behind data center networking, software defined networking, and RF-optical networking. Physical layer issues in light of networking architectures and protocols. Optical communications systems design and integration. Systems technologies and higher-level network architecture, case studies. WDM, TDM, and EON networking, optical and wireless access technologies based on PON and ROF.

courses.title: Semiconductor Device Physics
courses.desc: Physical principles, characteristics and models of fundamental semiconductor device types, including P-N and Schottky diodes, MOSFETs and MESFETs Bipolar Junction Transistors, and light emitters/detectors.

courses.title: Introduction to Molecular Electronics
courses.desc: Examines molecules for electronic devices and sensors. Covers: electronic states of molecules, charge transport in nanoscale systems, and fabrication and measurement of molecular-scale devices. Specific Topics: Hartree-Fock & Density Functional Theory, Landauer formalism, coulomb blockade, tunneling and hopping transport.

courses.title: Advanced Nanostructured Devices
courses.desc: Physics of nano-structured materials and device operation.  Overview of new devices enabled by nanotechnology; fabrication and characterization methods; applications of nano-structures and devices.

courses.title: Optical Imaging & Microscopy
courses.desc: Theory and techniques of optical imaging & microscopy. Fourier optics; light propagation & light detection; imaging contrast mechanisms; optical & microscopy techniques.

courses.title: Design of Microelectromechanical Systems (MEMS)
courses.prereqs: EEC 140A;  EEC 140B;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Theory and practice of MEMS design. Micromechanical fundamentals, CAD tools, and case studies. A MEMS design project is required. Designs will be fabricated in a commercial foundry and tested in EEC 244B.

courses.title: Microsciences
courses.desc: Introduction to the theory of physical and chemical principles at the microscale. Scale effects, surface tension, microfluidic mechanics, micromechanical properties, intermolecular interactions and micro tribology.

courses.title: Micro- & Nano-Technology in Life Sciences
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Survey of biodevice design from engineering and biological perspectives; micro-/nano-fabrication techniques; surface science and mass transport; essential biological processes and models; proposal development skills on merging aforementioned themes.

courses.title: Advanced Semiconductor Devices
courses.desc: Semiconductor devices, including MOSFETs, heterojunction transistors, light-emitting diodes, lasers, sensors, detectors, power and high-voltage transistors, MEMS resonators, organic semiconductors and photovoltaics. All material is from recent literature, encouraging students to utilize search methods and critically assess the latest research.

courses.title: Photovoltaics & Solar Cells
courses.prereqs: EEC 140B;  or Consent of Instructor.  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Physics and application of photovoltaics and solar cells, including design, fabrication technology, and grid incorporation. Mono and microcrystalline silicon devices; thin-film technologies, heterojunction and organic-semiconductor technologies. Collectors, electrical inverters and infrastructure issues. Challenges and concerns.

courses.title: Nanofabrication
courses.desc: Theory and practice of nanofabrication (top-down and bottom-up approaches), used for producing integrated circuits, electronic devices, sensors, and microstructures. Process development and characterization.

courses.title: Linear Systems & Signals
courses.desc: Mathematical description of systems. Selected topics in linear algebra. Solution of the state equations and an analysis of stability, controllability, observability, realizations, state feedback and state estimation. Discrete-time signals and systems, and the Z-transform.

courses.title: Nonlinear Systems
courses.desc: Nonlinear differential equations, second-order systems, approximation methods, bifurcations, Lyapunov stability, absolute stability, Popov criterion, circle criterion, sliding-mode control, feedback linearization techniques.

courses.title: Multivariable Control System Design
courses.desc: Review of single-loop feedback design. Stability, performance and robustness of multi-input multi-output control systems. H-infinity design. Frequency response methods. Optimization-based design. Algebraic design methods for uncertain systems.

courses.title: Optimization
courses.prereqs: MAT 022A;  Knowledge of FORTRAN or C.
courses.desc: Modeling optimization problems in engineering design and other applications; optimality conditions; unconstrained optimization (gradient, Newton, conjugate gradient and quasi-Newton methods); duality and Lagrangian relaxation constrained optimization. (Primal method and an introduction to penalty and augmented Lagrangian methods.)

courses.title: Robotic Systems
courses.desc: Introduction to robotic systems.  Mechanical manipulators, kinematics, manipulator positioning and path planning.  Dynamics of manipulators.  Robot motion programming and control algorithm design.

courses.title: Stochastic Optimization in Dynamic Systems
courses.desc: Markov Decision Processes (MDP), dynamic programming, multi-armed bandit, Partially observable MDP, optimal stopping, stochastic scheduling, sequential detection and quickest change detection, competitive MDP and game theory, applications in dynamic systems such as queueing networks, communication systems, and multi-agent systems.

courses.title: Random Signals & Noise
courses.desc: Random processes as probabilistic models for signals and noise. Probability and random variables, Convergence and limit theorems, Specification of random processes, Markov Chains, Wiener process and white Gaussian noise, Poisson process and shot noise, Processing and frequency analysis of random signals.

courses.title: Signal Processing for Communications
courses.prereqs: EEC 165;  EEC 260;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Signal processing in wireless and wireline communication systems. Characterization and distortion of wireless and wireline channels. Channel equalization and maximum likelihood sequence estimation. Channel precoding and pre-equalization. OFDM and transmit diversity. Array processing.

courses.title: Multi-access Communications Theory
courses.prereqs: (EEC 173A or ECS 152A);  STA 120;  Or equivalent of STA 120.
courses.desc: Maximum stable throughput of Poisson collision channels.  Classic collision resolution algorithms.  Carrier sensing multiple access and its performance analysis.  System stability analysis.  Joint design of the physical/medium access control layers.  Capacity region of multi-access channels. Multi-access with correlated sources.

courses.title: Optimal & Adaptive Filtering
courses.desc: Geometric formulation of least-squares estimation problems. Theory and applications of optimum Wiener and Kalman filtering. MAP and maximum likelihood estimation of hidden Markov models, Viterbi algorithm. Adaptive filtering algorithms, properties and applications.

courses.title: Estimation & Detection of Signals in Noise
courses.desc: Introduction to parameter estimation and detections of signals in noise. Bayes and Neyman-Pearson likelihood-ratio tests for signal detection. Maximum-likelihood parameter estimation. Detection of known and Gaussian signals in white or colored noise.  Applications to communications, radar, signal processing.

courses.title: Principles of Digital Communications
courses.prereqs: EEC 165;  EEC 260;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Introduction to digital communications. Coding for analog sources. Characterization of signals and systems. Modulation and demodulation for the additive Gaussian channel. Digital signaling over bandwidth-constrained linear filter channels and over fading multipath channels. Spread spectrum signals.

courses.title: Information Theory & Coding
courses.desc: Topics include Entropy, Relatively Entropy, Mutual Information; Asymptotic Equipartition Property; Entropy Rates of Stochastic Process; Data Compression; Channel Capacity; Differential Entropy; Gaussian Channel; Rate Distortion Theory; Network Information Theory.

courses.title: Mobile Communications
courses.desc: Time-varying multi-path fading channel models and receiver performance in fading channels;  multiple access techniques and multiple access receivers design and performance;  optimum design and the capacity of wireless channels.

courses.title: Error Correcting Codes I
courses.desc:
Introduction to the theory and practice of block codes, 
linear block codes, cyclic codes, decoding algorithms, coding techniques.

courses.title: Error Correcting Codes II
courses.desc: Introduction to convolutional codes, turbo codes, trellis and block coded modulation codes,soft-decision decoding algorithms, the Viterbi algorithm,reliability-based decoding, trellis-based decoding, multistage decoding.

courses.title: Computer Architecture
courses.desc:
Introduction to modern techniques for high-performance single and
multiple processor systems. Topics include advanced pipeline design, advanced memory hierarchy design, optimizing pipeline and memory use, and memory sharing among multiprocessors. Case studies of recent single and multiple processor systems.

courses.title: Computer Architecture
courses.desc: Introduction to modern techniques for high-performance single and multiple processor systems. Topics include advanced pipeline design, advanced memory hierarchy design, optimizing pipeline and memory use, and memory sharing among multiprocessors. Case studies of recent single and multiple processor systems.

courses.title: High-Performance Computer Architecture
courses.desc: Designing and analysis of high performance computer architecture with emphasis on vector processing, on-chip interconnect networks, chip-level multiprocessors, memory and storage subsystem design and impact of technological advances on computer architecture.

courses.title: Networking Architecture & Resource Management
courses.desc: Design & implementation principles of networking architecture and protocols. Internet, data center, and telephony case studies. Topics: Internet data & control planes; application & services; resource management; Quality of Service (QoS) provisioning; traffic engineering; performance evaluation, software-defined networks, & future research issues.

courses.title: Internet Measurements & Network Interference
courses.desc: Internet measurements and network inference, covering the entire data pipeline from data collection, analysis, modeling, to design of data-driven novel/intelligent networked systems. Operational networks: Internet backbone, cellular networks, edge networks, software-defined networks and network function virtualization, data center networks, cloud infrastructure, peer-to-peer and content distribution networks, online social networks, and networked Internet-of-things (IoTs).

courses.title: Fault-Tolerant Computer Systems: Design & Analysis
courses.desc: Introduces fault-tolerant digital system theory and practice. Covers recent and classic fault-tolerant techniques based on hardware redundancy, time redundancy, information redundancy, and software redundancy. Examines hardware and software reliability analysis, and example fault-tolerant designs.

courses.title: Graphics Architecture
courses.desc: Design and analysis of the architecture of computer graphics systems.  Topics include the graphics pipeline with a concentration on hardware technqiues and algorithms, exploiting parallelism in graphics, and case studies of noteworthy and modern graphics arhitectures.

courses.title: Modern Parallel Computing
courses.prereqs: ECS 036B or ECS 034;  EEC 170 or ECS 154A recommended.
courses.desc: Exploration of the architecture of modern parallel computers, their programming models, and their programming systems.

courses.title: VLSI Digital Signal Processing
courses.prereqs: EEC 150B;  EEC 170;  (EEC 180 or EEC 180B);  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Digital signal processors, building blocks, and algorithms. Design and implementation of processor algorithms, architectures, control, functional units, and circuit topologies for increased performance and reduced circuit size and power dissipation.

courses.title: Advanced Design Verification of Digital Systems
courses.desc: Design verification techniques for digital systems; simulation-based design verification techniques; formal verification techniques, including equivalence checking, model checking, and theorem proving; timing analysis and verification; application of design cerification techniques to microprocessors.

courses.title: Design & Optimization of Embedded Computing Systems
courses.prereqs: EEC 170;  (EEC 180 or EEC 180B);  or Consent of Instructor.  ECS 122A recommended.
courses.desc: Introduction to design and optimization of digital computing systems for embedded applications. Topics include combinatorial optimization techniques, performance and energy optimization in embedded systems, compilation and architecture-specific mapping, programmable and reconfigurable platforms; design automation and algorithmic improvements to design process.

courses.title: Introduction to Digital System Testing
courses.desc: Review of several current techniques used to detect physical faults in both combinational and sequential circuits. Topics include fault modeling, fault simulation, test generation, compression techniques, and testing architectures.

courses.desc: Special topics in Computer Science.

courses.desc: Special topics in Programming Systems.

courses.title: Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Optoelectronics
courses.desc: Special topics in Optoelectronics.

courses.title: Special Topics in Electrical Engineering & Computer Science: Computer Networks
courses.desc: Special topics in Computer Networks.

courses.title: Energy Systems
courses.desc: Theory and application of energy systems. Systems analysis, energy conversion technologies, environmental considerations, economics and system optimization.

courses.title: Life Cycle Assessment for Sustainable Engineering
courses.desc: Life cycle assessment methodology. Emphasis on applications to infrastructure and energy systems. Life cycle design, life cycle cost methods, other tools from industrial ecology, and links to policy.

courses.title: Energy & Climate Policy
courses.prereqs: ECN 100A or ARE 100A;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Fundamentals of energy technology, economics, and policy. Survey and analysis of current and prospective climate policies at the local and global level, including but not limited to cap-and-trade, emissions offsets, intensity standards, technology standards, mandates and subsidies.

courses.title: Mechanical Engineering
courses.desc: Description of the field of mechanical engineering with examples taken from industrial applications, discussions of the practice with respect to engineering principles, ethics, and responsibilities.

courses.title: Computer Programming for  Engineering Applications
courses.prereqs: MAT 016A (can be concurrent) or MAT 021A (can be concurrent).
courses.desc: Structured programming in C for solving problems in engineering. Introduction to MATLAB and comparison study of C/C++ with MATLAB.

courses.title: Manufacturing Processes
courses.prereqs: ENG 004 C- or better;  PHY 009A C- or better.
courses.desc: Modern manufacturing methods, safety, manufacturing instructions, computer-aided manufacturing and their role in the engineering design and development process.

courses.title: Thermo-Fluid Dynamics
courses.prereqs: ENG 103 C- or better;  ENG 105 C- or better.
courses.desc: Inviscid incompressible flow, compressible flow, ideal gas mixtures, psychrometrics, reacting mixtures and combustion.

courses.title: Measurement Systems
courses.prereqs: ENG 100 C- or better;  ENG 102 C- or better;  ENG 104 recommended.
courses.desc: Experiments to illustrate principles of mechanical systems. Signal analysis; Demonstration of basic sensors for mechanical systems; Experimental project design; Experiments involving voltage measurement; strain gauges, dynamic systems of 1st order.

courses.title: Experimental Methods for Thermal Fluids
courses.desc: Experiments illustrating principles of thermal-fluid systems and related measurement devices. Statistical design of experiments and uncertainty analysis of data; thermodynamic cycles, combustion, compressible and incompressible flows.

courses.title: Introduction to Numerical Analysis & Methods
courses.prereqs: (ENG 006 C- or better or EME 005 C- or better or ECS 030 C- or better or ECM 006 C- or better);  (MAT 021A C- or better,  MAT 021B C- or better,  MAT 021C C- or better,  MAT 021D C- or better,  MAT 022A C- or better,  MAT 022B C- or better);  (PHY 009A C- or better,  PHY 009B C- or better,  PHY 009C C- or better).
courses.desc: Number representation, Taylor expansions, error  and stability analysis, roots of nonlinear equations, sets of linear equations, numerical integration, ordinary differential equations.

courses.title: Introduction to Numerical Analysis & Methods
courses.prereqs: (ENG 006 C- or better or EME 005 C- or better or ECS 030 C- or better or ECS 032A C- or better or ECS 036A C- or better or ECH 060 C- or better or ECM 006 C- or better);  ((MAT 021A C- or better,  MAT 021B C- or better,  MAT 021C C- or better,  MAT 021D C- or better,  (MAT 022A C- or better or MAT 027A C- or better),  (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better)),  (PHY 009A C- or better,  PHY 009B C- or better,  PHY 009C C- or better).
courses.desc: Number representation, Taylor expansions, error  and stability analysis, roots of nonlinear equations, sets of linear equations, numerical integration, ordinary differential equations.

courses.title: Engineering Applications of Dynamics
courses.prereqs: ENG 102 C- or better;  (ENG 006 C- or better or EME 005 C- or better or ECS 030 C- or better).
courses.desc: Technical elective that revisits dynamic principles with emphasis on engineering applications; Equations of motion are derived and put into a format for computer solution; There is a computer laboratory where real engineering systems are simulated.

courses.title: Vehicle Stability
courses.desc: Analytical and experimental studies of the dynamics, stability and control of vehicles such as cars, trailers, airplanes, motorcycles, bicycles and rail cars.

courses.title: Stability of Flexible Dynamic Systems
courses.prereqs: ENG 102 C- or better;  ENG 103 C- or better.
courses.desc: Stability of flexible systems. Introduction to fluid-structure interaction. Mechanical vibrations. Design of mechanical subsystems or systems under constraints. Dynamic instabilities. Flutter. Control effectiveness. Energy extraction from fluid-structure interactions. Design applications to aerospace, mechanical and biomedical systems.

courses.title: Mechanical Design
courses.prereqs: (ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better);  (ENG 104 C- or better,  EME 050 C- or better (can be concurrent)).
courses.desc: Principles of mechanics applied to design. Deformation and stress analysis. Structural integrity under static and fluctuating loads. Projects demonstrate progression from concept to engineering analysis, with emphasis on strength and durability.

courses.title: Mechanical Design
courses.desc: Principles of engineering mechanics applied to the design and selection of mechanical components. Design projects, which concentrate on conceptual design, engineering analysis, methods of manufacture, material selection, and cost.

courses.title: Statistical Methods in Design & Manufacturing
courses.desc: Methods of statistical analysis with emphasis on applications in mechanical design and manufacturing. Applications include product evaluation and decision making, probabilistic design, systems reliability, and fatigue under random loading.

courses.title: Computer-Aided Mechanism Design
courses.prereqs: ENG 102 C- or better;  (EME 005 C- or better or ENG 006 C- or better or ECS 030 C- or better).
courses.desc: Principles of computer-aided mechanism design. Computer-aided kinematic, static, and dynamic analysis and design of planar mechanisms such as multiple-loop linkages and geared linkages. Introduction to kinematic synthesis of mechanisms.

courses.title: Mechatronics
courses.prereqs: ENG 100 C- or better;  ENG 102 C- or better;  EME 050 C- or better.
courses.desc: Overview of mechatronics system and control system design concepts, control software architecture, control hardware architecture, microcontroller and interface technology for mechatronics control, sensor for mechatronics systems, actuator drives.

courses.title: Combustion & the Environment
courses.desc: Introduction to combustion kinetics; premixed and diffusion flames; turbulent combustion; pollutant formation; examples of combustion devices such as internal combustion engines, gas turbines, furnaces and incinerators; alternative fuels.

courses.title: Internal Combustion Engines & Future Alternatives
courses.prereqs: EME 050 C- or better;  EME 106 C- or better.
courses.desc: Fundamentals of internal combustion engine design and performance. Future needs to adapt to environmental concerns, and the feasibility of better alternatives in the future.

courses.title: Introduction to Heating, Ventilation & Air Conditioning Systems
courses.prereqs: EME 106 C- or better;  EME 165 C- or better.
courses.desc: Introduction to basic mechanisms and processes associated with heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC), including equipment and systems used for HVAC in residential and commercial buildings.

courses.title: Heat Transfer
courses.prereqs: (ENG 006 C- or better or EME 005 C- or better or ECS 030 C- or better);  ENG 103 C- or better;  ENG 105 C- or better.
courses.desc: Conduction, convection, and radiation heat transfer. Computational modeling of heat transfer in engineering. Applications to engineering equipment with the use of digital computers.

courses.title: Analysis, Simulation & Design of Mechatronic Systems
courses.prereqs: ENG 100 C- or better;  ENG 102 C- or better.
courses.desc: Modeling of dynamic engineering systems in various energy domains. Analysis and design of dynamic systems. Response of linear systems. Digital computer simulation and physical experiments.

courses.title: Automatic Control of Engineering Systems
courses.prereqs: ENG 100 C- or better;  ENG 102 C- or better.
courses.desc: Classical feedback control systems; block diagrams; performance specifications; steady state errors; rise and settling times; root locus; PID controllers; Bode and Nyquist plots; stability; phase and gain margins; advanced topics as time allows.

courses.title: Mechanical Engineering Systems Design Project
courses.prereqs: EME 050 C- or better;  EME 150A C- or better;  EME 165 C- or better (can be concurrent);  ENG 003, CMN 001 or CMN 003 recommended; upper division composition recommended.
courses.desc: Major mechanical engineering design experience; the mechanical engineering design process and its use in the design of engineering systems incorporating appropriate engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints.

courses.title: Mechanical Engineering Systems Design Project
courses.prereqs: EME 185A;  senior standing in the Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering.
courses.desc: Major mechanical engineering design experience; the mechanical engineering design process and its use in the design of engineering systems incorporating appropriate engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints.

courses.title: Joan Viteri Memorial Clinic (JVMC) Student Volunteer
courses.desc: Field experience in health care delivery, patient histories and physical examinations, health promotions and disease prevention, diagnosis and treatment of episodic, acute and chronic illness, basic laboratory testing and appropriate referral and follow-up. Students must apply and interview.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Point-of-Care Ultrasound
courses.desc: First in a longitudinal elective course spanning the first two years of medical school. Introduces the fundamental concepts and technique of ultrasonography in preparation for patient assessment during clinical work. Through a series of lectures accompanied by hands-on practice sessions and case challenges, spaced teaching and deliberate practice, students will grasp the fundamentals of diagnostic ultrasound and solidify their knowledge of key medical science concepts.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Point-of-Care Ultrasound
courses.desc: Second longitudinal elective course spanning the first two years of medical school. Introduces the fundamental concepts and technique of ultrasonography in preparation for patient assessment during clinical work. Through a series of lectures accompanied by hands-on practice sessions and case challenges, spaced teaching and deliberate practice, students will grasp the fundamentals of diagnostic ultrasound and solidify their knowledge of key medical science concepts.

courses.title: Wilderness Medicine
courses.desc: Introductory elective course for students to explore how physicians can interact with the environment in austere conditions through lectures, hands-on/field experience, and case-based learning.

courses.title: Understanding Health Policy: A Focus on Analysis & Translation
courses.desc: Paradigm of healthcare delivery in the U.S. is changing rapidly. To prepare the next generation of physician leaders, provide the skills, tools, and knowledge needed to impact decisions made at the policy level.

courses.title: Cardiac Arrest, Resuscitation & Repurfusion SSM
courses.desc: Special Studies Module, a four-week course specific to the topics of Cardiac Arrest, Resusciatation & Repurfusion.

courses.title: Cardiac Arrest, Resuscitation & Repurfusion SSM
courses.desc: Special Studies Module, a four-week course specific to the topics of Cardiac Arrest, Resusciatation & Repurfusion.

courses.title: Materials Marvels: The Science of Superheroes
courses.desc: Introduction to science and technology of materials as key engineering ingredients. Explores the relationship between art and materials, and how superheroes are both products and resources of ideas for new materials' technologies.

courses.title: Principles of Polymer Materials Science
courses.prereqs: CHE 002A;  CHE 002B;  ((CHE 008A,  CHE 008B) or (ENG 045 or ENG 045Y));  introductory physics.
courses.desc: Basic principles of polymer science presented including polymer structure and synthesis; polymerization mechanisms, polymer classes, properties, and reactions; polymer morphology, rheology, and characterization; polymer processing.

courses.title: Thermodynamics of Materials
courses.prereqs: (ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better);  PHY 009B C- or better;  MAT 022B C- or better;  CHE 002C recommended.
courses.desc: Review of thermodynamic principles of interest to materials scientists and engineers. Application of thermodynamics to material processing, phase stability, corrosion.

courses.title: Structure & Characterization of Engineering Materials
courses.prereqs: (ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better);  MAT 022A C- or better;  PHY 009B C- or better.
courses.desc: Description of the structure of engineering materials on the atomic scale by exploring the fundamentals of crystallography. Importance of this structure to materials’ properties. Description of experimental determination using x-ray diffraction techniques.

courses.title: Kinetics of Materials
courses.prereqs: (ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better);  EMS 160;  (ECH 060 or ENG 006).
courses.desc: Basic kinetic laws and the principles governing phase transformations. Applications in diffusion, oxidation, nucleation, growth and spinodal transformations.

courses.title: Sustainable Energy Technologies: Batteries, Fuel Cells, & Photovoltaic Cells
courses.desc: Basic principles of future energy devices such as lithium batteries, fuel cells, and photovoltaic cells. Examines the current status of these energy technologies and analyze challenges that still must be overcome.

courses.title: Smart Materials
courses.prereqs: CHE 110A or PHY 009D;  ENG 006 or ECH 060 or equivalent recommended.
courses.desc: Electronic, optical, and magnetic properties of materials as related to structure and processing of solid state materials. Physical principles for understanding the properties of metals, semiconductors, ceramics, and amorphous solids and the applications of these materials in engineering.

courses.title: Mechanical Behavior of Materials
courses.prereqs: (ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better);  EMS 162 recommended.
courses.desc: Microscopic and macroscopic aspects of the mechanical behavior of engineering materials, with emphasis on recent development in materials characterization by nondestructive testing. Fundamental aspects of plasticity in engineering materials, strengthening mechanisms and mechanical failure modes of materials systems.

courses.title: Materials in Engineering Design
courses.prereqs: ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better.
courses.desc: Quantitative treatment of materials selection for engineering applications. Discussion of design & material selection strategy; process & process selection strategy; process economics; life-cycle thinking & eco-design. Use of materials selection software.

courses.title: Manufacturing of 3D & Composite Materials
courses.prereqs: (ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better);  (ENG 105 or ECH 152B or EEC 140A or EMS 164).
courses.desc: Fundamental physical and chemical principles underlying various processing techniques, used in manufacturing processes for bulk (3D) and composite structural and functional materials. Effects of processing variables on structure-property relationships.

courses.title: Failure Analysis
courses.prereqs: ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better;  EMS 174 recommended.
courses.desc: Analysis of the way materials fail. Effects of temperature, mechanical deformation and corrosion on the properties of materials. forensics and methodologies for investigating failures of materials including optical microscopy, x-ray analysis and scanning electron microscopy. Investigation of practical problems.

courses.title: Processing of 2D & Nanomaterials
courses.prereqs: (ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better);  (ENG 105 or ECH 152B or EEC 140A or EMS 164).
courses.desc: Fundamentals of processing methods for two-dimensional materials, including thin films and graphene-like materials; as well as nanomaterials, including nanoparticles, nanowires, and quantum dots.

courses.title: Directed Group Study
courses.desc: Group study of selected topics.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Electron Microscopy
courses.desc: Principles and techniques of scanning and transmission of electron microscopy used in the study of materials will be described. Emphasis upon practical applications.

courses.title: Interaction of Materials & their Environment
courses.prereqs: (ENG 045 or ENG 045Y);  ENG 105A recommended; or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Thermodynamic and kinetic foundations of the corrosion and oxidation processes. Practical aspects of corrosion control and prevention. Stress-corrosion and gas-embrittlement phenomena. Special topics in corrosion; microbiological and atmospheric corrosion.

courses.title: Micro- & Nano-Technology in Life Sciences
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Survey of biodevice design from engineering and biological perspectives; micro-/nano-fabrication techniques; surface science and mass transport; essential biological processes and models; proposal development skills on merging aforementioned themes.

courses.title: Photovoltaics & Solar Cells
courses.prereqs: EEC 140B;  or Consent of Instructor.  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Physics and application of photovoltaics and solar cells, including design, fabrication technology, and grid incorporation. Mono and microcrystalline silicon devices; thin-film technologies, heterojunction and organic-semiconductor technologies. Collectors, electrical inverters and infrastructure issues. Challenges and concerns.

courses.title: Fracture of Engineering Materials
courses.desc: Description of the failure of materials by crack propagation.  Topics include the stress fields about elastic cracks, the Griffith-Irwin analysis, descriptions of plastic zones, fracture toughness testing, microstructural aspects of fracture and failure at elevated temperatures.

courses.title: Mechanisms of Fatigue
courses.prereqs: EMS 174;  or Consent of Instructor.  EMS 248 recommended.
courses.desc: Microstructural description of the mechanisms of fatigue in metals.  Topics include a phenomenological treatment of cyclic deformation, dislocation processes in cyclic deformation, fatigue crack nucleation, Stage I growth, threshold effects and high temperature cyclic deformation.

courses.title: Special Topics in Polymer & Fiber Science
courses.desc: Selected topics of current interest in polymer and fiber sciences. Topics vary each time course is offered.

courses.title: Special Topics in Polymer & Fiber Science
courses.desc: Selected topics of current interest in polymer and fiber sciences. Topics vary each time course is offered.

courses.title: Special Topics in Polymer & Fiber Science
courses.desc: Selected topics of current interest in polymer and fiber sciences. Topics vary each time course is offered.

courses.title: Advanced Thermodynamics of Solids
courses.desc: Thermodynamic principles, formalism and their application to solid materials. Statistical mechanics and the relations between microscopic and macroscopic properties. Prediction of phase diagrams and phase stability, particularly for solids.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Structure of Materials
courses.prereqs: EMS 162;  EMS 174 recommended; graduate standing in Engineering or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Nature of microstructure in engineering materials. Crystalline and non-crystalline structures, with special emphasis on grain boundary segregation in the development of polycrystalline microstructure and the radial distribution function of amorphous materials.

courses.title: Transport Phenomena in Materials Processes
courses.desc: Thermodynamic driving forces and atomic-scale mechanisms underlying diffusive mass transport and interface motion in materials.  Nucleation, growth and coarsening dynamics of phase transformations.

courses.title: Advanced Materials Characterization
courses.desc: Fundamental working principles for characterization methods used in structural and compositional analysis of engineering materials. Topics include x-ray, electron, ion, and neutron interactions with materials and techniques include diffraction, spectroscopy, and imaging methods.

courses.title: Advanced Functional Properties of Materials
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing in Physics, Chemistry, and Engineering.
courses.desc: Fundamental physical properties of solid materials important to solid state devices, specifically electronic, magnetic, and optical properties. Topics include band structures, metals, superconductors, semiconductors, dielectrics, optical properties, and magnetic properties and implementation of these properties into devices.

courses.title: Advanced Mechanical Properties of Materials
courses.desc: Comprehensive study of mechanical properties of materials, with special attention to dislocations and deformation and fracture control mechanisms. Mechanical properties of conventional engineering materials as well as advanced materials such as nanocrystalline solids and thin films are considered.

courses.title: Glass: Science & Technology
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing in Chemistry, Physics or Engineering, or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Modern paradigms in glass science and their applications to technologies. Relation of macroscopic properties of glasses and glass-forming liquids to atomic-level structures, including principles of formation, relaxation, transport phenomena, nucleation, crystallization and phase separation in glasses.

courses.title: Advanced Computational Materials Science
courses.prereqs: Prior numerical programming experience and familiarity with control flow statements is recommended.
courses.desc: Capabilities and limitations of modern approaches in computational materials science. Implementation and use of these approaches. Molecular dynamics, cellular automata, and phase field techniques.

courses.title: Living Matter: Physical Biology of the Cell
courses.desc: Introduction to the origin, maintenance, and regulation of the dynamic architecture of the cell, including cellular modes of organization, dynamics and energy dissipation, molecular transport, motility, regulation, and adaptability.

courses.title: Special Topics in Materials Science
courses.desc: Special topics in the discipline of Materials Science & Engineering. Topics will vary by instructor.

courses.title: Introduction to Engineering
courses.desc: Introduction to the role of engineers in the acquisition and development of engineering knowledge, the differences and similarities among engineering fields, and the work ethic and skills required for engineering.

courses.title: Introduction to Engineering Design
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Introduction to the engineering design process that incorporates the development of oral and written communication skills integral to the design process. Conducted in workshop format with hands-on engagement in the design process.

courses.title: Engineering Graphics in Design
courses.desc: Engineering design, descriptive geometry, pictorial sketching, computer-aided graphics, and their application in the solution of engineering problems.

courses.title: Engineering Problem Solving
courses.prereqs: (MAT 016A C- or better or MAT 017A C- or better or MAT 021A C- or better);  (MAT 016B C- or better (can be concurrent) or MAT 017B C- or better (can be concurrent) or MAT 021B C- or better (can be concurrent)).
courses.desc: Methodology for solving engineering problems. Engineering computing and visualization based on MATLAB. Engineering examples and applications.

courses.title: Introduction to Entrepreneurship
courses.desc: Students from all majors will learn the processes involved in modern entrepreneurship and identify an opportunity for innovation. The 3 C's of the entrepreneurial mindset (developed by KEEN) will be covered: Curiosity, Connections, and Creating Values.

courses.title: The Science Behind the Technology in Our Lives
courses.desc: Understanding of how the technology in our lives works using only basic concepts and rudimentry mathematics.

courses.title: Issues in Engineering
courses.desc: Engineering profession and its role in society; engineering design and development process; introduction to the engineering grand challenges; and professional resources for students.

courses.title: Issues in Engineering
courses.desc: Engineering disciplines; the engineering profession’s methods, principles, and career opportunities; professional resources for students.

courses.title: Circuits I
courses.desc: Basic electric circuit analysis techniques, including electrical quantities and elements, resistive circuits, transient and steady-state responses of RLC circuits, sinusoidal excitation and phasors, and complex frequency and network functions.

courses.title: Introduction to Space Exploration: Understanding the Technological & Environmental Challenges to Our Exploration of the Solar System
courses.prereqs: High school level Algebra, Geometry, General Science (Physics and Chemistry).
courses.desc: Introductory overview of the space environment. Discussion of space exploration technology including propulsion, orbital mechanics, and spacecraft engineering.

courses.title: Statics
courses.prereqs: (PHY 009A C- or better or PHY 009HA C- or better);  MAT 021D C- or better (can be concurrent).
courses.desc: Force systems and equilibrium conditions with emphasis on engineering problems.

courses.title: Properties of Materials
courses.prereqs: (MAT 016C C- or better or MAT 021C C- or better);  CHE 002A C- or better;  PHY 009A C- or better.
courses.desc: Introduction to the properties of engineering materials and their relation to the internal structure of materials.

courses.title: Launching a Company
courses.desc: Technological innovation and product development. Working as a team to turn ideas into companies through customer development.

courses.title: Dynamics
courses.prereqs: ENG 035 C- or better;  MAT 022B C- or better.
courses.desc: Kinematics and kinetics of particles, systems of particles, and of rigid bodies; application of these topics are applied to engineering problems.

courses.title: Dynamics
courses.prereqs: ENG 035 C- or better;  (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better).
courses.desc: Kinematics and kinetics of particles, systems of particles, and of rigid bodies; application of these topics are applied to engineering problems.

courses.title: Fluid Mechanics
courses.prereqs: ENG 035 C- or better;  PHY 009B C- or better;  (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better).
courses.desc: Fluid properties, fluid statics, continuity and linear momentum equations for control volumes, flow of incompressible fluids in pipes, dimensional analysis and boundary-layer flows.

courses.title: Fluid Mechanics
courses.prereqs: ENG 035 C- or better;  MAT 022B C- or better;  PHY 009B C- or better.
courses.desc: Fluid properties, fluid statics, continuity and linear momentum equations for control volumes, flow of incompressible fluids in pipes, dimensional analysis and boundary-layer flows.

courses.title: Mechanics of Materials
courses.prereqs: ENG 035 C- or better;  (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better).
courses.desc: Uniaxial loading and deformation. General concepts of stress-strain-temperature relations and yield criteria. Torsion of shafts. Bending of beams. Deflections due to bending. Introduction to stability and buckling.

courses.title: Thermodynamics
courses.prereqs: MAT 022B C- or better;  PHY 009B C- or better.
courses.desc: Fundamentals of thermodynamics: heat energy and work, properties of pure substances, First and Second Law for closed and open systems, reversibility, entropy, thermodynamic temperature scales. Applications of thermodynamics to engineering systems. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Thermodynamics
courses.prereqs: PHY 009B C- or better;  (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better).
courses.desc: Fundamentals of thermodynamics: heat energy and work, properties of pure substances, First and Second Law for closed and open systems, reversibility, entropy, thermodynamic temperature scales. Applications of thermodynamics to engineering systems. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Engineering Economics
courses.desc: Analysis of problems in engineering economy; the selection of alternatives; replacement decisions. Compounding, tax, origins and cost of capital, economic life, and risk and uncertainty are applied to methods of selecting most economic alternatives.

courses.title: Engineering Economics
courses.desc: The analysis of problems in engineering economy; the selection of alternatives; replacement decisions. Compounding, tax, origins and cost of capital, economic life, and risk and uncertainty are applied to methods of selecting most economic alternatives.

courses.title: Electric Machinery Fundamentals
courses.desc: Principles of AC and DC electric motors and generators, their control systems and power sources. Selection of electric power equipment components based on their construction features and performance characteristics.

courses.title: Fluid Power Actuators & Systems
courses.prereqs: ENG 100 C- or better;  ENG 102 C- or better.
courses.desc: Hydraulic and pneumatic systems with emphasis on analysis and control of actuators. Design of hydraulic and pneumatic systems, specification and sizing of components, and selection of electro-hydraulics/electro-pneumatics, servo valves, and closed loop systems to solve basic control problems.

courses.title: Introduction to Mechanical Vibrations
courses.prereqs: ENG 102 C- or better;  (ENG 006 C- or better or ENG 005 C- or better or ECS 030 C- or better);  Ability to program in MATLAB.
courses.desc: Free and forced vibrations in lumped-parameter systems with and without damping; vibrations in coupled systems; electromechanical analogs; use of energy conservation principles.

courses.title: Environmental Physics & Society
courses.prereqs: (PHY 009D or PHY 010 or PHY 001B);  MAT 016B;  Or the equivalent of MAT 016B.
courses.desc: Impact of humankind on the environment are discussed from the point of view of the physical sciences. Calculations based on physical principles will be made, and the resulting policy implications are considered.

courses.title: Engineering Analysis
courses.prereqs: (ENG 006 C- or better or EME 005 C- or better or ECS 030 C- or better);  (MAT 021D C- or better,  MAT 022B C- or better).
courses.desc: Solutions of systems of linear and nonlinear algebraic equations; approximation methods; solutions of ordinary differential equations; initial and boundary value problems; solutions of partial differential equations of Elliptic, parabolic, and hyperbolic types; Eigen value problems.

courses.title: Engineering Analysis
courses.prereqs: (ENG 006 C- or better or EME 005 C- or better or ECS 030 C- or better or ECS 032A C- or better or ECS 036A C- or better);  ((MAT 021D C- or better,  (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better)).
courses.desc: Solutions of systems of linear and nonlinear algebraic equations; approximation methods; solutions of ordinary differential equations; initial and boundary value problems; solutions of partial differential equations of Elliptic, parabolic, and hyperbolic types; Eigen value problems.

courses.title: Science & Technology of Sustainable Power Generation
courses.prereqs: PHY 007C or PHY 009C;  upper division standing.
courses.desc: Focus on scientific understanding and development of power generation that is the basis of modern society. Concentration on power generation methods that are sustainable, in particular, discussion of the most recent innovations.

courses.title: Professional Responsibilities of Engineers
courses.desc: Organization of the engineering profession; introduction to contracts, specifications, business law, patents, and liability; discussion of professional, ethical, societal, and political issues related to engineering.

courses.title: Technology Management
courses.desc: Management of the engineering and technology activity. Functions of design, planning, production, marketing, sales, and maintenance. Technological product life cycle. Research and development activity. Project planning and organization. Manufacturing issues. Case studies.

courses.title: Introduction to Environmental Horticulture/Urban Forestry
courses.desc: Introduction to the use of plants to enhance the physical, visual and social environment, the use of ecological principles in developing sustainable, low maintenance landscape systems, and the career opportunities in these areas.

courses.title: Introduction to Environmental Plants
courses.desc: Classification, nomenclature and variation of environmental plants. The use of floral and vegetative characteristics and terminology to key unknown plants. Characteristics of plant groups and basics of climate, soils and plant selection. Identification of 150 common landscape plants.

courses.title: Urban Forestry
courses.desc: Principles and practices of planning and managing urban vegetation. Basics of tree appraisal, natural resource inventory, and development of long term urban forest management plans.

courses.title: Trees of the Urban Forest
courses.desc: Identification and evaluation of 200 tree species of the urban forest on campus, in the Arboretum, and in the city of Davis; appraised and aesthetic values, condition, and branch structure; contribution of trees to this ecosystem. Bicycle required.

courses.title: Physiological Principles in Environmental Horticulture
courses.desc:
Physiological principles and processes essential to floriculture, nursery crop production, turfculture and landscape horticulture.
Emphasis on the control of vegetative and reproductive development for a broad species range in greenhouse and extensive landscape environments.

courses.title: Taxonomy & Ecology of Environmental Plant Families
courses.desc: Classification and identification of introduced and native species used in urban forests, with emphasis on floral and vegetative characteristics of the prominent families of angiosperms and gymnosperms, adaptations to environmental variations in western landscapes, and horticultural classification.

courses.title: Management of Container Media
courses.desc: Principles of soil science and practices related to management of container media are taught, emphasizing appropriate use of soils and amendments, irrigation, and fertilizers.Physical and chemical properties are tested and effects of management on crops are evaluated in the laboratory.

courses.title: Greenhouse & Nursery Crop Production
courses.desc: Principles and techniques for the production of ornamental greenhouse and nursery crops. Hands-on experience producing greenhouse crops. Optional weekend field trip.

courses.title: Woody Plants in the Landscape: Growth, Ecology & Management
courses.desc: Principles and practices of managing trees and shrubs in the urban landscape and other managed environments. Topics include woody plant form; growth response and adaptation; tree management in relation to soil, moisture, climate; plant problems.

courses.title: Genetics & Plant Conservation: The Biodiversity Crisis
courses.desc: Conservation of genic diversity, measurement of diversity, threats to diversity and reasons for protection, the process of extinction, distribution of diversity, determination of what to conserve and means of conservation. Examples drawn largely from forest tree species.

courses.title: Restoration Ecology
courses.prereqs: PLB 117 or EVE 117 or PLS 147;  or equivalent course in ecology/plant ecology.
courses.desc: Broad, interdisciplinary approach to effective restoration. Design and implementation of restoration projects based on principles of physiology, population, community, ecosystem and landscape ecology.

courses.title: Restoration Ecology
courses.prereqs: SSC 112 C or better or ESP 100 C or better or ESM 144 C or better or LDA 050 C or better or PLS 162 C or better or PLS 163 C or better or PLS 130 C or better or PLS 144 C or better or PLS 147 C or better or PLS 160 C or better or ESP 121 C or better or ESP 127 C or better or ESP 155 C or better or EVE 101 C or better or EVE 104 C or better or EVE 117 C or better or EVE 119 C or better or EVE 181 C or better or PLB 117 C or better or ECL 200AN C or better or ECL 200BN C or better;  or Consent of Instructor.  or equivalent course in ecology/plant ecology.
courses.desc: Broad, interdisciplinary approach to effective restoration. Design and implementation of restoration projects based on principles of physiology, population, community, ecosystem and landscape ecology.

courses.title: Introduction to Literature
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc:
Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing
both analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.

courses.title: Introduction to Creative Writing: Fiction
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Elementary principles of writing fiction. Write both in prescribed forms and in experimental forms of their own choosing. No final examination.

courses.title: Introduction to Creative Writing: Non-Fiction
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Elementary principles of writing creative non-fiction. Work in prescribed literary forms (such as essay, meditation, biography, memoir, book review, documentary, or experimental non-fiction forms) and forms of students' choosing. No final examination.

courses.title: Introduction to Creative Writing: Poetry
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Elementary principles of writing poetry. Write both in prescribed forms and in experimental forms of their own choosing. No final examination.

courses.title: Literatures in English I: To 1700
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Historical introduction to English language and literature from 800-1700. Linguistic borrowing, innovation, and change. Emergence of key literary genres. Colonial America as a new site of English literary production and consumption.

courses.title: Literatures in English II: 1700-1900
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Historical introduction to English language and literature from 1700-1900. Linguistic borrowing, innovation, colonization, and change. Emergence and development of key literary genres. America, Britain, Ireland, Scotland, and India as important sites of English literary production and consumption.

courses.title: Literatures in English III: 1900 to Present
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Historical introduction to English language and literature from 1900-present. Linguistic borrowing, innovation, and change. Emergence and development of key literary genres. Formal experimentation. Modernism as transnational phenomenon.

courses.title: Introductory Topics in Literature
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Study of a special topic. Literature written in English in any period or place or genre.  Thematic, formal, or temporal focus.

courses.title: Introductory Topics in Literature & Media
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y);  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Study of a topic centered on the relationships between literature and moving-image media.

courses.title: Approaches to Reading
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y);  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Close reading and interpretation of literature from a variety of traditional and contemporary approaches.  Topics include traditional textual and historical approaches; new criticism; formalism; psychological criticism; feminism and gender; reader-response; materialist approaches. Frequent written assignments.

courses.title: Introductory Topics in Drama
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Close reading of, and topics relating to selected works of British and American drama from a range of historical periods.

courses.title: Introductory Topics in Fiction
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y);  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Close reading of, and topics relating to, British and American Fiction: short stories, novellas, novels.

courses.title: Introductory Topics in Poetry
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y);  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Topical study and close reading of selections from English and American poetry.

courses.title: Hot Bars, Supreme Lyrics, & Rhymes for Days: Hip Hop as Poetry
courses.desc: Literary approaches to hip hop as poetry. Formal examination of rap lyrics in relation to technology, visual expression, dance, and knowledge production. Historical and cultural consideration of race, ethnicity, gender, urban culture, and politics.

courses.title: Pop Culture Shakespeare
courses.desc: Critical approaches to the study of Shakespeare’s afterlife in contemporary American media. Focus on visual, audio, and kinesthetic modes of analysis and presentation. Relation of Shakespeare to contemporary society, politics, media, and economics.

courses.title: Youth in Revolt
courses.desc: American literary and cultural representations of adolescence as a time of rebellious refusals and wild behaviors in relation to questions of gender and sexuality, psychological states, economic pressures, racial inequality, and methods of discipline and punishment.

courses.title: Introduction to Games
courses.desc: Introduction to the history, theory, and practice of play.  Survey of both analog and digital games. Overview of gaming cultures, aesthetics, industries, and technologies.

courses.title: History of the English Language
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y);  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc:
History of the English language. Examination of the language as recorded from Old English to present-day English. Relationship of English to
other languages; development of vocabulary, phonology, and grammatical patterns.

courses.title: English Grammar
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or LIN 001 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Survey of present-day English grammar as informed by contemporary linguistic theories. The major syntactic structures of English; their variation across dialects, styles, and registers; their development; and their usefulness in describing the conventions of English.

courses.title: Freedom of Expression
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y);  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historical development of fundamental issues and contemporary controversies about freedom of expression, with emphasis on literary and artistic censorship.

courses.title: Introduction to Literary Theory
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.
courses.desc: Key theoretical terms, concepts, and thinkers from the Greeks to the modern era.

courses.title: Introduction to Modern Literary & Critical Theory
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.
courses.desc: History of literary criticism in the modern era, with emphasis on the ties with the past and the special problems presented by modern literary theory.

courses.title: Topics in Medieval Literature
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically focused intensive examination of selected topics in Medieval British literature.

courses.title: Chaucer: Troilus & the "Minor" Poems
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Development of the poet's artistry and ideas from his first work to his masterpiece, "Troilus and Criseyde."

courses.title: Chaucer: The Canterbury Tales
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Literary analysis of the complete "Canterbury Tales."  Courtly love, literary forms, medieval science and astrology, theology and dogma as they inform the reading of Chaucer's work.

courses.title: Topics in 16th- & 17th-Century Literature
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically focused study of works of the Renaissance.

courses.title: Shakespeare
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically, generically, or thematically focused study of Shakespeare's works.

courses.title: Law & Literature
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically, thematically, or generically focused study of the relationship between law and literature.

courses.title: Milton
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.
courses.desc: Selected major works, including Paradise Lost.

courses.title: 18th-Century British Literature
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically focused study of 18th-century English literature.

courses.title: Topics in Irish Literature
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Intensive study or treatment of special topics relating to the emergence, invention, and re-invention of Irish literature.

courses.title: British Romantic Literature
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically focused study of works of Romantic English literature.

courses.title: 19th-Century British Literature
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically focused study of works of 19th-century English literature.

courses.title: British Literature, 1900-1945
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically focused study of works of British literature (drama, poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1900 and the end of World War II.

courses.title: British Literature, 1945 to Present
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically focused study of works of British literature (drama, poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1945 and the present. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Topics in Global Literatures & Cultures
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.
courses.desc: Historically or regionally focused study of world literatures in English (other than the national literatures of British Isles and the United States), particularly from post-colonial regions in Africa, the Caribbean, and Asia, and immigrant cultures in the English-speaking world.

courses.title: Topics in Postcolonial Literatures & Cultures
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Study of postcolonial literature of Anglophone colonies. Specific emphases may include literature from and about Anglophone India, the Caribbean, the Middle East, South Asia, Africa, and/or South America.

courses.title: Topics in Diasporic Literatures & Migration
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Study of literatures, histories, and cultures of one or more diasporic groups.

courses.title: Early American Literature
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically focused study of American literature of the 17th and 18th centuries.

courses.title: 19th-Century American Literature to the Civil War
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically focused study of works of 19th-century American literature.

courses.title: Post-Civil War American Literature
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically focused study of works of post-Civil War American literature.

courses.title: American Literature 1900-1945
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically focused study of American literature (drama, poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1900 and the end of World War II.

courses.title: American Literature, 1945 to the Present
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically focused study of American literature (drama, poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1945 and the present.

courses.title: Topics in Literature
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.
courses.desc: Intensive examination of literature considered in topical terms, not necessarily historically. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: British Drama to 1800
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically focused study of works of English drama prior to 1800.

courses.title: Drama from 1800 to the Present
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically focused study of works of British drama from 1800 to the present.

courses.title: Topics in Drama
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.
courses.desc: Historical or thematic study of drama.

courses.title: The Graphic Novel
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or equivalent courses.
courses.desc: Thematically, historically, and formally focused study of the graphic novel genre. Contents may include any regional, national, or transnational group of graphic novels.

courses.title: 18th-Century British Novel
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically organized examination of the 18th-century British novel, with particular emphasis on its evolution, including the epistolary novel, the picaresque novel, and the Gothic novel: Richardson, Fielding, Sterne, Austen.

courses.title: 19th-Century British Novel
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically organized examination of 19th-century British novelists, with emphasis on the historical novel, the social novel, and novels by women: Scott, Dickens, the Brontes, Eliot, Hardy.

courses.title: 20th-Century British Novel
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically organized examination of the 20th-century British novel, with emphasis on impressionism; the revolt against naturalism; the experimental novel; the anti-modernist reaction: Conrad, Joyce, Woolf, Lawrence, Drabble, Rhys.

courses.title: The Short Story
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.
courses.desc: The short story as a genre; its historical development, techniques, and formal character as a literary form. European as well as American writers.

courses.title: Detective Fiction
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.
courses.desc: Historically, formally, and thematically focused study of novels and short stories in the detective fiction genre.

courses.title: The American Novel to 1900
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc:
Historically or thematically organized examination of the rise and development of the American novel from its beginnings; Hawthorne,
Melville, Twain, James, and others.

courses.title: The American Novel from 1900 to the Present
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historically or thematically organized examination of important American novelists from 1900 to the present: authors may include Willa Cather, Nathanael West, William Faulkner, Ralph Ellison, Zora Neale Hurston, Thomas Pynchon, Ishmael Reed, Maria Helena Viramontes, Rachel Kushner, and others.

courses.title: Topics in the Novel
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.
courses.desc: Examination of major novels arranged thematically. Topics might include Bildungsroman, stream-of-consciousness novel, Gothic novel, historical novel.

courses.title: Film as Narrative
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.
courses.desc: Study of modern film (1930 to present) as a storytelling medium.

courses.title: Film History I: Origins to 1945
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.
courses.desc: Cultural and aesthetic history of film making from its origins in the 1890's through 1945. ENL 161A & ENL 161B need not be taken in sequence.

courses.title: Film History II: 1945 to present
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.
courses.desc: Cultural and aesthetic history of film making from its origins in the 1890's through 1945. ENL 161A & ENL 161B need not be taken in sequence.

courses.title: Film Theory & Criticism
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.
courses.desc: Film theory and criticism, with a study of ten major works of international film art.

courses.title: Literary Study in the British Isles
courses.prereqs: ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.
courses.desc: Literary Study in the British Isles: On-site study of the literature, film, and/or performance of the British Isles. Taught abroad.

courses.title: Writing Science
