courses.desc: Rise of the U.S. to superpower standing during the 20th century, from colonialism to the war on terror, including political, diplomatic, cultural, and economic activities of both US government and private American agencies beyond U.S. borders.

courses.title: America in the 1960s
courses.desc: Tumult and upheaval in American politics, culture, and society 1961-1969. Civil rights; Vietnam, the draft and the anti-war movement; rock and roll and the counterculture; modern feminism; modern conservatism; student movements; urban unrest and insurrection.

courses.title: California History
courses.desc: California history from the pre-colonial period to the present including dispossession of California's Indians, political economy of the Spanish and Mexican periods, Gold Rush effects, industrialization, Hollywood, water politics, World War II, Proposition 13, and the emergence of Silicon Valley.

courses.title: Middle Eastern History I: The Rise of Islam, 600-1000
courses.desc: Middle Eastern history from the rise of Islam to the disintegration of the Abbasid Caliphate; the formative centuries of a civilization. Politics and religion, conquest and conversion, arts and sciences, Christians, Jews and Muslims, gender and sexuality, orthodoxy and heterodoxy.

courses.title: Middle Eastern History II: The Age of the Crusades, 1001-1400
courses.desc: Middle Eastern history during the age of the Crusades and Mongol invasions. The idea of holy war, the Crusades, the Mongols as the bearers of Chinese arts, nomads and sedentary life, feudalism, mysticism, slavery, women in the medieval Middle East.

courses.title: Middle Eastern History III: The Ottomans, 1401-1730
courses.desc: Middle Eastern history from the foundation of the Ottoman Empire on the borderlands of Byzantine Anatolia through its expansion into Europe, Asia, and Africa, creating a new cultural synthesis including the Arab, Greek, Islamic, Mongol, Persian, Slavic, and Turkish traditions.

courses.title: Middle Eastern History IV: Safavids Iran, 1300-1720
courses.desc: Middle Eastern history focusing on Safavid Empire (present-day Iran, Iraq, Afghanistan, up to Georgia), beginning with the origins of the dynasty as a powerful religious family, to the establishment of the Empire, focusing on Social, Religious, Economic, and Political History.

courses.title: Classical China
courses.desc:
History of Chinese civilization from its origins through the establishment of city states and the flowering of classical philosophy,
to the rise and fall of the First Empire.

courses.title: High Imperial China
courses.desc: Political disunion and the influx of Buddhism; reunification under the great dynasties of T'ang, Sung, and Ming with analysis of society, culture and thought.

courses.title: Late Imperial China
courses.prereqs: HIS 009A or upper division standing recommended.
courses.desc: Patterns and problems of Chinese life traced through the Ming and Ching dynasties (c.15001800), prior to the confrontation with the West in the Opium War. Readings include primary sources and novels portraying elite ethos as well as popular culture.

courses.title: 19th-Century China: The Empire Confronts the West
courses.prereqs: HIS 009A or upper division standing recommended.
courses.desc: Decline and fall of the Chinese Empire, with particular attention to the social and political crises of the 19th century, and the response of government officials, intellectuals, and ordinary people to the increasing pressures of Western imperialism.

courses.title: The Chinese Revolution
courses.desc: Analysis of China's cultural and political transformation from Confucian empire into Communist state. Emphasis on emergence and triumph of peasant revolutionary strategy (to 1949), with some attention to its implications for post-revolutionary culture and politics.

courses.title: History of the People's Republic of China
courses.desc: Comprehensive analysis of recent Chinese history, including land reform, the Cultural Revolution, the post-Mao era, and the consequences of the new economic policies of the 1980s.

courses.title: Special Topics in Chinese History to 1800
courses.desc: Topics in the history of China from the beginning of the imperial period through the high Qing dynasty.  Topics may be framed chronologically (e.g.,the Ming Dynasty) or thematically (e.g., Trade in early Chinese history).

courses.title: Special Topics in Chinese History after 1800
courses.desc: Topics in the history of China since 1800.  Topics may be framed chronologically (e.g., The Republican Period (1911-1948)) or thematically (e.g., The Modern Evolution of Chinese Law).

courses.title: Sex & Society in Modern Chinese History
courses.desc: Role of sex, gender, and family relations in the development of Chinese politics, society, and personal life in the modern period, 1900-present.

courses.title: History of the Modern Middle East, 1750-1914
courses.desc: State and society within the Middle East from 1750 to 1914 under pressure of the changing world economy and European imperialism. Themes: colonialism, Orientalism, intellectual renaissance, Islamic reform, state-formation, role of subaltern groups.

courses.title: History of the Modern Middle East, From 1914
courses.desc: Middle East from the turn of the 20th century to the present. Themes include the legacy of imperialism, cultural renaissance, the World Wars, nationalism, Palestine/Israel, Islamic revival, gender, revolutionary movements, politics of oil and war, cultural modernism,exile and diaspora.

courses.title: The Middle East Environment: Historical Change & Current Challenges
courses.desc: Examines Middle East environment and human use of nature over last 10,000 years. Introduction to desert ecology, environmental history and current environmental problems. Case Studies of Egypt, Maghreb countries, Arabian peninsula/Gulf countries, desertification, water, indigenous knowledge, and national parks.

courses.title: History of Modern Iran, From 1850 to Present
courses.desc: Modern Iran from the mid 19th century to the present. Themes include the legacy of imperialism, cultural renaissance, the World Wars, nationalism, modernization, Islamic revival, gender, revolutionary movements, politics of oil and war.

courses.title: Aristocratic & Feudal Japan
courses.desc: Broad survey of the cultural, social, religious, and political aspects of Japanese history from mythological times through the 16th century emphasizing comparison of the organizations, values, and beliefs associated with the aristocratic and feudal periods.

courses.title: Early Modern Japan
courses.desc: Survey of the cultural, social, economic,and political aspects of Japanese history from the 17th through the 19th centuries emphasizing the development of those patterns of thought and political organization with which Japan met the challenge of the nineteenth-century Western expansionism.

courses.title: Modern Japan
courses.desc: Survey of the cultural, social, economic, and political aspects of Japanese history in the 20th century emphasizing labor and social movements, militarism and the Pacific war, and the emergence of Japan as a major economic power.

courses.title: Business & Labor in Modern Japan
courses.desc: Survey of labor and management relations in Japan from the mid-18th century to the present.

courses.title: Education & Technology in Modern Japan
courses.desc: Survey of education and technology in Japan from the mid-18th century to the present.

courses.title: History of Modern Korea
courses.desc: History of Modern Korea, from Yi dynasty period to 1990s. Covers the political and socioeconomic changes in 19th century, modernization under Japanese colonialism, postwar economic growth and effects of the Cold War.

courses.title: A History of Vietnam
courses.desc: Overview of Vietnamese history: early state formation in Southeast Asia; expansion/contention in the 17th and 18th centuries; colonial period; war with the US; and post-war developments (with an emphasis on relations with China and the US).

courses.title: Medieval India
courses.desc: Survey of history of India in the millennium preceding arrival of British in the 18th century, focusing on interaction of the civilizations of Hinduism and Islam and on the changing nature of the state.

courses.title: Modern India
courses.desc: Survey of cultural, social, economic, and political aspects of South Asian history from arrival of the British in the 18th century to formation of new independent states-India, Bangladesh, and Pakistan in the 20th century.

courses.title: Human Wrongs/Human Rights
courses.desc: Introduction to Human Rights and the problems they seek to address. Using key episodes of inhumanity like slavery, genocide, and racism. Examines how international movements for social justice led to the emergence of the international Human Rights system.

courses.title: Art, Architecture, & Human Rights
courses.desc: Study of human rights as they relate to art, architecture, and cultural heritage. Examines museums, art collections, and cultural-heritage management, their relation to the cultural prerogatives of communities and indigenous groups, and protection of cultural heritage during war and conflict.

courses.title: Special Topics in Human Rights
courses.desc: Thematic study of human rights. Topics may include contemporary or historical issues in the promotion, protection, and violation of human rights; human rights and the arts, religion, literature are possible topical areas.

courses.title: Genocide
courses.desc: Comparative and critical study of the modern phenomenon of genocide from religious, ethical and historical perspectives.

courses.title: Human Rights
courses.desc: Introduction to the interdisciplinary study of the origins, evolution, denial and protection of Human Rights.

courses.title: Human Rights in the Middle East
courses.desc: Study of the experience of Human Rights in the modern Middle East, with special attention to the Human Rights issues raised by events of Arab Spring; Palestine-Israel conflict; history of genocide, mass killing and totalitarianism in the region.

courses.title: Human Rights, Gender, & Sexuality
courses.desc: Gender and sexuality in the context of human rights. Topics include women's participation in the public sphere, the right to change gender, the right for family privacy, and the right to marriage.

courses.title: Human Rights & the Popular Imagination
courses.desc: Arts, music, literature, film and television in the rise of human rights movements and the protection, promotion and violation of human rights. Topics may include: human rights & science fiction; human rights & the graphic novel; human rights & contemporary cinema; human rights & rock and roll.

courses.title: Art & Politics of Memory: Truth, Justice, Reconciliation & Human Rights
courses.desc: Critical exploration of the role of art and memory in the dictatorships, authoritarian societies, civil conflicts, and genocides of the late 20th and early 21st centuries. Case studies focus on the violation of massive human rights and political and cultural conflict for truth, justice, and reconciliation in the aftermath of those violations. Emphasis on how memory is constructed and contested by states, artitists, writers, historians and different ethnic and political communities.

courses.title: The Art & Politics of Memory in Latin America: Truth, Justice, & Reconciliation
courses.desc: Critical analysis of the dictatorships and civil conflicts that took place in Cold War Latin America. Case studies focus on the violation of human rights as well as on the political and cultural battles for truth, justice, and reconciliation that take place in the aftermath of those violations. Emphasis on how memory is constructed, in what forms, by whom, and for what purposes.

courses.title: Human Rights in Latin America
courses.desc: History of the origins, denial and protection of Human Rights in Latin America. Emphasis on dictatorships, political violence, social resistance, democracy, justice, accountability, truth commissions, memory.

courses.title: The History of Human Rights in Europe
courses.desc: History of the origins, development, and state of international humanitarian law (IHL) and international human rights law (IHRL) in Europe. Emphasis on Enlightenment-era and modern theories of the source, utility, and limits of human rights.

courses.title: Oncology
courses.prereqs: Approval by the SOM Committee on Student Promotions.
courses.desc: Covers the principles of oncology and the pathophysiology of specific, common cancers correlated with organ systems pathophysiology and systemic pathology courses.

courses.title: Cannabis & Cannabinoids in Physiology & Medicine
courses.prereqs: NPB 100 or NPB 101 or NPB 110B;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: In-depth scientific analysis of cannabis and cannabinoids, topics include biochemical, physiological, behavioral, pharmacological, social and therapeutic aspects of cannabinoids, with emphasis on the physiological impacts on major organ systems in humans and animals, and the potential medicinal uses.

courses.title: Advanced Physiology of Animal/Human Disease
courses.prereqs: NPB 101 B+ or better or NPB 110C B+ or better;  Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Centers on fundamental mechanisms and pathophysiological basis for animal and human diseases. Case-based and uses animal and human diseases to help exemplify the physiological consequences of organ dysfunction.

courses.title: Advanced Physiology
courses.prereqs: Physiology Ph.D. program or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Advanced course on fundamental principles of cell physiology, transport physiology, signal transduction, physiology of excitable cells, and muscle physiology.

courses.title: Advances in Computational Physiology & Pharmacology
courses.prereqs: No formal requirements; basic knowledge of mathematics, physics, chemistry, and biology helpful.
courses.desc: Multi-scale biomedical modeling methodologies and applications, with emphasis on ion channel structure-function, computer-aided drug design, and membrane excitability. State-of-the-art techniques used for multi-scale modeling of biomedical systems and their applications.

courses.title: Human Physiology
courses.desc: General and cellular physiology of neurons, muscle, and epithelial cells and systemic physiology of cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, and renal systems.

courses.title: Medical Neuroanatomy
courses.desc: Anatomy of the normal human nervous system, to include gross external and internal morphology of brain and spinal cord, and function neuroanatomy of motor, sensory and cognitive systems. Incorporates application of neuroanatomy to clinical problem solving.

courses.title: Cannabis & Cannabinoids in Physiology & Medicine
courses.desc: Provides an in-depth scientific analysis of current knowledge on cannabis and cannabinoids pertaining to human physiology and potential medicinal uses.

courses.title: Physiological Principles in SICU SSM
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Restricted to UC Davis School of Medicine students only.
courses.desc: Special Study Module, a four-week course on the topic: Care of the Critically Ill Surgical Patient: Use of Physiological Principles to Guide Treatment of Patients with Common Surgical Problems.

courses.title: Horticulture & Agronomy: Principles
courses.desc: Core course to introduce students to the principles that are of general importance in horticultural and agronomic research, including agroecology, plant developmental physiology, crop improvement, and biotechnology. Generally taken in the first year of the graduate program.

courses.title: Horticulture & Agronomy: Practices
courses.desc: Introduction to horticultural and agronomic cropping systems.  Covers current applied research within agroecology, crop improvement, crop production, postharvest biology.

courses.title: Research Perspectives in Horticulture
courses.desc: Following lectures/discussions of scientific methodology, students develop research proposals aided by classroom discussions and individual interactions with instructors. Lectures and critiques of classical papers provide a sense of the evolution of the current concepts in perennial plant biology.

courses.title: Modeling Horticultural Systems
courses.prereqs: PLS 142;  or Consent of Instructor.  Calculus.
courses.desc: Development and application of models.  Emphasis on physiological and ecological models, with examples from areas of interest to class participants.  Applications to horticultural systems.

courses.title: Humanities Forum
courses.desc: Reading and discussion of a single work representative of a particular culture, historical period, or genre and significant for its ongoing cultural impact in the humanities, sciences, social sciences, technology, and popular arenas. Attention to provocative implications for contemporary society.

courses.title: Global Humanities Forum
courses.desc: Introduction to humanities topics and methodologies; analysis of major figures, works, and genres in world arts and literatures, with emphasis on relationships between history, society, and culture.

courses.title: American Humanities Forum
courses.desc: Introduction to humanities topics and methodologies; analysis of major figures, works, and genres in American arts and literatures, with emphasis on relationships between history, society, and culture.

courses.title: Medicine & Humanities
courses.prereqs: Satisfaction of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Evolution of the "medical arts" into the "science of medicine." Culture of medicine in the context of society, medical ethics.

courses.title: Animals & Human Culture
courses.desc: Meaning of human relations with animals studied across a variety of historical periods and cultures and from a variety of humanistic perspectives.

courses.title: Travel & Travel Literature
courses.prereqs: Satisfaction of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: History of travel from the age of exploration to the modern era. Contemporary trends in travel, including mas tourism, adventure travel, and ecotravel.  Social, economic, and cultural issues related to modern trends in travel. Analysis of literary representations of travel.

courses.title: Introduction to Perspectives on Narrative
courses.prereqs: Satisfaction of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary approach to the use of story across time, culture, and discipline. How the telling and retelling of particular stories reflect the values, concerns, and assumptions of their original audiences and genres.

courses.title: Don Quixote & the Modern World
courses.desc: Reading Don Quixote as emblem of modernity in the West. Issues of reality versus illusion, heroism, freedom and self-fulfillment, racial tolerance and love. Don Quixote in other cultural and popular media: film, dance, art, musical drama, and television. GE credit with concurrent enrollment in HUM 009D: ArtHum, Wrt.

courses.title: How to be a Critic: Understanding Cultural Products & Practices
courses.desc: Introduction to key topics and methodologies of interest to humanists. Series uses a variety of critical approaches to examine the cultural significance of subjects such as: fashion, film, architecture, music, food, dance.

courses.title: Witches: Myth & Historical Reality
courses.desc: Examines the historical construction of the witch. Four areas covered are: European pagan religions and the spread of Christianity; the "Burning' Times" in early modern Europe; 17th-century New England and the Salem witch trials; and fairy tales.

courses.title: Language & Identity
courses.desc: Introduction to topics related to the construction of identity through language use, including geographical and social factors affecting language groups. Language ideology affecting linguistic groups, including bilinguals and non-native speakers of English.

courses.title: Narrative & Argumentative Approaches to Major Current Issues in the Media, Culture, & Society
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary approach to contemporary issues (abortion, AIDS, civil rights, war and peace, welfare state) around which individuals, communities and institutions define themselves in American society, by applying principles of narrative theory to the narratives where those issues are embedded.

courses.title: Marx, Nietzsche, Freud
courses.desc: Study of major texts of Marx, Nietzsche, and Freud, selected with an eye to their impact on 20th-century economics, ethics, and attitudes toward eros. Particular focus on conceptions of the self and the individual's relation to society.

courses.title: Topics in the Humanities
courses.desc: Analysis of interdisciplinary issues in the Humanities. Topics vary. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Graduate Internship
courses.desc: Individually designed supervised internship, off campus, in community or institutional setting.  Developed with advice of faculty mentor.

courses.title: Water, Power, Society
courses.desc: Water resources issues. How water has been used to gain and wield socio-political power. Water resources development in California as related to current and future sustainability of water quantity and quality. Roles of science and policy in solving water problems.

courses.title: Fluid Mechanics Fundamentals
courses.desc: Fluid mechanics axioms, fluid statics, kinematics, velocity fields for one-dimensional incompressible flow and boundary layers, turbulent flow time averaging, potential flow, dimensional analysis, and macroscopic balances to solve a range of practical problems.

courses.title: Irrigation Principles & Practices
courses.desc: General course for agricultural and engineering students dealing with soil and plant aspects of irrigation and drainage. Soil-water principles including water movement, plant responses to irrigation regimes, water use by crops; also irrigation systems and water quality.

courses.title: Irrigation Systems & Water Management
courses.desc: Soil and plant aspects of irrigation and drainage. Soil-water principles including water storage and movement, plant response to irrigation, water use by crops, irrigation systems (i.e., micro-irrigation, sprinkler irrigation and surface irrigation), and related salinity and water quality impacts.

courses.title: Evapotranspiration Principles, Measurement & Modeling
courses.prereqs: HYD 124 C or better;  Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Estimation of evapotranspiration (ET) for irrigation management and water resources planning; including the basic principles and key factors controlling evaporation and ET rates, methods of measuring these factors in the field and remotely, and determination of likely water requirements for crops and various landscape conditions as needed for water resources planning.

courses.title: Evapotranspiration Principles, Measurement & Modeling
courses.prereqs: HYD 124 C or better;  Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Estimation of evapotranspiration (ET) for irrigation management and water resources planning; including the basic principles and key factors controlling evaporation and ET rates, methods of measuring these factors in the field and remotely, and determination of likely water requirements for crops and various landscape conditions as needed for water resources planning.

courses.title: Plant-Water-Soil Relationships
courses.prereqs: (SSC 100 (can be concurrent) or SSC 107 (can be concurrent));  (PLS 100A (can be concurrent) or PLB 111 (can be concurrent));  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Principles of plant interactions with soil and atmospheric water environments and practical applications to crop management (e.g., irrigation) and plant eco-physiology (e.g., drought).

courses.title: Aqueous Geochemistry
courses.desc: Chemistry of natural waters; dielectric properties of water; thermodynamic and mass-action relations; metal hydrolysis; acid-base equilibria; metal-coordination chemistry; solubility calculations; electron-exchange reactions; sorptive partitioning; ion exchange; and dissolved organic matter.

courses.title: Physical Hydrology
courses.desc: Introduction to the processes that constitute the hydrologic cycle. Special emphasis on a quantitative description of the following processes: precipitation, infiltration, evaporation, transpiration, surface runoff, and groundwater runoff.

courses.title: Systems Hydrology
courses.desc: General course considering hydrologic processes from a systems or statistical model perspective. General probability concepts are applied to frequency, time series and spatial data analysis. Linear systems are also considered in conjunction with Kalman filter techniques.

courses.title: Ecohydrology
courses.prereqs: HYD 010 or HYD 141 or ESP 001 or ESM 100 or ESM 108 or ESM 120 or GEL 001 or GEL 050 or SSC 100;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Movement and storage of water in individual ecosystems and the integrated functioning of water and biota at the watershed scale.

courses.title: Groundwater Hydrology
courses.prereqs: MAT 016B or MAT 021A;  HYD 103 or ENG 103 recommended.
courses.desc: Fundamentals of groundwater flow and contaminant hydrology. Occurrence, distribution, and movement of groundwater. Well-flow systems. Aquifer tests. Well construction operation and maintenance. Groundwater exploration and quality assessment. Agricultural threats to groundwater quality: fertilizers, pesticides, salts.

courses.title: Water Science & Design
courses.prereqs: (HYD 141 or ESM 100);  (MAT 016B or MAT 021B);  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Introduction to watershed engineering, storm water management, design of hydraulic systems. Topics include hydrological risk analysis, flood routing, design storms, open channel flow, pipes, culverts, spillways, and detention basins. Class project and field trips will apply theory to real-life problems.

courses.title: Hydrogeology & Contaminant Transport
courses.prereqs: HYD 144 or ECI 144;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Physical and chemical processes affecting groundwater flow and contaminant transport, with emphasis on realistic hydrogeologic systems. Groundwater geology and chemistry. Fundamentals of groundwater flow and transport analysis. Laboratory includes field pumping test and work with physical and computer models.

courses.title: Runoff, Erosion & Water Quality Management
courses.prereqs: (PHY 007B or PHY 009B);  (MAT 016C or MAT 017C or MAT 021C);  (ECI 142 or HYD 141 or ESM 100);  or equivalent.
courses.desc: Practical hydrology and runoff water quality management from disturbed watersheds. Development of hillslope and soils restoration concepts and practice, modeling and application.

courses.title: Water Law
courses.prereqs: Consent of instructor or upper division standing.
courses.desc: Principles and issues of California Water Law.Types of water rights, groundwater rights and management, and protection of instream uses.Water projects, role of federal government and federal/state relations. Basic water quality acts, endangered species act, water transfers and current water issues.

courses.title: Field Methods in Hydrology
courses.desc: Measurement methods and data analysis for evaluation of water storage, movement and contamination in the field.  Equipment such as data loggers, water and sediment samplers, pressure transducers, weather stations, surveying equipment, and flow meters will be used.

courses.title: Environmental Analysis using GIS
courses.prereqs: ABT 150 or LDA 150;  Or equivalent GIS experience and skills; general biology and/or ecology courses are recommended.
courses.desc: Ecosystem and landscape modeling with emphasis on hydrology and solute transport. Spatial analysis of environmental risk analysis including ecological risk assessment, natural resource management. Spatial database structures, scripting, data models, and error analysis in GIS.

courses.title: Hydrologic Sciences Core Survey
courses.desc: Considers the primary sub-disciplines while reviewing the fundamental scientific concepts/processes of the hydrologic sciences research community, and includes a basic writing component.

courses.title: Vadose Modeling & Characterization
courses.desc: Principles and modeling of water flow and chemical transport in the vadose zone, with specific applications to soils. Topics include hydraulic properties, finite difference application to unsaturated water flow, parameter optimization, diffusive and convective transport in gaseous and liquid phases.

courses.title: Precision Irrigation Systems & Management
courses.desc: Advanced irrigation science and engineering for agricultural, horticultural, engineering, and hydrology graduate students. Precision irrigation techniques for application of water to meet specific requirements of individual plants or management units and maximum economic benefits of crop production.

courses.title: Hydrology & Sustainability of Irrigated Lands
courses.prereqs: ABT 110 or ESM 110 or HYD 110 or EBS 145.
courses.desc: Impact of irrigated agricultural on groundwater depletion, surface water and groundwater quality, soil salinization, downstream ecosystems, and seawater intrusion. Exploration of efficient resource use, and policies adopted in California to enhance sustainability of irrigated crop production.

courses.title: Water Resource Planning & Management
courses.desc: Applications of deterministic and stochastic mathematical programming techniques to water resource planning, analysis, design and management. Water allocation, capacity expansion, and reservoir operation. Conjunctive use of surface water and groundwater. Water quality management. Irrigation planning and operation models.

courses.title: Climate Change, Water & Society
courses.desc: Integration of climate science and hydrology with policy to understand hydroclimatology and its impact upon natural and human systems. Assignments: readings, take-home examination on climate and hydrologic science, paper that integrates course concepts into a research prospectus or review article.

courses.title: Hillslope Geomorphology & Sediment Budgets
courses.prereqs: HYD 141 or GEL 035 or ECI 142;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Exploration of theoretical and empirical foundations of sediment production on hillslopes using computer models and field experiments to promote an understanding of how watersheds evolve naturally and with human impacts.

courses.title: Geomorphology of Estuaries & Deltas
courses.prereqs: HYD 141 or GEL 035;  or ECI 042 or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Survey of the processes and landforms associated with sediment deposition in the coastal zone. Application of geomorphic principles to coastal management issues.

courses.title: Modeling of Hydrologic Processes
courses.desc: Techniques used to model the spatio-temporal structure of rainfall and runoff are introduced. Procedures studied include those based on stochastic point processes, chaos theory, fractal geometry, and fractional noises.

courses.title: Numerical Modeling of Groundwater Systems
courses.desc: Finite difference and finite element techniques in modeling groundwater flow and transport. Fundamentals of constructing and calibrating models with hands-on applications. Methods and limitations of numerical solution of transport equations. Model interpretation and ethics.

courses.title: Introduction to Geostatistics
courses.desc: Statistical treatment of spatial data with hydrologic emphasis. Topics: theory of random functions, variogram analysis, Kriging/co-Kriging, indicator geostatistics, and stochastic simulation of spatial variability. Geostatistical software use.

courses.title: Practice of Groundwater Flow & Transport Modeling
courses.desc: Selecting and building groundwater flow and transport models. Planning, preparation, execution, presentation, and review of modeling projects. Review of methods, assumptions, and limitations of groundwater models; practicing with MODFLOW, MT3D, associated GUI, and with other groundwater modeling software of choice.

courses.title: Analysis of Spatial Processes
courses.prereqs: STA 102;  Or the equivalent; HYD 273 or STA 273A recommended.
courses.desc:
Characterization of homogeneous random fields; extremes and spectral parameters; geometry of excursions, local averaging; scale of fluctuation; non-Gaussian and irregular random fields; geostatistical
applications.

courses.title: Hazardous Waste Operations Training
courses.prereqs: Upper division standing in College of Agricultural and Environmental Sciences.
courses.desc:
Forty-hour course designed to meet the requirements of Federal OSHA
regulation CFR 1910.120. Covers the health, regulatory, processing and safe handling issues/problems associated with working with hazardous
materials.

courses.title: Introduction to International Agricultural Development
courses.desc: Theories, practices and institutions relating to agricultural development; the interaction of changing social, cultural and economic organization through successive stages of economic development; impact of new agricultural technology on underdeveloped regions.

courses.title: Social Change & Agricultural Development
courses.prereqs: Introductory social science course (Anthropology (ANT), Sociology (SOC), Economics (ECN), International Agricultural Development (IAD)).
courses.desc: How social and cultural factors influence technological change in agriculture; theories of diffusion of innovations; social impact analysis and technology assessment.

courses.title: Equipment & Technology for Small Farms
courses.desc: Types and characteristics of agricultural equipment and technologies appropriate for small commercial farming. Adjustment and calibration of equipment. Selection of and budgeting for equipment.

courses.title: Agroforestry: Global & Local Perspectives
courses.prereqs: PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C;  (PLS 142 or PLS 150 or BIS 002B);  Or general ecology course in lieu of PLS 142 or PLS 150 or BIS 002B.
courses.desc: Traditional and evolving use of trees in agricultural ecosystems; their multiple roles in environmental stabilization and production of food, fuel, and fiber; and socioeconomic barriers to the adoption and implementation of agroforestry practices.

courses.title: Program Development for International Agriculture
courses.desc: Principles of leadership and management for international agricultural development. Organizations and organizational behavior, and the implications for planning and administering organizations involved in the global development effort.

courses.title: Philosophy & Practice of Agricultural Development
courses.desc: Introduces key elements of philosophy and practice of agricultural development in less developed countries; major paradigms of development; historical context within which these paradigms operate; various development techniques and initiatives emerging from agricultural production to institutional capacity building and management.

courses.title: Economics of Small Farms & Farming Systems
courses.prereqs: ARE 100A or ECN 100;  or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Economic perspective on small farm development. Establishes a basis for predicting farmers' responses to changes in the economic environment, and for proposing government policies to increase small farm production and improve farmer and national welfare.

courses.title: Analysis & Determinants of Farming Systems
courses.prereqs: PLS 110C or PLS 111;  or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Unifying concepts of cropping systems in temperate and tropical climatic zones; agroecosystems stability, diversity and sustainability; management strategies, resource use efficiency and their interactions; role of animals, their impact on energy use efficiency, nutrient cycling, and providing food and power.

courses.title: Topics in International Agricultural Development
courses.desc: Selected topics dealing with current issues in agricultural development in lesser developed nations. Variable content.

courses.title: Orientation in United States Law
courses.desc: Investigation of the Common Law System of the United States. Includes structure of the U.S. government, Constitutional law, contracts, torts, real property, consumer law, securities law, intellectual property, antitrust, taxation, labor law, environmental law, ethics, remedies, legal research and trial practice.

courses.title: Fundamentals in United States Law
courses.desc: Investigation of the Common Law System of the U.S. Includes the American constitutional system, the American judiciary, the American civil trial, and foundational substantive and procedural law such as real property, torts, criminal law and procedure, civil procedure, and contracts.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in United States Law
courses.desc: Orientation to advanced topics in U.S. law: Intellectual Property (including copyright and trademarks), Commercial and Consumer Law, Advanced Contracts, Antitrust, Taxation, Remedies, Labor Law, Environmental Law, Dispute Resolution, Remedies and introduction to trial techniques and legal research/writing.

courses.title: Introduction to Contracts
courses.desc: Examines sorts of promises that are enforced and the nature of protection given promissory obligations in both commercial and noncommercial transactions. Inquiry is made into the means by which traditional doctrine adjusts to changing social demands.

courses.title: Introduction to Contracts Formation
courses.desc: Examines formation of the sorts of promises that are enforced and the nature of protection given promissory obligations in both commercial and noncommercial transactions. Inquiry is made into the means by which traditional doctrine adjusts to changing social demands.

courses.title: Introduction to Contracts Formation
courses.desc: Examines formation of the sorts of promises that are enforced and the nature of protection given promissory obligations in both commercial and noncommercial transactions. Inquiry is made into the means by which traditional doctrine adjusts to changing social demands.

courses.title: Contracts Performance
courses.desc: Examines issues of performing promises that are enforceable and possible breach of promissory obligations in both commercial and noncommercial transactions. Inquiry is made into the means by which traditional doctrine adjusts to changing social demands.

courses.title: Contract Performance
courses.prereqs: ICL 202A;  Or equivalent; Law school education or equivalent.
courses.desc: Examines issues of performing promises that are enforceable and possible breach of promissory obligations in both commercial and noncommercial transactions. Inquiry is made into the means by which traditional doctrine adjusts to changing social demands.

courses.title: Civil Procedure
courses.desc: Study of the fundamental and recurrent problems in civil actions including the methods used by federal and state courts to resolve civil disputes.

courses.title: International Joint Ventures
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or equivalent.
courses.desc: International and U.S. business and legal transactions. Legal planning, problem solving, decision making and negotiations related to the break-up and dissolution of a major international joint venture. U.S. laws including finance, tax, bankruptcy, labor, antitrust, environmental, corporate structures and intellectual property. Offered every three years.

courses.title: Introduction to Constitutional Law
courses.desc: Principles, doctrines and controversies regarding the structure and division of powers in American government. Includes judicial review, jurisdiction, standing to sue, federalism, federal and state powers and immunities, and the separation of powers among branches of the federal government.

courses.title: Overview of US Constitutional Law
courses.desc: Principles, doctrines and controversies regarding the structure and division of powers in American government. Includes judicial review, jurisdiction, standing to sue, federalism, federal and state powers and immunities, and the separation of powers among branches of the federal government.

courses.title: Overview of US Constitutional Law
courses.desc: Principles, doctrines and controversies regarding the structure and division of powers in American government. Includes judicial review, jurisdiction, standing to sue, federalism, federal and state powers and immunities, and the separation of powers among branches of the federal government.

courses.title: Constitutional Law–Protection of Individual Rights
courses.desc: Principles, doctrines and controversies regarding the U.S. Constitution Bill of Rights, including due process of law, equal protection, freedom of expression, freedom of religion, state action, and congressional legislation in aid of civil rights and liberties.

courses.title: Negotiations & Alternative Dispute Resolution
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Mechanisms for resolving disputes including the alternatives to litigation such as negotiation, mediation, and arbitration. Advantages and disadvantages of each approach. Offered every three years.

courses.title: Introduction to Negotiation
courses.desc: Introduction to theoretical and empirical approaches to negotiation for the purposes of making deals and resolving legal disputes.

courses.title: Introduction to Negotiation
courses.desc: Introduction to theoretical and empirical approaches to negotiation for the purposes of making deals and resolving legal disputes.

courses.title: Advanced Negotiation
courses.desc: Principles and empirical approaches to advanced negotiations including negotiation framework, models, styles, multiple party/issue negotiations and settlements.

courses.title: Advanced Negotiation
courses.desc: Principles and empirical approaches to advanced negotiations including negotiation framework, models, styles, multiple party/issue negotiations and settlements.

courses.title: Business Associations
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Legal rules and concepts applicable to business associations including general partnerships, joint ventures, limited partnerships, limited liability entities, and sole proprietorships.

courses.title: Business Associations
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Legal rules and concepts applicable to business associations including general partnerships, joint ventures, limited partnerships, limited liability entities, and sole proprietorships.

courses.title: International Business Transactions
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Legal problems arising from international business transactions. Focus on international sales contracts, choice of law, forum selection clauses, letters of credit, transfers of technology, regulation of bribery, development of joint ventures, repatriation of profits, foreign exchange problems, and national efforts to control imports.

courses.title: Alternative Dispute Resolution
courses.desc: Introduces students to a wide variety of alternative dispute resolution procedures, with an in-depth emphasis on negotiation, mediation and arbitration.

courses.title: United States Taxation of Multinational Investments
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or the equivalent.
courses.desc: An analysis of the United States taxation of multinational investments including jurisdiction of tax, the U.S. tax system, foreign tax credits, treaties, and transfer pricing.

courses.title: Criminal Procedure
courses.desc: Federal constitutional limits on government authority to gather evidence and investigate crime. Includes Fourth Amendment limits on search, seizure, and arrest; Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination; Sixth Amendment right to counsel.

courses.title: Mergers & Acquisitions Law
courses.desc: Practical approach to mergers and acquisitions with an in-depth look at the planning, negotiation and completion of mergers and acquisitions.

courses.title: Mergers & Acquisitions Law
courses.desc: Practical approach to mergers and acquisitions with an in-depth look at the planning, negotiation and completion of mergers and acquisitions.

courses.title: United States Securities Law & Regulation
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Structural and jurisdictional issues associated with securities practice. Topics include the regulation of public offerings, transactions by corporate insiders, regulation of corporate disclosure and conduct, and the liabilities of corporations and individuals under anti-fraud provisions.

courses.title: Mediation
courses.desc: Introduction to the mediation process. Development of communication skills, the ability to analyze disputes, to understand why mediations succeed or fail, and understand the advantages and limitations of mediation as a method of resolving disputes.

courses.title: Private International Law
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Operating law across national borders; emphasis on methods of resolving international disputes. International aspects of jurisdiction, choice of law, judgment enforcement, forum choice, process service, taking of evidence, foreign sovereign immunity, extraterritorial regulation of antitrust, securities; other national laws.

courses.title: Private International Law
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Operating law across national borders; emphasis on methods of resolving international disputes. International aspects of jurisdiction, choice of law, judgment enforcement, forum choice, process service, taking of evidence, foreign sovereign immunity, extraterritorial regulation of antitrust, securities; other national laws.

courses.title: Banking Law
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Institutional features of international banking transactions, the structure of a large financial deal, and the mechanics of overseeing large loans. Emphasis on negotiable instruments such as bills of lading, letters of credit, standby letters of credit, and interbank transactions. Offered every three years.

courses.title: Comparative Law
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or the equivalent.
courses.desc: A comparative study of the development of schools of legal thought, chiefly Common law systems and Civil law traditions. Attention to the historical reasons for their divergence, contemporary aproaches to universal problems such as succession, torts, and contracts, the cross-fertilization of laws and difficulties commonly associated with importing foreign law into new territory.

courses.title: International Trade Law
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or the equivalent.
courses.desc: An investigation of global trading systems including international trade in goods and services, e-commerce, international intellectual property, international tax planning and investment. Includes substantive and procedural provisions of the World Trade Organization (WTO) and the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). Offered every three years.

courses.title: United States Litigation Issues
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Prevention and resolution of disputes in international commerce. Emphasis on preparing for a trial in the United States. Includes the study of pre-trial motions, jury selection, opening statements, rules of evidence, closing arguments, and the selection of appropriate strategies. Offered every three years.

courses.title: Antitrust
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Historical and institutional background of Antitrust law in the United States. The statutory framework including price fixing, limits on distribution, monopolization and mergers, and reporting requirements.

courses.title: Financing International Transactions
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or the equivalent.
courses.desc: How capital is raised in international markets. Investment strategies for U.S. markets. Taxation of financial investments, international currency regulation, and assessing rates of return on international investments. Offered every three years.

courses.title: Intellectual Property
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Intensive study of intellectual property law. Including copyright, trademark and patent law and unfair competition.

courses.title: Intellectual Property
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law school education or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Intensive study of intellectual property law. Including copyright, trademark and patent law and unfair competition.

courses.title: Contract Remedies
courses.desc: Covers a range of remedies for contract breach: remedies under common law and equity, liquidated damages clauses, remedies for mistake and unconscionability as well as breach of contract for the Sale of Goods under UCC Article II.

courses.title: Environmental Law
courses.desc: Introduction to federal and state environmental law. Historical development of environmental law; the role of courts, the legislature and the executive branch in the development and implementation of environmental policy. Review of major statutes.

courses.title: Licensing Academy in Intellectual Property & Technology Commercialization
courses.prereqs: ICL 201;  Law School education or equivalent.
courses.desc: Intellectual property as it relates to current forms of legal protection and how new innovations fit into these models, including public-private technology transfer, patents, institutional objectives, technology transfer offices, startups, and licenses.

courses.title: International Commercial Law Seminar
courses.desc: Advanced seminar in a current topic in International Commercial Law. Topic changes each year course is offered.

courses.title: International Commercial Law Seminar
courses.desc: Advanced seminar in a current topic in International Commercial Law.  Topic changes each year course is offered.

courses.title: Infectious Diseases of Humans
courses.prereqs: Introductory knowledge in biology and chemistry recommended.
courses.desc: Integrates information on biological and molecular nature of the causative organism, modern diagnostics, treatment and prevention strategies, and the role of infectious diseases in contemporary society and throughout human history.

courses.title: Epidemiology & Prevention of Infectious Diseases
courses.desc: Infectious disease epidemiology and prevention, with equal emphasis on human and veterinary diseases. Major categories of infectious diseases by mode of transmission.

courses.title: Clinical & Social Care of the Injection Drug User
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  First- and second-year medical students in good academic standing.
courses.desc: Lecture and guided clinical practice in a supervised clinical setting, focusing on the social and medical aspects of health care for injection drug users.

courses.title: Outbreak Investigation & Infection Prevention
courses.desc: Outbreak investigation is a central aspect of infectious disease epidemiology. Gathering of clinical data and its analysis for surveillance underpins outbreak identification, response and control. Focuses on understanding routine and unusual outbreak and the application of methods for detection, investigation and control in both inpatient and outpatient settings as well as local and global environments.

courses.title: Seminar in Medical Ethics
courses.desc: Seminar Series covering the current topics in Medical Ethics.

courses.title: Cardiovascular System
courses.prereqs: HPH 200;  and Consent of Instructor.  Graduate student status.
courses.desc: Principles of etiology, mechanisms, diagnosis and management of the major diseases of the cardiovascular system.  Included are ischemic, valvular, hypertensive, cardiomyopathic, pericardial, and electrical disorders.

courses.title: Medicine & the Law
courses.desc: Legal and bioethical principles and concepts in medicine. Topics include standard of care, informed consent, reproductive medicine, and end-of-life issues.

courses.title: Hematology
courses.desc: Malignant disorders of blood cells and transfusion therapy. Covers acute leukemia, myelodysplasia, myeloproliferative disorders, lymphoma, and myeloma.

courses.title: Gastrointestinal System
courses.prereqs: Approval of Committee on Student Progress.
courses.desc: Basic pathophysiologic principles of digestive diseases on which clinical concepts and judgments can be developed. Emphasis on pathophysiologic basis of gastroenterological and hepatic disorders with discussion of major disorders and their diagnosis and management.

courses.title: Pulmonary & Critical Care Medicine
courses.prereqs: Approval of SOM's Committee on Student Promotions.
courses.desc: Clinical aspects of respiratory anatomy, physiology, and pathology. Diagnostic procedures and a description of the major pulmonary diseases & disorders, and critical care medicine.

courses.title: Cardiovascular System
courses.prereqs: Approval of the School of Medicine Committee on Student Promotions.
courses.desc: Principles of etiology, mechanisms, diagnosis and management of the major diseases of the cardiovascular system. Included are ischemic, valvular, hypertensive, cardiomyopathic, pericardial, and electrical disorders.

courses.title: Nephrology
courses.desc: Fundamental aspects of disorders of body water, electrolytes and acid/base balance; major categories and mechanisms of parenchymal renal diseases; urinary tract infections.

courses.title: Oncology: Research & Treatment of Cancer
courses.prereqs: Second-, third-, or fourth-year medical student and/or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Comprehensive review of current treatment practices of cancer and state-of-the-art research impacting treatment and prevention of cancer. Emphasis on epidemiology, molecular biology, and pharmacology.

courses.title: Medicos-Global Health Sciences
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Medical students only.
courses.desc: Travel to foreign country for four weeks to collaborate with faculty from local universities and work in urban and rural environments, including hands-on experience with clinic patients. Cultural exchange and awareness of global health care.

courses.title: Medical Spanish for Providers
courses.desc: Provides ample experience in Spanish patient interviews, supervision of interview styles and Spanish-language skills, discussion of common diagnoses, procedural consent, management/treatment plans, and patient education in Spanish to empower medical students to practice medicine with the nationally growing monolingual Spanish-speaking patient population. Curriculum adapted with permission from the Medical Spanish Taskforce.

courses.title: Person Centered Assessment
courses.desc: Person-centered assessment modalities and diagnostic approaches with regards to Internal Medicine and its different subspecialties.

courses.title: Medical Care for Underserved & Marginalized Communities
courses.desc: Review the evidence about health outcomes for marginalized communities, to use the frameworks of ‘structural competency’ and ‘implicit bias’ to understand phenomena that drive disparities, to study the cases of several underserved communities in the Sacramento area, experience first-hand community organizations that are providing care to marginalized communities and practice how to identify in the clinical setting unmet social needs and their impact on health.

courses.title: Medicine, Bioethics & the Holocaust
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Medical students only.
courses.desc: Concept of "evil" and the role of collaborators, bystanders and participants exemplified by the holocaust and compared to problems physicians face in practice today. Demonstration that evil emerges incrementally until taken for granted.

courses.title: Introductory Immunology
courses.desc: Comprehensive introduction to the principles of immunology.

courses.title: Cancer Immunology
courses.desc: Covers concepts in cancer biology, progression and immune evasion. It will also cover topics such as: immune surveillance, immune effector mechanisms and current concepts in immune therapy.

courses.title: Current Concepts in Immunology
courses.desc: Innate and acquired immunity as defense mechanisms against disease. Mechanisms regulating the distinct cell types driving these responses and current concepts in the literature.

courses.title: Comparative Clinical Immunology
courses.desc: Clinical immunology in animals and man. Pathogenesis of representative infectious diseases, hypersensitive reactions, and autoimmunity. Emphasis on specific and nonspecific immune effector mechanisms to combat infections or mediate pathology.

courses.title: Cytokines
courses.desc: Cytokines and their involvement in human and animal physiology/disease, molecular mechanisms and receptor signaling. Immune and non-immune actions. Overlapping/redundant functions (referred to as the "cytokine network").

courses.title: Mucosal Immunology
courses.desc: Basic concepts and current research topics in the field of mucosal immunology, with an emphasis on human immunology. Major emphases include innate and adaptive mucosal immunity, the gastrointestinal tract, the lung, lymphocyte trafficking, and mucosal vaccination.

courses.title: Global Interdependence
courses.desc: Development of the concept of global interdependence along its political, economic, demographic, cultural, technological, and environmental dimensions. Focus on the ways societies and states interact. Provides the foundation for upper division multidisciplinary work in international relations.

courses.title: The Political Economy of International Migration
courses.prereqs: SOC 001, SOC 002, SOC 003, or SOC 004 recommended.
courses.desc: Analysis of worldwide migration patterns, and social scientific theories of international and transnational migration. Focus in economical, political, and social impact of immigration and potential for international and regional cooperation.

courses.title: Topics in International Relations
courses.desc: Selected topics in international relations. Variable content.

courses.title: Special Topics in Natural Science & Mathematics
courses.desc: Group study of a special topic in natural sciences and mathematics. Varies with topic offered.

courses.title: Special Topics in Humanities
courses.desc: Group study of a special topic in humanities. Varies with topic offered.

courses.title: Special Topics in the Social Sciences
courses.desc: Group study of a special topic in the Social Sciences. Varies with topic offered.

courses.title: Accelerated Intensive Elementary Italian
courses.desc: Special 12-week accelerated, intensive summer session course that combines the work of ITA 001, ITA 002, and ITA 003.  Introduction to Italian grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communicative ability.

courses.title: Elementary Italian
courses.desc: Continuation of ITA 002 or ITA 002S. Review of grammar and vocabulary, and practice of all language skills through cultural texts.

courses.title: Intermediate Italian
courses.desc: Review of grammar and syntax through written exercises and short prose works. Intended to develop the linguistic foundations of students who have completed the first year language classes.

courses.title: Intermediate Italian
courses.prereqs: ITA 003 or ITA 003S;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Review of grammar and syntax through written exercises and readings of short prose works. Intended to develop the linguistic foundations of students who have completed the first year language classes. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Intermediate Italian
courses.desc: Review and study of grammar and syntax, readings of short prose works, and written exercises. Intended to prepare students to read, understand, and discuss modern Italian.

courses.title: Intermediate Italian
courses.desc: Review and study of grammar and syntax, readings of short prose works, and written exercises. Intended to prepare students to read, understand, and discuss modern Italian. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Reading Italian
courses.desc: Reading and discussion of modern Italian prose, including selections from creative, scientific and journalistic writings.  Introduction to contemporary Italian literature and culture. Strengthening the student's command of the Italian language.

courses.title: Reading Italian
courses.desc: Reading and discussion of modern Italian prose, including selections from creative, scientific and journalistic writings. Introduction to contemporary Italian literature and culture as well as strengthening the student's command of the Italian language. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Beginning Italian for Spanish Speakers
courses.prereqs: SPA 003 or SPA 003V or SPA 003Y;  Or two years of high school Spanish or native or heritage speaker of Spanish.
courses.desc: Intensive introductory course on Italian language with emphasis on structural similarities between Italian and Spanish.

courses.title: Beginning Italian for Spanish Speakers
courses.prereqs: SPA 003 or SPA 003V or SPA 003Y;  Consent of Instructor.  SPA 003 or two years of high school Spanish or native or heritage speaker of Spanish.
courses.desc: Intensive Introductory course on Italian language with emphasis on structural similarities between Italian and Spanish.

courses.title: Beginning Italian for Spanish Speakers
courses.prereqs: ITA 031 or ITA 031Y;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Continuation of ITA 031. Intensive introductory course to Italian language and grammar with emphasis on oral and written communication. Highlights the structural similarities between Italian and Spanish.

courses.title: Beginning Italian for Spanish Speakers
courses.prereqs: ITA 031 or ITA 031Y;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Continuation of ITA 031. Intensive introductory course to Italian language and grammar with emphasis on oral and written communication. Highlights the structural similarities between Italian and Spanish.

courses.title: Studies in Italian Cinema
courses.desc: Introduction to Italian cinema through its genres. Focus is on cinema as a reflection of and a comment on modern Italian history. Film will be studied as an artistic medium and as a form of mass communication.

courses.title: Advanced Conversation, Composition & Grammar
courses.prereqs: ITA 009 or ITA 009S;  or Consent of Instructor.  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Instruction and practice in expository writing in Italian, with emphasis on advanced grammar, organization, and vocabulary building.

courses.title: Advanced Conversation, Composition & Grammar
courses.prereqs: ITA 009 or ITA 009S;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Instruction and practice in expository writing in Italian, with emphasis on advanced grammar, organization, and vocabulary building. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Italian Translation & Style
courses.prereqs: ITA 009 or ITA 009S;  Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Practice in translation from Italian to English and English to Italian, using literary and nonliterary texts of different styles. Analysis of linguistic problems and elements of style contained in the translation material.

courses.title: Italian Translation & Style
courses.desc: Practice in translation from Italian to English and English to Italian, using literary and non-literary texts of different styles. Analysis of linguistic problems and elements of style contained in the translation material. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Introduction to Italian Literature
courses.prereqs: ITA 009 or ITA 009S;  Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Introduction to the study of the principal authors, works, and movements of the Medieval, Renaissance, and Early Modern periods in Italy.

courses.title: Survey of Italian Culture & Institutions
courses.desc: Assessment of the impact of regional autonomy on Italian cultural life from the Middle Ages to the present. Special emphasis will be placed upon achievements in literature, the arts, philosophy, and socio-political institutions. Taught in English.

courses.title: Survey of Italian Culture & Institutions
courses.desc: Assessment of the impact of regional autonomy on Italian cultural life from the Middle Ages to the present. Special emphasis will be placed upon achievements in literature, the arts, philosophy, and socio-political institutions. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Contemporary Issues in Italian Culture & Society
courses.desc: Analysis of cultural issues in contemporary Italy: Myth and reality of imagined Italies, Italian identities; immigration and race relations; the media and popular culture. Taught in Englsih.

courses.title: Contemporary Issues in Italian Culture & Society
courses.desc: Analysis of cultural issues in contemporary Italy; myth and reality of imagined Italies; Italian identities; immigration and race relations; the media and popular culture. May be taught abroad & in English.

courses.title: Medieval & Renaissance Poetry: St. Francis to Petrarch
courses.prereqs: ITA 009 or ITA 009S;  Consent of Instructor.  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Study of the origins of Italian religious and secular poetry of the 13th and 14th centuries. Diversified poetry is illustrated in works of St. Francis, Dante, Cavalcanti, Petrarch, the Sicilian School, the Sweet New Style Poets, and other authors.

courses.title: Dante Alighieri, Divina Commedia (Inferno, Purgatorio, Paradiso)
courses.prereqs: ITA 009 or ITA 009S;  Consent of Instructor.  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Study of Dante Alighieri's Divina Commedia, and its role in the development of Italian language and literature. Emphasis will be placed on reading the whole poem within the historical context of the Middle Ages.

courses.title: Boccaccio, Decameron, & the Renaissance Novella
courses.prereqs: ITA 009 or ITA 009S;  Consent of Instructor.  Or the equivalent course.
courses.desc: Study of the development of the short story in Italy, as exemplified in Giovanni Boccaccio's Decameron, in his predecessors and Renaissance followers.

courses.title: Studies in the Cinquecento
courses.prereqs: ITA 009 or ITA 009S;  or Consent of Instructor.  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Analysis of key texts from the high moment of the Italian Renaissance. The political and aesthetic legacy of humanism will be foregrounded in relation to authors such as Ficino, Ariosto, Machiavelli, Aretino, Castiglione, and Tasso.

courses.title: Italian Literature of the Renaissance & the Baroque: From Cellini to Marino
courses.desc: Continued examination into the loss of an ideal. Emphasis on the conflicts in Michelangelo and Tasso leading to Marino, with an excursus on Galileos role in the formation of a modern literary standard.

courses.title: Italian Drama from Machiavelli to the Enlightenment
courses.desc: Development of comic and tragic forms as critical representations of their societal and historical contexts, i.e. Machiavelli and the logic of power, Baroque dramatists in the service of counter-reformation Italy, Goldoni's comedies and bourgeois social consciousness.

courses.title: Early Modern Italian Lyric
courses.prereqs: ITA 009 or ITA 009S;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Examination of the poetic tradition influenced by Petrarch. Consideration of the relation between gender and genre in such poets as Petrarch, Bembo, della Casa, Tasso, Marino, Gaspara Stampa, Veronica Franco, Isabella di Morra.

courses.title: Italian Literature of the 18th Century
courses.prereqs: ITA 009 or ITA 009S;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Development of modern Italian literature. Emphasis on the work of Goldoni, Bettinelli, Baretti, Parini, Alfieri, and Vico.

courses.title: Italian Literature of the 19th Century
courses.prereqs: ITA 009 or ITA 009S;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Romanticism in Italy, including Manzoni, Verga, and Verismo.

courses.title: Italian Literature of the 20th Century: The Novel
courses.desc: Development of the novel from Svevo to the present. Emphasis on the work of Svevo, Levi, Moravia, Pavese, and Vittorini.

courses.title: Italian Literature of the 20th Century: Poetry & Drama
courses.desc: Italian poetry with emphasis on Hermeticism; the theater of Luigi Pirandello and its role in the development of contemporary Italian drama.

courses.title: New Italian Cinema
courses.prereqs: FMS 001;  or Consent of Instructor.  And upper division standing.
courses.desc: Italian cinema of the 21st century in the context of profound cultural and social changes in Italy since World War II. Productions by representative directors such as Amelio, Giordana, Moretti, Muccino are included. Knowledge of Italian not required.

courses.title: New Italian Cinema
courses.prereqs: FMS 001;  and Consent of Instructor.  And upper division standing.
courses.desc: Italian cinema of the 21st century in the context of profound cultural and social changes in Italy since World War II. Productions by representative directors such as Amelio, Giordana, Moretti, Muccino are included. Knowledge of Italian not required. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Topics in Italian Culture
courses.prereqs: ITA 009 or ITA 009S;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: In-depth study of a particular topic in Italian Culture. Topics include: Italian Cities; Church and State; the "Southern Question"; Fascism and Resistance; 1968: Counter Culture, Feminism and Terrorism; Multicultural Italy.

courses.title: Autobiography in Italy
courses.prereqs: ITA 009 or ITA 009S;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Development of representations of selfhood with particular attention to generic conditions, the confessional tradition and the problem of women's self-representation. Authors studied may included Petrarch, Tasso, Casanova, Alfieri, Zvevok, Sibilla Aleramo and Primo Levi.

courses.title: Italian Literature in English: Boccaccio, Petrarch & the Renaissance
courses.desc: Petrarch and Boccaccio and their relations to the Middle Ages and the Renaissance; the Renaissance, with particular attention to the works of Lorenzo de' Medici, Leonardo da Vinci, Machiavelli, Ariosto, Michelangelo, and Tasso.

courses.title: Italian Literature in English Translation: Dante, Divine Comedy
courses.prereqs: Any course from the GE Literature Preparation List.
courses.desc: Reading of Dante Alighieri's Divine Comedy, through the otherworld realms of Inferno, Purgatory, and Paradise.

courses.title: Gender & Interpretation in the Renaissance
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Critical analysis of Renaissance texts with primary focus on issues such as human dignity, education and gender politics; "high" and "low" culture and its relation to literary practices.

courses.title: Masterpieces of Modern Italian Narrative
courses.desc: Analysis of major works of Italian narrative fiction from unification of Italy to present. Students will learn to use representative methods and concepts which guide literary scholarship. Consideration of works within European social and cultural context.

courses.title: Special Topics in Italian Literature
courses.prereqs: ITA 009 or ITA 009S;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Study of special topics and themes in Italian literature, such as comic literature, epic poetry, pre-20th-century theater, fascism, futurism, women and literature, and the image of America, etc.

courses.title: Special Topics in Italian Literature
courses.prereqs: ITA 009 or ITA 009S;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Study of special topics and themes in Italian literature, such as comic literature, epic poetry, pre-20th-century theater, fascism, futurism, women and literature, the image of America, etc. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Studies in Italian Cinema
courses.desc: Introduction to Italian cinema through its genres. Focus on cinema as a reflection or a comment on modern Italian history. Film as an artistic medium and as a form of mass communication.

courses.title: Elementary Japanese
courses.desc:
Introduction to spoken and written Japanese in cultural contexts, with
emphasis on communication.

courses.title: Accelerated Intensive Elementary Japanese
courses.desc: Special 12-week accelerated, intensive summer session course that combines the work of JPN 001, JPN 002 and JPN 003. Introduction to Japanese grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communication.

courses.title: Intensive Elementary Japanese
courses.desc: Intensive course taught combining the work of JPN 001, JPN 002 and JPN 003. Introduction to Japanese grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communication. Taught abroad in Japan.

courses.title: Elementary Japanese
courses.prereqs: JPN 001 C- or better;  Or the equivalent language proficiency.
courses.desc: Continuation of training in basic Japanese spoken and written skills.

courses.title: Elementary Japanese
courses.prereqs: JPN 002 C- or better;  Or the equivalent language proficiency.
courses.desc: Continuation of training in basic spoken and written skills in Japanese language. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Intermediate Japanese
courses.prereqs: JPN 003 C- or better;  Or the equivalent language proficiency.
courses.desc: Intermediate-level training in spoken and written Japanese in cultural context, based on language skills developed in JPN 003.

courses.title: Intermediate Japanese
courses.prereqs: JPN 004 C- or better;  Or the equivalent language proficiency.
courses.desc: Intermediate-level training in spoken and written Japanese in cultural context, based on language skills developed in JPN 004.

courses.title: Intermediate Japanese
courses.prereqs: JPN 005 C- or better;  Or the equivalent language proficiency.
courses.desc: Intermediate-level training in spoken and written Japanese in cultural context, based on language skills developed in JPN 005. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Intensive Intermediate Japanese
courses.prereqs: JPN 002 C- or better;  or the equivalent language proficiency. Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Special intensive course that combines the work of JPN 003, JPN 004, JPN 005, and JPN 006. Introduction to Japanese grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communication. Taught abroad in Japan.

courses.title: Masterworks of Japanese Literature (in English)
courses.desc: Introduction to Japanese literature: readings and discussion in English of important works from earliest times to the present.

courses.title: Introduction to Japanese Culture
courses.desc: Aspects of Japanese culture: literature, history, religion, art, language, and society. Taught abroad in Japan; in English.

courses.title: Japanese Language & Culture (in English)
courses.prereqs: JPN 001 or LIN 001 or ANT 004 recommended.
courses.desc: Classification and communication of experience in Japanese culture; principles of language use in Japanese society. Speech levels and honorific language, language and gender, minority languages, literacy. Role of Japanese in artificial intelligence and computer science.

courses.title: Basic Kanji
courses.prereqs: JPN 001 C- or better;  or Consent of Instructor.  Or equivalent proficiency of basic writing system (Hiragana and Katakana).
courses.desc: Introduction and mastery of 300 basic Kanji or Chinese characters to establish a solid foundation in the novel and complex Kanji encountered while learning Japanese.

courses.title: Introduction to the Literature of China & Japan
courses.desc: Methods of literary analysis and their application to major works from the various genres of Chinese and Japanese literature (in translation), including film. East Asian cultural traditions will also be introduced.

courses.title: Japanese Literature in Translation: The Early Period
courses.desc: Study of early Japanese literature from the Nara to the end of the Heian period through a broad survey of the major literary genres such as lyric poetry, court diaries, prose narratives, poem-tales, and classical Chinese writings.

courses.title: Japanese Literature in Translation: The Middle Period
courses.desc: Study of the major literary genres from the 12th century to the second half of the 19th century including poetry, linked-verse, military chronicles, no drama, Buddhist literature, haiku, haibun, kabuki, bunraku, plays and Edo prose narratives.

courses.title: Japanese Literature in Translation: The Modern Period
courses.desc: Modern Japanese literature from the late 19th century to the present with focus on the concept of modernity; in addition to the study of authors and genres, examines historical and cultural contexts. Lectures, readings and discussions in English.

courses.title: Modern Japanese Literature: War & Revolution
courses.desc: Perspectives and sensibilities with which major modern Japanese writers have interpreted the traumatic and often poignant experiences of war and socio-political upheavals from the late 19th century to the 1970s. Lectures, discussions, and readings in English.

courses.title: Modern Japanese Literature: Hero & Anti-Hero
courses.desc: Ways in which representative hero and anti-hero protagonists in modern Japanese literature perceive, confront, challenge, and resolve a wide array of social, political, and moral problems of their times. Taught in English.

courses.title: Japanese Culture Through Film
courses.desc: Aspects of Japanese culture such as love, sexuality, war, the military, the family, the position of women, growing up and death as portrayed in Japanese cinema. Lectures, discussion, and readings in English. Films with English subtitles.

courses.title: Modern Japanese Autobiographies (in English)
courses.desc: Exploring the modern and contemporary Japanese social and cultural landscape through critical analysis of modern Japanese autobiographies by prominent and other authors in the 19th and 20th centuries.

courses.title: Poetry of China & Japan (in English)
courses.desc: A comparative approach to Chinese and Japanese poetry, examining poetic practice in the two cultures; includes a general outline of the two traditions, plus study of poetic forms, techniques, and distinct treatments of universal themes: love, nature, war, etc.

courses.title: Modern Japanese: Reading & Discussion
courses.prereqs: JPN 006 C- or better;  or the equivalent language proficiency.
courses.desc: Readings in modern Japanese short stories, newspaper articles, and essays; conversation practice based on these readings.

courses.title: Modern Japanese: Reading & Discussion
courses.prereqs: JPN 006 C- or better;  Or the equivalent language proficiency.
courses.desc: Readings in modern Japanese short stories, newspaper articles, and essays; conversation practice based on these readings.

courses.title: Modern Japanese: Reading & Discussion
courses.prereqs: JPN 111 C- or better;  Or the equivalent language proficiency.
courses.desc: Continuation of JPN 111.

courses.title: Modern Japanese: Reading & Discussion
courses.prereqs: JPN 112 C- or better;  Or the equivalent language proficiency.
courses.desc: Continuation of JPN 112. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Japanese Composition
