courses.desc: Analysis at the molecular level of the interactions of microbes with the environment, microbes with other microbes, and microbes in symbiotic and/or pathogenic associations with eukaryotic hosts. Topics discussed will vary.

courses.title: Natural History of Infectious Diseases
courses.desc: Topics in the natural history of infectious diseases principally affecting humans.  Introduction to infectious microbial agents, ecology, epidemiology, and induction of disease.  Focus on diseases of a contemporary nature.

courses.title: Introductory Microbiology
courses.desc: Survey of microorganisms emphasizing their interactions with humans and diseases. Topics include microscopy, survey of various microbes, the immune system, food microbiology, microbial pathogens, and mechanisms of disease transmission. Designed for students requiring microbiology for professional schools.

courses.title: Introductory Microbiology
courses.desc: Essentials of microbial biology, emphasizing phylogeny, physiology, genetics, ecology, and pathogenesis. Interactions with other microbes, humans, and the biosphere. Uses of microbes in agriculture and biotechnology. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Introductory Microbiology Laboratory
courses.desc: Introduction to principles and laboratory methods employed in working with microorganisms. Designed for students requiring microbiology for professional school admission. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: General Microbiology Laboratory
courses.prereqs: MIC 102 C or better;  (CHE 008B or CHE 118B or CHE 129A);  and Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Principles and laboratory methods employed in working with microorganisms. Designed for students continuing in microbiology, genetics, or biochemistry.

courses.title: Microbial Diversity
courses.prereqs: MIC 102 or MIC 104;  BIS 101; BIS 103 or BIS 105 strongly recommended.
courses.desc: Survey of the major groups of microorganisms emphasizing diversity of energy metabolism, morphology, evolution, and natural history.

courses.title: Microbial Diversity Laboratory
courses.prereqs: (MIC 102 or MIC 104);  (MIC 102L or MIC 104L);  MIC 105 (can be concurrent).
courses.desc: Classical enrichments for the isolation of metabolically diverse microbes; modern molecular methods for the identification of isolates; cultivation independent analysis of microbial communities from local environmental samples.

courses.title: Human Microbiology
courses.desc: Biology of microorganisms that form commensal, mutualistic, and pathogenic relationships with human beings, emphasizing their phylogeny, physiology, genetics, and ecology. Effects on human nutrition, development and physiology. Mechanisms of pathogenesis, immune response evasion, antibiotic action, and antibiotic resistance.

courses.title: Recombinant DNA Cloning & Analysis
courses.desc: Cloning and analysis of recombinant DNA, with emphasis on Escherichia coli host-vector systems. DNA-modifying enzymes; vectors and their use; manipulation and expression of insert DNA; polymerase chain reaction; and sequence annotation. Graduate students see MIC 215.

courses.title: Analysis of Molecular Genetic Circuits
courses.prereqs: BIS 002A;  MAT 017A;  MAT 017B;  MAT 017C;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Project-based course focused on problem-solving strategies in biology and medicine. Testing hypotheses by translating real-world problems into an appropriate mathematical model and translating the results into real-world understanding.

courses.title: Microbial Ecology
courses.desc:
Interactions between non-pathogenic microorganisms and their environment, emphasizing physiological and metabolic characteristics
of various groups and their adaptation to and modification of specific habitats.

courses.title: Bacterial Physiology
courses.prereqs: (BIS 101,  BIS 102,  BIS 103 (can be concurrent)) or (BIS 101,  BIS 105);  MIC 102 recommended.
courses.desc: Fundamentals of bacterial growth and bacterial responses to environmental stresses. Topics will include carbon and nitrogen regulation, growth rate control, post-exponential growth, and motility and chemotaxis.

courses.title: Genomes of Pathogenic Bacteria
courses.desc: Molecular genetics and comparative genomics of representative pathogenic bacteria. Roles of mobile genetic elements, lateral gene transfer, and genome rearrangements in pathogen evolution. Mutation, recombination, and complementation as tools for genetic analysis. Content includes close examination of primary research articles.

courses.title: Bacterial Physiology Lab
courses.prereqs: (MIC 140 or MIC 150);  MIC 120L;  and Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Physiology and genetics of bacteria.  Isolation and characterization of mutant strains.  Mapping of mutations by conjugation and transduction studies of control of enzyme synthesis by induction, repression, and catabolite repression.

courses.title: General Virology
courses.desc: Integrated presentation of the nature of animal, bacterial, and plant viruses, including their structure, replication and genetics.

courses.title: General Virology
courses.desc: Integrated presentation of the nature of animal, bacterial, and plant viruses, including their structure, replication and genetics.

courses.title: Yeast Molecular Genetics
courses.prereqs: BIS 101;  MIC 102 or MIC 105 strongly recommended.
courses.desc: Survey of the genetics, cell biology and technologies in yeasts and related lower eukaryotes. Topics include diversity of yeasts; cell structure; metabolism; cell cycle; genetic approaches and genomics; gene expression; yeasts as models to study higher eukaryotes; and contemporary techniques.

courses.title: Host-Parasite Interactions
courses.prereqs: MIC 102 or MIC 101 or MIC 104;  BIS 101;  Biological Sciences 102 or 105 strongly recommended.
courses.desc: Exploration of host-parasite interactions at multiple levels, with an emphasis on global health and medically important human parasites.

courses.title: Cancer Biology
courses.desc: Exploration of the causes and treatments of cancer at multiple levels: molecular/cell biology, clinical manifestations, epidemiology and prevention.

courses.title: Advanced Bacteriology
courses.desc: Intended for first-year graduate students in Microbiology and closely-related fields. Advanced topics in phylogeny, physiology and diversity of bacteria.

courses.title: Recombinant DNA
courses.prereqs: BIS 101;  BIS 102;  BIS 103;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Application of recombinant DNA technology to modern problems in biology, biochemistry, and genetics, emphasizing molecular cloning strategies, choice of vectors, preparation of insert DNA, and selection procedures.

courses.title: Analysis of Molecular Genetic Circuits
courses.desc: Project-based course focused on problem-solving strategies in biology. Emphasis on testing hypotheses by translating real-world problems into an appropriate mathematical model and translating the results into real-world understanding.

courses.title: Advanced General & Molecular Virology
courses.desc: Advanced integrated presentation of animal, bacterial, and plant viruses, including their structure, modes of regulation, expression and replication, and effects on host cells and organisms.

courses.title: Principles of Protein-Nucleic Acid Interactions
courses.prereqs: Advanced graduate standing and completion of one year of basic graduate course work in biochemistry, biophysics, chemistry, genetics, microbiology, or molecular biology.
courses.desc: Physical basis of protein-nucleic acid interaction. Topics include nucleic acid recognition by proteins, thermodynamics of protein-nucleic acid stability, and kinetics of binding process for both non-specific and sequence-specific nucleic acid binding proteins. Emphasis on systems that represent paradigms in protein-nucleic acid interactions.

courses.title: Advanced Concepts in DNA Metabolism
courses.prereqs: MCB 221C or GGG 201C or equivalent course recommended.
courses.desc: DNA damage checkpoints, homologous recombination, and meiotic recombination. An advanced treatment of the clinical and current literature to discuss emerging principles and current models in these research areas.

courses.title: Medical Mycology
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  A course in pathogenic microbiology.
courses.desc: Various aspects of pathogenic fungi, particularly affecting humans, will be discussed including epidemiology, pathogenesis and pathology, diagnosis and therapy. Course offered in alternate years.

courses.title: Human Immunology
courses.desc: Human immune system and mechanisms of immunity. Basic components and function of immune system. Molecular basis of immune response; basic cellular and molecular mechanisms. Interactions between cells of immune system producing immune responses; regulating molecules.

courses.title: Mechanisms for Microbial Interactions with Hosts
courses.desc:
Study of mechanisms involved in microbial interactions within a host
environment. The following principles are basic to understanding these interactions: host recognition, invasion, competition and growth, and host defense.

courses.title: Critical Analysis of Contemporary Research on Animal Models of Human Infectious Disease
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Students funded by the Animal Models of Infectious Diseases Training Grant.
courses.desc: Topics will include diverse vertebrate and invertebrate models of human infectious diseases.

courses.title: Comparative Analysis of Animal Models of Human Infectious Diseases
courses.prereqs: Students funded by the Animal Models of Infectious Diseases Training Grant; others by consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Compares the major vertebrate and invertebrate animal models that are used most commonly to study human infectious disease, including mouse, non-human primate, Caenorhabditis elegans, and drosophila.

courses.title: Medical Parasitology
courses.prereqs: Graduate student with consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Epidemiology, pathogenesis, diagnostic methods and current literature discussion of protozoa, helminths and arthropods of medical importance.

courses.title: The Endogenous Microbiota in Health & Disease
courses.desc: Recent insights into the microbial communities inhabiting mucosal surfaces, and will discuss how the composition of these communities contributes to normal development, metabolism, education of the immune system, and disease susceptibility. Offered in spring quarter; even years.

courses.title: Physician Scientist Molecular Medicine Journal Club
courses.desc: Weekly seminars by students on research articles in current literature.  Topics/articles to be selected by instructors to include a broad range of frontiers in biomedical literature.

courses.title: Medical Mycology
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  A course in pathogenic microbiology.
courses.desc: Various aspects of pathogenic fungi, particularly affecting humans, will be discussed including epidemiology, pathogenesis and pathology, diagnosis and therapy.

courses.title: Medical Immunology
courses.desc: Helping to understand the immune system, the nomenclature and functional significance of the tissues, cells, proteins and genes of the immune system, as well as the normal regulatory mechanisms and pathologic outcomes related to the immune response.

courses.title: Medical Microbiology
courses.desc: Discussion of the diseases caused by infectious agents includes their pathogenesis, clinical manifestations, diagnosis, treatment epidemiology and prevention. Covers the general properties of and diagnostic techniques for bacteria, fungi and viruses.

courses.title: Medical Microbiology D
courses.desc: Continuation of longitudinal medical microbiology course series.

courses.title: Emerging Issues at the Interface of Animal, Human, & Ecosystem Health
courses.desc: Introduce one health topics emphasizing relationships between environmental, animal and human health. Topics include ecosystem change and impacts on animals and humans, cross-species disease transmission and approaches for addressing critical data gaps to inform ecosystem health and disease prevention.

courses.title: Medical Statistics I
courses.prereqs: MPVM or MPH standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Basic statistics in clinical, laboratory and population medicine: descriptive statistics; probability; binomial, Poisson, normal, t-, F-, and Chi-square distributions; sampling distributions; parameter estimation; hypothesis testing; elementary nonparametric methods, simple linear regression and correlation; life table construction and analysis.

courses.title: Medical Statistics II
courses.prereqs: MPM 202;  or Consent of Instructor.  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Continuation of MPM 202. Analysis of variance in biomedical sciences; nonparametric methods; multiple regression; unconditional logistic regression; biomedical applications of statistical methods. Microcomputer applications in population medicine to reinforce principles that are taught in lecture. Required for students in the Preventive Veterinary Program Graduate Group (PVM) and the Masters of Public Health Program (MPH).

courses.title: Medical Statistics III
courses.desc: Continuation of MPM 203. Selecting the best regression equation, conditional logistic regression, Poisson regression, survival analysis, analysis of time dependent variation and trends. Microcomputer applications in population medicine to reinforce principles that are taught in lecture.

courses.title: Principles of Epidemiology
courses.prereqs: MPM 202;  or Consent of Instructor.  An introductory statistics course.
courses.desc: Basic epidemiologic concepts and approaches to epidemiologic research, with examples from veterinary and human medicine, including outbreak investigation, infectious disease epidemiology, properties of tests, and an introduction to epidemiologic study design and surveillance.

courses.title: Epidemiologic Study Design
courses.desc: Builds on concepts presented in MPM 205. Concepts of epidemiologic study design—clinical trials, observational cohort studies, case control studies—introduced in MPM 205A are covered in more depth, using a problem-based format. Discussion of published epidemiologic studies.

courses.title: Research Planning & Reporting I
courses.desc: Identify and implement research questions through hypothesis construction, articulation of aims, acquiring permits, working as a team, and all other techniques needed to develop a successful research program.

courses.title: Research Planning & Reporting II
courses.desc: Concepts and skills in effective scientific writing for publication in a peer-reviewed journal in animal health or biomedicine. Includes developing an argument, organizing and writing a manuscript, improving readability, and responding to peer review.

courses.title: Advanced Health Leadership
courses.desc: Develop skills for effective scientific leadership, including: project management and collaboration, conflict resolution, communication with the public, dynamic distribution of health information, and evidence-based policy influence.

courses.title: Concepts & Methods in Infectious Disease Surveillance & Control
courses.desc: Basic and advanced level of conceptual and methodological foundations in infectious disease epidemiology necessary for veterinarians to develop and evaluate programs for detection, prevention, and control of infectious diseases in animal populations.

courses.title: General Science:  Science in the News
courses.desc: Basic principles in science including numeracy, scale, energy, and time; the scientific method; good and bad science. Emphasis on science topics recently in the news.

courses.title: Mathematical & Physical Sciences Seminar
courses.prereqs: Mentorship for undergraduate research participants in the physical and mathematical sciences.
courses.desc: Research and writing in the mathematical and physical sciences. Presentations by various science faculty members.

courses.title: Mathematical & Physical Sciences Seminar
courses.prereqs: Mentorship for undergraduate research participants in the physical and mathematical sciences.
courses.desc: Research and writing in the mathematical and physical sciences. Presentations by various science faculty members.

courses.title: Middle East & South Asia: Comparative Perspectives
courses.desc: Ethnographic and historical points of intersection and divergence in various aspects of the Middle East and South Asia in precolonial, colonial, and postcolonial societies.  Anthropological, historical, and theoretical debates surrounding the region.

courses.title: Great Cities of Arab Middle East & South Asia
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Some knowledge of Islamic/Middle Eastern history is very useful.
courses.desc: In-depth examination of the great cities of North Africa, the Middle East and South Asia as cultural and historical artifacts. Topics include: the concept of the Islamic city, processes of modernity, and representations that reinforce imagination, memory and personal identity.

courses.title: History of South Asian Islam
courses.desc: Comparative study of Muslim communities of South Asia. Commonalities in cultural identity and historical experience. Rise and spread of Islam, comparative history of Islamic Empires, colonial rule, and post-colonial nationalism.

courses.title: Shahnameh: The Persian Book of Kings
courses.desc: In-depth analysis of the Persian Book of Kings (Shahnameh) by Abu al-Qasim Ferdowsi (d. 1020 CE) in its historical context with a comparative perspective on the role of this work in Persian and world literature.

courses.title: A Story for a Life: The Arabian Nights
courses.desc: In-depth exploration of The Arabian Nights, the best-known work of pre-modern Arabic literature and a major work of world literature. Analysis of the work in its historical context and in comparison to other frame tales in world literature.

courses.title: Themes in the Arabic Novel
courses.desc: Select modern Arabic fiction (novels and short stories) in translation. Thematically connected readings supplemented by non-fictional writings when appropriate.

courses.title: Modern Iranian Cinema
courses.prereqs: Upper division standing, or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Iranian cinema of the 20th century in the context of profound cultural and social changes in Iran especially since the Iranian Revolution. Productions by representative directors such as Kiarostami, Makhmalbaf, Bahram Beizaie are included. Knowledge of Persian not required.

courses.title: Modern South Asia Cinema
courses.prereqs: upper division standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: South Asian cinema of last 100 years in the context of cultural, social, and political changes. South Asian history, Independence, Partition, urban life, class, migration, postcolonial identity, diaspora, gender, sexuality, religion, sport, performance, etc

courses.title: Religion & Media in Arab World
courses.desc: Exploration of the role and experience of media technologies in the Arab world. Study of digital and electronic media as well as alternative media practices. Investigation of new trends in political activism and identity formation.

courses.title: Women & Islamic Discourses
courses.desc: Introduction to the debates/discourses about women and Islam. Transformations in debates/discourses in colonial and postcolonial periods in the Middle East & South Asia. Comparative study of debates/discourses on family, work, law, sexuality, religion, comportment, human rights, feminist and religious movements.

courses.title: Iranian Society & Culture
courses.desc: In-depth investigation of modern Iranian society and culture. Exploration of structures of Iranian society: family, gender, religion, minorities, economy, politics, and state. Iran’s role in the globalizing world, and the role of Iranian diasporas.

courses.title: Topics in Middle East & South Asian Studies
courses.desc: Comparative perspective on the Middle East and South Asia. Topics may include: modernity, religious traditions, colonialism, subalternity and social movements, gender and sexuality, history and memory, science and development, ritual and performance, public culture, diasporas.

courses.title: Topics in Regional ME/SA Studies
courses.desc: Iran & Persian topics for students specializing in region-specific Middle East & South Asia Studies.

courses.title: Topics in Regional ME/SA Studies
courses.desc: Indian/South Asia topics for students specializing in region-specific Middle East & South Asia Studies.

courses.title: Topics in Regional ME/SA Studies: Arab Studies
courses.desc: Arab Studies topics.

courses.title: U.S. Army Leadership & Personal Development
courses.desc: United States Army, its organization, customs, courtesies, and rank structure. Surveys personal development skills needed for effective leadership such as critical thinking, time management, and health and fitness. Familiarization with the Army ROTC program.

courses.title: Introduction to Tactical Military Leadership
courses.desc: Military leadership fundamentals to include setting direction, problem-solving, presenting briefs, and using effective writing skills. Basic military tactics, orienteering and land navigation. Dimensions of leadership values, attributes, skills, and actions.

courses.title: Introduction to Basic Military Operations
courses.desc: Basic military tactical theories and their application at the individual and squad level. Military tactical operations and basic military first aid.

courses.title: Military History, Study of Battles
courses.desc: Application of the nine Principles of War to key battles in American and World history. Tactics on a strategic and operational level. Evaluation of leadership and decision-making processes of key leaders.

courses.title: Innovative Team Leadership
courses.prereqs: Lower division standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Leadership values, attributes and theories. Use of basic military skills such as land navigation and squad operations to enhance understanding of the Army.  Types of military briefings.  Practice in interpersonal skills.  Presentation of a briefing.

courses.title: Foundations of Tactical Leadership
courses.desc: Leadership of tactical teams in complex operating environment. Self-assessment of leadership style. Basic military skills: terrain analysis, patrolling and operations orders. Dynamics of adaptive leadership in the context of military operations.

courses.title: Military Leadership & Management
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Upper division standing.
courses.desc: Leadership and management in organizational context. Team dynamics, leadership styles, professional ethics, development of a leadership framework. Management skills for planning, decision making, and organizing developed through definition of problems, development of courses of action, implementation of solutions.

courses.title: Advanced Military Operations
courses.prereqs: MSC 131;  or Consent of Instructor.  Upper division standing.
courses.desc: Military small unit tactical theory as the basis for leadership development.  Principles of war, contemporary operating environment, Geneva Law of Land Warfare, military offensive and defensive operations.  Emphasis on development of critical thinking, problem solving, and communication skills.

courses.title: Applied Leadership
courses.prereqs: MSC 132A;  or Consent of Instructor.  Upper division standing.
courses.desc: Military small unit tactical theory and application as basis for leadership development.  Application of leadership styles and skills to complete problem-solving exercises and the development of an adaptable framework applicable to a variety of shifting environments and situations.

courses.title: Ethical Leadership
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Upper division standing.
courses.desc: Direct influence of leaders on individual motivation and group processes. The complexities of balancing moral, legal, and ethical obligations while applying fundamental business principles in determining the best possible outcome from competing solutions.

courses.title: Military Law
courses.prereqs: MSC 141;  or Consent of Instructor.  Upper division standing.
courses.desc: The United States Constitution and the Military Justice System. Basic law of war, with an emphasis on issues that might arise on the battlefield or during a national emergency.

courses.title: U.S. Army Management Systems
courses.prereqs: MSC 142;  or Consent of Instructor.  Upper division standing.
courses.desc: Leadership and management, focusing on four management systems: planning, organizing, leading and controlling. Practical methodologies for assessing management decisions while balancing competing ethical, economic, infrastructure and future growth trade-offs.

courses.title: Early Medieval Culture
courses.desc: Readings (in translation) in medieval culture, such as Codes of Justinian, Confessions of Saint Augustine, Beowulf, the Nibelungenlied, The Song of Roland, the Summa Theologica of Thomas Aquinas, the Chronicles of Froissart, Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, and Dante's Divine Comedy.

courses.title: The Culture of the High Middle Ages
courses.desc: Great transformations that created the modern world: Constitutional Government, the Hundred Years War, the Black Death, and the Peasants Revolts, the Renaissance, Reformation and Counter-Reformation, and the Baroque.

courses.title: Special Themes in Medieval Cultures
courses.desc: Each offering concentrates on an interdisciplinary aspect of medieval culture in the Middle East and Europe: the idea of the hero, mysticism, urban development. Extensive readings focused on medieval source material.

courses.title: Special Themes in Renaissance Culture
courses.desc: Each theme illuminates an interdisciplinary aspect of Renaissance culture in the eastern and western hemispheres: exploration, medical pathology, daily life, baroque culture. Immersion in source material from 1500-1650.

courses.title: Cross-Cultural Relations in the Medieval and/or Early Modern World
courses.prereqs: MST 020A or MST 020B;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Medieval and/or Renaissance aspects of cross culturalism. Relations between Christians, Jews, and Muslims: Europeans, Africans, and Asians; Old World and New World.

courses.title: Introduction to Music Theory, Part 1
courses.desc: Fundamentals of music theory, ear-training, harmony, counterpoint, and analysis directed toward the development of listening and writing techniques. Intended for the general student.

courses.title: Introduction to Music Theory, Part 2
courses.desc: Continuation of MUS 003A. Development of melodic and harmonic writing skills. Basic analysis training. Intended for the general student.

courses.title: Elementary Theory, Part 1
courses.prereqs: MUS 002A (can be concurrent);  MUS 016A (can be concurrent);  required concurrently.
courses.desc: Development of music writing and listening skills through the study of music fundamentals, species counterpoint, harmony, analysis of repertory. Intended primarily for music majors.

courses.title: Elementary Theory, Part 2
courses.prereqs: MUS 002B (can be concurrent);  MUS 016B (can be concurrent);  required concurrently; completion of MUS 006A or demonstration of required proficiency level on diagnostic exam.
courses.desc: Continuation of MUS 006A.

courses.title: Elementary Theory, Part 3
courses.prereqs: MUS 002C (can be concurrent);  MUS 016C (can be concurrent);  MUS 002C & MUS 016C required concurrently; completion of MUS 006B or demonstration of required proficiency level on diagnostic exam.
courses.desc: Continuation of MUS 006A & MUS 006B.

courses.title: Intermediate Theory, Part 1
courses.desc: Homophonic music of the Classical era with a focus on analysis of music by Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven. Composition of pieces in the homophonic forms such as minuet and trio, theme and variations, rondo and sonata. Intended for music majors.

courses.title: Intermediate Theory, Part 2
courses.desc: Harmony and voice of the 19th century leading through the music of the Romantic era. Focus on analysis of music by Chopin, Schumann, Brahms, Wagner, and Wolf. Composition of character pieces and songs. Intended for Music majors.

courses.title: Intermediate Theory, Part 3
courses.desc: Music of the first thirty years of the 20th century and various analytical tools pertaining to it. Works of Debussy, Stravinsky, Schoenberg, Berg, and others. Composition of small pieces for solo instruments, voice and piano. Intended for music majors.

courses.title: Introduction to Musical Literature
courses.desc: Introduction to composers and major styles of Western music. Lectures, listening sections, and selected readings. For non-majors.

courses.title: Musics of the World
courses.desc: Survey of selected art, folk, and popular music cultures from different parts of the world. Emphasis on understanding relationship of musical style, aesthetic principles, and performance practice to wider cultural contexts.

courses.title: Elementary Musicianship, Part 1
courses.prereqs: MUS 002A (can be concurrent);  MUS 006A (can be concurrent);  MUS 002A and MUS 006A required concurrently.
courses.desc: Melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic materials of Western music. Includes sight singing, explanations, drills, melodic/rhythmic/harmonic dictations, and listening analysis.

courses.title: Elementary Musicianship, Part 2
courses.prereqs: MUS 016A;  (MUS 002B (can be concurrent),  MUS 006B (can be concurrent));  MUS 002B and MUS 006B required concurrently. Completion of MUS 016A or demonstration of required proficiency level on diagnostic exam.
courses.desc: Melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic materials of Western music. Includes sight singing, explanations, drills, melodic/rhythmic/harmonic dictations, and listening analysis.

courses.title: Elementary Musicianship, Part 3
courses.prereqs: MUS 016B;  (MUS 002C (can be concurrent),  MUS 006C (can be concurrent));  MUS 002C and MUS 006C required concurrently. Completion of MUS 016B or demonstration of required proficiency level on diagnostic exam.
courses.desc: Melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic materials of Western music. Includes sight singing, explanations, drills, melodic/rhythmic/harmonic dictations, and listening analysis.

courses.title: Intermediate Musicianship, Part 1
courses.prereqs: MUS 016C;  MUS 007A (can be concurrent);  Or demonstrate required proficiency level on diagnostic exam.
courses.desc: Melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic materials of Western music. Includes sight singing, explanations, drills, melodic/rhythmic/harmonic dictations, and listening analysis.

courses.title: Intermediate Musicianship, Part 2
courses.prereqs: MUS 017A;  (MUS 007B (can be concurrent);  MUS 007B required concurrently. Completion of MUS 017A or demonstration of required proficiency level on diagnostic exam.
courses.desc: Melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic materials of Western music. Includes sight singing, explanations, drills, melodic/rhythmic/harmonic dictations, and listening analysis.

courses.title: Intermediate Musicianship, Part 3
courses.prereqs: MUS 017B;  Completion of MUS 017B or demonstration of required proficiency level on diagnostic exam; MUS 007C required concurrently.
courses.desc: The melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic materials of Western music. Includes sight singing, explanations, drills, melodic/rhythmic/harmonic dictations, and listening analysis.

courses.title: Introduction to the History of Music I
courses.prereqs: MUS 006A (can be concurrent);  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: History of music from the late Baroque to Beethoven. Intended primarily for majors in music.

courses.title: Introduction to the History of Music II
courses.desc: History of music from the Romantic Period to the 19th century. Intended primarily for majors in Music.

courses.title: Introduction to the History of Music III
courses.desc: History of music of the 20th century. Intended primarily for majors in music.

courses.title: Introduction to African American Music
courses.desc: Survey of African American music, such as spirituals, blues, ragtime, jazz, theater, gospel, R&B, rap, and art music. Emphasis on historical and sociocultural contexts, as well as African roots.

courses.title: Advanced Theory, Part 1
courses.desc: Music of the 20th century from 1930 through 1950 and the various analytical tools pertaining to it. Works of Copland, Sessions, Schoenberg, Bartók, and Stravinsky. Composition of small pieces for piano and voice.

courses.title: Advanced Theory, Part 2
courses.desc: Music from 1950 to the present and the analytical tools pertaining to it. Works of Babbit, Carter, Dallapiccola, Ligeti, Messiaen, Reich and others. Composition of small pieces for ensemble.

courses.title: Tonal Counterpoint
courses.desc: Imitative tonal counterpoint with an analytical focus on the Two-Part Inventions and fugues from the The Well-Tempered Klavier by J. S. Bach. Composition of exercises and short pieces using contrapuntal techniques. Intended for music majors.

courses.title: History & Analysis of Jazz
courses.prereqs: MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010 or MUS 011 or MUS 028;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Jazz and the evolution of jazz styles in historical and cultural context. For non-majors.

courses.title: History of Rock Music
courses.desc: Rock and the evolution of rock styles in historical and cultural context. For non-majors.

courses.title: Introduction to Electronic Music
courses.desc: Basics of electronic music history, techniques, and composition. Fixed media creation using field recordings. Focus on history, theory and techniques of musique concrète, elektronische musik, and related repertoire.

courses.title: Handmade Electronic Music
courses.desc: Hacking, bending, and creating electronic circuits to make sound. Learning to read circuit diagrams, to build prototypes, and to solder components together. Repertoire study.

courses.title: Orchestration
courses.desc: Techniques of orchestration from study of basic instrumental techniques to analysis of orchestral scores and scoring for various instrumental combinations.

courses.title: Orchestration
courses.desc: Techniques of orchestration from study of basic instrumental techniques to analysis of orchestral scores and scoring for various instrumental combinations.

courses.title: Music of a Major Composer: Beethoven
courses.prereqs: MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Work of Beethoven will be studied in the context of his time and his contemporaries. Lectures, discussion/guided listening sections, and selected readings. For non-majors.

courses.title: Music of a Major Composer: Stravinsky
courses.prereqs: MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Work of Stravinsky will be studied in the context of his time and his contemporaries. Lectures, discussion/guided listening sections, and selected readings. For non-majors.

courses.title: Music of a Major Composer: Bach
courses.prereqs: MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Work of Bach will be studied in the context of his time and his contemporaries. Lectures, discussion/guided listening sections, and selected readings. For non-majors.

courses.title: Music of a Major Composer: Mozart
courses.prereqs: MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Work of Mozart will be studied in the context of his time and his contemporaries. Lectures, discussion/guided listening sections, and selected readings. For non-majors.

courses.title: Music of a Major Composer: Haydn
courses.prereqs: MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Work of Haydn in the context of his time and his contemporaries. Lectures, discussion/guided listening sections, and selected readings. For non-majors.

courses.title: American Masters
courses.prereqs: MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010 or MUS 011 or MUS 028;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Overview of American concert music by master composers from Charles Ives to the present. Lectures, discussion/guided listening sections, and selected readings. For non-majors.

courses.title: Music of a Major Composer: Handel
courses.prereqs: MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Work of Handel in the context of his time and his contemporaries. Lectures, discussion/guided listening sections, and selected readings. For non-majors.

courses.title: Jazz Fundamentals
courses.prereqs: MUS 003A C- or better;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Fundamentals of Jazz music theory, ear training, harmony and composition techniques. Designed to complement participation in Jazz Combo or Jazz Band. First of a three-course sequence.

courses.title: Jazz Theory
courses.prereqs: MUS 112A C- or better;  Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Intermediate level Jazz music theory, ear training, harmony, and composition techniques including improvisation. Designed to complement participation in Jazz Combo or Jazz Band. Second of a three-course sequence.

courses.title: Jazz Composition
courses.prereqs: MUS 112B C- or better;  Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Jazz compositions and arranging in different styles using techniques of Jazz theory, harmony and improvisation. Third of a three-course sequence.

courses.title: Introduction to Conducting
courses.desc: Principles and techniques of conducting as they apply to both choral and instrumental ensembles.

courses.title: Intermediate Conducting
courses.desc: Intermediate conducting with a continued focus on principles and techniques as they apply to both choral and instrumental ensembles.

courses.title: History of Film Music
courses.desc: Film music from silent films to movies of the past decade. How music supports and shapes film narrative and structure. Use of jazz, rock and classical music in film.

courses.title: Introduction to the Music of The Beatles
courses.desc: Survey of music of The Beatles, focusing on the songs of Lennon and McCartney. Emphasis on understanding their evolution as musicians, composers and cultural figures. Discussion of their musical influences in wider cultural contexts.

courses.title: The Broadway Musical
courses.desc: Exploration of a variety of Broadway and film musicals from different time periods, and how musicals reflect and help create social reality, and the different aspects of the creative process as manifested through music, dance, scenery, and acting.

courses.title: Music as Culture
courses.desc: Introduction to the study of music in cross-cultural perspective. Basic theories and frameworks of ethnomusicology; in-depth case studies of three musical traditions from around the world. Intended for music majors.

courses.title: History of Western Music: Middle Ages to 1600
courses.desc: Historical survey of composers and musical styles from the Middle Ages to the beginning of the 17th century.

courses.title: History of Western Music: 1600-1750
courses.desc: Historical survey of composers and musical styles from the late 1500s to the mid-18th century.

courses.title: American Music
courses.prereqs: MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010 or MUS 011 or MUS 028;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Introductory survey of American musics, including Native American music, Hispanic polyphony, New England psalmody, and selected 20th-century composers and styles.

courses.title: Music from Latin America
courses.desc: Examination of music from Latin America. Characteristic music (i.e., tango, bossa nova, salsa, musica motena, musica andina) as well as its implications in other musical genres. Taught in English or Spanish depending on instructor.

courses.title: Music from Latin America
courses.desc: Examination of music from Latin America. Characteristic music (i.e. tango, bossa nova, salsa, musica motena, musica andina) as well as its implications in other musical genres. Taught abroad in Spanish or English depending on instructor.

courses.title: Musics of the Americas
courses.prereqs: MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010 or MUS 011 or MUS 028;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Survey of music cultures from North, Central, and South America, including the Caribbean, with emphasis on the role of music in society and on the elements of music (instruments, theory, genres and form, etc.). Introduction to ethnomusicological theory, methods, approaches.

courses.title: Musics of Africa, Middle East, Indian Subcontinent
courses.prereqs: MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010 or MUS 011 or MUS 028;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Survey of music cultures with special emphasis on the role of music in society and on the elements of music (instruments, theory, genres and form, etc.). Introduction to ethnomusicological theory, methods, approaches.

courses.title: Musics of East & Southeast Asia
courses.prereqs: MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010 or MUS 011 or MUS 028;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Survey of music cultures from Japan, China, Korea, Vietnam, and Indonesia, with special emphasis on the role of music in society and on the elements of music (instruments, theory, genres and form, etc.). Introduction to ethnomusicological theory, methods, approaches.

courses.title: Folk Musics of Europe
courses.prereqs: MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010 or MUS 011 or MUS 028;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Survey of folk musics from all of Europe, with emphasis on the role of music in society and on the elements of music (instruments, genres, form, etc.). Introduction to ethnomusicological theory, methods, approaches.

courses.title: Introduction to Native American Studies
courses.desc: Introduction to Native American Studies with emphasis upon basic concepts relating to Native American historical and political development.

courses.title: Introduction to Native American Literature
courses.desc: Intensive focus on analysis of Native American literary texts, with frequent writing assignments to develop critical thinking and composition skills.

courses.title: Indigenous & Minority Languages
courses.desc: Survey of the status of indigenous, immigrant, and other minority languages in the Americas and around the world. Topics include linguistic diversity, language endangerment & revitalization, heritage language maintenance in immigrant communities, and language change due to transcultural interactions.

courses.title: Native American Experience
courses.desc: Introduction to the diverse cultures of Native American peoples from North, Central, and South America. Emphasis on Native American voices in the expression of cultural views and in the experience of conflicting values.

courses.title: Native American/Indigenous Film
courses.desc: Survey and analysis of the visual colonization of Native American peoples and the contemporary responses by Native American/Indigenous filmmakers claiming visual sovereignty. Examines a range of filmic genres including documentary, features, shorts, festivals, TV and Internet screening.

courses.title: Native American Music & Dance
courses.desc: Introduction to the music and dance of Indigenous peoples across the Americas. Indigenous music and dance from comparative, interdisciplinary, and global perspectives in order to learn about historic and contemporary issues (e.g., social, cultural, economic, technical, and aesthetic) facing Indigenous communities, and the ways in which the issues are expressed through music and dance practices.

courses.title: Introduction to Native American Art
courses.desc: Introduction to Native American Art from throughout North America, inclusive of traditional forms, techniques and designs in a range of media including ceramics, basketry, fiberwork, carving, painting, sculpture and photography within a context of social and political history.

courses.title: Native American Art Studio
courses.desc: Studio projects to be influenced by contemporary and traditional Native American arts. Examples of designs and media presented in lectures will be of indigenous origin. Introduction and familiarized with various materials and techniques.

courses.title: Contemporary Native American Art
courses.desc: Examination of contemporary artworks by selected Native American and Indigenous Master artists, in a wide range of media, including ceramics, metal arts, photography, video, painting, installation and performance within a context of political and social histories.

courses.title: Learning Native American Languages
courses.desc: Self-directed study of a Native American language using revitalization strategies. Origins of language endangerment and the importance of language for cultural reclamation.

courses.title: Indigenous Languages of California
courses.desc: Survey of the indigenous languages of the California region: linguistic prehistory, languages at first European contact, subsequent language loss, current efforts at language and cultural revitalization, indigenous languages of recent immigrants to California.

courses.title: Native American Language Spotlight
courses.desc: In-depth examination of the history, structure, and sociolinguistics of a particular Native American language or language family. Different language studied each time the course is offered. Oral proficiency component included in some years.

courses.title: Quechua Language & Society: Beginning Level 1
courses.desc: Quechua language and society emphasizing the practical use of the language. Provides some basic Quechua communication skills and with an initial knowledge about contemporary Andean society and the status of Quechua language today.

courses.title: Quechua Language & Society: Beginning Level 2
courses.desc: Second Level of the teaching of Quechua language and society.  Emphasis on development of conversational and reading skills.  Continuation of the study of aspects of contemporary Andean society and the status of Quechua language today.

courses.title: Quechua Language & Society: Intermediate Level 1
courses.desc: Third level of the teaching of Quechua language and society. Emphasis on development of conversational and reading skills. Introduction to more complex grammatical structures. Continuing the study of contemporary Andean society and the status of Quechua language today.

courses.title: Quechua Language & Society: Intermediate Level 2
courses.desc: Fourth level of the teaching of Quechua language and society. Emphasis on complex structural patterns while emphasizing conversational skills and improving reading competence. Study of different sociopolitical processes that have affected Andean identity and the status of Quechua language.

courses.title: Native Americans in the Contemporary World
courses.prereqs: Upper division standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Important issues facing Native Americans in the contemporary world. Focus primarily on the diverse ways of life, histories and realities of indigenous people throughout the Americas as they develop their own cultural and political institutions.

courses.title: Native American Traditional Governments
courses.desc: Study of selected Native American Tribal Governments, confederations, leagues, and alliance systems.

courses.title: Native American Governmental Decision Making
courses.desc: Native American governmental and community decision making with emphasis on federal and state programs, tribal sovereignty, current political trends and funding for tribal services.

courses.title: Native American Politics
courses.prereqs: Upper division standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Examination of the various interest groups and movements found among Native people and how they relate to the determination of Indian affairs. Study of political action available to Native groups, and local communities, along with relevant theory relating to underdevelopment.

courses.title: Introduction to Federal Indian Law
courses.desc: Introduction to the foundational cases and statutes of federal Indian law, from European Contact through the 20th century.

courses.title: Ethnopolitics of South American Indians
courses.desc: Social, political, cultural movements of indigenous South Americans in response to establishment, expansion of European colonialism, post-colonial nation-states. Ethnopolitical processes developed through interactions between Indians, Euroamericans. Socioethnographic analysis of main indigenous areas and the development of national societies. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Corporate Colonialism
courses.prereqs: NAS 001, NAS 010 or NAS 012 encouraged, but not required.
courses.desc: Price of progress and modernity for native and non-native people. History of the corporation and neoliberalism, military and intelligence agencies, debt, Taylorism, education institutions, media, and law. Discussion of alternatives advocated by contemporary and indigenous social movements.

courses.title: Native American Community Development
courses.desc:
Application of community development theory and techniques to the
development problems of Native American communities.

courses.title: Native Foods & Farming of the Americas
courses.desc: Crop domestication, agrodiversity, and cuisines of the Americas. Cultural and social history of native American foods like maize, potatoes, quinoa, chocolate, peppers, beans, avocados, etc. Discussion of socio-economic, environmental, legal challenges facing indigenous and peasant farmers today.

courses.title: Performance & Culture Among Native Americans
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary study of public expressive forms among Native Americans. Comparison and analysis of music, dances, rituals, and dramas from throughout North, Central, and South America in their social and cultural contexts. Extensive film viewing.

courses.title: Native American Ethno-Historical Development
courses.prereqs: Upper division standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Study of Native American ethno-history in North America before 1770s.

courses.title: Native American Ethno-Historical Development
courses.prereqs: Upper division standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Study of Native American ethno-history in North America, 1770-1890.

courses.title: Native American Ethno-Historical Development
courses.prereqs: Upper division standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Study of Native American ethno-history in North America after 1890.

courses.title: Ethnohistory of Native People of Mexico & Central America
courses.desc: Ethnohistorical development of pre-colonial, colonial, post-colonial Mexican and Central American indigenous people; the impact of economic and political factors on the process of cultural adaptation. Attention is given to the questions of nation-building, forced assimilation, indigenous resistance, organized political responses.

courses.title: Ethnohistory of Native Peoples of Mexico & Central America to 1500
courses.desc: Ethnohistorical development of the indigenous peoples of Mexico and Central America up to and including the earliest period of European contact. Focus is on indigenous written historical records of the Maya, Mixtec, and Nahuatl peoples.

courses.title: Ethnohistory of Native Peoples of Mexico & Central America 1500 to 2000
courses.desc: Ethnohistory of indigenous peoples of Mexico and Central America from 1500 to contemporary times. Focus on social and cultural dynamics, particularly the role of indigenous people in the process of nation-state building in Mexico and Central America.

courses.title: Race, Culture, & Nation
courses.prereqs: Upper division standing or consent of instructor. NAS 001 or NAS 010 encouraged, but not required.
courses.desc: Exploration of complexities of Native American racial, cultural and national identities and alliances. Study of tribal and federal citizenship, mixed descent and diasporic people(s), claims to resources, ethnic fraud and contemporary movements of cultural resurgence and political sovereignty and self-determination.

courses.title: Gender Construction in Native Societies
courses.prereqs: Upper division standing or consent of instructor; NAS 001 or NAS 010 encouraged, but not required.
courses.desc: Historical and traditional Native American constructions of feminine, masculine, and non-binary genders with attention to culture- and place-based gender roles and statuses. Analysis of problems with contemporary terminologies and impacts of colonization on contemporary constructions of gender identities.

courses.title: Orientation to Research in Native American Studies
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Native American Studies major or minor, or consent of instructor; NAS 001 or NAS 010 encouraged, but not required.
courses.desc: Introduction to basic research resources pertinent to Native American subjects available in the region, including libraries, archives, museums, etc. Emphasis on learning to use documentary resources or other collections of data. Students will carry out individual projects.

courses.title: Native American Religion & Philosophy
courses.desc: Religious and philosophical traditions of Native American/indigenous peoples of the Americas.

courses.title: California Indian Environmental Policy I
courses.desc: Contemporary California Indian environmental policy issues, with a focus on water, minerals, contamination, and alliance-building. Issues will be placed within historical and political context, drawing on theories of Native environmental ethics, environmental justice, and Federal Indian law.

courses.title: California Indian Environmental Policy II
courses.desc: Contemporary California Indian environmental policy issues, with a focus on planning, site protection, and collaborative structures. Issues will be placed within historical and political context, drawing on theories of Native environmental ethics, environmental justice, and Federal Indian law.

courses.title: Native American Women
courses.desc: Native American women's life experiences, cross-cultural comparisons of gender roles, and Native women's contemporary feminist thought. Utilizes texts from literature, social science, and autobiography/biography.

courses.title: Native American Literature
courses.prereqs: NAS 005 or ENG 003 or COM 001 or COM 002 or COM 003.
courses.desc: Works of fiction (short story, novel) by contemporary Native American authors, with an emphasis on writers from the United States.

courses.title: Native American Literature
courses.prereqs: NAS 005 or ENG 003 or COM 001 or COM 002 or COM 003.
courses.desc: Works by or about Native Americans including non-fiction novels, biographies and autobiographies. Explore ways Native Americans create and recreate their culture through the creative process in literature.  Examine from a critical perspective autobiographies and testimonial literature.

courses.title: Contemporary Native American Poetry
courses.desc: Works of poetry by contemporary Native American/indigenous poets, with some attention to traditional cultural poetic expressions.

courses.title: Contemporary Indigenous Literature of Mexico
courses.prereqs: NAS 001 or NAS 010;  NAS 181A or NAS 181C recommended; reading knowledge of Spanish required.
courses.desc: Contemporary indigenous literature of Mexico, with a focus on the genres (poetry, fiction, drama, essay); analysis of cultural, historical, and spiritual themes, imagery, styles and performances; biographies of and influences on the Native writers themselves.

courses.title: Special Topics in Native American Literary Studies
courses.prereqs: Upper division standing and one of the following recommended: NAS 005, NAS 010, NAS 181A, NAS 181C.
courses.desc: Special topics drawn from Native American literature.

courses.title: Topics in Native American Studies
courses.desc: Selected topics in Native American Studies related to indigenous knowledges and worldviews from a historical, cultural, hemispheric perspective.

courses.title: General Plant Nematology
courses.desc: An introduction to the classification, morphology, biology, and control of the nematodes attacking cultivated crops.

courses.title: Introduction to Nematology
courses.desc: Relationship of nematodes to the human environment. Classification, morphology, ecology, distribution, and importance of nematodes occurring in water and soil as parasites of plants and animals.

courses.title: Molecular & Physiological Plant Nematology
courses.desc: Molecular biology and physiology of nematodes using Caenorhabditis elegans as a model, but with emphasis on plant-parasitic species. Plant responses to nematodes. Discussion of current literature emphasized.

courses.title: Ecology of Parasitic Nematodes
courses.prereqs: (NEM 100 or NEM 110 or ENT 156);  (EVE 101 or PLB 117).
courses.desc: Major concepts in population and community ecology of animal- and plant-parasitic nematodes. Current advances in techniques, theory, and basic information about nematode-host dynamics, and application to management of nematode diseases.

courses.title: Management of Plant-Parasitic Nematodes
courses.desc: Theory, foundation, principles and practices of nematode management. Techniques and equipment used to manage nematodes and methods used to analyze their effectiveness.

courses.title: Insect Nematology & Biological Control
courses.desc: Biology of insect-parasitic nematodes, their effect on the host, and their potential as biological control agents of insect and other invertebrate pests. Application of ecological theory in classical and augmentative biological control.

courses.title: Nematode Systematics & Evolution
courses.prereqs: NEM 100 or NEM 110 or ENT 156;  EVE 100 recommended.
courses.desc: Nematode diversity as revealed by morphological and molecular evidence. Laboratory experience focuses on structural features used in taxonomy. Phylogenetic relationships based on morphological and molecular data used to consider patterns of character change among taxa.

courses.title: Molecular Phylogenetic Analysis
courses.desc: Theory and practice of inferring phylogenetic trees using molecular sequence data. Practical techniques for obtaining sequence data, advantages and disadvantages of common approaches for inferring trees, statistical methods for comparing alternative hypotheses.

courses.title: Human Clinical Neuroanatomy
courses.desc: Clinically relevant anatomy of the normal human nervous system, including external and internal anatomy of the brain, spinal cord, and cranial nerves. Blood supply to the brain and spinal cord. Functional neuroanatomy of motor, sensory, and cognitive systems. Application of neuroanatomical principles relevant to clinical problem solving for students entering health care professions.

courses.title: Clinical Neurosciences
courses.desc: Pathophysiology underlying neurological disorders, including disorders of development, muscle, nerve, cerebral circulation, metabolism, myelin, cortical function, movement, cerebrospinal fluid, autonomic function and special senses.  Anatomical basis of clinical testing, nervous system infection, neoplasia and trauma.

courses.title: Where Drugs Come From: How They are Discovered, Developed, Regulated, & Marketed
courses.desc: Includes the following topics: Overview of the Drug Discovery Process; Drug Regulation in the United States; Patents and Other Forms of Exclusivity; Drug Targets and Pharmacology; Identification of Lead Candidates; Preclinical Assessment; ADME Including Basic Pharmacokinetic Principles; Principles of Drug Toxicity; Principles of Drug Safety; Clinical Trials; Generic Drugs; Pharmaceutical Industry; Drug Distribution and Marketing; Dietary Supplements; Controlled Substances.

courses.title: Elementary Human Physiology
courses.desc: Introduction to physiology for non-science majors. Includes basic cell physiology and survey of major organ systems and how they function in homeostasis and human health.

courses.title: Exercise & Fitness: Principles & Practice
courses.desc: Human movement from physiological, psychological, sociological, and historical perspectives. Biology and psychology of exercise across the human lifespan.

courses.title: The Human Brain & Disease
courses.desc: Normal function and diseases of the human brain and nervous system. Diseases discussed include Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, leprosy, amnesia and schizophrenia. Intended for non-science majors.

courses.title: Extreme Animal Athletes
courses.desc: Overview of biomechanics, focusing on animal locomotion. Physical principles underlying traits such as speed, maneuverability, endurance, and precision. Comparisons of animals and human athletes performing similar feats, with animals often outperforming humans by a wide margin. Biomechanical concepts through hands-on exercises, problem sets, and readings from the scientific literature.

courses.title: Illusions: Fooling the Brain
courses.desc: Introduction to perceptual processing in the human nervous system; illusions.

courses.title: The Biology & Physiology of Aging
courses.desc: Broad examination of age-associated changes in body functions. Includes basic cell physiology, a survey of major organ systems and the age-induced alterations in system function. Some age-associated diseases will also be examined. Intended for non-science majors.

courses.title: The Path to Cyborgs: Introduction to Prostheses & Human Machine Interfaces
courses.desc: Interface of biology and technology. Mind-controlled prosthetic limbs, artificial organs, and implantable devices. Emphasis on basic physiological functions and how they can be replaced by devices. Suitable for majors and non-majors.

courses.title: Biological Science for Social Justice
courses.desc: Broad survey of the many ways one can use the biological sciences to better the lives of others and break down barriers that have restricted social mobility.

courses.title: Biology of Drug Addiction & Abuse
courses.desc: Broad examination of addictive substances and their use/abuse. Topics include historical perspective, physiological effects, etiology, neurobiology of addiction and the impact of drugs on contemporary society. Intended for non-science majors.

courses.title: Neurobiology
courses.prereqs: BIS 002A;  PHY 009A, PHY 009B or PHY 007A, PHY 007B recommended.
courses.desc: Brains and nervous systems, neurons and neural circuits. Coordination of movement. Development of nervous systems. Vision, hearing, and feature extraction by the central nervous system. The cell biology of learning and memory. Perception, cognition, and disorders of the brain.

courses.title: Neurobiology Laboratory
courses.prereqs: NPB 100 (can be concurrent) or NPB 110B (can be concurrent).
courses.desc: Experimental basis of neurobiology principles discussed in NPB 100. Topics include neurophysiology, sensory systems, motor systems, cellular neuroscience, cognitive neuroscience, and quantitative data analysis and modeling techniques.

courses.title: Systemic Physiology
courses.prereqs: BIS 002A;  (CHE 002B or CHE 002BH);  PHY 001B or PHY 007C strongly recommended.
courses.desc: Systemic physiology with emphasis on aspects of human physiology. Functions of major organ systems, with the structure of those systems described as a basis for understanding the functions.

courses.title: Animal Behavior
courses.desc: Basic principles of behavioral organization in vertebrate and invertebrate animals. Underlying physiological and ethological mechanisms. The evolution of behavior, with special emphasis on behavior under natural conditions.

courses.title: Cellular Physiology/Neurobiology
courses.desc:
Cellular physiology with emphasis on membrane transport processes and neuronal physiology. Fundamental physical-chemical and biological mechanisms of membrane transport will be considered in relation to
cytoplasmic homeostasis, communication between cells,and the cellular mechanisms of sensory and motor transduction.

courses.title: Cellular Physiology/Neurobiology  Laboratory
courses.desc: Experiments in the physical and chemical processes of cells and tissues.

courses.title: Cell Signaling in Health & Disease
courses.desc: Basics of cell signaling pathways, their disruption in disease, and their current utility and future potential as therapeutic targets. Focus is on signaling pathways specific to nervous, endocrine and immune systems, and those fundamental to all cells.

courses.title: Animal Behavior Laboratory
courses.desc: Hybrid course, consisting of limited in-person lectures and the rest laboratory exercises. Laboratory exercises are online, and require students to view and score videos of animal behavior in order to test behavioral hypotheses.

courses.title: Kinesiology: Analysis & Control of Human Movement
courses.prereqs: PHY 007A;  PHY 007B;  NPB 101 or NPB 110C recommended; CHA 101 & CHA 101L (Same as EXB 106 & EXB 106L) or equivalent recommended.
courses.desc: Functional anatomy, motor control, and biomechanics of human movement understood in the context of body structures, basic principles of physics, and functional characteristics of muscle.

courses.title: Foundations 1: From Molecules to Individuals
courses.prereqs: (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B);  (CHE 002B or CHE 003A);  PHY 007A and PHY 007B recommended; BIS 002C recommended.
courses.desc: Major concepts in cell biology with special emphasis on connections between cell biology and behavior. Includes: cellular metabolism, cellular sensing and signaling, membrane structure-function, molecular switches, electrical and chemical signaling, endocrine signaling, cell cycle and differentiation, cytoskeleton, and integrative examples. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Foundations 2: Neurobiology
courses.prereqs: NPB 110A C- or better;  PHY 007A and PHY 007B recommended.
courses.desc: Core concepts of neurobiology including single-neuron biophysics, synapses and transmitters, neuronal development, motor systems, central pattern generation, neuronal circuits, intracellular signal transduction, sensory processing, multisensory integration, autonomic nervous system, neuromodulation, learning and memory, and higher cognition and disease.

courses.title: Foundations 3: Physiology
courses.prereqs: NPB 110A C- or better;  PHY 007A;  PHY 007B and PHY 007C recommended.
courses.desc: Focuses on the structure, function, and interactions of human and other animal organ systems in homeostasis and reproduction, and the response to perturbations of homeostasis; neural and endocrine signaling; skeletal muscle and movement; cardiovascular and respiratory systems; renal, digestive, immune, and reproductive physiology.

courses.title: Advanced Systemic Physiology Laboratory
courses.desc: Selected comprehensive experiments in the autonomic nervous system and the cardiovascular, respiratory, and neuromuscular systems.  Emphasis on conceptual and methodological approaches in demonstrating the physiology of organ systems.

courses.title: Cardiovascular, Respiratory, & Renal Physiology
courses.prereqs: (NPB 110C or NPB 101);  CHE 008B, PHY 007B and PHY 007C recommended.
courses.desc: Intense and advanced presentation of concepts in cardiovascular, respiratory, and renal physiology including discussion of acid-base balance.

courses.title: Gastrointestinal Physiology
courses.prereqs: (NPB 110C or NPB 101);  BIS 105 or BIS 103 recommended, BIS 105 preferred.
courses.desc: Gastrointestinal anatomy and physiology.  Digestion, secretion, absorption, motility, comparative physiology and pathology.  Strong emphasis on neural and hormonal regulation and on cellular mechanisms of secretion and absorption.

courses.title: Stress Physiology in Health & Disease
courses.prereqs: BIS 002A C- or better;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Adaptive and maladaptive physiological responses to acute and chronic stress in mammals, with emphasis on humans. Role of endocrine and autonomic nervous system in stress response. Prenatal and postnatal effects of stress on cognitive and affective development. Wellness interventions.

courses.title: Avian Physiology
courses.prereqs: (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B);  CHE 002B;  NPB 101 or NPB 110C  strongly recommended.
courses.desc: Physiology of the various systems of birds with emphasis on digestion, respiration, excretion, and endocrine systems.

courses.title: Physiology of Reproduction
courses.desc: Physiological mechanisms related to reproduction, breeding efficiency and fertility, with special reference to domestic animals.

courses.title: Developmental Endocrinology
courses.desc: Hormonal control of development, maturation and senescence from the cellular to organismal level, with emphasis on the human. Prenatal and neonatal life, childhood and adolescence, adulthood and pregnancy, as well as the endocrinology of aging.

courses.title: Comparative Vertebrate Organology
courses.desc: Functional anatomy of major organ systems in vertebrates.  Each system examined from cellular to gross level in fish, birds, and mammals. Emphasis on how differentiated cell types are integrated into tissues and organs to perform diverse physiological functions.

courses.title: Comparative Neuroanatomy
courses.prereqs: NPB 101 or NPB 100 or NPB 110B or PSC 121.
courses.desc: Overview of the neuroanatomy in mammalian vertebrates, focusing on the cerebral cortex and experimental techniques. Examine changes or modifications to neural structures as a result of morphological or behavioral specializations.

courses.title: Comparative Physiology: Sensory Systems
courses.desc: Basic physiological mechanisms involved in sensory systems. Comparative approach to considerations of mechanosensitive systems (audition, lateral lines, touch, echolocation, equilibrium), chemosensitive systems (olfaction, taste, pheromones), photosensitive systems (vision, infrared detection, UV detection), electroreception, and pain. Emphasis on receptors.

courses.title: Comparative Physiology: Endrocrinology
courses.desc: Comparison of physiological functions in the animal kingdom: animal hormones and their functions.

courses.title: Physiology of the Endocrine Glands
courses.desc: Advanced presentation of concepts in endocrinology with emphasis on the role of hormones in reproduction, metabolism, and disease.

courses.title: Nature vs. Nurture: Physiological Interactions Among Genes, Nutrients & Health
courses.prereqs: BIS 001A or BIS 002A;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Biochemical, physiological, genetic, and nutritional causes of important medical problems such as obesity, anorexia, heart disease and diabetes.

courses.title: Genes & the Brain
courses.prereqs: NPB 110B or NPB 100;  or Consent of Instructor.  BIS 101 recommended.
courses.desc: Genetic contributions to brain evolution, development and disorders. Topics include evolution of genomic programs of neurodevelopment and the role of genetics in autism, intellectual disability, and schizophrenia.

courses.title: General Immunology for Physiologists
courses.prereqs: NPB 101 C- or better or NPB 110C C- or better;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Immunology for undergrads interested in physiology aimed at understanding the physiological role of immune responses. Illustrated with examples of human diseases including diabetes, allergies and asthma, and emerging diseases such as Ebola and Zika.

courses.title: Frontiers in Physiology
courses.desc: Lectures by leading authorities and discussion of the latest research in newly emerging areas in physiology. Offered every fourth year.

courses.title: Principles of Environmental Physiology
courses.desc: Physiological aspects of interactions of organisms and environmental, cellular, system, and organismal levels. Emphasis on regulatory responses/mechanisms to thermal, pressure, gravity and light environmental variables.

courses.title: Physiological Adaptation of Marine Organisms
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Upper division standing; residence at Bodega Marine Laboratory required.
courses.desc: Physiological adaptation to the environment among organisms in marine and estuarine habitats.

courses.title: Environmental Endocrinology: Mechanisms for Life Cycles
courses.desc: Effects of environmental factors on endocrine responses that affect vertebrate life history and fitness. Introduction to finite state machine theory and allostasis in life histories and coping strategies. Focus on life history stages including non-breeding, hibernation, reproduction, migration and moult.

courses.title: Advanced Animal Behavior
courses.prereqs: NPB 102 or PSC 101;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Advanced integrative survey of biological principles of behavioral organization, emphasizing historical roots, current research directions, conceptual issues and controversies. Laboratory exercises on the description and analysis of the behavior of captive and free-living animals.

courses.title: Hormones & Behavior
courses.desc: Endocrine physiology with an emphasis on the principles of behavior. Fundamental relationships between hormones and various behaviors engaged in by the organism during its lifetime. Role of hormones in behavioral homeostasis, social behavior, reproductive behavior, parental behavior, adaptation to stress.

courses.title: Advanced Physiology of Animal/Human Disease
courses.prereqs: NPB 101 B+ or better or NPB 110C B+ or better;  Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Centers on fundamental mechanisms and pathophysiological basis for animal and human diseases. Case-based and uses animal and human diseases to help exemplify the physiological consequences of organ dysfunction.

courses.title: Frontiers in Behavior
courses.desc: Lectures by leading authorities and discussion of the latest research in newly emerging areas in behavioral biology. Offered every fourth year.

courses.title: Developmental Neurobiology
courses.desc: Issues, theoretical concepts, and methodologies in developmental neurobiology. Topics include prenatal and postnatal differentiation of neurons, and plasticity in the mature and aging brain. Integration of neurochemical, structural, physiological and behavioral perspectives.

courses.title: Neural Mechanisms of Behavior
courses.desc: Relationship between brain and behavior. Identification and analysis of the relevant neural circuits involved. Examples of systems to be considered are birdsong, locomotion, echolocation.

courses.title: Systems Neuroscience
courses.prereqs: NPB 100 or NPB 110B;  Or equivalent basic neuroscience training with consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Concepts and techniques in systems neuroscience: e.g., measuring and manipulating neural activity, structure of neocortex, sensory processing, motor control, storage of information, neural codes, neural mechanisms underlying cognitive functions.

courses.title: Mammalian Vision
courses.desc: Structure and function of the mammalian visual system, from the formation of images on the retina through visually guided behavior and perception. Emphasis on biological mechanisms underlying vision.

courses.title: Neurobiology of Speech Perception
courses.prereqs: NPB 110B or NPB 100 or NPB 101;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary approach to speech perception with emphasis on functional neuroanatomy and behavior. Topics include auditory processing in time and space, intelligibility in noisy environments, visual speech, evolution of vocal communication, models of speech perception, development, and hearing impairment.

courses.title: Math Tools for Neuroscience
courses.prereqs: (NPB 100 or NPB 110B);  (MAT 016A,  MAT 016B,  MAT 016C) or (MAT 017A,  MAT 017B,  MAT 017C) or (MAT 021A,  MAT 021B,  MAT 021C);  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Introduction to mathematics techniques used in neuroscience. Applications to neuroscience of differential equations, linear algebra, Fourier transforms, correlation and convolution, and probability theory.

courses.title: Computational Neuroscience
courses.prereqs: (NPB 100 or NPB 110B);  (MAT 016A,  MAT 016B,  MAT 016C) or (MAT 017A,  MAT 017B,  MAT 017C) or (MAT 021A,  MAT 021B,  MAT 021C);  or Consent of Instructor.  PHY 007A, PHY 007B or equivalent recommended.
courses.desc: Mathematical models and data analysis techniques used to describe computations performed by nervous systems. Lecture topics include single neuron biophysics, neural coding, network dynamics, memory, plasticity, and learning. Lab topics include programming mathematical models and data analysis techniques in MATLAB.

courses.title: Neurobiology of Addictive Drugs
courses.prereqs: NPB 100 or NPB 110B or NPB 110C or NPB 101;  Or equivalents.
courses.desc: Neurobiological basis for the effects and mechanisms of action of drugs with addictive potential, including opiates (morphine, heroin, methadone), amphetamines, cocaine, nicotine, marijuana (cannabinoids), alcohol, caffeine, and mind-altering drugs such as LSD and antidepressants.

courses.title: Frontiers in Neurobiology
courses.desc: Lectures by leading authorities and discussion of the latest research in newly emerging areas in neurobiology. Offered every fourth year.

courses.title: Physiology of Neuroimmune Interactions
courses.prereqs: BIS 002A;  (NPB 012 (can be concurrent) or NPB 100 (can be concurrent) or NPB 110B (can be concurrent));  or Consent of Instructor.  Completion of PMI 126 or MMI 188 recommended prior to this course.
courses.desc: Explores the complex interactions of the nervous and immune systems, and examine how the systems function together to serve homeostasis, behavior, and disease (such as Alzheimer's, autism, and multiple sclerosis).

courses.title: Map Formation in the Brain
courses.prereqs: NPB 100 C- or better or NPB 110B C- or better;  or equivalent basic neuroscience training with consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Topographic map connection is a fundamental principle for establishing neural network in the brain. Provides comprehensive understanding of the current concepts of map formation in various sensory and motor nervous systems.

courses.title: Neurobiology of Brain Disorders
courses.prereqs: NPB 110B or NPB 100;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Examination of brain disorders from a basic science perspective to gain insights into the mechanisms of their action. Genetic, molecular, cellular, circuit, and environmental basis of a variety of brain disorders. How insights about underlying mechanisms may lead to the development of improved therapies.

courses.title: Light & Fluorescence Microscopy
courses.desc: Theory and practical application of light and fluorescence microscopy in the biological sciences. Laboratory component focuses on an optics bench, where we build simple compound and confocal microscopes on an optical rail.

courses.title: Cellular Neuroscience
courses.desc: Advanced course on cellular and subcellular organization of the nervous system. Membrane channels, sensory transduction, synaptic transmission and cellular aspects of development and learning.

courses.title: Systems Neuroscience
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Integrative and information-processing aspects of nervous system organization.  Topics include sensory systems, motor function, sensorimotor integration, the limbic system, and the neurobiology of learning and memory.

courses.title: Computational Models of Cellular Signaling
courses.desc: Computational and mathematical techniques in modeling of regulatory and signaling phenomena in neurobiology and cell physiology, focusing on linear and nonlinear ordinary differential equation models.
