courses.title: Postharvest Technology of Horticultural Crops
courses.prereqs: Upper division or graduate student standing.
courses.desc: Intensive study of postharvest considerations and current procedures and challenges in postharvest handling for fruits, nuts, vegetables, and ornamentals in California.  Scheduled first two weeks immediately following last day of spring quarter.

courses.title: Experimental Design & Analysis
courses.desc: Introduction to the research process and statistical methods to plan, conduct and interpret experiments.

courses.title: Applied Multivariate Modeling in Agricultural & Environmental Sciences
courses.desc: Multivariate linear and nonlinear models. Model selection and parameter estimation. Analysis of manipulative and observational agroecological experiments. Discriminant, principal component, and path analyses. Logistic and biased regression. Bootstrapping. Exercises based on actual research by UC Davis students.

courses.title: Postharvest Biology & Biotechnology of Fruits & Nuts
courses.desc: Review of postharvest biology of fruits and nuts and biotechnological approaches to address postharvest challenges.  Morphology, biology and postharvest handling of fruits and nuts are presented along with current research, including biotechnology, and discussion of future research needs and approaches.

courses.title: Postharvest Physiology of Vegetables
courses.desc: Comparative physiology of harvest vegetables; emphasis on maturation, senescence, compositional changes, physiological disorders and effects of environmental factors. Concepts and research procedures.

courses.title: Genomics & Biotechnology of Plant Improvement
courses.desc: Integration of modern biotechnology and classical plant breeding including the impact of structural, comparative and functional genomics on gene discovery, characterization and exploitation. Covers molecular markers, plant transformation, hybrid production, disease resistance, and novel output traits.

courses.title: Genomics & Breeding of Vegetable Crops
courses.desc: Preview of genome structure, mapping, gene tagging and development of other genetic resources applied to improvement of major vegetables. For graduate students contemplating a career in modern vegetable breeding and biotechnology.

courses.title: Advanced Plant Breeding
courses.prereqs: PLS 154;  PLS 205;  GGG 201D or ANG 107 recommended.
courses.desc: Philosophy, methods, and problems in developing improved plant species. Topics include: inbreeding, heterosis, progeny testing, breeding methodology, index selection, germplasm conservation, and breeding for stress resistance. Laboratories include tours of breeding facilities and calculation and interpretation of quantitative data.

courses.title: Forest Biology
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or advanced undergraduate with consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Cross-disciplinary review of forest biology, including physiology, genetics, pathology, ecology, and silviculture.

courses.title: Advanced Neuropathology
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Third- or fourth-year medical student.
courses.desc: Presents an integrated introduction to mechanisms of the central and peripheral nervous system injury. Gain an understanding of pathological mechanisms underlying disease, the anatomic and molecular manifestations of pathologic processes of the CNS and PNS.

courses.title: General & Endocrine Pathology
courses.desc: Pathologic mechanisms of human disease. Concepts of general pathologic processes, i.e., cell death, inflammation and neoplasia. Endocrine pathology in the context of clinical human disease. Emphasis on integration of clinical practice with gross and histologic images emphasizing team-based learning.

courses.title: Systemic Pathology
courses.prereqs: Approval by SOM Committee on Student progress.
courses.desc: Anatomic and clinical pathology of organ system human disease with an emphasis on integration with clinical medicine. Topics include hematopathology and neuropathology.

courses.title: Systemic Pathology
courses.prereqs: Approval by SOM Committee on Student progress.
courses.desc: Anatomic and clinical pathology of organ system human disease with an emphasis on integration with clinical medicine. Topics include pulmonary pathology, cardiovascular pathology, hematopatology, oncologic pathology, and nephropathology.

courses.title: Systemic Pathology
courses.prereqs: Approval by SOM Committee on Student progress.
courses.desc: Anatomic and clinical pathology of organ system human disease with emphasis on integration with clinical medicine. Content parallels concurrent clinical courses with integration of lectures and discussions. Topics include gastrointestinal and gynecologic pathology, hepatopathology, oncologic pathology and musculoskeletal pathology.

courses.title: Surgery-Pathology-Radiology (SPR) Research Laboratory
courses.desc: Provide future clinicians and scientists with basic clinical and bioengineering laboratory skills to prepare for careers in translational research

courses.title: Diagnostic Medicine: Pathology in Practice
courses.desc: Asynchronous learning course bridges the gap between foundational pathophysiology learned in pre-clerkship curriculum and the utilization of pathology and laboratory medicine studies in clinical practice.

courses.title: Sub-Specialty in Didactic Pathology
courses.desc: Externship provides in-depth exposure to one of a variety of sub-specialties in Pathology.

courses.title: Interdisciplinary Study of Gastrointestinal Cancer
courses.desc: In-depth study of gastrointestinal, hepatic and pancreatic cancer. Emphasis on an integration of basic science and clinical medicine. Participating departments include pathology, surgical oncology, medical oncology, gastroenterology, radiology and radiotherapy.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Immunology
courses.prereqs: BIS 102;  or Consent of Instructor.  Or equivalent.
courses.desc: Overview of immunology including components of the immune system, initiation and regulation of the immune response, infection and immunity, hypersensitivity and immune dysfunction.  Clinical immunologic techniques, immunodeficiency, and vaccinology.

courses.title: Medical Bacteria & Fungi
courses.prereqs: Any Microbiology course with lab; Immunology strongly recommended.
courses.desc: Introduction to the bacterial and mycotic pathogens of man and animals, with emphasis on pathogenic mechanisms and ecologic aspects of infectious disease.

courses.title: Biology of Animal Viruses
courses.desc: Fundamental physical and chemical properties of animal viruses; methods of propagation, purification and assay.  Mechanisms of viral replication and pathogenesis of viral infections in man and animals. Immunity to virus diseases and oncogenic properties of animal viruses.

courses.title: One Health: Human, Animal & Environment Interfaces
courses.desc: Introduction to fundamentals, challenges, and opportunities in One Health  using local and global health case studies. Animal, human, and environmental health problems, along with tools and transdisciplinary approaches, will be introduced to foster innovative thinking that addresses complex issues.

courses.title: Integrative Pathobiology Core I
courses.desc: Overview of molecular biology techniques, tissue structure and function, cell membrane pathology and cellular mechanisms of disease including cellular responses and adaptations to stress, cell cycle, cell death, cell biomechanics, vascular disturbances, and mechanisms of neoplasia and tumorigenesis.

courses.title: Integrative Pathobiology Core II
courses.desc: The second required core course in the graduate group with topics in inflammation, host-pathogen interaction, regenerative medicine, integrative pathology and population and ecosystem health.

courses.title: Experimental Design and Data Analysis in Pathobiology
courses.desc: Follows two required core courses in, PMI 201 and 202,  for Ph.D. and M.S. students. Goal is to bridge gap between statistics and real-world pathobiology to increase students' skills and independence in experiment design and data analysis.

courses.title: Experimental Design & Data Analysis in Pathobiology
courses.desc: Follows two required core courses, PMI 201 & PMI 202, for Ph.D. and M.S. students. Goal is to bridge gap between statistics and real-world pathobiology to increase students' skills and independence in experiment design and data analysis.

courses.title: Vector-borne Infectious Diseases: Changing Patterns
courses.prereqs: Open to graduate students, MPVM and MPH students, DVM and medical students with second- or third-year standing. Open to upper division undergraduate students with consent of instructor(s).
courses.desc: Vector-borne infectious diseases especially as they relate to changing patterns associated with climatic changes, trade and population movement.

courses.title: Advanced Immunology
courses.desc: Current concepts of immunology with an emphasis on interactions between the host, the environment and the pathogen. These interactions will include those that are protective and successful for the host as well as those that are deleterious.

courses.title: Research Approaches to Disability & Rehabilitation
courses.desc: Discussion and evaluation of research approaches to medical rehabilitation, community integration, and quality of life of disabled persons, with a focus on the progressive disabilities associated with neuromuscular diseases. Intent is to encourage interest in professions that serve the disabled community and increase awareness of rehabilitation goals.

courses.title: Healthy Living: Leading by Example
courses.desc: Improve the physical and mental health of participating students while supplementing their medical education with specific concepts.

courses.title: Healthy Living: Leading by Example
courses.desc: Improve the physical and mental health of participating students while supplementing their medical education with specific concepts.

courses.title: Healthy Living: Leading by Example
courses.desc: Improve the physical and mental health of participating students while supplementing their medical education with specific concepts.

courses.title: Introduction to Sports Medicine
courses.desc: Introduction to basic concepts of Sports Medicine in Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation. Students attend afternoon clinic with Sports Medicine attending; attend lectures focusing on Sports Medicine topics. Students also eligible to cover sporting events with attending physicians where available.

courses.title: Applied Musculoskeletal Anatomy: Sports & Spine SSM
courses.desc: This four-week module will review the anatomy and biomechanics of the musculoskeletal system as well as its associated pathology. The students will be instructed on appropriate musculoskeletal exam techniques and logical approach to the patient in the clinical setting.

courses.title: American National Government
courses.desc: Survey of American national government, including the constitutional system, political culture, parties, elections, the presidency, Congress, and the courts.

courses.title: Introduction to Comparative Politics
courses.desc: Introduction to basic concepts in political analysis and application of them in comparative studies of selected countries. Coverage is given to cultural and other informal dimensions of politics as well as to more formal political and governmental structures.

courses.title: International Relations
courses.desc: International conflict and cooperation, including the Cold War, nuclear weapons, and new techniques for understanding international politics.

courses.title: Basic Concepts in Political Theory
courses.desc: Analysis of such concepts as the individual, community, liberty, equality, justice, and natural law as developed in the works of the major political philosophers.

courses.title: Contemporary Problems of the American Political System
courses.desc: In-depth treatment of selected problems and issues of American politics, governmental institutions, and policies.

courses.title: America Decides: Who Will Win This Year's Election?
courses.desc: Survey of factors influencing presidential and congressional elections. Analysis of candidate nominations, campaign strategy, campaign finance, media coverage, and voter decision-making.

courses.title: Citizen Lawmaking: Direct Democracy, Public Policy & Political Representation in America
courses.desc: Analysis of direct participation by citizens in the lawmaking process.

courses.title: Politics & Film
courses.desc: Survey of portrayals of politics and policy issues in moving pictures. Analysis of political processes, policy development, social mores, and historical periods as highlighted in Hollywood movies, television, and/or documentary films.

courses.title: Political Persuasion
courses.desc: Examination of political influence and persuasion.

courses.title: Politics & Sports
courses.desc: Core issues in American and world politics through the lens of sports and the athletes who play them. Introduction of American civil rights movement, the Cold War, Middle East Tensions, and democratization.

courses.title: Climate Change & Politics
courses.desc: Analysis of political institutions' response and adaptation to climate change.

courses.title: Data Visualization in the Social Sciences
courses.desc: Introduction to quantitative data across the social sciences (Communications, Political Science, Psychology, Sociology, and other disciplines). Transforming data, describing data, producing graphs, visual reasoning, and interpretations.

courses.title: Scientific Study of Politics
courses.desc: Introduction to the basic principles of the scientific study of politics. Research design and empirical analysis of data with applications to different methodological approaches and different substantive areas in political science.

courses.title: Local Government & Politics
courses.desc: Politics and government of local communities in the United States, including cities, counties and special districts. Emphasizes sources and varieties of community conflict, legislative and executive patterns, expertise, decision making and the politics of structure. Observation of local governing boards.

courses.title: Urban Public Policy
courses.desc:
Political and economic relationships among central cities, suburbs, and
regional, state, and federal governments. Focuses upon policy areas such as poverty, transportation, welfare, and housing, and upon who governs and who benefits from the policies in these areas.

courses.title: California State Government & Politics
courses.desc: California political system. Political culture, constitution, elections and parties, direct democracy, legislature, governor, executive branch, courts, finances, state-local relations and policy issues.

courses.title: The Legislative Process
courses.desc: Legislative process with emphasis on the United States Congress; legislative organization and procedures, legislative leadership and policy making, legislators and constituents, relations between Congress and other agencies.

courses.title: The Presidency
courses.desc: American presidencies origins and development; presidential power and influence as manifest in relationships with Congress, courts, parties, and the public in the formulation and administration of foreign and domestic policy; nominations, campaigns, and elections.

courses.title: Environmental Politics & Administration
courses.desc: Environment as a political issue in the United States. Development of administrative mechanisms for handling environmental problems. Changing role of Congress, the presidency, the bureaucracy and the courts in environmental policy formulation and implementation.

courses.title: Policy Making in the Public Sector
courses.desc: Theoretical rationale for governmental activity, program evaluation, PPBS, positive theories of policy making, the quantitative study of policy determinants, implementation, and proposals for improved decision making.

courses.title: Public Policy & the Governmental Process
courses.desc: Processes of formulating public policy, including individual and collective decision making, political exchange, competition, bargaining, coalition formation and the allocation of public goods, resources and opportunities.

courses.title: The Strategy of Politics
courses.desc: Introduction to game theory. Explanation of the behavior of individuals in strategic interaction. Rational and behavioral approaches. Applications to political science and other fields.

courses.title: Contemporary Democratic Theory
courses.desc: Major contemporary attempts to reformulate traditional democratic theory, attempts to replace traditional theory by conceptual models derived from modern social science findings.

courses.title: American Political Thought
courses.desc: Origins and nature of American political thought. Principles of American thought as they emerge from the founding period to the present.

courses.title: Quantitative Analysis of Political Data
courses.desc: Logic and methods of analyzing quantitative political data. Topics covered include central tendency, probability, correlation, and non-parametric statistics. Particular emphasis will be placed on understanding the use of statistics in political science research.

courses.title: Medieval Political Thought
courses.desc: Examination of the ideas central to medieval political thinking. Emphasis will be upon the thoughts of the major political thinkers of the period, rather than upon political history.

courses.title: Foundations of Political Thought
courses.desc: Analysis and evaluation of the seminal works of a major political philosopher or of a major problem in political philosophy.

courses.title: Topics in the History of Political Thought
courses.desc: Political thought of a specific historical period. Topics may include: Ancient Athens, the Italian Renaissance, the Enlightenment, or 19th-century Germany.

courses.title: History of Political Theory:  Ancient
courses.desc: Critical analyses of classical and medieval political philosophers such as Plato, Aristotle, Cicero and St. Thomas.

courses.title: History of Political Theory: Early Modern
courses.desc: Critical analysis of the works of early modern political philosophers such as Machiavelli, Montaigne, Hobbes, Locke and Hume.

courses.title: History of Political Theory:  Late Modern
courses.desc: Critical analyses of the works of late modern political philosophers such as Rousseau, Kant, Hegel, Tocqueville, Mill, Marx and Nietzsche.

courses.title: Contemporary Political Thought
courses.desc: Contemporary political thought from the end of the 19th century to the present. Emphasis upon an individual philosopher, concept, or philosophical movement; e.g., Nietzsche, Continental political thought, Rawls and critics, theories of distributive justice, feminist theory.

courses.title: Theories of International Politics
courses.desc: Major contemporary approaches to the study of international politics, including balance of power, game theory, Marxist-Leninist theory, systems theory, and decision-making analysis.

courses.title: Scientific Study of War
courses.desc: Analysis of political processes involved in the initiation, conduct and termination of modern interstate warfare.

courses.title: International Law
courses.desc:
Selected topics in international law; territory, sovereign immunity,
responsibility, the peaceful settlement or nonsettlement of international disputes.

courses.title: The Politics of Interdependence
courses.desc: In the past several decades, growing economic interdependence has generated new problems in international relations. Deals with difficulties in managing complex interdependence and its implication on national policies and politics.

courses.title: The Politics of Global Inequality
courses.desc: Analysis of current economic and political international relations resulting from a long standing division of the global system into rich and poor regions.

courses.title: Ethnic Self-Determination & International Conflict
courses.desc: Compares the claims of the state and ethnic peoples in countries undergoing internal conflicts; e.g., South Africa, Northern Ireland. Analyzes the role of the international community in facilitating the peaceful resolution of conflicts.

courses.title: Special Studies in International Politics
courses.desc: Intensive examination of one or more special problems in international politics. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Recent U.S. Foreign Policy
courses.desc: Broad survey of the development of U.S. foreign policy in 20th century with emphasis on transformation of policy during and after World War II, and the introduction to analytic tools and concepts useful for understanding of current foreign policy issues.

courses.title: Analysis of U.S. Foreign Policy
courses.desc: Detailed presentation and examination of the formulation of execution of U.S. foreign policy. Survey of numerous factors influencing policy outcomes and how such determinants vary according to policy issue areas.

courses.title: National Security Policy
courses.desc: Development of national security policies since 1945. Analysis of deterrence and assumptions upon which it is based. Effects of nuclear weapons upon conduct of war, alliance systems, and the international system. Prospects of security and stability through arms control.

courses.title: Africa & U.S. Foreign Policy
courses.desc: Overview of American foreign policy toward Africa. Relationship to global adversaries. Legacies of colonialism. Challenge of national self-determination and white racism. Policies on non-alignment, producer cartels, multinational corporations, continental integration and trade and aid relations.

courses.title: International Politics of the Middle East
courses.desc: International politics of the Middle East as a microcosm of world politics. The Middle East as a regional system. Domestic and International Politics in the Middle East. Changing Political Structures in the Middle East. Superpower involvement in the Middle East.

courses.title: The Arab-Israeli Conflict
courses.desc: Causes, course, and implications of Arab-Israeli conflict. Competing Israeli and Arab narratives, politics of force, diplomacy. Domestic politics and A-I conflict, the superpowers and the A-I conflict, A-I conflict and world politics, potential solutions.

courses.title: International Relations in Western Europe
courses.desc: Analysis of European unity, problems of the Atlantic alliance, Atlantic political economy, East-West relations, communism in Western Europe and the relationship between domestic politics and foreign policy. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Special Studies in Foreign Policy
courses.desc: Extensive examination of one or more special problems in foreign policy.

courses.title: Comparative Political Institutions:  Electoral Systems
courses.desc: Workings of electoral institutions, focusing on systems used to elect presidents and assemblies, pass laws, and generally make decisions. Examples from systems throughout the world, including cases from both the advanced industrial and developing worlds.

courses.title: Comparative Political Institutions:  Parties
courses.desc: Factors shaping political parties and their role in democratic representation.

courses.title: Comparative Political Institutions:  Legislatures
courses.desc: Examination of legislatures from a comparative perspective.

courses.title: When Institutions Fail
courses.desc: Examination of factors contributing to the success and failure of political institutions.

courses.title: Policy-Making Processes
courses.desc: Comparative analysis of policy-making in the U.S. and other countries.

courses.title: Comparative Development:  Political Development in Modernizing Societies
courses.desc: Nature and sequence of political development; its economic and social concomitants; role of elites, military, bureaucracy, and party systems; social stratification and group politics; social mobilization and political participation; instability, violence, and the politics of integration.

courses.title: Comparative Development: Politics & Inequality
courses.desc: Linkages between politics and the distribution of social and economic goods. Impact of civil rights legislation, the politics of welfare states, and the effects of political participation on the distribution of goods.

courses.title: Comparative Political Development: Democracy & Democratization
courses.desc: Examination of conditions promoting democratization and democratic stability.

courses.title: Latin American Politics
courses.desc: Issues related to democratic consolidation in Latin America, with a regional focus on South America. Topics include transitions to democracy, the role of the military, political economy, and political behavior.

courses.title: Mexican Politics
courses.desc: Introduction to the politics of contemporary Mexico. Focus on rise, fall, and aftermath of Mexico's one-party dominant system.

courses.title: Politics of Post-Communist Countries:  East European Politics
courses.desc: Post-war democratization, state-building and economic reform in East European states.

courses.title: Politics of Post-Communist Countries:  Russia
courses.desc: Democratization, state-building and economic reform; creation of new institutions; impacts of Soviet rule.

courses.title: Politics of Africa: Issues in Contemporary African Politics
courses.desc: African politics since the end of the Cold War. Topics include: Strategic Security Approach, Democratization, Human Rights, HIV/AIDS, African Peacekeeping, Terrorism, Religious and Ethnic Conflict, Debt and Stalled Development.

courses.title: Politics of Africa:  Development in Africa
courses.desc: Political and economic development within Sub-Saharan Africa. States and institutions, democracy, party systems, military coups/rule, bureaucracy/corruption, race/ethnicity, national/regional integrations, trade unions, economic development strategies, class formation, and women's roles and ideology.

courses.title: West European Politics
courses.desc: Evolution, politics, and contemporary problems of selected political systems of Western Europe. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: West European Politics:  British Politics
courses.desc: Evolution, politics, and contemporary problems of Britain's political system.

courses.title: West European Politics:  French Politics
courses.desc: Evolution, politics and contemporary problems of France's political system.

courses.title: West European Politics: German Politics
courses.desc: Evolution, politics and contemporary problems of Germany's political system.

courses.title: Government & Politics of East Asia: China
courses.desc: Evolution of political institutions and political culture in China with emphasis on the post-1949 period. Primary attention to nationalism, modernization and political efficacy.

courses.title: Government & Politics in East Asia: Japan
courses.desc: Japanese politics, with an emphasis on the postwar period. Particular emphasis on political parties, elections, political economy, and social problems.

courses.title: Government & Politics in East Asia: Southeast Asia
courses.desc: Evolution of political institutions and economy of selected nations in Southeast Asia. Emphasis on imperialist legacy, nation building in multi-ethnic communities, and contrasts in economic performance.

courses.title: Judicial Politics & Constitutional Interpretation
courses.desc: Politics of judicial policy making, issues surrounding constitutional interpretation and decision making, prerequisite for courses on the politics of constitutional law.

courses.title: Constitutional Politics of the First Amendment & the Right to Privacy.
courses.desc: Constitutional politics surrounding such issues as the right to free expression, associational rights, the right to free exercise of religious beliefs and the right to privacy.

courses.title: The Constitutional Politics of the Equality
courses.desc: Constitutional politics of equality in the American political system; issues surrounding constitutional doctrine and judicial policymaking; special attention on racial and sexual equality.

courses.title: The Constitutional Politics of the Justice System
courses.desc: Constitutional politics of the American criminal justice system. Issues surrounding constitutional doctrine and judicial policymaking on issues such as search and seizure. Arrest, trial, incarceration and other issues of due process.

courses.title: Legal Philosophy
courses.desc: Analysis of the nature and functions of law; law as an instrument of social control and the relationship between law and morality.

courses.title: Judicial Process & Behavior
courses.desc: Analysis of the behavior of judges and courts in the political process. Techniques of judicial decision making. Relationships among courts and other decision-making bodies.

courses.title: American Political Parties
courses.desc: Analysis of the structured operations of the party system in the United States; party functions and organizations, nomination processes, campaigns and elections, party trends and reforms.

courses.title: Ballots, Bucks, & Maps: The Rules of the Electoral Game in American Politics
courses.desc: Analysis of laws and court cases on the organization and administration of elections in the United States. Topics include campaign finance, redistricting, voting rights, race & representation, and comparisons with other democracies.

courses.title: Elections & Voting Behavior
courses.desc: Analysis of American elections and partisan behavior; political socialization, political participation, partisanship and individual and group determinants of voting.

courses.title: Group Politics
courses.desc: Groups, institutions and individuals, especially in American politics. Historical and analytical treatment of group theories as applied to interest groups (especially labor, business, agriculture, science, military); to racial, ethnic and sectional groups; to parties, public and legislative groups, bureaucracies.

courses.title: Public Opinion
courses.desc: Nature of public opinion in America as it is supposed to be and as it is. Distribution of opinions among different publics and the significance of that distribution for system stability and institutions. Opinion polling and its problems.

courses.title: Mass Media & Politics
courses.desc: Organization of and decision making within the media; media audiences and the effect of the media on attitudes and behavior; the relationship of the government to the media (censorship, secrecy, freedom of the press, government regulation);the media in election campaigns.

courses.title: Women in Politics
courses.desc: Role of women in American politics. Historical experiences; contemporary organizations and strategies; areas of legislative concern; the impact of differences in social class, race, and ethnicity upon the involvement of women in politics.

courses.title: Chicano Politics
courses.desc: Political aspects of Chicano life in America; examines the Chicano's political role as it has been historically defined by different groups in society and the Chicano's responses to his/her political environment.

courses.title: Political Psychology
courses.desc: Overview to the growing literature on political psychology. Introduction to how psychological concepts (personality, attitudes, stereotypes, heuristics, affect, identity, group dynamics) help us understand how citizens think about politics.

courses.title: The Politics of Energy
courses.desc: Nature and performance of political processes for making energy choices at the international, national and state levels. Interaction of energy policy with other political goals and the ability of governmental institutions to overcome constraints on policy innovation.

courses.title: American Political Development
courses.desc: Systematic analysis of contemporary issues in American political development: historical determinants of political change; the timing and character of institutional development; conditions for successful political action. Democratization, cultural change, party formation, state-building, constitutionalism, race relations.

courses.title: Government & the Economy
courses.desc: Political basis of economic policy (taxation, spending and regulation); impact of prices, employment and growth on political demands; elite responses to economic conditions; policy alternatives and the public interest.

courses.title: Science, Technology, & Policy
courses.desc: Analysis of policymaking for science and the use of scientific expertise for making decisions about technology. Topics include funding of basic research, relationship of science to technological development, science and military policy, technological risks, technology assessment and scientists and politics.

courses.title: Racial Politics
courses.desc: Race, racial attitudes and racial policies in the United States with a specific emphasis on African Americans.

courses.title: Special Studies in Comparative Politics
courses.desc: Intensive examination of one or more special problems appropriate to comparative politics. Coverage is given to formal and informal political institutions, economically developing and developed countries, and non-democratic, democratic, and democratizing countries.

courses.title: Bureaucracy in Modern Society
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  POL 001 or POL 002 recommended.
courses.desc: Role of bureaucracy in a complex society, with emphasis upon changing relationships between government and the economy; consequences of rapid technological and social change for bureaucratic structures and processes; the problems of reconciling expertise and democracy and increasing the responsiveness of public bureaucracy.

courses.title: Administrative Behavior
courses.desc: Implications for American public administration of evolving concepts about behavior in organizations.

courses.title: Administrative Theory
courses.desc: Historical and critical analysis of the principal theories of organization and management of public agencies in light of such concepts as decision making, bureaucracy, authority and power, communication and control; examination of role of government bureaucracies in the total society.

courses.title: International Relations
courses.desc: Analysis and evaluation of substantive issues in contemporary international relations. Readings drawn from current academic and non-academic periodicals. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Washington Center Research Seminar
courses.prereqs: POL 192W (can be concurrent);  POL 192W required concurrently.
courses.desc: Core academic component of Washington Program.  Topics coordinated with internships.  Research draws on resources uniquely available in Washington, DC.  Supervised preparation of extensive paper.

courses.title: Research in Political Theory
courses.desc: Special research seminar on problems and issues in the study of political theory.

courses.title: Research in International Relations
courses.desc: Special research seminar on select problems and issues in the study of international relations.

courses.title: Research in Comparative Government & Policy
courses.desc: Special research seminar on select problems and issues in the study of comparative government and policy.

courses.title: Research in Methodology
courses.desc: Special research seminar on selected problems and issues in methods in political science.

courses.title: Elementary Portuguese
courses.desc: Introduction to Portuguese grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with special emphasis on communication.

courses.title: Accelerated Intensive Elementary Portuguese
courses.desc: Intended for students who wish to complete three quarters of Portuguese 1, 2, and 3.

courses.title: Elementary Portuguese
courses.desc: Continuation of POR 001 in the areas of grammar and development of all basic language skills in cultural context with special emphasis on communication.

courses.title: Elementary Portuguese
courses.desc: Continuation of POR 002 in the areas of grammar and development of all basic language skills in cultural context with special emphasis on communication.

courses.title: Intermediate Portuguese
courses.desc: Review and develop the grammar, vocabulary, and composition acquired in first year Portuguese through exercises and reading of modern texts.

courses.title: Intermediate Portuguese
courses.desc: Continuation of POR 021. Focus on more difficult grammar concepts and further composition practice. Development of all language skills through exercises and reading of modern texts.

courses.title: Portuguese Composition I
courses.desc: Development of writing skills by way of reading, discussion, and analysis of authentic materials, literary texts, and videos. Selective review of grammar. Class activities include composition, journals, letters, individual and group projects.

courses.title: Intermediate Portuguese for Spanish Speakers
courses.desc: Development of linguistic and learning skills required for Spanish-speaking students in upper division courses in Portuguese.

courses.title: Portuguese for Spanish-Speaking Graduate Students
courses.desc: Intensive review of grammar and composition. Development of all language skills, but with emphasis on reading of modern texts, presentation/discussion, and writing on academic topics. Development on the following writing skills: analytical, argumentative, and creative.

courses.title: Principles of Luso-Brazilian Literature & Criticism
courses.prereqs: POR 022 or POR 023;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Principles of literary criticism applied to the study of fiction, poetry, and essays of major literary writers of the Luso-Brazilian world.

courses.title: Structure of Portuguese: Sounds & Words
courses.desc: Linguistic description of sound patterns of Portuguese and how those sounds can be used to form larger units, such as morphemes and words. Theoretical and practical comparisons with English and with other Romance languages.

courses.title: Survey of Luso-Brazilian Literature: 1500-1800
courses.desc: Overview of Luso-Brazilian literature, covering three major literary periods: Renaissance, Baroque, and Enlightenment. Attention to the concept of imitation and nativism.

courses.title: Portuguese Literature: Medieval & Renaissance
courses.desc: Overview of the origins of the Portuguese literature, spanning from the 13th century to the 16th century. Studies of lyrical and epic poetry, drama, and travel narratives.

courses.title: Luis de Camões
courses.desc: Overview of the greatest Renaissance Portuguese poet, Luis de Camões.  Study his famous epic poem, Os Lusiadas, and a series of sonnets written by him.

courses.title: Introduction to Luso-Brazilian Culture
courses.desc: Introduction to history, geography, and culture of Portugal and Brazil. Art, history of ideas, and everyday cultural manifestations. Introduction to critical reading and textual analysis. Taught in Portuguese.

courses.title: Special Topics in Luso-Brazilian Literature & Culture
courses.desc: Special topics in the study of Luso-Brazilian literature and culture.

courses.title: Luso-Brazilian Literature & Culture
courses.desc: Colonial Brazilian literature survey. Readings include 16th-18th centuries manuscripts and books of cultural importance in a society dominated by censorship and with no printing presses. Study of the role literary Academies played in the so called "culture of manuscripts."

courses.title: Introduction  to Brazilian Literature
courses.desc: Narrative and poetic texts of the 19th and 20th centuries in Brazil. In-depth and comparative study of Romantic and (Neo)Naturalist movements as a forum for discussion about literary tradition and modernity in Latin America.

courses.title: 20th C Masters in Brazilian Literature
courses.desc: Overview of modern Brazilian literature from early 20th C to the poetry by João Cabral de Melo Neto and the Concretists (1960s), including European avant-garde movements and literary and cultural manifestos leading to a revolutionary body of literature.

courses.title: General Psychology
courses.desc: Principles and basic concepts of psychology. The empirical study of individual behavior including perception, cognition, development, personality, social interactions and the biological underpinnings of behavior.

courses.title: General Psychology
courses.desc: Introduction to empirical approaches. Focus on perception, cognition, personality and social psychology, and biological aspects of behavior.

courses.title: Data Visualization in the Social Sciences
courses.desc: Introduction to quantitative data across the social sciences (Communications, Political Science, Psychology, Sociology, and other disciplines). Transforming data, describing data, producing graphs, visual reasoning, and interpretations.

courses.title: Research Methods in Psychology
courses.prereqs: (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y);  PSC 012Y, STA 013, or STA 100 strongly recommended.
courses.desc: Introduction to experimental design, interviews, questionnaires, field and observational methods, reliability, and statistical inference.

courses.title: Relationship Science: Lust, Love, & Evolution
courses.prereqs: PSC 001 or PSC 001Y;  or introductory social science course or introductory life science course.
courses.desc: Evolutionary perspectives on attraction and close relationships. Integrating social psychological and evolutionary theories with empirical evidence pertaining to human mating.

courses.title: Mindreading: Understanding Other Minds
courses.desc: Psychological perspectives on the process of understanding other people’s minds. Integration of social-cognitive theories with empirical evidence to explore the human ability to make sense of others' thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.

courses.title: Introduction to Cognitive Psychology
courses.desc: Introduction to human information processing, mental representation and transformation, imagery, attention, memory, language processing, concept formation, problem solving, and computer simulation.

courses.title: Introduction to Biological Psychology
courses.desc: Survey and integration of the relationships between behavior and biological processes, including physiology, genes, development, ecology, and evolution.

courses.title: Statistical Analysis of Psychological Data
courses.prereqs: (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y);  PSC 041;  (STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 102).
courses.desc: Design and statistical analysis of psychological investigations and the interpretation of quantitative data in psychology.

courses.title: Statistical Analysis of Psychological Data
courses.desc: Probability theory, sampling distributions, statistical inference, and hypothesis testing using standard parametric and correlational approaches. Simple regression analysis, multiple regression analysis, non-parametric statistics, introduction to multivariate statistics, with applications in psychology.

courses.title: Applied Psychometrics: An Introduction to Measurement Theory
courses.prereqs: PSC 041;  PSC 103A;  (STA 013 or STA 013Y);  Upper division standing in Psychology.
courses.desc: Examination of the basic principles and applications of classical and modern test theory. Topics include test construction, reliability theory, validity theory, factor analysis and latent trait theory.

courses.title: Questionnaire & Survey Research Methods
courses.prereqs: PSC 001 or PSC 001Y;  and Consent of Instructor.  PSC 041 or an equivalent course on social or behavioral research methods or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Introduction to survey and questionnaire research methods with emphasis on how to ask questions. Social and psychological factors that influence survey response. Practical aspects of fielding survey and questionnaire research.

courses.title: Developmental Psychobiology
courses.desc: The biology of behavioral development; survey and integration of the organismic and environmental processes that regulate the development of behavior.

courses.title: Agent-Based Modeling
courses.desc: Introduction to agent-based computer simulation and analysis with emphasis on learning how to model animals, including humans, to achieve insight into social and group behavior.

courses.title: Physiological Psychology
courses.desc: Relationship of brain structure and function to behavior, motivation, emotion, language, and learning in humans and other animals. An introduction to the methodology of physiological psychology and neuroscience.

courses.title: Advanced Animal Behavior
courses.desc: Advanced integrative survey of biological principles of behavioral organization, emphasizing historical roots, current research directions, conceptual issues and controversies. Laboratory exercises on the description and analysis of the behavior of captive and free-living animals

courses.title: Hormones & Behavior
courses.desc: Endocrine physiology with an emphasis on the principles of behavior. Fundamental relationships between hormones and various behaviors engaged in by the organism during its lifetime. Role of hormones in behavioral homeostasis, social behavior, reproductive behavior, parental behavior, adaptation to stress.

courses.title: Comparative Neuroanatomy
courses.prereqs: NPB 100 or NPB 101 or NPB 110B or PSC 121.
courses.desc: Overview of the neuroanatomy in mammalian vertebrates, focusing on the cerebral cortex and experimental techniques. Examine changes or modifications to neural structures as a result of morphological or behavioral specializations.

courses.title: Behavioral Epigenetics
courses.desc: Review of basic principles in genetics and epigenetics with emphasis on behavior. Introduction to the use of modern molecular methods in understanding the complex relationships between genes, environment, and behavior.

courses.title: Health Psychology
courses.desc: Psychological factors influencing health and illness. Topics include stress and coping, personality and health, symptom perception and reporting, heart disease, cancer, compliance, and health maintenance and promotion.

courses.title: Human Learning & Memory
courses.prereqs: (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y);  PSC 041;  (PSC 012Y or STA 013 or STA 100);  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Consideration of major theories of human learning and memory with critical examination of relevant experimental data.

courses.title: Perception
courses.desc: Cognitive organizations related to measurable physical energy changes mediated through sensory channels. Perception of objects, space, motion, events.

courses.title: Language & Cognition
courses.prereqs: (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y);  PSC 041;  (PSC 100 or PSC 135);  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Introduction to the cognitive processes involved in language comprehension and production. Topics include the biological foundations of language, speech perception, word recognition, syntax, reading ability, and pragmatics.

courses.title: Neuroeconomics/Reinforcement Learning & Decision Making
courses.prereqs: (PSC 100 or PSC 100Y or PSC 135 or ARE 100A or ECN 100A or NPB 162 or NPB 163);  (STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 100 or PSC 103A);  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Theoretical and empirical approaches to neuroeconomics (neuroscience of decision making) from psychology, neuroscience, economics, and computer science. Neuroscience of judgment and decision making, behavioral economics, and reinforcement learning.

courses.title: Cognitive Neuroscience: The Biological Foundations of the Mind
courses.prereqs: (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y);  PSC 041;  or Consent of Instructor.  PSC 101 or PSC 121 recommended.
courses.desc: Neuroscientific foundations of higher mental processes including attention, memory, language, higher-level perceptual and motor processes, and consciousness. Emphasis on the neural mechanisms which form the substrates of human cognition and the relationship of mind to brain. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Psychology of Music
courses.prereqs: (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y);  PSC 041;  (PSC 100 or PSC 135 or MUS 006C);  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Introduction to the mental and neural representations of musical structures and processes involved in perceiving, remembering, and performing music. Music and emotion.

courses.title: Neurobiology of Learning & Memory
courses.desc: Overview of the neural basis of learning and memory focusing on modern behavioral  neuroscience research with animals. Topics include consolidation, neural plasticity, cellular competition for memory storage, and the role of neurogenesis in learning.

courses.title: Consciousness & Cognition
courses.desc: Current theoretical and empirical evidence in the study of cognition and consciousness. Theories of consciousness, psychological and neural basis of conscious and unconscious processes such as attention, intentionality, and dreams.

courses.title: Advanced Cognitive Neuroscience
courses.prereqs: (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y);  PSC 041;  PSC 135;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Advanced integrative survey of cognitive neuroscience, including perception, attention, memory, and navigation. Emphasis on reviewing literature in psychology, neuroscience, and statistics; understanding methods in cognition; and presentation skills.

courses.title: Developmental Psychology
courses.desc: An ontogenetic account of human behavior through adolescence with emphasis on motor skills, mental abilities, motivation, and social interaction.

courses.title: Cognitive Development
courses.desc: Theories, methods, evidence, and debates in the field of cognitive development, such as nature/nurture, constraints on learning, and the role of plasticity. Topics include attention, memory, concepts about the physical and social world, and language.

courses.title: Social & Personality Development
courses.desc: Social and personality development of children, infancy through adolescence. Topics include the development of personality, achievement motivation, self-understanding, sex-role identity, and antisocial behavior. Emphasis on the interface between biological and social factors.

courses.title: Infant Development
courses.desc: Psychological development in infancy. Topics include physical and motor development, sensory and nervous system development, and memory and cognitive development. Emphasis will be  on evaluating theories, empirical research, and experimental methods for understanding infant development.

courses.title: Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience
courses.prereqs: PSC 135 or ((PSC 140 or HDE 100A or HDE 100B);  (PSC 101 or PSC 121 or NPB 161 or HDE 163));  PSC 141 recommended.
courses.desc: Neuroscientific theories and methods (EEG, ERP, fNIRS, fMRI) that inform an understanding of behavioral and cognitive development over infancy and childhood. Neurodevelopmental correlates of perception, action, language, and social cognition; value of the neuroscientific perspective; limitations and challenges of neuroscientific research in the developmental context.

courses.title: Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience
courses.prereqs: PSC 135 or ((PSC 140 or HDE 100A or HDE 100B);  (PSC 101 or PSC 121 or NPB 161 or HDE 163));  PSC 141 recommended.
courses.desc: Neuroscientific theories and methods (EEG, ERP, fNIRS, fMRI) that inform an understanding of behavioral and cognitive development over infancy and childhood. Neurodevelopmental correlates of perception, action, language, and social cognition; value of the neuroscientific perspective; limitations and challenges of neuroscientific research in the developmental context.

courses.title: The Development of Memory
courses.prereqs: (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y);  PSC 041;  and any Psychology upper division course from Core Group A or D.
courses.desc: Theory and research on memory development with focus on infancy and childhood.

courses.title: Developmental Disorders
courses.prereqs: (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y);  PSC 041;  (PSC 140 or PSC 141 or HDE 100A or HDE 100B).
courses.desc: Current scientific knowledge of the influences of biological, cognitive, and environmental factors on the emergence of disorders with onset in childhood.  Examples include autism spectrum, ADD/ADHD, dyslexia and dyscalculia.  Emphasis placed on understanding these disorders, their causes and their treatments.

courses.title: Social Psychology
courses.desc: Behavior of the individual in the group. Examination of basic psychological processes in social situations, surveying various problems of social interaction: group tensions, norm-development, attitudes, values, public opinion, status.

courses.title: Social Cognition
courses.desc: Examines how social factors influence how we attend to, encode, and process information and how these mental processes affect subsequent judgments and behavior.

courses.title: Psychology & Law
courses.desc: Current theoretical and empirical issues in the study of psychology and law. Topics include eyewitness testimony, child abuse, jury decision making, juvenile delinquency and criminology, prediction of violence, insanity defense, and memory for traumatic events.

courses.title: Psychology of Emotion
courses.desc: Introduction to current theories and research on emotion and bodily feelings with special reference to self-knowledge.

courses.title: Stereotyping, Prejudice, & Stigma
courses.desc: Social psychological underpinnings of stereotyping, prejudice, and stigma from sociocultural, motivational, and cognitive perspectives. Topics include: origins, maintenance, change, effects on person perception and memory, and the automaticity/controllability of stereotyping and prejudice.

courses.title: Sexual Orientation & Prejudice
courses.desc: Current scientific knowledge about sexual orientation and prejudice based on sexual orientation. Emphasis is placed on learning the skills necessary for a critical understanding of science and public policy issues relevant to sexuality.

courses.title: Gender & Human Reproduction
courses.desc: Psychology of reproduction. Reproductive events over the course of an individual’s life, including sexual development, mate choice, relationships, and reproduction. Biological and social psychological explanations at the levels of mechanism and evolutionary function.

courses.title: Psychology of the Self
courses.desc: Psychological theory and research on the self. Topics include: self-knowledge, self-esteem, self-regulation, self-presentation, cognitive and emotional aspects of the self, and the role of the self in shaping social interaction.

courses.title: Introduction to Personality Psychology
courses.desc: Scientific study of personality. Methods of personality research. Overview of current research and theory in the field of personality psychology. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Introduction to Clinical Psychology
courses.desc: Major theoretical formulations in the history of clinical psychology, from classical psychoanalysis to contemporary existentialism and behavior modification. Survey based on lectures, films, and tapes, of what clinical psychologists do, including methods of appraisal, professional roles, and approaches to treatment.

courses.title: Abnormal Psychology
courses.desc: Descriptive and functional account of behavioral disorders, with primary consideration given to neurotic and psychotic behavior.

courses.title: Psychology of Religion
courses.desc: Major theories, issues, data, and research methodologies of the psychology of religion. Religious experience and expression; religious development in childhood, adolescence, and adulthood; conversion; religious influences on physical and mental health; cross-cultural perspectives.

courses.title: Genius, Creativity, & Leadership
courses.prereqs: (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y);  PSC 041;  or Consent of Instructor.  Or equivalents.
courses.desc: Phenomenon of genius is examined from a diversity of theoretical, methodological, and disciplinary perspectives, with an emphasis on outstanding creativity and leadership in art, music, literature, philosophy, science, war, and politics.

courses.title: Research in Cognitive & Perceptual Psychology
courses.prereqs: PSC 041;  four upper division Psychology courses and consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Empirical research on selected topics in general experimental psychology (general research design and analysis, perception, cognition, cognitive development, etc.). Specific content will vary from quarter to quarter.

courses.title: Research in Psychobiology
courses.prereqs: PSC 101;  three additional upper division Psychology courses and consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Empirical research on selected topics in psychobiology (animal learning, animal behavior, physiological and sensory psychology, developmental psychobiology, computer modeling of neural systems). Content varies.

courses.title: Research in Personality & Social Psychology
courses.prereqs: PSC 041;  four upper division Psychology courses and consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Empirical research on selected topics in personality and social psychology (personality, social psychology, organizational psychology, etc.). Content will vary from quarter to quarter.

courses.title: Research in Developmental Psychology
courses.prereqs: PSC 041;  Consent of Instructor.  Four upper division Psychology courses.
courses.desc: Empirical research on selected topics in developmental psychology (research design and analysis, development, cognitive development, social and personality development etc.).

courses.title: Methods in Laboratory Research
courses.desc: Training in specific lab-based research methods coupled with hands-on experience in a research lab. Students assessed on their ability report and interpret research findings. Content varies from quarter to quarter.

courses.title: History of Psychology
courses.prereqs: (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y);  PSC 041;  Upper division standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Development of psychological thought and research in context of history of philosophy and science.

courses.title: Statistical Analysis of Psychological Experiments
courses.prereqs: STA 102;  Or equivalent; graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Probability theory, sampling distributions, statistical inference, and hypothesis testing using standard parametric and correlational approaches. Analysis of variance, factorial and repeated measures, and tests of trends.

courses.title: Causal Modeling of Correlational Data
courses.prereqs: PSC 204A;  Or the equivalent course and graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Examination of how to make causal inferences from correlational data in the behavioral sciences. Emphasis is on testing rival causal models using correlations among observed variables. Beginning with multiple regression analysis, discussion advances to path analysis and related techniques.

courses.title: Advanced Statistical Inference from Psychological Experiments
courses.prereqs: PSC 204A;  Or the equivalent; graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Advanced topics in statistical inference, which may include probability theory, sampling distributions, statistical inference and hypothesis testing, nonparametric statistics, Bayesian approaches, and advanced issues in analysis of variance.

courses.title: Applied Multivariate Analysis of Psychological Data
courses.prereqs: PSC 204A;  PSC 204B;  PSC 204D;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Review of the major methods of multivariate data analysis for psychological data.  Students will program statistical routines using a linear algebra-based computing language.  Topics will include multivariate analysis of variance. discriminant analysis, canonical analysis factor analysis, and component analysis.

courses.title: Factor Analysis
courses.prereqs: PSC 204A;  PSC 204B;  or Consent of Instructor.  Or equivalent courses; graduate standing.
courses.desc: Theory and methods of factor analysis, including exploratory factor analysis, confirmatory factor analysis, and principal component analysis.

courses.title: Structural Equation Modeling
courses.prereqs: PSC 204A;  PSC 204B;  or Consent of Instructor.  Or equivalent courses; graduate standing.
courses.desc: Theory and methods of structural equation modeling, including path analysis, confirmatory factor analysis, multiple-group modeling and latent growth curve modeling.

courses.title: Multilevel Models
courses.prereqs: PSC 204A;  Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Introduction to statistical techniques for the analysis of normal, hierarchically structured data, such as cross-sectional clustered data or repeated-measures data.  Topics include hierarchical linear models, latent growth curve models, and how these methods handle unbalanced and/or missing data.

courses.title: Applied Psychometrics & Measurement Theory
courses.prereqs: PSC 204A;  Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Examination of the basic principles and applications of classical and modern test theory. Topics include test construction, reliability theory, validity theory, factor analysis, and latent trait theory.

courses.title: Item Response Theory
courses.prereqs: PSC 204A;  Or the equivalent; graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Item response theory allows for the creation of precise measurement instruments in psychological testing. Review Classical Test Theory, and then cover basic IRT models through advanced applications.

courses.title: Applied Longitudinal Data Analysis
courses.prereqs: PSC 204A;  Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Modeling and understanding of intraindividual change and interindividual differences in change. Reviews conventional methods and introduces contemporary techniques for modeling intraindividual change.

courses.title: Theoretical Foundations: Research Methods in Psychology
courses.desc: Examines the philosophy and research practices underlying experimental psychology. Topics to be covered include philosophy of science/epistemology, research design, inference and bias in research, theory development, validity, the social context of research, and critical thinking about research.

courses.title: Research Methods in Psychology: Applications in Social-Personality Research
courses.desc: Overview of the research designs, assessment methods, and statistical procedure used by social-personality psychologists. Focus on the practical issues that arise when using each method in specific research contexts.

courses.title: Survey & Questionnaire Research Methods
courses.prereqs: Completion of a course on social or behavioral research methods, graduate standing.
courses.desc: Survey and questionnaire research methods with emphasis on how to ask questions. Cognitive, motivational, and social processes that influence how respondents answer questions; sampling techniques; Internet resources; practical aspects of fielding survey and questionnaire research.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Human Electrophysiology
courses.desc: In-depth introduction and hands-on experience with the event-related potential (ERP) method in the study of attention, executive control, memory, language and social cognitive neuroscience.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming: Matlab
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: The Matlab programming environment as a means of organizing, analyzing, and visualizing scientific data.  Basic programming concepts such as variables, loops, conditional branching, and efficient programming techniques will be emphasized.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Cognitive Neuroimaging
courses.prereqs: Basic knowledge of inferential statistics and experimental Psychology.
courses.desc: Introduction to empirical foundations and methodology of neuroimaging, emphasizing pragmatics of functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to study cognition. Topics include MR physics, the relationship between neural activity and the BOLD response, experimental design, and analysis of fMRI data.

courses.title: Behavioral Genetics
courses.desc: Review basic principles in genetics and select topics in molecular genetics with emphasis on behavior. Use of modern molecular methods to outline complex relationships between genes, environment, and behavior.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Animal Behavior
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Upper division undergraduate introduction to the biology of behavior, such as PSC 101, PSC 122, PSC 123, NPB 102, NPB 150, NPB 152, WFC 141, ENT 104, or ANS 105.
courses.desc: Survey of the phenomena and theory of animal behavior from the perspectives of multiple biological disciplines, including evolution, ecology, psychology, genetics, neurobiology, endocrinology, and animal science.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Animal Behavior
courses.desc:
Survey of the phenomena and theory of animal behavior from the 
perspectives of multiple biological disciplines, including evolution, ecology, psychology, genetics, neurobiology, endocrinology, and animal science.

courses.title: History of Psychology
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: A lecture-seminar on the history of psychology and on the applicability of early psychological theory and research to contemporary investigations.

courses.title: Academic Writing in Psychology
courses.desc: Strategies for developing and honing academic writing skills and writing productivity, with a particular focus on how to write a clear and compelling empirical journal article in psychology.

courses.title: Attitudes & Social Influence
courses.desc: Survey of theory and research in the field of attitudes and social influence. Topics include attitude definition and measurement, major theories of attitude formation and change, the relationship between attitudes and behavior, and recent directions and controversies.

courses.title: Social Cognition
courses.desc: Processes underlying the perception, memory, and judgment of social stimuli, the effects of social and affective factors on cognition, and the interpersonal consequences of those processes. Topics include automaticity/control, motivated cognition, person perception, stereotyping, attitudes, and persuasion.

courses.title: Stereotyping, Prejudice, & Stigma
courses.desc: Examines the social psychological underpinnings of stereotyping, prejudice, and stigma, including sociocultural, motivational, and cognitive factors.

courses.title: Cognitive Neuroscience
courses.prereqs: Graduate student standing in Psychology or Neuroscience or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Graduate core course for neuroscience. Neurobiological bases of higher mental function including attention, memory, language. One of three in three-quarter sequence.

courses.title: Core Concepts & Methods in Learning, Memory, & Plasticity
courses.prereqs: Graduate Standing or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Core concepts and methods used in studies of learning, memory and plasticity. Behavioral paradigms and measurement approaches in human and animal studies of learning and plasticity, as well as a consideration of the functional, anatomical and neuronal mechanisms underlying brain plasticity.

courses.title: Core Concepts & Methods in Learning, Memory, & Plasticity
courses.desc: Core concepts and detailed survey methods used in studies of learning, memory and plasticity, from the cellular and molecular level to the level of neural circuits. Areas of learning, memory, and plasticity research where recent progress has been made in linking across these levels of analysis.

courses.title: Translational Approaches to Learning, Memory, & Plasticity Disorders
courses.desc: Neurological disorders, the effect of these disorders on learning, memory and plasticity, approved therapeutic options and current research designed to improve understanding and treatment of these diseases: (i) the clinical presentation, diagnostic criteria, and existing therapies, (ii) mechanistic studies in humans and animal models, and (iii) molecular pathways involved in the disease and approaches for drug discovery.

courses.title: The Teaching of Psychology
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Advanced graduate standing in Psychology or a closely related discipline.
courses.desc: Methods and problems of teaching psychology at the undergraduate and graduate levels; curriculum design and evaluation. Practical experience in the preparation and presentation of material.

courses.title: Psychiatry Grand Rounds
courses.prereqs: Medical students or staff or other qualified mental health professionals with consent of instructor.
courses.desc:
Weekly conference at UCDMC for presentation of selected clinical cases,
presentation of lecture and research reports.

courses.title: Functional Genomics
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc:
The theory, methods and principles of functional neurogenomics with
emphasis on the relationship to molecular mechanisms involved in development and disease of the nervous system.

courses.title: Principles of Pharmacology & Toxicology I
courses.desc: First of three courses presenting fundamental principles of pharmacology and toxicology. Introductory overview of basic concepts in pharmacology/toxicology, followed by in-depth blocks on fate processes of chemicals in the body, fate processes in tissue selective responses, selective toxicity employed therapeutically.

courses.title: Principles of Pharmacology & Toxicology II
courses.desc: Second of three courses presenting fundamental principles of pharmacology and toxicology. Principles of pharmacodynamics and mechanisms of drug/toxicant actions.

courses.title: Principles of Pharmacology & Toxicology III
courses.desc: Integrated physiological systems, cardiovascular and nervous systems and how drugs and toxicants act to perturb function.

courses.title: Electrophysiology Techniques & Applications
courses.desc: Broad scope of topics in electrophysiology techniques and applications.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Pharmacology & Toxicology
courses.desc: In-depth coverage of selected topics for graduate students in Pharmacology-Toxicology and related disciplines. Topics determined by instructor in charge for each quarter.

courses.title: Molecular Mechanisms in Cancer & other Diseases
courses.prereqs: MCB 121 or MCB 122;  Undergraduate or graduate introductory course in cell biology (such as BIS 104), and general biochemistry (MCB 121 or MCB 122) required; PTX 202 recommended.
courses.desc: Exploration of cutting edge investigations on the underlying mechanisms of cancer biology, cancer therapy and other diseases. Current medical research in cancer and other diseases, as it spans the bench to bedside.

courses.title: Advanced Research Conference
courses.desc: Provide credit for participation in and attendance at research conferences.

courses.title: Current Topics in Immunology: From Presentations to Grants
courses.desc: Current developments in various aspects of immunology and their interrelationships. Focus on areas of immunology not currently covered in the basic and advanced immunology courses. Oral presentation, written review and grant preparation.

courses.title: Radiological Diagnosis II (Physics of Diagnostic Radiology)
courses.desc:
Physics of diagnostic imaging; x-ray production and interaction; image formation; modulation transfer function; fluoroscopy; cine fluoroscopy; stereoscopy; xeroradiography; computerized and geometrical tomography;
magnetic resonance and ultrasound. Principles of radiation protection in imaging will be covered.

courses.title: Medical Radiation Biology
courses.desc: Medical radiation biology; molecular cellular and organ system response to acute and chronic irradiation; radiation carcinogenesis and genetic effects; radiation risk assessment; diagnostic ultrasound and magnetic resonance imaging health effects. Medical/legal considerations of radiation exposure.

courses.title: Diagnostic Imaging of Acquired & Congenital Heart Disease
courses.prereqs: RDI 461 (can be concurrent);  Fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.
courses.desc: Main emphasis on radiology of acquired and congenital heart disease, but also on magnetic resonance, nuclear medicine, and echocardiography of heart diseases.

courses.title: Biomedical Radiochemistry
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Open to graduate and medical students.
courses.desc: Approved for graduate degree credit. Designed to combine basic nuclear physics, chemistry, and biology into a comprehensive and vigorous lecture-laboratory experience in biomedical nuclear chemistry. Subjects include choice and purification of appropriate gamma & beta radioisotopes, compounding biological pharmacodynamics and radioimmunoassay.

courses.title: Radiological Physics I (Physics of Nuclear Medicine)
courses.desc: Physics of diagnostic and therapeutic nuclear medicine, nuclear physics, radioactive decay; interaction of ionizing radiation; dosimeters; attenuation; internal and external dosimetry; health physics; radiation detection and imaging, scintillation cameras, computerized planar and tomographic imaging. Offered at UC Davis Medical Center.

courses.title: Radiobiology Lecture Course
courses.desc: Radiobiology lectures are designed to engage the physician residents, physics residents and medical students in learning Radiobiology principles and concepts during the year the Radiation Physics course is taught.

courses.title: Survey of Religion
courses.desc: Basic concepts introduced through readings of the primary religious literature. Discussion of central ideas (creation, history, law, prophecy, suffering, mysticism, asceticism, karma, reincarnation, moksha, etc.); readings from the Bible, Bhagavad Gita, the Koran, selections from Plato and early Buddhist writings.

courses.title: Pilgrimage
courses.desc: Introduction to comparative religion, focusing on the theme of pilgrimage in different religious traditions.

courses.title: Death & Afterlife
courses.desc: Introduction to comparative religion, focusing on the theme of death and the afterlife in different religious traditions.

courses.title: Sacrifice
courses.desc: Introduction to comparative religion, focusing on the theme of sacrifice in different religious traditions.

courses.title: Conversion
courses.desc: Introduction to comparative religion, focusing on the theme of conversion in different religious traditions.

courses.title: Fundamentalism
courses.desc: Introduction to comparative religion, focusing on the idea of fundamentalism in different religious traditions.

courses.title: Religion Today
courses.desc: Introduction to comparative religion, focusing on different religious traditions in the contemporary world.

courses.title: Myth, Ritual, & Symbolism
courses.desc: Myths, rituals and religious symbols found in a variety of religious traditions including examples from ancient and contemporary religious life. Variety of religious phenomena; validity of different approaches to the study of religion.

courses.title: Sex, Marriage, & Divorce in Medieval & Modern Society
courses.desc: Methods used in the study of religion, focusing on a particular theme in a number of religious traditions.

courses.title: Music, Voice, & the Word
courses.desc: Exploration of relation between religion and musical traditions in various cultures. Investigation of ways music, vocal performance and sound production reflect and shape modern religious sensibilities. Special attention to gender, ethnicity, race, class, nationalism, secularism and mass media.

courses.title: Comparative Religion
courses.desc: Comparative Religion based on rotating topics such as Dreams and Revelations, Evil, Prophecy, Salvation, and Crime and Punishment.

courses.title: Introduction to Health Sciences & the Humanities
courses.desc: Humanities in the health sciences focusing on illness, the practice of medicine, and the role of culture in biomedical research.

courses.title: Contemporary Ethical Issues
courses.desc: Presents challenging, contemporary ethical issues from a multi-cultural perspective. Rotating topics will include Ethical Eating, Capital Punishment, Euthanasia, Poverty, and Animal Rights.

courses.title: Ethical Eating
courses.desc: Introduction to the complex and varied ethical, religious, and cultural meanings that food has had across the centuries and globe.

courses.title: Emergence of Judaism, Christianity & Islam
courses.desc: History of religion in the ancient Near East and Mediterranean, from the Persian period through the rise of Islam. Emphasis on historical and social contexts of the formation of new traditions, in particular Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

courses.title: Reading War/Fighting War
courses.desc: Introduction to both classic religious texts about war and a set of actual scenarios drawn from the experience and training of soldiers in recent military conflicts.

courses.title: The Bible & Its Interpreters
courses.desc: Introduction to the Hebrew Bible (Old Testament): key narratives and themes (creation, flood, prophecy, justice, sexuality, etc.); origins in Ancient Israel; diverse ways it has been interpreted in Jewish and Christian communities.

courses.title: Introduction to Judaism
courses.desc: Introduction to the study of religion using examples from the rituals, art and holy texts of Judaism. No prior knowledge of either Judaism or the study of religion is necessary.

courses.title: Introduction to Judaism
courses.desc: Introduction to the study of religion using examples from the rituals, art and holy texts of Judaism. No prior knowledge of either Judaism or the study of religion is necessary.

courses.title: Religions of South Asia
courses.desc: Introduction to South Asian religions, including Hinduism, Buddhism, Islam, Jainism and Sikhism. Traces historical developments from Vedic texts and their ascetic reformulation by sages such as Yajnavalkya, Siddhartha Gautama, and Mahavira into our global present.

courses.title: Introduction to Jainism
courses.desc: Introduction to topics central to Jain tradition through critical, historical and ethical perspectives.

courses.title: History of Yoga
courses.desc: History of yoga from antiquity to its most recent formulation in American popular and consumer culture.

courses.title: Magic & Demons in South Asia
courses.desc: Exploration of magic, demons, and other powers in South Asian religions from the ancient to the modern periods.

courses.title: New Testament
courses.desc:
New Testament literature from critical, historical, and theological
perspectives.

courses.title: Religion & Science Fiction
courses.desc: Representations of actual and fictional religious movements in science fiction and fantasy writing and film. Examination of: the characteristics of religion and religiosity in fictional religious movements; the relationship between religion, science, and technology in modern speculative fiction.

courses.title: Christianity
courses.desc: Major concepts and practices in the Christian tradition. Survey of the history of Christianity and Christian expansion from antiquity to modern times. Pays particular attention to Christianity in China, India, Africa, the Middle East, and Latin America.

courses.title: Introduction to Islam
