courses.desc: Introduction to topics central to the Islamic tradition. Muhammad, the Qur'an, Islamic law, theology, philosophy, cosmology, worship, and mysticism. Race and gender in Islam, Islamic revival, and varying experiences of Islam in different historical and cultural settings.

courses.title: The Qur'an & Its Interpretation
courses.desc: The Qur'an, its history, its various functions in the lives of Muslims, and its different interpretations. Quranic themes such as God and humankind, nature and revelation, eschatology and Satan. Islam and other religions; women, gender, and sexuality.

courses.title: The Song of God: The Bhagavad Gita
courses.desc: The Bhagavad Gita, its history and reception, and its significance in the lives of Hindus. Themes explored include Hindu theories of god, self, war, peace, duty, and action.

courses.title: Modern Hinduism
courses.desc: Historical survey of modern Hinduism from the early-19th century to the present. Topics include Rammohun Roy, Sir William Jones, and Mahatma Gandhi, nationalism, post-colonialism and diasporic religion.

courses.title: Hinduism
courses.desc: Hindu tradition from ancient to modern times.  Multiplicity of religious forms within Hinduism with mention of Jainism, Buddhism, and Sikhism and their relation to the mainstream of Hindu religion.

courses.title: Introduction to Hindu Mythology
courses.desc: Survey of the major narrative traditions within Hinduism, including epic literature and local stories in oral, textual, visual and performative forms.

courses.title: Religion & Language
courses.desc: Basic toolkit for studying religious discourse in a variety of traditions. Concentration on the sacred and profane, the wondrous and ordinary, and the mystical and reasonable.

courses.title: Introduction to Chinese Philosophy
courses.desc: Introduction to Chinese philosophy from classical pre-modern times; emphasis on basic concepts and their impact on social conduct; the Age of Philosophers, the Han synthesis, the medieval Buddhist contribution.

courses.title: Religion, Gender, Sexuality
courses.desc:
Constructions of gender and sexuality within one or more religious 
traditions, pre-modern and modern.  Emphasis on the interaction between religious, medical, and ethical definitions of the human body and sexual behavior.

courses.title: Study of Religion: Issues & Methods
courses.desc: Principal issues and methods of Religious Studies and associated fields.

courses.title: Christian Origins
courses.desc: Development of Christianity from the end of the 1st century through the major controversies of the 5th century. Emphasis on the relationship between the new religious movement and the Roman Empire, and issues of early Christian identity and diversity.

courses.title: Medieval & Byzantine Christianity
courses.desc: Christianity in Europe and the Near East from the year 600 to 1450. Focus on the development of Catholic and Orthodox traditions in ritual, art, and thought, with attention to interactions between regional groups, and Christian interaction with Islam.

courses.title: Christianity 1450-1700
courses.desc: History of  Reformation conflicts over the authority of scripture, the nature of man and the universe, and the basis of morality with the goal of understanding how these conflicts laid the foundation for the modern world.

courses.title: Christianity & Modernity, 1700-1920
courses.desc: Reaction of Christian critics and apologists to the profound cultural and scientific transformations resulting from the Scientific Revolution, the Enlightenment, and the advent of the modern critical study of religion.

courses.title: Christianity in the Contemporary World
courses.desc: Christianity in the 20th and 21st centuries. Relationship of Christianity to globalization, industrialization, mass media, and the contemporary secular state. Focus on Christianity in America and developing nations, and on the relationship of established Christian institutions to new Christian movements.

courses.title: Life, Meaning & Identity
courses.desc: Study of religious lives, the quest for meaning and for personal identity; how religions frame the problems of life; how cultural and personal crises affect youthful identity; the nature and structure of dreams, myths, and ideals.

courses.title: Persuasion & Conviction in Religious Tradition
courses.desc: Selected topics in religious argument. Familiarizes students with the discourse structures of religious persuasion and enables them to perform analysis of such texts. Covers argument styles and structures used in ethics, theology, and preaching.

courses.title: Mysticism
courses.prereqs: One lower division Religious Studies course.
courses.desc: Historical and descriptive analysis of selected key figures in mystical traditions and readings of representative mystical texts. Analytic term paper.

courses.title: Religion, Magic & Science
courses.desc: Religion, magic, and science from the middle ages to the present. Contrast between modern scientific methodology and religious and magical thinking.

courses.title: Studies in Biblical Texts
courses.desc: Study of a book from the Prophets or writings from critical, historical, and religious perspectives.

courses.title: Sex & Gender in the Bible
courses.desc: Gender and sexuality in the Bible and its interpretation in Judaism and Christianity. Femininity and masculinity; gender roles; homosexuality; sexual violence. Historical origins in the ancient world; influence on contemporary views.

courses.title: Topics in Judaism
courses.desc: Examination of selected aspects of Jewish life, religion, or literature. Potential topics include: Jewish Perspectives on Jesus; The Golem: History and Legend; Sexuality and Gender in Late Antique Judaism and Early Christianity.

courses.title: Dead Sea Scrolls, Apocrypha, & Pseudepigrapha
courses.desc: Survey of the Dead Sea Scrolls, apocryphal and pseudepigraphical writings of Judaism and Christianity and their historical, social, and religious importance.

courses.title: The Formation of the Rabbinic Tradition
courses.desc: Survey of the classical rabbinic Jewish texts such as the Talmud and of the social and historical contexts of their production in Palestine and Babylonia.

courses.title: Topics in Religious Studies
courses.prereqs: RST 001 or RST 002 or RST 003A or RST 003B or RST 003C;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Thematic study of a phenomenon in more than one religious tradition or of the relationship between religion and another cultural phenomenon. Topics may include archeology and the Bible, women and religion, religion and violence.

courses.title: Topics in Mediterranean Ancient Religion
courses.desc: Thematic study of specific sociological, literary or theological theme across the religious traditions of the ancient Mediterranean/Near East: Greek and Roman religions, Judaism, Christianity, Zoroastrianism, Manichaeism, etc. Topics may include creation, sacrifice, priesthoods, prophecies, holy books, the afterlife.

courses.title: The Bible & Film
courses.desc: Examination of the uses of the Judeo-Christian Scriptures in film. Topics include dramatic depictions of biblical stories, the tension between science and religion, allegorical treatments of biblical themes, and the problems of religious conviction.

courses.title: Topics in Jainism
courses.desc: Thematic study of specific periods, literary movements, sects and important figures within Jainism from a ranges of disciplinary perspectives.

courses.title: Topics in Buddhism
courses.desc: Thematic exploration of historic developments, periods, regions and sects in Buddhism from an interdisciplinary perspective.

courses.title: Topics in Hinduism
courses.desc: Thematic study of specific periods, movements, leaders, regions, ethics or philosophies within Hinduism from an interdisciplinary perspective.

courses.title: Christian Theology
courses.desc: Historical and systematic introduction to Christian doctrine, with attention to divergent traditions and the problem of orthodoxy and heresy.

courses.title: New Testament Literature: Synoptic Gospels
courses.desc: Life and thought of the early Church as reflected by the Synoptic Tradition; Matthew, Mark, Luke and Acts. Offered every third year to alternate with RST 141B, RST 141C.

courses.title: New Testament Literature: John
courses.desc: Life and thought of the early Church as reflected by the Johannine Tradition; the Gospel and letters of John. Offered every third year to alternate with RST 141A, RST 141C.

courses.title: New Testament Literature: Paul
courses.desc: Life and thought of the early Church as reflected by the Pauline tradition. The letters of Paul. Offered every third year to alternate with RST 141A, RST 141B.

courses.title: New Testament Apocrypha
courses.desc: Extra-canonical Christian writings and their reception, from antiquity to the present. Emphasis on the importance of New Testament figures both as literary characters and as authors within different Christian traditions.

courses.title: History of the Bible
courses.desc: History of the formation of the Christian biblical canon, with emphasis on differences between Christian traditions; survey of translations and adaptations of biblical narrative in Christianity, Judaism, and Islam, as well as in contemporary culture.

courses.title: Contemporary American Religion
courses.desc: Examination of several major movements and phenomena in 20th-century American religion.

courses.title: Religious Ethics
courses.desc: Study of the religious bases of ethics through examination of ethical problems that arise in different religious cultures around the world and in nations where multiple religious cultures face similar issues.

courses.title: The Hindu Temple
courses.desc: Comparative history of architecture and symbolism of the Hindu Temple in India, Southeast Asia and the United States. Attention to the temple as expression of religious knowledge, political authority, and cultural heritage through the lens of colonialism and postcolonialism.

courses.title: Bhakti: Indian Devotional Traditions to 1200 CE
courses.desc: Exploration of Indian devotional traditions through literary, visual, and performance culture. Emphasis on period up to 1200 CE in southern India.

courses.title: Religion & the Performing Arts in India
courses.prereqs: RST 030;  RST 068;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Survey of religion and performing arts in India. Emphasis on the influence of colonialism, nationalism, and regionalism on the history of Indian performing arts.

courses.title: Hindu Women & Goddesses
courses.desc: Hindu goddesses and the religious lives of Hindu women in India and the diaspora.

courses.title: The Ramayana
courses.desc: Exploration of the Indian epic, Ramayana, through the lens of literature, performance, and visual art. Emphasis on the text's diversity and its contemporary global relevance. Topics include Ramayanas in Southeast Asia, and in various South Asian diaspora communities.

courses.title: The Mahabharata
courses.desc: Survey of the Indian epic, the Mahabharata, through textual, oral, and visual culture.

courses.title: Introduction to Islamic Thought
courses.desc: The development of Islamic thought from the first centuries of Islam to the 18th century. Theology, philosophy, ethics, Sufism, historiography, political theory, fundamentalism, al-Farabi, al-Ghazzali, Ibn Rushd, Tusi, Ibn al-Arabi, Rumi, Molla Sadra, Ibn Khaldun, Ibn Abd al-Wahhab.

courses.title: Modern Islam
courses.desc: Response of Islam to modernity: secularism, reformism, fundamentalism. Islam and imperialism, women, media and immigration. Islamic modernism, political Islam, Islam in Europe and America.

courses.title: Modern Islam: Authority & Tradition In Process
courses.desc: Survey of Islamic thought, social organization, politics from 18th century through present. Focus on changing notations of moral authority and tradition. Concentration on Middle East and South Asia with sustained treatment of North American engagements with the Islamic world.

courses.title: Introduction to Islamic Law
courses.desc: The development of Islamic law in the formative centuries of Islam, ca. 600-1000, as well as its adaptation to changing economic, social, and political conditions in subsequent periods. Legal schools, legal theory, the Shari'a, reformist movements, human rights.

courses.title: Social Life of Islam
courses.desc: Introduction to culture and social life in Muslim societies.  Focus on the plurality of traditions in Muslim faith, reason, and everyday practice.  Special attention to Muslim rituals, ethical values, verbal genres, family life, sexuality and veiling, and youth culture.

courses.title: Islam in Asia
courses.desc: Islam as a lived religion in the Indian sub-continent, Central Asia, China, and Southeast Asia.  Emphasis is on primary sources studied comparatively and historically.

courses.title: Religion & Media in the Arab World
courses.desc: Exploration of the role and experience of media technologies in the Arab world. Study of digital and electronic media as well as alternative media practices. Investigation of new trends in political activism and identity formation.

courses.title: Buddhism
courses.desc: Buddhism in its pan-Asian manifestations, from its beginning in India to its development in Sri Lanka and Southeast Asia, Central Asia, China and Japan; teachings and practices, socio-political and cultural impact.

courses.title: Buddhist Art
courses.desc: A historical survey of Buddhist art in relation to the development of Buddhist doctrine and philosophy.

courses.title: Ch'an (Zen) Buddhism
courses.desc: Doctrines and methods of the Ch'an Buddhism, both ancient and modern. Review of ritual techniques, including meditation.

courses.title: Chinese Intellectual Traditions: Daoist Traditions
courses.prereqs: A course in Chinese history recommended.
courses.desc: English-language survey of key Daoist texts and scholarship. Topics include Daoist concepts of the cosmos, the natural world, scripture, the body, and immortality; Daoist divinities; Daoism and the state.

courses.title: Popular Religious Art in India
courses.desc: Survey of Indian popular religious art in prints, trade labels, comics and photographs.

courses.title: Hindu Gods & Hindu Symbols
courses.prereqs: RST 068: Hinduism or RST 069: Hindu Mythology recommended, but not required.
courses.desc: A historical survey of the development of the language of symbolism and iconography in Hinduism.

courses.title: Religion & Media
courses.desc: Many communities are finding global media technologies useful for religious practice. Examines how religious revitalization is historically situated. Phenomenological approach will enable students to situate media and religion within the social and material world of practitioners.

courses.title: Accelerated Intensive Elementary Russian
courses.desc: Special 12-week accelerated, summer session intensive combining the work of RUS 001, RUS 002, and RUS 003. Introduction to Russian grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communication.

courses.title: Advanced Russian
courses.desc: Topics in Russian. Grammar for the advanced student. Reading and discussion of journalistic texts and classic and contemporary literature. Conversation exercises utilizing literary and colloquial variants of current Russian speech.

courses.title: Advanced Russian
courses.desc: Continuation of RUS 101A. Topics in Russian grammar for the advanced student. Reading and discussion of journalistic texts and classic and contemporary literature. Conversational exercises utilizing literary and colloquial variants of current Russian speech.

courses.title: Advanced Russian
courses.desc: Continuation of RUS 101B. Topics in Russian grammar for the advanced student. Reading and discussion of journalistic texts and classic and contemporary literature. Conversational exercises utilizing literary and colloquial variants of current Russian speech.

courses.title: Russian Composition
courses.desc: Practice in writing Russian.  One composition on a different topic each week.  Topics include: history, geography, politics, and literature of Russia; comparison of Russian and American lifestyles; current events.  Conducted in Russian.

courses.title: Topics in Russian Literature & Culture
courses.prereqs: Upper division standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Knowledge of Russian not required. Investigation of significant themes and issues of Russian literature and culture within their European context.

courses.title: 19th-Century Russian Literature
courses.prereqs: RUS 101C when offered in Russian; no prerequisite when offered in English.
courses.desc: Study of Russian literature (prose fiction, drama, poetry) from the period between 1800 and the end of the 19th century. May include authors like Pushkin, Lermontov, Gogol, Turgenev, Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Chekhov. Offered alternately in English or Russian.

courses.title: 20th-Century Russian Literature
courses.prereqs: RUS 101C when offered in Russian; no prerequisite when offered in English.
courses.desc: Study of Russian literature (prose, drama, poetry) from the period between 1900 and the end of the 20th century. Authors like Y. Olesha, M. Bulgakov, D. Kharms, and L. Petrushevskaia. Taught in Russian.

courses.title: The Russian Theater
courses.desc: The main works of Russian dramatists from Fonvizin to the present, including Gogol, Turgenev, Tolstoy, Ostrovsky, Chekhov, Blok, Mayakovsky, Kharms.  Conducted in Russian.

courses.title: Russian Film
courses.desc: History of Russian film; film & social revolution, the cult of Stalin, dissident visions; film & the collapse of the Soviet empire; gender and the nation in Russian film. Taught in English; Russian films with English subtitles.

courses.title: Contemporary Russian Culture
courses.desc: Trends in Russian culture and the relationship between artists and the government. Topics: recent changes in the cultural scene, postmodernist trends in literature, visual art, film, and theater.

courses.title: Post-Soviet Literature
courses.desc: Major authors and trends in Russian literature in post-1991 period. Discussion of impact of economic, social, and cultural turmoil of post-Soviet period on literary marketplace. Analysis of development of literary postmodernism in Russia.

courses.title: Pushkin
courses.desc: Three major periods of Pushkin's poetical works: his early Lyceum verse; his poetry of the early 1820s; and the mature period. Further study of Pushkin's prose fiction, drama, and journalism.

courses.title: Dostoevsky (in English)
courses.desc: Reading and analysis of Dostoevskys principal works such as Crime and Punishment, The Idiot, The Brothers Karamazov, and The Diary. Study of social and political views as reflected in Dostoevskys works.

courses.title: Tolstoy (in English)
courses.desc: Study of Leo Tolstoy's literary evolution and moral quest. Readings include his Confession, a major novel such as War and Peace or Anna Karenina, and representative shorter fiction.

courses.title: Women in Russian Culture
courses.desc: Study of the representation of women in contemporary Russian fiction and film. Exploration of issues such as family dynamics/motherhood, sexuality, work, and women's relationship to the state. Offered in English.

courses.title: Chekhov (in English)
courses.desc: Examination of Chekhov's short stories and major plays, such as The Seagull, Uncle Vanya, The Three Sisters, The Cherry Orchard, and Ivanov, in the broader cultural context of European and Russian fin de siecle.

courses.title: Irrigation Practices for an Urban Environment
courses.desc: Basic design, installation, and operation principles of irrigation systems for turf and landscape: golf courses, parks, highways, public buildings, etc. Emphasis on hardware association with sprinkler and drip/trickle systems.

courses.title: Critical Inquiry into Contemporary Issues
courses.desc: Contemporary issues, including global population trends, economic and environmental changes, cultural diversity and biodiversity, nutrition and food safety, fiber and textiles, changing consumer cultures. Inquiry processes emphasize ethics, multiple disciplines, and multiple perspectives.

courses.title: Feeding the World: Influences on the Global Food Supply
courses.desc: Scientific principles and dynamic interactions involved in food production, food processing, nutrition, and agribusiness.  Physical, biological and social science issues influencing the availability and safety of the food supply worldwide.

courses.title: Science, Technology & Society
courses.desc: Impact of developments in science and technology on the individual in society and how economics, politics, culture and values affect technological development.

courses.title: Pathways to Discovery: Science & Society
courses.desc: Highlights a current issue and/or controversy found in contemporary society and looks at how this problem impacts and is affected by the physical, social and biological sciences. Topics vary.

courses.title: Career Discovery Seminar
courses.desc: Overview of skills needed to find and secure career opportunities, including job searches, professional communication, participation in informational and job interviews as both interviewer and interviewee, preparation of resumes and cover letters. Exploration of diverse career options.

courses.title: Terrorism & War
courses.desc: Exploration of terrorism and war from science and social sciences perspectives. Terrorist cells and groups; biological, chemical, nuclear, and environmental terrorism; intelligence gathering and espionage; military strategy; genocide; epochal wars; clash of civilizations; nation building; and future global scenarios.

courses.title: Water Quality at Risk
courses.desc: Natural and human threats to water quality. Balance of science and policy in all aspects of attaining, maintaining, and managing water quality, water contamination. Decoding popular media coverage of water quality and water contamination.

courses.title: Crisis in the Environment
courses.desc: Explores contemporary environmental issues by examining the causes, effects and solutions to a wide range of environmental problems facing the global ecosystem. Integrated discussion of political, societal and economic impact linkages with environmental problems. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Water, Power, Society
courses.desc: Water resources issues. How water has been used to gain and wield socio-political power. Water resources development in California  related to current and future sustainability of water quantity and quality. Roles of science and policy in solving water problems.

courses.title: California Geography
courses.desc: Introduction to cultural/societal patterns of California and their relationship to natural resources, biomes,geomorphology, and physiography. Focus on diversity of California's environments and their impacts on and alterations by human activities. Environmental issues in the State.

courses.title: Plants & Society
courses.desc: Dependence of human societies on plant and plant products. Plants as resources for food, fiber, health, enjoyment and environmental services. Sustainable uses of plants for food production, raw materials, bioenergy, and environmental conservation. Global population growth and future food supplies.

courses.title: Disease & Society
courses.desc: Introduction to the concept of disease, the societal and personal impacts of past, present and future diseases, and the science behind disease discoveries, causes, evolution, diagnosis, treatment, and prevention.

courses.title: Forests & Society
courses.desc: Sociology, natural history and current issues of the world's forests. Application of scientific principles in outdoor laboratories and on-campus field trips.

courses.title: Soil, Water, & Civilizations
courses.desc: Exploring past civilizations and examining how management of soil, water, and natural resources allowed them to flourish, decline, or perhaps fail. Important issues include agricultural practices, deforestation, water quality, and land management.

courses.title: GIS & Society
courses.desc: Geographic Information Systems (GIS) as a spatial technology and a tool for change in society. Evaluate physical, biological and social impact of GIS in the context of case studies such as land, water and community planning.

courses.title: Genetics & Society
courses.desc: Basic concepts of genetics, modern methods of biotechnology, the process of scientific discovery and the public perception of the process; present and future impact of genetics on society.

courses.title: Global Climate Change: Convergence of Biological, Geophysical, & Social Sciences
courses.desc: Causes of global climate change and the biological, geophysical, and social consequences of such change. Methods used by different scientists for predicting future events. Complexity of global affairs. Decision making under uncertainty.

courses.title: Mushrooms, Molds, & Society
courses.desc: Fungi as organisms with which humans interact daily, societal issues arising from these interactions. Fungi in medicine, religion, agriculture, and industry, as well as cultural perceptions of fungi.

courses.title: Germs: The Good, the Bad, & the Ugly
courses.desc: Impact of microorganisms on Earth, Humans and Society. Historical, scientific, and contemporary issues dealing with microbes on natural and built environments.

courses.title: Photography: Bridging Art & Science
courses.desc: Photography is used to explore the common ground between art and science. Photographic processes, creativity and aesthetics, chaos and order, principles of space, time and light. Photographic interpretation and documentation of the natural world. Camera required.

courses.title: Understanding Performance: Appreciation of Modern Theatre, Dance, Film & Performance Art for the Humanities & Sciences
courses.desc: Relevance of theatre and performance to modern culture, science and society. Approaches to theatre/dance/media/performance art, integrated into Mondavi Centre for the Arts and Theatre and Dance Department programs.

courses.title: Earth, Water, Science, Song
courses.desc: Fusion of water and soil science with performing arts. Creative communication of scientific concepts and facts through exercises in song writing and poetry. Design, discuss and conduct public performances related to the functioning of the natural world.

courses.title: Energy, Materials, & Design Over Time
courses.desc: Global history of design across time, viewed through the lens of the effects of the creation and discovery of new energy sources, processes, and materials on design.

courses.title: Genetic Engineering in Medicine, Agriculture, & Law
courses.desc: Historical and scientific study of the impact of genetic engineering in medicine, agriculture, and law, including examination of social, ethical, and legal issues raised. Offered in a distance-learning format.

courses.title: Environmental Change, Disease & Public Health
courses.desc: Analysis of environmental changes from pre-history to the present and their influence on disease distribution, virulence and public health. Focus on critical study of many human-driven environmental changes and the accelerated transformation/spread of pathogens under globalization.

courses.title: Applications of Evolution in Medicine, Human Behavior, & Agriculture
courses.desc: Applications of evolutionary biology in medicine, human behavior, and agriculture. Examination of the imprint of evolution on the human life cycle from conception to death.

courses.title: Science & Contemporary Societal Issues
courses.desc: Study of a contemporary societal issue/problem emphasizing critical thinking with information drawn from several disciplines. Multiple instructors illustrate the necessity of an interdisciplinary and cooperative approach in solving important issues. Topics will vary.

courses.title: Global Poverty: Critical Thinking & Taking Action
courses.desc: Social science and engineering analysis of causes and effects of world poverty and of policies to reduce it via economic growth, foreign aid, and community-level interventions; e.g., in potable water, sanitation, lighting, small scale energy, irrigation, health and microfinance.

courses.title: Contemporary Leadership
courses.desc: Leadership, including issues, skills, and practices as they relate to individuals, organizations, diverse social settings and communities. Written and verbal communications, personality styles for collaborative work, and ethics.

courses.title: Digital Communication in Agricultural, Environmental, & Human Sciences
courses.desc: Use digital media to communicate a succinct, compelling story. In lecture, discussion and activities, create storyboards and scripts, use video, audio, and editing technology, and produce a short media-rich video to effectively convey a message.

courses.title: Introduction to Sociology
courses.desc: Principles and basic concepts of sociology. The study of groups, culture, collective behavior, classes and caste, community and ecology, role, status, and personality.

courses.title: Self & Society
courses.desc: Exploration of how self and identity are formed and transformed by socialization and social interaction in relation to roles, groups, institutions, power, and social change. Consideration of how people make decisions, fall in love, and come to blows.

courses.title: Social Problems
courses.desc: General sociological consideration of contemporary social problems in relation to sociocultural change and programs for improvement.

courses.title: Immigration & Opportunity
courses.desc: Social and demographic analysis of immigration: motives and experiences of immigrants; immigration and social mobility; immigration, assimilation, and social change; multicultural societies. Detailed study of immigration into the U.S., with comparative studies of Europe, Australia, and other host countries.

courses.title: Global Social Change: An Introduction to Macrosociology
courses.desc: Introduction to change and diversity in world history, including the United States. Examines population and family, technological change and economic development, power and status, culture and identity.

courses.title: Health & Illness
courses.desc: Introduction to the sociology of health and illness, including social determinants of health, social inequalities in health/health disparities, social construction of health, the organization of health care, and the politics of health care reform.

courses.title: Sociology of Labor & Employment
courses.desc: Labor and employment issues in the contemporary United States with some use of historical and comparative materials. Topics include strategies pursued by employers and employees, labor market discrimination and the role of social policies in shaping labor markets.

courses.title: Data Visualization in the Social Sciences
courses.desc: Introduction to quantitative data across the social sciences (Communications, Political Science, Psychology, Sociology, and other disciplines). Transforming data, describing data, producing graphs, visual reasoning, and interpretations.

courses.title: Sociology of Popular Culture
courses.desc: Social mechanisms that shape modern popular culture. High, folk, and mass culture: historical emergence of popular culture. Mass media, commercialization, ideology and cultural styles. Theories and methods for analyzing cultural expressions in pop music, street art, film, television, and advertising.

courses.title: Intercultural Relations in Multicultural Societies
courses.desc: Macro-structural analysis of contemporary multicultural societies; immigration and assimilation in comparative perspective; social construction of racial and ethnic group identities; ethnicity and gender; group conflict and cooperation; controversies surrounding multiculturalism. First course in a two-course Multicultural Immersion Program.

courses.title: Intercultural Relations in Multicultural Societies
courses.desc: Social-psychological analysis of personal experiences living in a multicultural society; conforming to or rejecting group identity or stereotypes; managing and reducing conflict; cross-cultural communication; promises and problems of diversity at UC Davis. Second course in a two-course Multicultural Immersion Program.

courses.title: Introduction to Social Research
courses.desc:
Examination of the methodological problems of social research. Selection
and definition of problems of investigation, data-gathering techniques, and sampling.

courses.title: Introduction to Social Research
courses.desc: Data-analysis techniques, measurement, scaling, multivariate analysis, and quantitative measures of association.

courses.title: Origins of Modern Sociological Theory
courses.desc: Origins of modern sociological thought. Special emphasis on three major theorists from the classical tradition of 19th-century European social thought: Karl Marx, Max Weber, and Emile Durkheim.

courses.title: Evaluation Research Methods
courses.prereqs: SOC 001 or SOC 002 or SOC 003 recommended; SOC 046A and SOC 046B recommended.
courses.desc: Surveys applications of research methods to the evaluation of social programs, primarily emphasizing methodological issues, e.g., research design and data collection; uses of evaluation research are also discussed and placed in theoretical context. Participation in an evaluation project.

courses.title: The Political Economy of International Migration
courses.prereqs: SOC 001, SOC 002, SOC 003, or SOC 004 recommended.
courses.desc: Analysis of worldwide migration patterns, and social scientific theories of international and transnational migration. Focus in economical, political, and social impact of immigration and potential for international and regional cooperation.

courses.title: Intermediate Social Statistics
courses.desc: Intermediate level course in statistical analysis of social data, emphasizing the logic and use of statistical measures, procedures, and mathematical models especially relevant to sociological analysis.

courses.title: Political Sociology
courses.desc: Relation of social cleavages and social cohesion to the functioning of political institutions; the social bases of local and national power structures; social sources of political movement, analysis of concepts of alienation, revolution, ideology, ruling class, and elite.

courses.title: Deviance
courses.desc:
Social structural sources, institutional practices and microprocesses
associated with illegality, evil, disease, immorality, disability, racial and class differences, citizenship, and the body. Special emphasis on expert knowledge and the production and management of social difference.

courses.title: Sociology of Adolescence
courses.desc: Chronological age and social status; analysis of social processes bearing upon the socialization of children and adolescents. The emergence of youth cultures. Generational succession as a cultural problem.

courses.title: Education & Inequality in the U.S.
courses.desc: Functions of schooling in contemporary U.S. society. Racial, ethnic, social class, and gender inequalities in student outcomes. Consideration of classic and current controversies in the sociology of education and education policy.

courses.title: Sociology of Culture
courses.desc: Sociological approaches to study of historical and contemporary culture and mass media, and their structuring in relation to social actors, institutions, stratification, power, the production of culture, audiences, and the significance of culture in processes of change.

courses.title: Social Interaction
courses.desc: Everyday interaction in natural settings; ethnographic approaches to the understanding of social meanings, situations, personal identity and human relationships. Particular attention to the work of Erving Goffman and to principles of field observation and qualitative analysis.

courses.title: Interracial Interpersonal Dynamics
courses.desc: Analysis of the influences of cultural differences and racial stratification on interpersonal interaction in instrumental settings (e.g., work, education, political action) and intimate settings (e.g., friendship, love, marriage, family). Minority/majority relationships.

courses.title: Sociology of Black Experience in America
courses.desc: Survey of historical and contemporary theoretical sociological perspectives on the Black experience in United States. Emphasis on comparisons of Black sociological perspectives and mainstream perspectives of specific sociologists.

courses.title: Race Relations
courses.desc: Functions of the social definitions of race and racial groups. Analysis of racial conflict, oppression, and other forms of ethnic stratification. Models of ethnic interaction and social change. Emphasis on racial relationships within the U.S.

courses.title: The Family
courses.desc: Contemporary family life in historical and cross-cultural perspective. How different family forms arose, their significance today and prospects for further family change. Attention to power relations within and beyond the family and to the social implications of family transformation.

courses.title: The Sociology of Gender
courses.desc: Analysis of biological, psychological, cultural and structural conditions underlying the status and roles of men and women in contemporary society, drawing on a historical and comparative perspective.

courses.title: Sexual Stratification & Politics
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  SOC 001, SOC 002, or SOC 003 recommended.
courses.desc: Analysis of origins, dynamics, and social implications of sexual stratification. Examination of classical and contemporary theorists such as Engels, Freud, J.S. Mill, de Beauvoir, Juliet Mitchell, D. Dinnerstein. Attention to selected issues in social movements for and against sexual equality.

courses.title: Social Relationships
courses.desc: Social and cultural factors influencing friendships and intimate relationships. Topics include relationship development, relationship maintenance, and relationship loss.

courses.title: African American Society & Culture 1790 to 1990
courses.desc: Political and social transformations of African American communities between 1790 and 1990, as seen through film, literature, and music. Topics include: Black consciousness, Afro-Slave culture, The Harlem Renaissance, and contemporary Hip Hop.

courses.title: Economic Sociology
courses.desc: Overview of the rapidly growing field of economic sociology. Focus on variations in the ways that markets are organized. The relationship between individual and collective rationality will also be emphasized.

courses.title: Corporations & Society
courses.desc: Study of the history and power of the modern corporation; corporate organization; politics, the state, and the corporation; labor unions and the labor process; competition, regulation and international markets; the multinational and conglomerate corporation; and mass markets and consumerism.

courses.title: Social Stratification
courses.desc: Systems of social ranking, theories of stratification; power, prestige, culture, and styles of life of various social classes; social mobility and its consequences for social structure.

courses.title: Industrialization & Social Change
courses.desc: Selected technological and social factors. Preconditions of economic development and industrialization. Social, political, and cultural issues at various levels of economic development. Major historical differences and major current trends. Emphasis either on highly industrialized countries or on less developed countries.

courses.title: Urban Society
courses.desc: Theories of city origins. Analysis of the historic process of urbanization and of varying city types. Comparison of American and European experience of metropolitanization,counterurbanization,and neighborhood change. Consideration of competing theories of urban growth and change and competing visions of the urban future.

courses.title: Sociology of City Life
courses.desc: Critical dissection of the loss of community issue. Analysis of the organization of primary ties in the city, of the culture of urban public life and of the learning of city skills.

courses.title: Agriculture & Society
courses.desc: Development of agriculture as a major enterprise in modern society with the concomitant reduction in the labor force and family farms. Analysis of issues including mechanization, migrant labor, corporate farming, and public resource policy.

courses.title: Sociology of Third World Development
courses.desc: Introduction to theories and contemporary issues in the sociology of development. Topics such as urbanization, rural/agrarian change, class, status groups, international division of labor, sectoral shifts, international capital, informal economy, gender, and political processes are analyzed within a comparative-historical framework.

courses.title: Sociology of Religion
courses.desc: Relationship between social structures and religions. The social setting of the major world religions. Religious innovators and institutionalization (churches, sects, cults). Secularization in the modern world and the rise of secular ideologies.

courses.title: Sociological Perspectives on East Asia
courses.desc: Sociological theories and concepts applied toward understanding East Asian society. Emphasis on the political structure, stratification, and economy in China and Japan. Analysis of historical and contemporary similarities and differences.

courses.title: Collective Behavior
courses.desc: Study of behavior of human crowds and masses in extraordinary circumstances, including crowd panics, mass scares, collective protests, riots, revolutionary situations, ecstatic and revivalist gatherings, crazes, fads, and fashions.

courses.title: Criminology
courses.desc: Sociological analysis of criminal behavior in relation to social structure and the criminalization process.

courses.title: The Criminal Justice System
courses.desc: Sociological analysis of the different components of the criminal justice system including the emergence and interpretation of criminal laws, the contemporary roles and functions of the police, criminal courts and correctional institutions.

courses.title: Juvenile Delinquency
courses.desc: Study of juvenile delinquency in relation to the family, peer groups, community, and institutional structures. Consideration of processing of the delinquent by formal agencies of control.

courses.title: The Sociology of Childhood
courses.desc: Contemporary childhood in historical, cross-cultural, and global perspectives. Examine changes in understanding of the nature of childhood and "best interests of the child" by class, race, gender, geographic region, and historical period.

courses.title: Sociology of Law
courses.desc: Law considered as social control; relation of legal institutions to society as affecting judicial decision making and administration of justice. Lawyers as an occupational group. Legal reform.

courses.title: Social Movements
courses.desc: Analysis of several aspects of social movements: mobilization, forms of organization, ideology, recruitment, leadership, strategies and tactics, development, effects. Frequent use of sound and film materials.

courses.title: Social Conflict
courses.desc: Analysis of the causes, dynamics, and regulation of social conflict within and between various kinds of social groupings with particular reference to nonviolent methods of waging and regulating conflict.

courses.title: Work, Employment, & Careers in the 21st Century
courses.desc: Historical and contemporary overview of employment, work, and occupations in American society. Study of authority and power relations, labor markets, control systems, stratification, and corporate structures, and how these factors shape work in diverse or organizational and employment setting.

courses.title: Sociology of the Environment
courses.desc: Production, consumption, and urban expansion. Basic social logics surrounding current problems of resource scarcity (environmental extractions) and excess wastes (environmental additions). Ways that society can change and re-organize itself to become more environmentally conscious and hence ecologically sustainable.

courses.title: The Civil Justice System
courses.desc: Empirical studies of the different aspects of the civil justice system in the United States and Global Society including the litigation, juries, civil rights, and international laws relating to trade, the environment, and human rights.

courses.title: Society, Culture, & Health
courses.prereqs: SOC 001, SOC 002, SOC 003, or SOC 006 recommended.
courses.desc: Analysis of how socio-cultural factors shape illness experience. Evaluation of how certain conditions come to be understood as health conditions; illness identities and biographies; doctor-patient interactions; biomedical cultures; how race, ethnicity, and gender shape health practices.

courses.title: Society, Culture, & Health
courses.prereqs: SOC 001, SOC 002, SOC 003, or SOC 006 recommended.
courses.desc: Analysis of how socio-cultural factors shape illness experience. Evaluation of how certain conditions come to be understood as health conditions; illness identities and biographies; doctor-patient interactions; biomedical cultures; and how race, ethnicity, and gender shape health practices.

courses.title: Population Health: Social Determinants & Disparities in Health
courses.prereqs: SOC 001, SOC 002, SOC 003, or SOC 006 recommended.
courses.desc: Survey of the social determinants and disparities in health: measurement of population health; health transitions and global disparities; domestic disparities in health by class, race/ethnicity, nativity, gender, and sexual orientation; social determinants including social support, social stress, neighborhoods, and policy.

courses.title: Health Policy & Politics
courses.prereqs: SOC 001, SOC 002, SOC 003, or SOC 006 recommended.
courses.desc: Introduction to health policy and politics, including health care access and delivery, and policies related to health inequalities, the social determinants of illness and health behaviors.

courses.title: Population
courses.desc: Introduction to the study of human population, including theories and statistical measures; social causes and consequences of population trends; changes in population structure; geographical distribution, migration, sociopsychological factors affecting fertility.

courses.title: Sociology of Violence & Inequality
courses.desc: How systems of social inequality organize the practice of violence. Definitions of violence and issues affecting the social capacity for violence. Analysis and comparison of different forms of violence associated with race, class, gender relations and social organization.

courses.title: Sociology Through Literature
courses.desc: Introduction to analysis of literature as sociological data. Reading of numerous works on American and other societies by authors such as Steinbeck, Lewis, Dreiser, Schulberg, Orwell, etc.

courses.title: American Jewish Identities & Communities
courses.desc: Sociology of Jewish life, analyzing challenges to Jewish identity and community in the diaspora. Diversity within the Jewish community, Americanization, women, new immigrants, post-Holocaust Jewish identity, and LGBT Jews.

courses.title: Sociology of Knowledge, Science, & Scientific Knowledge
courses.desc: Social, cultural, and historical dimensions of knowledge, especially scientific knowledge. Problems, methods, and theory in sociology of scientific knowledge. Laboratory and historical case studies. Scientific and technical knowledge in institutional and organizational contexts.

courses.title: Punishment & Corrections
courses.desc: Origins, characteristics, and consequences of various sanctions and punishment regimes including fines, banishment, incarceration, deportation, and execution.

courses.title: Complex Organizations
courses.desc:
Develops a sociological approach to organizations theory. Designed to
introduce sociological concepts, address the alternative psychological and economic models, and involve students in the practice of organizational analysis.

courses.title: Social Policy
courses.desc: Examination of social policies that affect the well-being of individuals, families and groups, including such policies as old-age pensions, health insurance, and aid to the poor.

courses.title: Markets, Culture & Inequality in China
courses.desc: Economic and political systems and patterns of social interaction and inequality in China. State and corporate structures and practices, market and consumer behaviors, social mobility and stratification, protest and resistance.

courses.title: Workshop in Field Research
courses.prereqs: SOC 046A;  (SOC 192 (can be concurrent) or SOC 199 (can be concurrent));  SOC 192 or SOC 199 required concurrently for 2-4 units; senior standing.
courses.desc: Overview of the process of collecting, recording, analyzing, and reporting qualitative social data.  Emphasis on application of principles; each participant completes an original research project.

courses.title: Social Research
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Comparative survey of sociological inquiry, taught as a practicum. Philosophy of social science; values and research; research agendas and research problem formulations; research process; explanations; interpretation; study design; concept formation, measure, sampling, data acquisition, inference; rhetoric and presentation of findings.

courses.title: Quantitative Analysis in Sociology
courses.desc: Survey of the statistical models and methods that serve as a foundation for quantitative research in sociology, with an emphasis on multivariate regression analysis, as well as measurement theory and time series analysis.

courses.title: Methods of Quantitative Research
courses.desc: Principles of study design, examination of measurement, survey research methods and multivariate analysis. Stresses actual practice of techniques. Carry out quantitative data analysis using packaged computer programs.

courses.title: Sociology of Reproduction
courses.desc:
Recent social science scholarship in such areas as teenage pregnancy,
family planning, abortion, adoption, AIDS, and new reproductive technologies; focus on the current situation in the United States.

courses.title: Ethnic (Race) Relations
courses.desc: Advanced study of the determinants of ethnic groupings and their interrelationships. Major theme will be the patterns of ethnic stratification and causes of ethnic conflict. Specific focus upon dominance and resistance to dominance. Influence of social science research.

courses.title: Classical Sociological Theory
courses.desc: Introduces graduate students to the work of the main classical thinkers in the tradition of social theory, such as Marx, Durkheim, Weber, Simmel, Freud, G.H. Mead, and Parsons, locating them within the historical,cultural,and philosophical milieu in which their ideas originated.

courses.title: Theory in Contemporary Sociology
courses.desc: Explores the uses of theories in contemporary sociology by tracing their connections with classical sociological writings and their relations to broader theoretical concerns of contemporary social thought, with particular emphasis on relevance to the current historical, cultural and social milieu.

courses.title: Special Topics Seminar
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Research topics in Sociology. Specific topic will vary according to faculty interest and student demand.

courses.title: The Teaching of Sociology
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing; required for first-time teaching assistants.
courses.desc: Practical instruction in teaching methods for qualitative and quantitative courses. Pedagogical issues involved in critical sociological analysis.

courses.title: The Teaching of Sociology
courses.desc: Practical instruction in devising course syllabi, lectures and assignments for Associate-Instructors and others interested in college teaching. Discussion of pedagogical methods of teaching qualitative and quantitative courses.

courses.title: Elementary Spanish
courses.desc: Introduction to Spanish grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with special emphasis on communication.

courses.title: Accelerated Intensive Elementary Spanish
courses.desc: Introduction to Spanish grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communication. Special 12-week accelerated, intensive summer session combining the work of SPA 001, SPA 002 and SPA 003.

courses.title: Elementary Spanish
courses.desc: Introduction to Spanish grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with special emphasis on communication. May be taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country under the supervision of a UC Davis faculty/lecturer.

courses.title: Elementary Spanish
courses.desc: Introduction to Spanish grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with special emphasis on communication.

courses.title: Elementary Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPA 001 or SPA 001S or SPA 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Continuation of SPA 001 and SPA 001S in the areas of grammar and basic language skills.

courses.title: Elementary Spanish
courses.desc: Continuation of SPA 001 and SPA 001S in the areas of grammar and basic language skills. May be taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country under the supervision of UC Davis faculty/lecturer.

courses.title: Elementary Spanish
courses.desc: Continuation of SPA 001 or SPA 001S in the areas of grammar and basic language skills. Hybrid format combining classroom instruction with technologically based materials.

courses.title: Elementary Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPA 002 or SPA 002S or SPA 002V or SPA 002Y.
courses.desc: Completion of grammar sequence and continuing practice of all language skills using cultural texts.

courses.title: Elementary Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPA 002 or SPA 002S or SPA 002V or SPA 002Y.
courses.desc: Completion of grammar sequence and continuing practice of all language skills using cultural texts. May be taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country under the supervision of UC Davis faculty.

courses.title: Elementary Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPA 002 or SPA 002S or SPA 002V or SPA 002Y.
courses.desc: Completion of grammar sequence and continuing practice of all language skills using cultural texts. Hybrid format combining classroom instruction with technologically based materials.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPA 003 or SPA 003S or SPA 003V or SPA 003Y.
courses.desc: Review and development of grammar, vocabulary and composition acquired in the first year through exercises and reading of modern texts.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPA 003 or SPA 003S or SPA 003V or SPA 003Y.
courses.desc: Review and development of the grammar, vocabulary and composition acquired in the first year through exercises and reading of modern texts. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPA 003 or SPA 003S or SPA 003V or SPA 003Y.
courses.desc: Continuation of SPA 003, SPA 003S, SPA 003V and SPA 003Y in the areas of grammar and basic language skills. Hybrid format combining classroom instruction with technologically based materials where learning takes place both face-to-face and online.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPA 021 or SPA 021S or SPA 021V or SPA 021Y.
courses.desc: Development of all language skills through exercises and reading of modern texts. Development on more difficult grammar concepts and further practice on composition.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPA 021 or SPA 021S or SPA 021V or SPA 021Y.
courses.desc: Development of all language skills through exercises and reading of modern texts. Development of more difficult grammar concepts and further practice on composition. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPA 021 or SPA 021S or SPA 021V or SPA 021Y.
courses.desc: Continuation of SPA 021, SPA 021S, or SPA 021V in the areas of grammar and basic language skills. Online format combining synchronous chatting with technologically based materials.

courses.title: Spanish Composition I
courses.prereqs: SPA 022 or SPA 022S or SPA 022V or SPA 022Y.
courses.desc: Development of writing skills by way of reading, discussion, and analysis of authentic materials, literary texts, and videos. Selective review of grammar. Composition, journals, individual and group projects.

courses.title: Spanish Composition I
courses.prereqs: SPA 022 or SPA 022S or SPA 022V or SPA 022Y.
courses.desc: Development of writing skills by way of reading, discussion, and analysis of authentic materials, literary texts, and videos. Selective review of grammar. Composition, journals, individual and group projects. May be taught abroad in Spanish speaking country.

courses.title: Spanish Composition II
courses.desc: Development of advanced level writing skills, with emphasis on how to write argumentative prose, essays, and research papers. Introduction to the analysis of literary genres. Compositions, journals, individual and group projects.

courses.title: Spanish Composition II
courses.desc: Development of advanced level writing skills, with emphasis on how to write argumentative prose, essays, and research papers. Introduction to the analysis of literary genres. Compositions, journals, individual and group projects. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish for Native Speakers I
courses.prereqs: SPA 003 or SPA 003V or SPA 003Y;  Or equivalent course or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: First course of a three-quarter series designed to provide bilingual students whose native language is Spanish with the linguistic and learning skills required for successfully completing upper division courses in Spanish. Intensive review of grammar and composition.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish for Native Speakers II
courses.desc: Continuation of SPA 031, intensive review of grammar and composition. Development of all language skills through reading of modern texts, presentation/discussion of major ideas, vocabulary expansion, and writing essays on topics discussed. Designed for students whose native language is Spanish.

courses.title: Intermediate Spanish for Native Speakers III
courses.desc: Development of writing skills, with emphasis on experimenting with various writing styles: analytical, argumentative, and creative. Analytical review of literary genres. Written essays will be assigned. Students will develop a research paper. Designed for students whose native language is Spanish.

courses.title: Principles of Hispanic Literature & Criticism
courses.desc: Principles of literary criticism applied to the study of fiction, drama, poetry, and essay of major literary writers of the Hispanic world.

courses.title: Principles of Hispanic Literature & Criticism
courses.desc: Principles of literary criticism applied to the study of fiction, drama, poetry and essay of major literary writers of the Hispanic world. May be taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country under the supervision of a UC Davis faculty/lecturer.

courses.title: Advanced Spanish Composition
courses.desc: Practice in expository writing with emphasis on clarity and idiomatic expression. Practical application and review of selected grammar topics. (Part of former SPA 110A & SPA 110B.)

courses.title: The Structure of Spanish: Sounds & Words
courses.prereqs: (SPA 024 or SPA 033);  or Consent of Instructor.  LIN 001 recommended.
courses.desc: Linguistic description of the sound patterns of Spanish and how those sounds can be used to form larger units, such as morphemes and words. Theoretical and practical comparisons with English and with other Romance languages. (Former SPA 132.)

courses.title: The Structure of Spanish: Words & Phrases
courses.desc: Study of Spanish word and phrase structure, with special emphasis on the constituent structure of noun and verb phrases. Theoretical and practical comparisons with English and with other Romance languages. (Former SPA 131.)

courses.title: Spanish Pronunciation
courses.desc: Sound structure of modern Spanish; theoretical analysis of selected problems in pronunciation. Strongly recommended for prospective teachers of Spanish.

courses.title: Contrastive Analysis of English & Spanish
courses.prereqs: SPA 024 or SPA 033;  or Consent of Instructor.  SPA 111N and SPA 112N recommended.
courses.desc: Contrastive analysis of English and Spanish, error analysis, introduction to structuralist and transformational linguistics. Individual and group conferences. (Former SPA 137.)

courses.title: History of the Spanish Language
courses.prereqs: SPA 024 or SPA 033;  or Consent of Instructor.  LIN 001 recommended.
courses.desc: Spanish language from its roots in spoken Latin to modernity. Emphasis on the close relationship between historical events and language change, and the role that literature plays in language standardization.

courses.title: History of the Spanish Language
courses.prereqs: SPA 024 or SPA 033;  or Consent of Instructor.  LIN 001 recommended.
courses.desc: Spanish language from its roots in spoken Latin to modernity. Emphasis on the close relationship between historical events and language change, and the role that literature plays in language standardization. Taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country under the supervision of a UC Davis faculty/lecturer.

courses.title: Applied Spanish Linguistics
courses.prereqs: SPA 024 or SPA 033;  or Consent of Instructor.  LIN 001 recommended.
courses.desc: Exploration of the major theoretical and practical issues concerning learning Spanish as a second language. For students interested in teaching Spanish as a career. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Applied Spanish Linguistics
courses.prereqs: SPA 024 or SPA 033;  or Consent of Instructor.  LIN 001 recommended.
courses.desc: Exploration of the major theoretical and practical issues concerning learning Spanish as a second language. For students interested in teaching Spanish as a career. May be taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country, in Spanish, under the supervision of UC Davis faculty.

courses.title: Teaching Spanish as a Native Tongue in the U.S.: Praxis & Theory
courses.prereqs: SPA 024 or SPA 033;  or Consent of Instructor.  LIN 001 recommended.
courses.desc: Designed for students interested in teaching Spanish to native speakers. Focus on cultural diversity of the Spanish speaking population in the United States; applied language teaching methodologies in the context of teaching Spanish to native speakers at different levels.

courses.title: Topics in Spanish Linguistics
courses.desc: Study of specialized topics in Spanish linguistics, for example: language and use; text and context; language and society; bilingualism; Spanish dialectology; syntax and semantics.

courses.title: Survey of Spanish Literature to 1700
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Survey of Spanish literature (narrative, poetry and drama) to 1700, Emphasis on the multicultural birth of the Spanish culture, the formation and growth of the Spanish language and letters through its written records and the literature of the early period.

courses.title: Survey of Spanish Literature: 1700 to Present
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Survey of modern Spanish literature, providing an overview of main literary movements (romanticism, realism, naturalism, modernism, avantgarde). Emphasis on the philosophical and historical background and on the European context for modern Spanish literature. (Part of former SPA 104A & SPA 104B.)

courses.title: Golden Age Drama & Performance
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Golden Age drama: text and performance. Study of Spanish Baroque drama as performance art. Close reading of plays and related aspects of 17th-century theater: theatrical spaces, staging, performance, actors, public, language, costumes. Final project is performance of a play.

courses.title: Golden Age Literature of Spain
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Introduction to the study of the principal authors and literary movements of 16th- and 17th-century Spain and Spanish American colonial literature.

courses.title: Don Quijote I
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Critical interpretation of Don Quijote Part One by Cervantes.  Focused study of key elements within the socio-cultural context of Golden Age Spain.  Don Quijote as prototype for the modern novel.

courses.title: Don Quijote II
courses.desc: Critical interpretation of Don Quijote Part Two by Cervantes.  Focused study of key elements within the socio-cultural context of Golden Age Spain.  Don Quijote as prototype for the modern novel.

courses.title: Spanish Romanticism
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Romanticism as a philosophical concept, and as a literary movement in Spain, with emphasis on its distinctive, specific "romantic" qualities and its literary expression in five leading authors of the early-19th century. (Former SPA 114.)

courses.title: The Spanish Novel of the 19th Century
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Literary realism in Spain, focusing on Leopoldo Alas (Clarín), Emilia Pardo Bazán and Benito Pérez Galdós unique characteristics of Spanish realism and its historical roots in Cervantes and the picaresque.

courses.title: 20th-Century Spanish Fiction
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Study of the main literary trends and authors of the modern Spanish novel and short story. Selected works by Unamuno, Valle-Inclán, Sender, Cela, Matute, Ayala and others.

courses.title: Modern & Contemporary Spanish Poetry
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Study of the main literary trends and authors of modern and contemporary Spanish poetry. Selected works by Machado, Juan Ramón Jiménez, García Lorca, Guillén, Aleixandre, Hernández Hierro and others. Offered in alternate years. (Former SPA 120C.)

courses.title: Modern Spanish Theater
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Study of the main dramatic trends and playwrights of modern Spanish theater. Selected works by Valle Inclán, García-Lorca, Mihura, Buero-Vallejo, Arrabal and others. Offered in alternate years.

courses.title: Modern Spanish Essay
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Ortega, Unamuno and the modern Spanish essay. Their concept of Spain and their relations with other movements and thinkers.

courses.title: Introduction to Spanish Culture
courses.desc: Introduction to history, geography and culture of Spain. Art, history of ideas, and everyday cultural manifestations.  Introduction to critical reading and textual analysis.

courses.title: Introduction to Spanish Culture
courses.desc: Introduction to history, geography and culture of Spain. Art, history of ideas, and everyday cultural manifestations. Introduction to critical reading and textual analysis. May be taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country under the supervision of UC Davis faculty.

courses.title: Special Topics in Spanish Cultural & Literary Studies
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Special topics in the study of Spanish literature and culture. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Spanish Art
courses.desc: Spanish art and the different historical, sociological and political manifestations that frame it. History of art, including Paleolithic, Roman, Visigothic, Romanesque, Goth, Renaissance, Baroque, Neoclassic and Contemporary art. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Topics in Spanish Cultural Studies
courses.desc: Study of specific historical tendencies in Spanish culture(s) from the Romans to the present.  Sources studied may include literature, film, art, journalism, and performance.  Approaches to material may address issues of aesthetics, politics, identity, and globalization.

courses.title: Anglos, Latinos & the Spanish Black Legend: Origins & Educational Implications of Anti-Hispanic Prejudice
courses.desc: Examination of anti-Hispanic prejudice in the United States focusing on the "Black Legend," a 16th-century, anti-Spanish myth underpinning the doctrine of "Manifest Destiny." Exploration of the Legend's presence in contemporary American society through interviews and analysis of school textbooks.

courses.title: Cinema in the Spanish-Speaking World in Translation
courses.desc: Analysis of the culture of the Spanish-speaking world through film in translation.  Emphasis on the cultural information illustrated by the films; no prior knowledge of cinematography required.  Films with subtitles.

courses.title: Cinema in the Spanish-Speaking World in Translation
courses.desc: Analysis of the culture of the Spanish-speaking world through film in translation. Emphasis on the cultural information illustrated by the films; no prior knowledge of cinematography required. Films with subtitles. May be taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country, in Spanish, under the supervision of UC Davis faculty.

courses.title: Latin-American Literature in Translation
courses.desc: Reading, lectures and discussions in English of works by Borges, Cortázar, Fuentes, García Márquez, Paz and others.

courses.title: Survey of Latin American Literature to 1900
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Latin American literature from preconquest texts and the chronicles of the Conquest to romanticism and modernism. Reading selections include fiction, poetry, drama and essays.

courses.title: Survey of Latin American Literature 1900 to Present
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Latin American literature from 1900 to the present. Reading selections include fiction, poetry, drama, essays, testimonio, etc.

courses.title: Latin American Short Story
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Evolution of the Latin American short story from the 19th century to the present. Emphasis on the contemporary period.

courses.title: Latin American Novel
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Evolution of the Latin American novel from the 19th century to the present. Emphasis on significant contemporary works.

courses.title: Mexican Novel
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc:
Evolution of the Mexican novel from the 19th century to the present. Emphasis on the narrative of the Revolution and significant contemporary
works.

courses.title: Latin American Literature of the Turn of the 20th Century
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Modernism as an authentic expression of Latin American literature and its influence on 20th-century poetry and prose. In depth analysis of the works of Darío and other major writers of the era. Offered in alternate years.

courses.title: Great Works of Latin American Literature/Culture
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Study of major works of Latin American literature/culture and their cultural and literary milieus. May include novels, poetry, film, etc.  Works may be analyzed in terms of style, influence, cultural significance, political importance, and/or commercial success.

courses.title: Latin American Poetry: From Vanguardism to Surrealism & Beyond
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Study of vanguardism, surrealism, and more recent movements of Latin American poetry. An in-depth analysis of the works of such major poets as Neruda, Vallejo, and Paz.

courses.title: Special Topics in Latin American Literature & Culture
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Special topics in the study of Latin American literature and culture.

courses.title: Special Topics in Latin American Literature & Culture
courses.prereqs: SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.
courses.desc: Special topics in the study of Latin American literature and culture. May be taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country under the supervision of UC Davis faculty.

courses.title: Latin American Women Writers in Translation
courses.prereqs: Upper division standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Latin American women writers from the 19th and 20th centuries. Recent theoretical approaches to literature by women in Latin America. Discussions in English of works by Matto de Turner, Avellaneda, Storni, Ocampo, Agustini, Mistral, Castellanos, and others.

courses.title: Borders of the Spanish Speaking World
courses.prereqs: SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Analysis of cultural dynamics of border contexts (contact zones) in which Spanish speaking populations are prominent. Contexts may include one or more of the following: US-Mexico, US-Caribbean, Mexico-Central America, Dominican Republic-Haiti, Spain-Portugal, Colombia-Venezuela, Argentina-Brazil, among others.

courses.title: Introduction to Latinx Culture
courses.prereqs: SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Introduction to histories and cultures of Latinx (Mexican American, Puerto Rican, Salvadoran American, Ecuadorian American, etc.) populations of the US. Multiple genres of cultural production and representation, with a focus on cultural diversity and regional difference. Introduction to critical analysis across multiple genres of cultural production (literature, visual culture, media culture, etc.).

courses.title: Special Topics in Chicanx/Latinx Studies
courses.prereqs: SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Special topics in the study of Chicanx and/or Latinx literature and culture.

courses.title: Introduction to Latin American Culture
courses.desc: Introduction to history, geography and culture of Latin America. Multiple genres of cultural production and representation, with a focus on cultural diversity and regional difference. Introduction to critical reading and textual analysis.

courses.title: Introduction to Latin American Culture
courses.desc: Introduction to history, geography and culture of Latin America. Multiple genres of cultural production and representation, with a focus on cultural diversity and regional difference. Introduction to critical reading and textual analysis. May be taught abroad in a Spanish-speaking country.

courses.title: Music from Latin America
courses.desc: Examination of music from Latin America. Characteristic music (i.e. tango, bossa nova, salsa, musica motena, musica andina) as well as its implications in other musical genres. Taught in English or Spanish depending on instructor.

courses.title: Music from Latin America
courses.desc: Examination of music from Latin America. Characteristic music (i.e. tango, bossa nova, salsa, musica motena, musica andina) as well as its implications in other musical genres. May be taught abroad in English or Spanish depending on instructor.

courses.title: Mexican Culture
courses.desc: Study of Mexican culture through a diversity of cultural expression, including elite, popular and mass media culture.  Focus on national icons and archetypes, multiculturalism, transnationalism.

courses.title: Cinema & Latin American Culture
courses.desc: Understanding Latin American cultures through cinema. History and critical analysis of Latin American film. Focus on a national cinematic tradition. Comparative experiences in different parts of Latin America and/or a particular era. Conducted entirely in Spanish.

courses.title: Chicano Culture
courses.desc:
Interdisciplinary survey of Chicano culture. Topics include literature, art, folklore, oral tradition, music, politics, as well as
everyday cultural manifestations. Conducted in Spanish. (Former SPA 124.)

courses.title: Topics in Latin American Cultural Studies
courses.desc: Specific historical tendencies and issues in Latin American culture(s) from precolombian times to present. Studies of literature, film, art, journalism and performance. Focus on issues of aesthetics, politics, identity, and globalization. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Literature in Spanish Written in the United States
courses.desc: Survey of the literary and cultural contributions of the main Spanish-speaking populations present in the U.S.: Chicanos, Puerto Ricans, Cuban-Americans, Central Americans, and other Latinos.

courses.title: California & Latin America
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary survey on the relationship between California and Latin America (1500s-present). Latin American representations of California and Californian representations of Latin America, as well as borderlands texts, with a special focus on Mexican-American perspectives. Conducted in Spanish.

courses.title: Spanish for the Professions
courses.desc: For students with an advanced level of Spanish interested in the use of Spanish in the health care, legal and law enforcement and marketing and business professions.  Field trips documenting the use of Spanish in the public context.

courses.title: Science & Politics of the Human Body in the Spanish-Speaking World
courses.desc: Interaction between the interpretations of scientific ideas, philosophical issues, and politics concerning the human body in the Spanish- speaking world through different historical periods.

courses.title: Catalan Language & Culture
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Good command of Spanish, Portuguese, French or Italian and graduate level of studies in any of these languages.
courses.desc: Foundation for the acquisition of Catalan oral, reading and elementary writing level skills for students of Spanish (Iberianists or Hispanists), with the capacity to interpret educated written language. Emphasis on weekly review of grammar and all language skills.

courses.title: The Teaching of Spanish
courses.prereqs: Senior or graduate standing; a major or minor in Spanish.

courses.title: The Teaching of Spanish in College
courses.desc: Theoretical instruction in modern teaching methods and demonstration of their practical application. Required of graduate teaching assistants.

courses.title: Introduction to Public Health
