courses.desc: Provide basic concepts and controversies in public health, basic science of public health, social and behavioral factors in health and disease, environmental and occupational health issues, the relationship of public health to the medical care system and health care reform.

courses.title: Introduction to Human Epidemiology
courses.desc: Practice of epidemiology as it relates to human populations. Content is fundamental to the Public Health minor and a required core course.

courses.title: Introduction to Health Economics, Services, Policy, Administration & Management
courses.desc: American health care system and how public health leaders, administrators, and researchers can make effective contributions to the populations served.

courses.title: Globalization & Health: Evidence & Policies
courses.desc: Provides an overview of the evidence on the multiple effects of globalization policies on health.

courses.title: Health Disparities in the U.S.
courses.desc: Introduction to the principles and practice of health disparities research.

courses.title: Health Issues Confronting Asian Americans & Pacific Islanders
courses.desc: Health issues confronting Asian Americans & Pacific Islanders.

courses.title: General Health Education & Prevention
courses.desc: Topics include addiction, substance abuse/prevention, nutrition, stress management, physical fitness, body image, reproductive anatomy & physiology, contraceptive options, safer sex, sexual health, healthy relationships, and other general wellness/health promotion topics. Practice in peer counseling and outreach presentations.

courses.title: Campus Alcohol/Other Drug Abuse Prevention Program Peer Educator Training
courses.prereqs: SPH 160 (can be concurrent);  and Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Preparation for internship in campus and community substance abuse prevention and educational intervention. Addiction and other physiological responses to alcohol and other drugs. Harm-reduction strategies for individuals and target populations. Practice in peer counseling skills and outreach presentations to groups.

courses.title: Health Advocates Peer Educator Training
courses.prereqs: SPH 160 (can be concurrent);  and Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Preparation for internship in campus and community health promotion and risk reduction. Nutrition, stress management, physical fitness, body image and disordered eating, skin cancer prevention, and other general wellness/health promotion topics.

courses.title: Introduction to Public Health
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Provides an overview of public health. Covers the history of public health in the U.S.; defines its major functions and constituencies; and, introduces fundamental principles of epidemiology, biostatistics, behavioral sciences, environmental health, infectious diseases, and reducing health disparities.

courses.title: Public Health Issues in California's Central Valley
courses.desc: Public health issues in California’s Central Valley, including the influences of  migration, racial and ethnic diversity, the agricultural industry, environmental exposures, and rurality.

courses.title: Learning & Teaching in Public Health Contexts
courses.desc: Aimed at current and future public health professionals interested in learning more about the educational potential for interactions with community members and other health professionals—all stakeholders in improving the health of communities.

courses.title: Globalization & Health: Evidence & Policies
courses.desc: Provides an overview of the evidence on the multiple effects of globalization policies on health.

courses.title: Epidemiology for Health Professionals
courses.desc: Basic epidemiologic concepts and approaches to epidemiologic research, with examples from  human medicine, including outbreak investigation, infectious disease epidemiology, properties of tests.

courses.title: Advanced Epidemiologic Methodology
courses.desc: In-depth integration of advanced epidemiological concepts. Theory, methods, and applications for observational studies including random and systematic error, confounding, counterfactuals, causal inference, effect modification, internal and external validity, estimability, and interpretation of effect measures, and advanced study designs.

courses.title: Principles & Applications of Cancer Prevention & Control
courses.desc: Principles and applications of cancer prevention and control from a public health perspective.

courses.title: History of Epidemiology in Public Health
courses.desc: Introduction to the history of epidemiology in solving major public health problems. Original historical articles will be read/discussed. Topics may include: infectious disease, accidents/adverse events, nutritional deficiencies, community vaccination trials, occupational exposures, cancer, birth defects, cardiovascular disease, and smoking.

courses.title: Public Health Informatics
courses.desc: Collection, verification, and utilization of data related to populations; infrastructure, functions, and tools used to generate public health knowledge supporting public health practices and policy development/dissemination.

courses.title: Migration & Health
courses.desc: Principles of migration and health. Topics will include demographics, public health invention programs, health care delivery, occupational health, and effects of international migration on the health in communities of origin, transit and destination. Guest presentations by outside experts.

courses.title: Health Disparities in the U.S.
courses.desc: Introduction to the principles and practice of health disparities research.

courses.title: Social & Behavioral Aspects of Public Health
courses.prereqs: STA 102;  STA 106;  and Consent of Instructor.  Graduate standing.
courses.desc: Theories and strategies of health behavior change at the individual, group, community, and environmental levels. Examples include: transtheoretical model, social networks, and social marketing. Theories are applied to solve common public health problems (cancer, obesity, smoking, and HIV/AIDS).

courses.title: Obesity Prevention in Community Settings
courses.desc: Look at causes of the obesity epidemic in the U.S.; identify and critically assess the research literature on various prevention strategies; understand, and apply evidence-based public health strategies to combat obesity; and translate the science to a general audience.

courses.title: Persuasive Technologies for Health
courses.desc: Theorizing, designing and evaluating ethical technology-based health communication interventions. Uses of social media, mobile communication apps, wearable devices, computer-generated tailored messages, educational games, and computational approaches in health promotion and healthcare delivery.

courses.title: Health Communication Campaigns
courses.desc: Principles of health communication campaign planning, implementation and evaluation. Strategies for changing health behaviors, shaping policy, and improving healthcare organizations’ relations with stakeholders.

courses.title: Introduction to Medical Statistics
courses.desc: Introduction to statistical methods and software in clinical, laboratory and population medicine. Graphical and tabular presentation of data, probability, binomial, Poisson, normal, t-, F-, and Chi-square distributions, elementary nonparametric methods, simple linear regression and correlation, life tables.

courses.title: Biostatistics for Biomedical Science
courses.prereqs: CLH 244 or SPH 244;  and Consent of Instructor.  Or an equivalent course.
courses.desc: Analysis of data and design of experiments for laboratory data.

courses.title: Biostatistics for Clinical Research
courses.desc: Emphasizes critical biostatistics for clinical research and targets biomedical audience. Students will develop understanding for basic planning and analysis of clinical studies and learn to develop collaborations with biostatisticians.

courses.title: Statistical Analysis for Laboratory Data
courses.desc: Statistical methods for experimental design and analysis of laboratory data including gene expression arrays, RNA-Seq, and mass spec.

courses.title: Social Epidemiology
courses.desc: Social determinants of health; psychosocial and physiological pathways; health and social inequality; gender and racial/ethnic disparities in health; social support, social cohesion and health; social gradient in behavioral risk factors; social ecological approaches to health intervention; interventions addressing social determinants.

courses.title: Human Reproductive Epidemiology
courses.prereqs: MPM 405;  MPM 406; PHY 220; PGG 222; or equivalents or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Human reproductive effects and risk of reproductive disorders, examined from macro- and micro-environmental exposures in community and occupational settings, epidemiologic study designs and analyses.

courses.title: Principles of Environmental Health Science
courses.desc: Principles, approaches and issues related to environmental health.  Recognizing, assessing, understanding and controlling the impact of people on their environment and the impact of the environment on the public.

courses.title: Public Health Econometrics
courses.desc: Principles of demand and supply; elasticity; benefits and costs; least squares regression; stepwise regression; economic and statistical significance; fixed and random effects; longitudinal data; non-linear relations; continuous and binary variables; instrumental variables; attrition bias; tobit regression; Two-part cost model.

courses.title: Applied Analytic Epidemiology
courses.desc: Principles and applications in analysis of epidemiologic data. Methods of analyzing stratified and matched data, logistic regression for cohort and case-control studies, Poisson regression, survival-time methods.

courses.title: Health Services Administration
courses.desc: Structure and function of public and private medical care. Topics include categories and trends in national medical spending, predictors of patient use, causes of death, managed care, HMOs, Medicare, Medicaid, costs of technology, and medical care in other countries.

courses.title: Economic Evaluation in Health Care
courses.prereqs: At least one semester of graduate level Statistics or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Cost-effectiveness/cost-benefit analysis (CE/CBA) methods among various economic evaluation methods. CE/CBA is increasingly used to evaluate alternative choices in public health and clinical practice and to enlighten and inform health policy determinations.

courses.title: Critical Assessment in Health Policy & Economics
courses.desc: Aims to develop critical reading skills of the health policy and health economics literature, mainly following the microeconomic paradigm and analytical techniques. Some basic concepts of micro economic theory will be explained.

courses.title: Net Benefit Regression
courses.prereqs: STA 100 or SPH 244 or MPM 202;  or Consent of Instructor.  Graduate student standing.
courses.desc: Uses regression methods for cost-effectiveness analysis.  Focus on methods that create and explain economic information in person-level data.

courses.title: Introduction to SAS Programming
courses.prereqs: Introductory statistics course; e.g., MPM 402, STA 102.
courses.desc: Introduction to SAS, an integrated software system for data retrieval and management, data manipulation and programming.

courses.title: Program Planning & Evaluation
courses.desc: Assessment of population needs, assets and capacities that affect communities’ health. Design and selection of methods for evaluating a population-based program.

courses.title: International Health
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Forum for learning health issues and health care systems in other countries. Topics include health care for refugees, the impact of political strife on health, the health care professional in international settings.

courses.title: Introductory Medical Spanish
courses.prereqs: Medical student or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: The vocabulary needed to conduct a basic history and physical examination in Spanish.

courses.title: International Health
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Medical student in good academic standing.
courses.desc: Forum for learning health issues and health care systems in other countries.  Topics include health care for refugees, the impact of political strife on health, the health care professional in international settings.

courses.title: Current Issues in Public Health
courses.desc: Topical issues in public health.  Speakers from the local public health community address issues such as disease control programs, access to care.

courses.title: Soils in Our Environment
courses.desc: Soils in our global ecosystem; soils as natural bodies formed by interactive environmental processes; soil response to use and management; sustainable use of soil resources; role of soils in  agricultural and environmental issues; role of soils in our daily lives.

courses.title: Principles of Soil Science
courses.prereqs: College-level courses in each of chemistry, physics, biology, and geology recommended.
courses.desc: Soil as part of natural and managed ecosystems and landscapes. Solid, liquid, and gas phases and their interactions in the soil. Water, gas and heat movement in soil. Soil biology. Plant nutrient acquisition and use.Soil development, management and use.

courses.title: Environmental Soil Chemistry
courses.prereqs: General chemistry; SSC 100 or equivalent recommended.
courses.desc: Soil chemistry processes related to the fate and transport of contaminants in soil. Soil minerals, natural organic matter, surface charge, soil solution chemistry, redox reactions in soil, and sorption of inorganic and organic contaminants.

courses.title: Soil Physics
courses.prereqs: SSC 100;  ERS 100;  MAT 016A;  Or the equivalent of MAT 016A.
courses.desc: Physical properties of soil. Principles of water, gas, heat, and solute movement in soil with selected examples related to soil and water management. Influence of soil properties on transfer processes.

courses.title: Sustainable Nutrient  Management
courses.desc: Availability of nutrients in organic and conventional agricultural, vineyard, orchard and plantation forest soils; management of fertilizers, cover crops, compost, sewage sludge and manures for crop production and to prevent loss to the environment is emphasized.

courses.title: Soil Microbiology
courses.desc: Major groups of microorganisms in soil, their interrelationships, and their responses to environmental variables. Role of microorganisms in cycling of nutrients. Plant-microbe relationships. Transformations of organic and inorganic pollutants.

courses.title: Soil Ecology
courses.desc: Overview of living constituents of soils, their interactions, importance to, and impact on biogeochemical cycles, decomposition, and soil properties. Practical applications of soil biological diversity are emphasized.

courses.title: Soils in Land Use & the Environment
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  SSC 100 or equivalent recommended.
courses.desc: Soils are considered as elements in land use planning and environmental quality. Topics include: soil survey reports, remote sensing, land capability classification, soil erosion/conservation, waste disposal on soils and soil reclamation. One one-day field trip.

courses.title: Soil Genesis, Morphology, & Classification
courses.desc: Recognition and description of soils; chemical, biological and physical processes of soil formation. Factors of soil formation. Interactions of soils with diverse ecosystems. Introduction to soil classification. Practice using soil taxonomy. Practical experience describing soil properties in the field.

courses.title: Topics in Advanced Soil Chemistry
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  General chemistry; SSC 100 or equivalent recommended.
courses.desc: Reviews of current research in soil chemistry. Topics include double layer theory; clay mineral and oxide surface chemistry; adsorption on soil surfaces; speciation and modeling of solution ions; solubility and mineral stability diagrams.

courses.title: Soil-Plant Interrelationships
courses.prereqs: SSC 100;  PLB 111;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Plant needs, occurrence and reactions of water and mineral nutrients in soils; root systems and their growth in soils; mass flow and diffusion mechanisms in nutrient acquisition; models relating nutrient uptake to soil and plant characteristics;nutrient assimilation and crop quality.

courses.title: Advanced Soil Microbiology
courses.prereqs: CHE 008A;  CHE 008B;  SSC 111;  BIS 102, BIS 103 or an equivalent course recommended.
courses.desc:
Microbial metabolism of organic chemicals in soil, both natural and
xenobiotic. Decomposition of organic matter. Kinetics of microbial processes in soil.

courses.title: Ecosystem Biogeochemistry
courses.prereqs: Introductory courses in ecology/biology and soils recommended; undergraduates accepted with consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Multidisciplinary analysis of energy and nutrient transfers within terrestrial ecosystems. Examination of processes and inter- and intra-system interactions between the atmosphere, biosphere, lithosphere and hydrosphere. Laboratory section uses biogeochemical simulation models to examine case studies.

courses.title: Pedology
courses.desc: Topics selected from studies of soil-forming processes, soil-geomorphic relations, mineral weathering, new developments in soil classification, and development of pedologic theory. Topics vary from year to year.

courses.title: Global Carbon Cycle
courses.prereqs: CHE 008A;  CHE 008B;  MAT 016A;  MAT 016B;  SSC 100;  Or the equivalent of SSC 100.
courses.desc: Global carbon cycle from Phanerozoic epoch to modern times. Examination of long and short-term carbon cycles.  Transfer of carbon among ocean, land and life with emphasis on humic substance formation, methods of characterization, reactions with organics and soil carbon stabilization.

courses.title: Statistical Thinking
courses.prereqs: Two years of high school algebra.
courses.desc:
Statistics and probability in daily life. Examines principles of collecting, presenting and interpreting data in order to critically assess results reported in the media; emphasis is on understanding polls, unemployment rates, health studies; understanding probability,
risk and odds.

courses.title: Introduction to Discrete Probability
courses.prereqs: Two years of high school algebra.
courses.desc:
Random experiments; countable sample spaces; elementary probability
axioms; counting formulas; conditional probability; independence; Bayes theorem; expectation; gambling problems; binomial, hypergeometric, Poisson, geometric, negative binomial and multinomial models; limiting distributions; Markov chains. Applications in the social, biological, and engineering sciences.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.prereqs: Two years of high school algebra or Mathematics D.
courses.desc: Descriptive statistics; basic probability concepts; binomial, normal, Student's t, and chi-square distributions. Hypothesis testing and confidence intervals for one and two means and proportions. Regression.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.prereqs: Two years of high school algebra or Mathematics D.
courses.desc: Descriptive statistics; basic probability concepts; binomial, normal, Student's t, and chi-square distributions. Hypothesis testing and confidence intervals for one and two means and proportions.  Regression.

courses.title: Gateway to Statistical Data Science
courses.prereqs: MAT 016B C- or better or MAT 021B C- or better or MAT 017B C- or better.
courses.desc: Probability concepts; programming in R; exploratory data analysis; sampling distribution; estimation and inference; linear regression; simulations; resampling methods. Alternative to STA 013 for students with a background in calculus and programming.

courses.title: Statistical Data Science I
courses.prereqs: MAT 016A (can be concurrent) or MAT 017A (can be concurrent) or MAT 021A (can be concurrent).
courses.desc: Principles of descriptive statistics; basic R programming; probability models; sampling variability; hypothesis tests; confidence intervals; statistical simulation.

courses.title: Statistical Data Science II
courses.prereqs: (STA 035A C- or better or STA 032 C- or better or STA 100 C- or better);  (MAT 016A (can be concurrent) or MAT 017A (can be concurrent) or MAT 021A (can be concurrent)).
courses.desc: Advanced programming and data manipulation in R. Principles of data visualization. Concepts of correlation, regression, analysis of variance, nonparametrics.

courses.title: Statistical Data Science III
courses.prereqs: STA 035B C- or better;  (MAT 016B C- or better or MAT 017B C- or better or MAT 021B C- or better).
courses.desc: Introduction to statistical learning; Bayesian paradigm; model selection; simultaneous inference; bootstrap and cross validation; classification and clustering methods; PCA; nonparametric smoothing techniques.

courses.title: Applied Statistics for Biological Sciences
courses.prereqs: MAT 016B C- or better or MAT 017B C- or better or MAT 021B C- or better.
courses.desc: Descriptive statistics, probability, sampling distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, contingency tables, ANOVA, regression; implementation of statistical methods using computer package.

courses.title: Advanced Applied Statistics for the Biological Sciences
courses.desc: Basic experimental designs, two-factor ANOVA without interactions, repeated measures ANOVA, ANCOVA, random effects vs. fixed effects, multiple regression, basic model building, resampling methods, multiple comparisons, multivariate methods, generalized linear models, Monte Carlo simulations.

courses.title: Applied Statistics for Business & Economics
courses.prereqs: (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better or STA 032 C- or better or STA 100 C- or better);  (MAT 016B C- or better or MAT 017B C- or better or MAT 021B C- or better).
courses.desc: Descriptive statistics; probability; random variables; expectation; binomial, normal, Poisson, other univariate distributions; joint distributions; sampling distributions, central limit theorem; properties of estimators; linear combinations of random variables; testing and estimation; Minitab computing package. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Applied Statistical Methods: Nonparametric Statistics
courses.prereqs: STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better or STA 032 C- or better or STA 100 C- or better.
courses.desc: Sign and Wilcoxon tests, Walsh averages. Two-sample procedures. Inferences concerning scale. Kruskal-Wallis test. Measures of association. Chi square and Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests.

courses.title: Applied Statistical Methods: Analysis of Variance
courses.prereqs: STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better or STA 032 C- or better or STA 100 C- or better.
courses.desc: Basics of experimental design. One-way and two-way fixed effects analysis of variance models. Randomized complete and incomplete block design. Multiple comparisons procedures. One-way random effects model.

courses.title: Applied Statistical Methods: Regression Analysis
courses.prereqs: STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better or STA 032 C- or better or STA 100 C- or better.
courses.desc: Simple linear regression, variable selection techniques, stepwise regression, analysis of covariance, influence measures, computing packages.

courses.title: Mathematical Statistics: Brief Course
courses.prereqs: (MAT 016C C- or better or MAT 017C C- or better or MAT 021C C- or better);  (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better or STA 032 C- or better or STA 100 C- or better).
courses.desc: Basic probability, densities and distributions, mean, variance, covariance, Chebyshev's inequality, some special distributions, sampling distributions, central limit theorem and law of large numbers, point estimation, some methods of estimation, interval estimation, confidence intervals for certain quantities, computing sample sizes.

courses.title: Mathematical Statistics: Brief Course
courses.prereqs: STA 130A C- or better or STA 131A C- or better or MAT 135A C- or better.
courses.desc: Transformed random variables, large sample properties of estimates. Basic ideas of hypotheses testing, likelihood ratio tests, goodness-of-fit tests. General linear model, least squares estimates, Gauss-Markov theorem. Analysis of variance, F-test. Regression and correlation, multiple regression. Selected topics.

courses.title: Introduction to Probability Theory
courses.prereqs: MAT 021C C- or better;  (MAT 022A C- or better or MAT 027A C- or better or MAT 067 C- or better);  MAT 021D strongly recommended.
courses.desc: Fundamental concepts of probability theory, discrete and continuous random variables, standard distributions, moments and moment-generating functions, laws of large numbers and the central limit theorem.

courses.title: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
courses.prereqs: STA 131A C- or better or MAT 135A C- or better;  Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Sampling, methods of estimation, bias-variance decomposition, sampling distributions, Fisher information, confidence intervals, and some elements of hypothesis testing.

courses.title: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
courses.desc: Testing theory, tools and applications from probability theory, Linear model theory, ANOVA, goodness-of-fit.

courses.title: Multivariate Data Analysis
courses.prereqs: (STA 130B C- or better or STA 131B C- or better);  (MAT 022A C- or better or MAT 027A C- or better or MAT 067 C- or better).
courses.desc: Multivariate normal distribution; Mahalanobis distance; sampling distributions of the mean vector and covariance matrix; Hotellings T2; simultaneous inference; one-way MANOVA; discriminant analysis; principal components; canonical correlation; factor analysis. Intensive use of computer analyses and real data sets.

courses.title: Applied Time Series Analysis
courses.desc: Time series relationships; univariate time series models: trend, seasonality, correlated errors; regression with correlated errors; autoregressive models; autoregressive moving average models; spectral analysis: cyclical behavior and periodicity, measures of periodicity, periodogram; linear filtering; prediction of time series; transfer function models.

courses.title: Analysis of Categorical Data
courses.desc:
Varieties of categorical data, cross-classifications, contingency tables, tests for independence. Multidimensional tables and log-linear models, maximum likelihood estimation; tests of goodness-of-fit. Logit
models, linear logistic models. Analysis of incomplete tables. Packaged computer programs, analysis of real data.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Statistical Data Science
courses.prereqs: STA 108 C- or better or STA 106 C- or better.
courses.desc: Introduction to computing for data analysis & visualization, and simulation, using a high-level language (e.g., R). Computational reasoning, computationally intensive statistical methods, reading tabular & non-standard data.

courses.title: Data & Web Technologies for Data Analysis
courses.desc: Essentials of using relational databases and SQL. Processing data in blocks. Scraping Web pages and using Web services/APIs. Basics of text mining. Interactive data visualization with Web technologies. Computational data workflow and best practices. Statistical methods.

courses.title: Big Data & High Performance Statistical Computing
courses.prereqs: STA 141B C- or better or (STA 141A C- or better,  (ECS 010 C- or better or ECS 032A C- or better)).
courses.desc: High-performance computing in high-level data analysis languages; different computational approaches and paradigms for efficient analysis of big data; interfaces to compiled languages; R and Python programming languages; high-level parallel computing; MapReduce; parallel algorithms and reasoning.

courses.title: Statistical Learning I
courses.prereqs: STA 141A C- or better;  (STA 130A C- or better or STA 131A C- or better or MAT 135A C- or better);  STA 131A or MAT 135A preferred.
courses.desc: Fundamental concepts and methods in statistical learning with emphasis on supervised learning. Principles, methodologies and applications of parametric and nonparametric regression, classification, resampling and model selection techniques.

courses.title: Statistical Learning II
courses.prereqs: STA 142A C- or better;  (STA 130B C- or better or STA 131B C- or better);  STA 131B preferred.
courses.desc: Fundamental concepts and methods in statistical learning with emphasis on unsupervised learning. Principles, methodologies and applications of clustering methods, dimension reduction and manifold learning techniques, graphical models and latent variables modeling.

courses.title: Sampling Theory of Surveys
courses.desc: Simple random, stratified random, cluster, and systematic sampling plans; mean, proportion, total, ratio, and regression estimators for these plans; sample survey design, absolute and relative error, sample size selection, strata construction; sampling and nonsampling sources of error.

courses.title: Bayesian Statistical Inference
courses.prereqs: STA 130B C- or better or STA 131B C- or better.
courses.desc: Subjective probability, Bayes Theorem, conjugate priors, non-informative priors, estimation, testing, prediction, empirical Bayes methods, properties of Bayesian procedures, comparisons with classical procedures, approximation techniques, Gibbs sampling, hierarchical Bayesian analysis, applications, computer implemented data analysis.

courses.title: Practice in Statistical Data Science
courses.prereqs: STA 106 C- or better;  STA 108 C- or better;  (STA 130B C- or better or STA 131B C- or better);  STA 141A C- or better.
courses.desc: Principles and practice of interdisciplinary, collaborative data analysis; complete case study review and team data analysis project.

courses.title: Introduction to Probability Theory
courses.prereqs: MAT 021A;  MAT 021B;  MAT 021C;  MAT 022A;  Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Fundamental concepts of probability theory, discrete and continuous random variables, standard distributions, moments and moment-generating functions, laws of large numbers and the central limit theorem.

courses.title: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics I
courses.desc: Sampling, methods of estimation, bias-variance decomposition, sampling distributions, Fisher information, confidence intervals, and some elements of hypothesis testing.

courses.title: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics II
courses.desc: Testing theory, tools and applications from probability theory, Linear model theory, ANOVA, goodness-of-fit.

courses.title: SAS Programming for Statistical Analysis
courses.prereqs: Introductory, upper division statistics course; some knowledge of vectors and matrices; STA 106 or STA 108 or the equivalent suggested.
courses.desc: Introductory SAS language, data management, statistical applications, methods. Includes basics, graphics, summary statistics, data sets, variables and functions, linear models, repetitive code, simple macros, GLIM and GAM, formatting output, correspondence analysis, bootstrap. Prepare SAS base programmer certification exam.

courses.title: Statistical Methods for Research with SAS
courses.prereqs: An introductory upper division statistics course and some knowledge of vectors and matrices; STA 100, or STA 102, or STA 103 suggested or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Focus on linear statistical models widely used in scientific research. Emphasis on concepts, methods and data analysis using SAS. Topics include simple and multiple linear regression, polynomial regression, diagnostics, model selection, variable transformation, factorial designs and ANCOVA.

courses.title: Statistical Methods for Research–I
courses.prereqs: Introductory statistics course; some knowledge of vectors and matrices.
courses.desc: Focus on linear statistical models. Emphasis on concepts, method and data analysis; formal mathematics kept to minimum. Topics include simple and multiple linear regression, polynomial regression, diagnostics, model selection, factorial designs and analysis of covariance. Use of professional level software.

courses.title: Statistical Methods for Research–II
courses.prereqs: STA 206;  Knowledge of vectors and matrices.
courses.desc: Linear and nonlinear statistical models emphasis on concepts, methods/data analysis using professional level software; formal mathematics kept to minimum. Topics include linear mixed models, repeated measures, generalized linear models, model selection, analysis of missing data, and multiple testing procedures.

courses.title: Statistical Methods in Machine Learning
courses.prereqs: STA 206;  STA 207;  STA 135;  Or their equivalents.
courses.desc: Focus on linear and nonlinear statistical models. Emphasis on concepts, methods, and data analysis; formal mathematics kept to minimum. Topics include resampling methods, regularization techniques in regression and modern classification, cluster analysis and dimension reduction techniques. Use professional level software.

courses.title: Optimization for Big Data Analytics
courses.desc: Optimization algorithms for solving problems in statistics, machine learning, data analytics. Review computational tools for implementing optimization algorithms (gradient descent, stochastic gradient descent, coordinate descent, Newton’s method.)

courses.title: Data & Web Technologies for Data Analysis
courses.desc: Essentials of using relational databases and SQL. Processing data in blocks. Scraping Web pages and using Web services/APIs. Basics of text mining. Interactive data visualization with Web technologies. Computational data workflow and best practices. Statistical Methods.

courses.title: Big Data & High Performance Statistical Computing
courses.desc: High-performance computing in high-level data analysis languages; different computational approaches and paradigms for efficient analysis of big data; interfaces to compiled languages; R and Python programming languages; high-level parallel computing; MapReduce; parallel algorithms and reasoning.

courses.title: Biostatistics: Survival Analysis
courses.desc: Incomplete data; life tables; nonparametric methods; parametric methods; accelerated failure time models; proportional hazards models; partial likelihood; advanced topics.

courses.title: Biostatistics: Generalized Linear Models
courses.desc: Likelihood and linear regression; generalized linear model; Binomial regression; case-control studies; dose-response and bioassay; Poisson regression; Gamma regression; quasi-likelihood models; estimating equations; multivariate GLMs.

courses.title: Analysis of Longitudinal Data
courses.prereqs: ((STA 222,  STA 223) or (BST 222,  BST 223));  STA 232B;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Standard and advanced methodology, theory, algorithms, and applications relevant for analysis of repeated measurements and longitudinal data in biostatistical and statistical settings.

courses.title: Clinical Trials
courses.prereqs: STA 223 or BST 223;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Basic statistical principles of clinical designs, including bias, randomization, blocking, and masking. Practical applications of widely-used designs, including dose-finding, comparative and cluster randomization designs. Advanced statistical procedures for analysis of data collected in clinical trials.

courses.title: Statistical Methods for Bioinformatics
courses.prereqs: STA 131C;  or Consent of Instructor.  Data analysis experience recommended.
courses.desc: Standard and advanced statistical methodology, theory, algorithms, and applications relevant to the analysis of -omics data.

courses.title: Mathematical Statistics I
courses.prereqs: STA 131A;  STA 131B;  STA 131C;  MAT 025;  MAT 125A;  Or equivalent of MAT 025 and MAT 125A.
courses.desc: First part of three-quarter sequence on mathematical statistics. Emphasizes foundations. Topics include basic concepts in asymptotic theory, decision theory, and an overview of methods of point estimation.

courses.title: Mathematical Statistics II
courses.desc: Second part of a three-quarter sequence on mathematical statistics. Emphasizes: hyposthesis testing (including multiple testing) as well as theory for linear models.

courses.title: Mathematical Statistics III
courses.desc: Third part of three-quarter sequence on mathematical statistics. Emphasizes large sample theory and their applications. Topics include statistical functionals, smoothing methods and optimization techniques relevant for statistics.

courses.title: Applied Statistics I
courses.prereqs: STA 106;  STA 108;  STA 131A;  STA 131B;  STA 131C;  MAT 167.
courses.desc: Estimation and testing for the general linear model, regression, analysis of designed experiments, and missing data techniques.

courses.title: Applied Statistics II
courses.prereqs: STA 106;  STA 108;  STA 131A;  STA 131B;  STA 131C;  STA 232A;  MAT 167.
courses.desc: Alternative approaches to regression, model selection, nonparametric methods amenable to linear model framework and their applications.

courses.title: Applied Statistics III
courses.desc: Multivariate analysis: multivariate distributions, multivariate linear models, data analytic methods including principal component, factor, discriminant, canonical correlation and cluster analysis.

courses.title: Design Experiments
courses.desc: Topics from balanced and partially balanced incomplete block designs, fractional factorials, and response surfaces.

courses.title: Probability Theory
courses.prereqs: (MAT 125B,  MAT 135A) or STA 131A;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Measure-theoretic foundations, abstract integration, independence, laws of large numbers, characteristic functions, central limit theorems. Weak convergence in metric spaces, Brownian motion, invariance principle. Conditional expectation. Topics selected from: martingales, Markov chains, ergodic theory.

courses.title: Probability Theory
courses.prereqs: STA 235A or MAT 235A;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Measure-theoretic foundations, abstract integration, independence, laws of large numbers, characteristic functions, central limit theorems. Weak convergence in metric spaces, Brownian motion, invariance principle. Conditional expectation. Topics selected from: martingales, Markov chains, ergodic theory.

courses.title: Probability Theory
courses.prereqs: STA 235B or MAT 235B;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Measure-theoretic foundations, abstract integration, independence, laws of large numbers, characteristic functions, central limit theorems. Weak convergence in metric spaces, Brownian motion, invariance principle. Conditional expectation. Topics selected from: martingales, Markov chains, ergodic theory.

courses.title: Time Series Analysis
courses.prereqs: STA 131B;  Or the equivalent of STA 131B.
courses.desc: Advanced topics in time series analysis and applications. Models for experimental data, measures of dependence, large-sample theory, statistical estimation and inference. Univariate and multivariate spectral analysis, regression, ARIMA models, state-space models, Kalman filtering.

courses.title: Time Series Analysis
courses.prereqs: STA 131B;  STA 237A;  Or the equivalent of STA 131B.
courses.desc: Advanced topics in time series analysis and applications. Models for experimental data, measures of dependence, large-sample theory, statistical estimation and inference. Univariate and multivariate spectral analysis, regression, ARIMA models, state-space models, Kalman filtering.

courses.title: Theory of Multivariate Analysis
courses.desc: Multivariate normal and Wishart distributions, Hotellings T-Squared, simultaneous inference, likelihood ratio and union intersection tests, Bayesian methods, discriminant analysis, principal component and factor analysis, multivariate clustering, multivariate regression and analysis of variance, application to data.

courses.title: Nonparametric Inference
courses.desc:
Comprehensive treatment of nonparametric statistical inference, including the most basic materials from classical nonparametrics, robustness, nonparametric estimation of a distribution function from
incomplete data, curve estimation, and theory of resampling methodology.

courses.title: Nonparametric Inference
courses.desc:
Comprehensive treatment of nonparametric statistical inference, including the most basic materials from classical nonparametrics, robustness, nonparametric estimation of a distribution function from
incomplete data, curve estimation, and theory of re-sampling methodology.

courses.title: Asymptotic Theory of Statistics
courses.desc: Topics in asymptotic theory of statistics chosen from weak convergence, contiguity, empirical processes, Edgeworth expansion, and semiparametric inference.

courses.title: Introduction to Statistical Programming
courses.prereqs: STA 130A;  STA 130B;  or equivalent of STA 130A and STA 130B.
courses.desc: Essentials of statistical computing using a general-purpose statistical language. Topics include algorithms; design; debugging and efficiency; object-oriented concepts; model specification and fitting; statistical visualization; data and text processing; databases; computer systems and platforms; comparison of scientific programming languages.

courses.title: Computational Statistics
courses.prereqs: (STA 130A,  STA 130B);  (MAT 067 or MAT 167);  Or equivalent of STA 130A and 130B, or equivalent of MAT 167 or MAT 067.
courses.desc: Numerical analysis; random number generation; computer experiments and resampling techniques (bootstrap, cross validation); numerical optimization; matrix decompositions and linear algebra computations; algorithms (markov chain monte carlo, expectation-maximization); algorithm design and efficiency; parallel and distributed computing.

courses.title: Topics in Applied & Computational Statistics
courses.desc: Resampling, nonparametric and semiparametric methods, incomplete data analysis, diagnostics, multivariate and time series analysis, applied Bayesian methods, sequential analysis and quality control, categorical data analysis, spatial and image analysis, computational biology, functional data analysis, models for correlated data, learning theory.

courses.title: Topics in Statistical Methods & Models
courses.prereqs: STA 231B;  Or the equivalent of STA 231B.
courses.desc: Topics may include Bayesian analysis, nonparametric and semiparametric regression, sequential analysis, bootstrap, statistical methods in high dimensions, reliability, spatial processes, inference for stochastic process, stochastic methods in finance, empirical processes, change-point problems, asymptotics for parametric, nonparametric and semiparametric models, nonlinear time series, robustness.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Biostatistics
courses.desc: Biostatistical methods and models selected from the following: genetics, bioinformatics and genomics; longitudinal or functional data; clinical trials and experimental design; analysis of environmental data; dose-response, nutrition and toxicology; survival analysis; observational studies and epidemiology; computer-intensive or Bayesian methods in biostatistics.

courses.title: Statistical Practice & Data Analysis
courses.prereqs: STA 207 or STA 232B;  Working knowledge of advanced statistical software and the equivalent of STA 207 or STA 232B.
courses.desc: Principles and practice of interdisciplinary collaboration in statistics, statistical consulting, ethical aspects, and basics of data analysis and study design. Emphasis on practical consulting and collaboration of statisticians with clients and scientists under instructor supervision.

courses.title: Methods of Teaching Statistics
courses.desc: Practical experience in methods/problems of teaching statistics at university undergraduate level.  Lecturing techniques, analysis of tests and supporting material, preparation and grading of examinations, and use of statistical software.  Emphasis on practical training.

courses.title: Methods in Statistical Consulting
courses.desc: Introduction to consulting, in-class consulting as a group, statistical consulting with clients, and in-class discussion of consulting problems. Clients are drawn from a pool of University clients.

courses.title: Introduction to Science, Technology & Medicine Studies
courses.desc: History, philosophy, sociology, politics, and cultural studies of science, technology, and medicine. Emphasis on a broad range of perspectives.

courses.title: Introduction to the History of Science & Technology
courses.desc: Introduction to topics and methods of the history of science and technology. Emphasis on understanding the role of science and technology in the modern world through a long-term historical perspective.

courses.title: Science on Trial: Law, Science, & Technology in the United States
courses.desc: Relationships among law, technology, and science. Scientific evidence and testimony, biology education, patenting, and sterilization.

courses.title: Sex, Science, & Society
courses.desc: Survey of the relationship between sex, science, and society in the history of the modern world. Emphasis on the development of scientific ideas about the human body against broader social, cultural, and political trends and from a global viewpoint.

courses.title: Methods in Science, Technology & Medicine Studies
courses.desc: Methodological issues concerning the historical, philosophical, sociological, ethical, and political analysis of science, technology, and medicine. Detailed case studies to illustrate different methods of analysis.

courses.title: Drugs, Science & Culture
courses.desc: Drugs, politics, science, society in a cultural perspective: emphasis on roles of science, government and the media in shifting attitudes toward alcohol, marijuana, Prozac and other pharmaceuticals; drug laws, war on drugs and global trade in sugar, opium, cocaine.

courses.title: Media History 1, Gutenberg to Oppenheimer
courses.desc: History of Media to 1945, with particular focus on mechanically reproduced mass media technologies including the printing press, the newspaper, photography, cinema, radio and early computing technology. Analysis of inter-related cultural and political topics.

courses.title: Media History 2 1945-Present
courses.desc: History of media from 1945 to present, with particular focus on the development of the computer, digital network and Internet technologies in the context of other media infrastructures like radio, television and satellite networks. Analysis of inter-related cultural/political topics.

courses.title: Ancient Science
courses.desc: Study of science in ancient Greece and Rome; consideration of its social context; concentration on the basic concepts of physics the world of medicine and biology the history of mathematics and the practices of astronomy astrology and meteorology.

courses.title: Ancient Medicine
courses.desc: Medicine in ancient Greece and Rome; physiological conceptions of the body within scientific and social frameworks; exploration of sanitation technology and health in antiquity; medical treatment of the female body; medicine and the economy.

courses.title: Introduction to Data Studies
courses.desc: Introduction to basic data science concepts, defining problems, clarifying questions, identifying stakeholders, caring for and cleaning data, interviewing techniques, structuring presentations, use of Excel for data problems.

courses.title: Intellectual Property in Science
courses.prereqs: STS 001;  Or other Social Science or Humanities writing course.
courses.desc: Historical and conceptual framework for contemporary debates about intellectual property and science. Topics include U.S. patent system and copyright law, interaction between patents and industrial policy, credit in academic and industrial science, role of IP in global knowledge politics.

courses.title: Visualization in Science: A Critical Introduction
courses.prereqs: STS 001 or STS 020 or ANT 002 recommended.
courses.desc: Anthropological approaches to scientific visualization techniques, informatics, simulations. Examination of different visualization techniques toward understanding the work involved in producing them, critical assessment of their power and limits, especially when visualizations are used socially to make claims.

courses.title: Computing, Data, & Law in the United States
courses.desc: Introduction to the problems in American law and policy borne out of the creation and use of information technologies. Topics include intellectual property, corporate law, privacy, and emerging problems surrounding big data.

courses.title: Visualizing Society with Data
courses.desc: Analysis and visualization of historical and contemporary data about populations and societies using R. Critical exploration of visual communication of information about people over time and critical assessment of role of data collection and analysis in societies.

courses.title: Business & Technology in the United States: From Electricity to E-Commerce
courses.desc: Historical introduction to the joint development of business and technology in the United States from the late-19th century to the present day.

courses.title: The Global Information Age
courses.desc: Introduction to the global spread of information technologies like computers and smartphones. Special focus on their social, cultural, and commercial impact.

courses.title: Data Sense & Exploration: Critical Storytelling with Analysis
courses.desc: Data science and the communication of data insights through critical storytelling. Attention to the historical and social contexts of data analysis, emphasizing narrative, visualization, and exploration. Introduction to the R computing environment for data analysis.

courses.title: Religion, Magic & Science
courses.desc: Religion, magic, and science from the middle ages to the present. Contrast between modern scientific methodology and religious and magical thinking.

courses.title: Special Topics in Medical Anthropology
courses.desc: Introduction to critical medical anthropology. Topics include anthropological analysis of bio-medicine, psychiatry, systems of knowledge and healing, the body, emotions, and clinical encounters in a cross-cultural perspective.

courses.title: Health & Medical Technologies
courses.desc: Critical/historical examination of medical technologies: imaging, pharmaceuticals, genetics, implants/devices. Exploration of mutually constitutive relationship between health, medical technologies, social difference (race/gender/class/sexuality).

courses.title: Health & Medicine in a Global Context
courses.desc: Recent works in medical anthropology and the science studies of medicine dealing with social and cultural aspects of global health issues such as AIDS, pandemics, clinical trials, cultural differences in illnesses, diabetes, organ trafficking, medical technologies, illness narratives, and others.

courses.title: From Natural History to the History of Nature
courses.desc:
Evolution and demise of natural history as a discipline from Aristotle
to Linnaeus. Considers ancient views of nature and its Renaissance rediscovery; the emergence of biology, botany, geology, and zoology; the history of taxonomy and classification.

courses.title: History of Modern Biology
courses.desc:
Development of modern biology from pre-Darwinian roots to the present. Considers emergence of modern biological specialities and consolidation of biological theory around evolutionary ideas. History of allied fields
such as genetics, paleontology, embryology, ecology, systematics and molecular biology.

courses.title: Darwin
courses.prereqs: Upper division standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Students will explore the life and times of Charles Darwin and will trace the development of evolutionary thinking before and after the Origin of Species to appreciate its place in Victorian society and in the corpus of Darwins thought.

courses.title: Gender & Science
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary approach to the relations between gender and science. Topics include the biological and cultural construction of sexual difference, the role of women as practitioners of science, and feminist approaches to science.

courses.title: Media Theory
courses.desc: Critical and theoretical approaches to the emergence of new technologies since the invention of photography. Examine various approaches to media (formalist, semiotic, structuralist, Frankfurt School, cybernetics, visual and gamer theory).

courses.title: Sounding Data: Critical Approaches to Sonification
courses.desc: Critical and creative approaches to auditory data and display in art, science, and technology. Practical introduction to sonification techniques through sound studies and sensory ethnography. Heuristic listening and collaborative sound design.

courses.title: Ghosts of the Machine: How Technology Rewires our Senses
courses.desc: Historical, aesthetic and critical approaches to how information technologies produced ghost effects or a sense of terror in response to new media like the photograph, gramophone, film, typewriter, computer, Turing Machine. Focus on technological media transforms sense perception.

courses.title: Time: Mechanism & Measurement
courses.desc: Cultural concepts of time; units and instruments of time measurement; historical differences in the social organization of time; and time measurement in 20th-century science.

courses.title: Surveillance Technologies & Social Media
courses.desc: Study of the ubiquitous presence of CCTV, face recognition software, global tracking systems, biosensors, and data mining practices that have made surveillance part of our daily life.  Exploration of the boundary between security and control, information and spying.

courses.title: History of Communication Technologies
courses.desc: History of communication technologies from the late Middle Ages to the 20th century. Questions of technology, knowledge, power and culture. Particular attention to questions about information and truth.

courses.title: Writing Science
courses.desc: Texts and writing practices in the production of scientific knowledge.  Surveys the literary structure of scientific arguments; history of scientific genres; rhetoric and semiotics in scientific culture; graphical systems in the experimental laboratory; narratives of science, including science fiction.

courses.title: Built Environments
courses.desc: Built environments, which are designed to support forms of life.  Their role as carriers of cultural memory and in turning knowledge of nature into social assets. Historical constellations of knowledge, social order, and power.

courses.title: Video Games & Culture
courses.prereqs: STS 001 or TCS 001 or ENL 003;  Or equivalent of any.
courses.desc: Critical approaches to the study of video games, focusing on formal, historical, and cultural modes of analysis. History of software and hardware in North American and global contexts. Relations of games to society, politics, economics, literature, media, and the arts.

courses.title: Science Fiction
courses.desc: The literary modes and methods of science fiction. Representative texts, authors, and themes of the genre; e.g., time travel, alternative universes, and utopias. Relations of science fiction to science, philosophy, and culture.

courses.title: Sociology of Knowledge, Science, & Scientific Knowledge
courses.desc: Social, cultural, and historical dimensions of knowledge, especially scientific knowledge. Problems, methods, and theory in sociology of scientific knowledge. Laboratory and historical case studies. Scientific and technical knowledge in institutional and organizational contexts.

courses.title: Seminar in Science, Technology & Medicine Studies
courses.prereqs: Open to junior and senior Science & Technology Studies majors only.
courses.desc: Intensive reading, discussion, research and writing by small groups in selected topics of science, technology, and medicine studies scholarship. Emphasis on individual research projects.

courses.title: Research in Data Studies
courses.desc: Analysis of real-world data in the form of case studies engaging current issues. Emphasizes teamwork in the identification of problems and sources of relevant data; data cleaning, exploration, analysis, and visualization using R; and interpretation and presentation of results to a variety of stakeholders in oral, visual, and textual formats.

courses.title: Critically Ill Surgical Patients SSM
courses.desc: Special Study Module, a four-week course on the topic: Application of Basic Cardiopulmonary Physiology to Problems Encountered in Critically Ill Surgical Patients.

courses.title: Physiological Principles in SICU SSM
courses.desc: Special Study Module, a four-week course on the topic: Care of the Critically Ill Surgical Patient: Use of Physiological Principles to Guide Treatment of Patients with Common Surgical Problems.

courses.title: Interdisciplinary Study of Gastrointestinal Cancer
courses.desc: In-depth study of gastrointestinal, hepatic and pancreatic cancer. Emphasis on an integration of basic science and clinical medicine. Participating departments include pathology, surgical oncology, medical oncology, gastroenterology, radiology and radiotherapy.

courses.title: Documentary Production
courses.prereqs: TCS 007B;  TCS 155;  Or equivalent proficiency to TCS 007B.
courses.desc: Traditional and new forms of documentary, with focus on technocultural issues.  Skills and strategies for producing work in various media. Progression through all stages of production, from conception through post-production to critique.

courses.title: New Radio Features & Documentary
courses.desc: New feature and documentary production for radio and other audiophonic media, including audio streaming websites and installation. Emphasis on new and experimental approaches to audio production for broadcast on community radio and in international arts programming.

courses.title: History of Sound in the Arts
courses.desc: A survey of the use of sound, voice, noise, and modes of listening in the modernist, avante-garde, and experimental arts, from the late-19th century to the present. Focus on audiophonic and audiovisual technologies.

courses.title: Introduction to Theories of the Technoculture
courses.desc: Major cultural theories of technology with emphasis on media, communications, and the arts. Changing relationships between technologies, humans, and culture. Focus on the evolution of modern technologies and their reception within popular and applied contexts.

courses.title: New Trends in Technocultural Arts
courses.desc: Current work at the intersection of the arts, culture, science, and technology including biological and medical sciences,  computer science and communications, and artificial intelligence and digital media.

courses.title: Concepts of Innovative Soundtracks
courses.desc: Innovative and unconventional soundtracks in cinema, media arts, and fine arts.  Introduction to basic analytical skills for understanding sound-image relationships.

courses.title: Outsider Machines
courses.desc: Invention, adaptation and use of technologies outside the mainstream,  commonsense, and the  possible. Topics include machines as metaphor  and embodied thought, eccentric customizing and  and fictional technologies.

courses.title: Introduction to Documentary Studies
courses.desc: Recent evolution of the documentary. The personal essay film; found-footage/appropriation work; non-linear, multi-media forms; spoken word; storytelling; oral history recordings; and other examples of documentary expression.

courses.title: Media Subcultures
courses.desc: Relationships between subcultural groups and media technologies. Media as the cohesive and persuasive force of subcultural activities. List-servs, websites, free radio, fan 'zines, and hip-hop culture.

courses.title: Ghosts of the Machine: How Technology Rewires our Senses
courses.desc: Historical, aesthetic and critical approaches to how information technologies produced ghost effects or a sense of terror in response to new media like the photograph, gramophone, film, typewriter, computer, Turing Machine. Focus on technological media transforms sense perception.

courses.title: Small Scale Film Production
courses.desc: Lecture and intensive workshop teaching small-scale film production. Appointments as a(n) director, director of photography, actor, writer, lighting designer, sound designer and other critical positions are used to produce and submit a short film to a film festival.

courses.title: Research Methods in Technocultural Studies
courses.desc: Introduction to basic research methods for Technocultural Studies: electronic and archived images, sounds and data, satellite downlinking, radiowave scanning, and oral histories.

courses.title: Writing Across Media
courses.desc: Introduction to experimental approaches to writing for different media and artistic practices. How written texts relate to the images, sounds, and performances in digital and media production.

courses.title: Transportation Survey Methods
courses.desc: Description of types of surveys commonly used in transportation demand modeling, including travel and activity diaries, attitudinal, panel, computer, and stated-response surveys. Discussion of sampling, experimental design, and survey design issues. Analysis methods, including factor, discriminant and cluster analysis.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Transportation Technology
courses.prereqs: MAT 021A;  MAT 021B;  MAT 022A;  and Consent of Instructor.  Graduate or junior/senior undergraduate as a technical elective.
courses.desc: Designed to prepare in the basics of thermodynamics, fluid mechanics and heat transfer as they relate to transportation.

courses.title: Transportation Planning & Policy
courses.desc: Transportation planning process at the regional level, including the role of federal policy in shaping regional transportation planning, tools and techniques used in regional transportation planning, issues facing regional transportation planning agencies, pros and cons of potential solutions and strategies.

courses.title: Selected Topics in Transportation Technology & Policy
courses.desc: Directed group study of special topics with instruction carried out through lecture or laboratory, or a combination of both.

courses.title: Selected Topics in Transportation Technology & Policy
courses.desc: Directed group study of special topics with instruction carried out lecture or laboratory, or a combination of both.

courses.title: Introduction to Textiles
courses.desc: Introduction to the structure and properties of textiles. Consumer use and fabric characteristics are emphasized.

courses.title: Style & Cultural Studies
courses.desc: Multiple and overlapping influences of gender, sexuality, ethnicity, and class on constructions of identity and community are explored through the study of style in popular culture and everyday life. Continuity and change in clothing and appearance styles are interpreted.

courses.title: The Textiles & Apparel Industries
courses.desc: Textile and apparel industries including fashion theory, production, distribution, and consumption of textile goods.

courses.title: Social & Psychological Aspects of Clothing
courses.desc: Social and cognitive factors influencing management and perception of personal appearance in everyday life. Concepts and methods appropriate to the study of meaning of clothes in social and cultural contexts.

courses.title: Social & Psychological Aspects of Clothing
courses.desc: Social and cognitive factors influencing management and perception of personal appearance in everyday life. Concepts and methods appropriate to the study of meaning of clothes in social and cultural contexts.

courses.title: Textile Fabrics
courses.desc: Properties of fabrics as related to serviceability, comfort, and appearance.

courses.title: Textile Fabrics
courses.desc: Properties of fabrics as related to serviceability, comfort, and appearance.

courses.title: Textile Coloration & Finishing
courses.desc: Basic principles of textile dyeing, printing, and finishing; color theory; structure, properties, and application of dyes and finishes; factors affecting application and fastness; maintenance of dyed and finished textiles.

courses.title: Principles of Apparel Production
courses.desc: Overview of characteristics, technology, processes, and research in apparel manufacturing industries including study of government statistics, material utilization and fabrication, mechanization, management, and production engineering.

courses.title: Principles of Apparel Production
courses.desc: Overview of characteristics, technology, processes, and research in apparel manufacturing industries including study of government statistics, material utilization and fabrication, mechanization, management, and production engineering.

courses.title: Textile Processes
courses.desc: Physical processes involved in the production of textiles from the individual fiber to the finished fabric. Includes spinning, texturing, yarn formation, weaving preparation, weaving and knitting, tufting and fabric finishing.

courses.title: Clothing Materials Science
courses.desc: The properties, characterization, and performance evaluation of clothing materials and structures for specific functional applications. Principles and methods related to wetting and transport properties, fabric hand and aesthetic properties, clothing comfort, and material and assembly technology.

courses.title: Principles of Fashion Marketing
courses.desc: Study of basic elements of fashion marketing including philosophy and objectives, organization, merchandising, pricing, promotion and personnel.

courses.title: Principles of Fashion Marketing
courses.desc: Study of basic elements of fashion marketing including philosophy and objectives, organization, merchandising, pricing, promotion and personnel.

courses.title: Introduction to World Trade in Textiles & Clothing
courses.desc: Structure of the global fiber/textile/apparel complex and its distribution patterns with an overview of political, economic and technological factors that are changing these industries and their markets.

courses.title: Introduction to World Trade in Textiles & Clothing
courses.desc: Structure of the global fiber/textile/apparel complex and its distribution patterns with an overview of political, economic and technological factors that are changing these industries and their markets.

courses.title: Behavorial Science Concepts in Textiles
courses.prereqs: TXC 107;  Upper division or graduate course in statistics (e.g., AMR 120) and one in a behavioral science (e.g., PSC 145).
courses.desc: Examination of theories and research concerning relationships between clothing and human behavior with emphasis on research techniques, including methods of measuring clothing variables.

courses.title: Recent Advances in Textiles
courses.prereqs: Two upper division courses in Textiles & Clothing (TXC) or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Critical reading and evaluation on selected topics of current interest in textiles. Multidisciplinary aspects of the topics selected will be stressed.

courses.title: Introduction to Academic Literacies
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Introduction to reading and composing processes and key rhetorical concepts for academic literacies. Multiple drafts of composing projects in a variety of genres and modes with feedback from peers and the instructor.

courses.title: Introduction to Academic Literacies
courses.prereqs: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).
courses.desc: Introduction to reading and composing processes and key rhetorical concepts for academic literacies. Multiple drafts of composing projects in a variety of genres and modes with feedback from peers and the instructor.

courses.title: Practices in College Reading & Writing
courses.desc: Development of skills required for success in college-level writing across genres and disciplines. Integrates reading, critical thinking, and written communication, using texts from across the curriculum.

courses.title: Practices in College Reading & Writing
courses.desc: Development of skills required for success in college-level writing across genres and disciplines. Integrates reading, critical thinking, and written communication, using texts from across the curriculum.

courses.title: Practices in College Reading & Writing for Multilingual Writers
courses.prereqs: Enrollment via campus placement (using the English Language Placement Exam or Analytical Writing Placement Exam) or after successful completion of UWP 022.
courses.desc: Development of multilingual writers' composition and English language skills across genres and disciplines.  Integrates college-level reading, critical thinking, and written communication, using texts from across the curriculum.

courses.title: Practices in College Reading & Writing
courses.desc: Development of skills required for success in college-level writing across genres and disciplines. Integrates reading, critical thinking, and written communication, using texts from across the curriculum.

courses.title: Introduction to Professional Writing Studies
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Introduction to writing as an object of study and to theories and research in the field. Survey of how writing is created, disseminated, and used in private, public, and academic contexts.

courses.title: Popular Science & Technology Writing
courses.desc: Positioning of science and technology in society as reflected and constructed in popular texts. Topics include genre theory, demarcation, rhetorical figures, forms of qualitative and quantitative reasoning, and the epistemic role of popularization in science.

courses.title: Writing & Visual Rhetoric
courses.desc: Introduction to writing needs, conventions, and genres in design contexts. Emphasis on applying critical reading, analysis, and writing skills to designed products, such as graphics, visual communications, and clothes, and designed spaces, such as exhibitions and interior architecture.

courses.title: Video Game Rhetorics
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better.
courses.desc: Examination of video games as rhetorical texts whose meaning is produced through complex interplay of procedures, narratives, rules, and context. Writing about video games using critical perspectives and analytic methods.

courses.title: Oral English for International Students
courses.desc: Intensive work in oral English for international students, to increase fluency, accuracy, and use of appropriate discourse strategies in academic settings; e.g., seminar, discussion, laboratory. Training in segmental features of English sounds, intonation, stress, non-verbal cues, and register.

courses.title: Introduction to Academic Reading & Writing for Multilingual Students
courses.desc: Reading and writing paragraphs and short multi-paragraph texts for academic purposes. Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

courses.title: Intermediate Academic Reading & Writing for Multilingual Students
courses.desc: Reading and writing short multi-paragraph texts for academic purposes. Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

courses.title: English Structures & Strategies in Academic Writing
courses.desc: Practice in academic writing designed to prepare undergraduate students from language backgrounds other than English for successful academic work. Development of academic writing, critical thinking, and reading skills. Development of clear, accurate language for presenting an effective argument.

courses.title: Academic Writing for ESL Students
courses.desc: Writing skills necessary for upper division courses, including skills crucial to writing lab and project reports, summaries, critiques, abstracts, and responses to exam questions.  Includes practice with the syntax, grammar, and vocabulary characteristics of academic writing.

courses.title: Reading in Scientific & Technical Subjects for ESL Students
courses.desc: Instruction and practice in reading scientific and technical texts. Techniques for comprehending and analyzing grammatical and organizational patterns. Notetaking skills, summarizing, vocabulary enrichment.

courses.title: Persuasive Writing for Multilingual Students
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better.
courses.desc: Instruction in analyzing style of persuasive texts, using appropriate vocabulary, and applying English grammatical structures in argumentation. Suitable for multilingual students desiring additional instruction in persuasive English writing.

courses.title: Research Writing for Multilingual Students
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better.
courses.desc: Reading and writing effectively in various research genres across the disciplines. Suitable for multilingual students desiring additional instruction in the linguistic and rhetorical features of research writing in English for academic purposes.

courses.title: Style in the Essay
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  or equivalent.
courses.desc: Principles of style, language, and structure in the essay. Analysis and development of voice and genre, including sentence revision for force and clarity, and development of effective paragraphs and essays.

courses.title: Writing Research Papers
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  or equivalent.
courses.desc: Principles of research writing. Analysis and development of research topics and effective arguments, including critical reading, analysis, integration, and documentation of source material.

courses.title: Genre Theory & Professional Writing
courses.prereqs: (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y);  UWP 010;  Or the equivalent of UWP 001.
courses.desc: Introduction to discipline of professional writing. Examination of writing as a social practice, using genre theory as a conceptual framework. Analysis of how genres function rhetorically in specific contexts and how social systems both shape and are shaped by genres.

courses.title: Advanced Composition
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Instruction in advanced principles of expository writing. Writing tasks within and beyond the University. Different writing modes, including narrative, analysis, explanation, argument, critique. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Advanced Composition
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Instruction for students in all disciplines in advanced principles of academic and professional writing. Focus on writing tasks both within and beyond the academy. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Advanced Composition
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Instruction for students in all disciplines in advanced principles of academic and professional writing.  Focus on writing tasks both within and beyond the academy.

courses.title: Writing in the Disciplines: Special Topics
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced instruction in writing in that discipline and practice in effective styles of communication.

courses.title: Writing in the Disciplines: Biology
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced instruction in writing in biology.

courses.title: Writing in the Disciplines: History
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced instruction in writing in history.

courses.title: Writing in the Disciplines: International Relations
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced instruction in writing in international relations.

courses.title: Writing in the Disciplines: Engineering
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced instruction in writing in engineering.

courses.title: Writing in the Disciplines: Food Science & Technology
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced instruction in writing in food science & technology.

courses.title: Writing in the Disciplines: Environmental Writing
