courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced instruction in writing and practice in effective styles of communication in the fields of environmental study, policy, or advocacy.

courses.title: Writing in the Disciplines: Human Development & Psychology
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced instruction in writing and practice in effective styles of communication in Human Development & Psychology.

courses.title: Writing in the Disciplines: Ethnic Studies
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced instruction in cross-disciplinary writing about race and ethnicity and practice in effective styles of communication.

courses.title: Writing in the Disciplines: Fine Arts
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced instruction in writing about the arts and practice in effective styles of communication.

courses.title: Writing in the Disciplines: Sociology
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced instruction in writing and practice in effective styles of communication in Sociology and related academic and professional fields.

courses.title: Writing in the Disciplines: Film Studies
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced instruction in writing about film and practice in effective styles of communication.

courses.title: Writing in the Disciplines: Community & Regional Development
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced instruction in writing in the Community & Regional Development discipline and practice in effective styles of communication.

courses.title: Writing in the Disciplines: Anthropology
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  4 or 5 on AP English Lit and Comp exam; or 6 or better on IB HL English Exam.
courses.desc: Advanced instruction in writing and practice in effective styles of communication in Anthropology and related academic and professional fields.

courses.title: Writing in the Professions: Business Writing
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Effective communication in and for organizations, including corporations, government agencies, and non-profit. Suitable for students entering careers such as management, public relations, and grant writing.

courses.title: Writing in the Professions: Business Writing
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Effective communication in and for organizations, including corporations, government agencies, and nonprofit. Suitable for students entering careers such as management, public relations, and grant writing.

courses.title: Writing in the Professions: Law
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced principles of critical thinking, argumentation, and style, with special emphasis on their application in the legal profession. Suitable for students planning careers in law, business, administration, or management.

courses.title: Writing in the Professions: Journalism
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Non-fiction for magazines and newspapers, with attention to style and language. Emphasis on research, interviewing, market analysis, and query letters.

courses.title: Writing in the Professions: Elementary & Secondary Education
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced expository writing in the contemporary American classroom. Strongly recommended for teaching credential candidates.

courses.title: Writing in the Professions: Science
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing or enrollment in a graduate science curriculum.
courses.desc: Writing abstracts, research proposals, scientific papers, other forms of scientific communication. Presenting data graphically. Primarily for students engaged in or planning careers in basic or applied research.

courses.title: Writing in the Professions: Health
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced expository writing common in the health professions, emphasizing effective communication between the writer and different audiences. Topics relate to health, disability, and disease. Suitable for students planning careers in professions such as medicine, dentistry, physical therapy, optometry.

courses.title: Writing in the Professions: Health
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better;  UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced expository writing common in the health professions, emphasizing effective communication between the writer and different audiences. Topics relate to health, disability, and disease. Suitable for students planning careers in professions such as medicine, dentistry, physical therapy, optometry.

courses.title: Writing in the Professions: Internships
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced instruction in writing in the workplace, including public and private sectors, government agencies, profit and non-profit organizations. Collaborative work and practice in effective styles of communication. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Writing in the Professions: Writing for Social Justice
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Advanced instruction in writing for Social Justice, using an interdisciplinary approach combining feminist, critical race, ethnic, cultural, and transnational studies; practice in techniques of research and styles of communication for diverse audiences. Suitable for activists in community organizing, non-profits, politics.

courses.title: Writing in the Professions: Technical Writing
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better;  and upper division standing.
courses.desc: Communicating effectively about technology and other technical subjects to varied audiences for varied purposes. Suitable for students entering professions that require communicating technical information to subject matter experts, managers, technicians, and non-specialists.

courses.title: English Grammar
courses.prereqs: UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y or ENL 003 or LIN 001 or LIN 001Y;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Survey of present-day English grammar as informed by contemporary linguistic theories. The major syntactic structures of English; their variation across dialects, styles, and registers; their development; and their usefulness in describing the conventions of English.

courses.title: Specialized Genres in Professional Writing
courses.prereqs: Satisfaction of the upper division writing requirement.
courses.desc: Instruction in the elements and practices of professional writing in specialized genres. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Specialized Topics in Journalism
courses.prereqs: Satisfaction of the upper division writing requirement.
courses.desc: Instruction in the elements and practices of advanced journalism.

courses.title: Specialized Topics in Journalism: Investigative Journalism
courses.prereqs: Satisfaction of the upper division writing requirement.
courses.desc: Instruction in the elements and practices of in-depth investigative journalism.

courses.title: Specialized Topics in Journalism: Science Journalism
courses.prereqs: Satisfaction of the upper division writing requirement.
courses.desc: Instruction in the elements and practices of science journalism.

courses.title: Introduction to Professional Editing
courses.prereqs: satisfaction of the upper division writing requirement.
courses.desc: Introduction to general editing practices and principles, with an emphasis on professional editing in organizational contexts, including academia and the workplace. Extensive practice in copy, comprehensive, and collaborative editing.

courses.title: Rhetorical Approaches to Scientific & Technological Issues
courses.desc: Application of rhetorical theories to scientific issues. Topics include: Rhetorical dimensions of scientific knowledge-making; scientific voice; rhetorical figures in science; incommensurability and demarcation; epistemology, definition, and classification; science wars; models of scientific literacy and accommodation, and implications for risk communication.

courses.title: History of Scientific Writing
courses.desc: History of scientific writing from the 17th century to the present; origins and evolution of scientific genres; role of scientific writing in producing scientific knowledge; discursive differences between disciplines; emergence of English as a global language of science.

courses.title: Capstone Portfolio Seminar
courses.desc: Capstone course for majors. Synthesis and application of  rhetorical concepts learned in the major. Development of professional digital and print portfolio for graduate school and career applications.

courses.title: Rhetorical Approaches to Genre Study
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Using genre theory and methods of analysis to understand and prepare to do research on different types of writing in varying academic and professional contexts. Emphasis on problems in organizational, professional, and/or interdisciplinary communication.

courses.title: English for International/ESL Graduate Students
courses.desc: Multi-skills ESL course designed to help international/ESL students improve their English language skills for successful academic study. Emphasis on writing, speaking, listening, reading, and academic culture.

courses.title: Writing for International Graduate Students
courses.desc: Focuses on writing needed for academic work, including summaries, critiques, research & grant proposals, memos, resumes, and research papers. Includes a review of grammar needed for writing and some focus on reading skills and American vocabulary and idioms.

courses.title: Writing Assessment
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Examines key testing and measurement concepts; the history of writing assessment; and relationships among writing tests and methods of teaching writing; the impacts of Information and Communication Technology (ICT), and how educational policies both drive and respond to writing assessments.

courses.title: Writing Program Administration
courses.desc: Theories, models, and procedures of writing programs, primarily in higher education. Developmental, first-year, and advanced writing programs, writing centers, writing-across-the-curriculum programs, writing minors and majors, and graduate programs in rhetoric and composition.

courses.title: Literacy & Technology
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Examines how the physical qualities of texts offer different affordances during production and reception; grounds these discussions in the development of literacy practices and writing technologies from ancient to contemporary; creates frameworks for research into literacy, teaching, and textual technologies.

courses.title: Oral English for ESL Students
courses.prereqs: Open only to non-native speakers of English with priority enrollment to international student teaching assistants; completion of any required ESL courses or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Intensive work in oral English for non-native English-speaking students, particularly international student teaching assistants, to increase fluency, accuracy, and use of appropriate discourse strategies in academic settings; e.g., seminar, discussion, laboratory.

courses.title: Introduction to Viticulture
courses.desc: Fundamental principles of biology and culture of the grapevine including taxonomy, morphology, physiology, distribution, domestication, utilization, propagation, production systems, harvesting, and storage and processing of grapes. Successful completion should prepare students for upper division courses in viticulture.

courses.title: Introduction to Winemaking
courses.desc: Overview of the history of wine, viticulture, fermentation, winery operations, the physiology of wine consumption, wines produced in California and other major wine-producing regions and the sensory evaluation of wine. May be taught abroad.

courses.title: Viticultural Practices
courses.desc: Identification, cultivation, and use of the major wine, table, raisin, and rootstock cultivars. Includes practices specific to the fall such as fruit contracts, maturity sampling, harvesting, cover crops, and soil-pests. One field trip required.

courses.title: Viticultural Practices
courses.desc: Theory, principles, and practices of pruning and grapevine propagation.  Plant materials and the certification process, weed control and weed identification, wood diseases, and frost protection. One field trip required.

courses.title: Viticultural Practices
courses.desc: Field oriented experience in the principles and practices of grapevine production, including vineyard establishment, vine training, trellising, canopy management practices, irrigation and water management, and methods of crop adjustment for improvement of fruit quality. One field trip required.

courses.title: Grapevine Growth & Physiology
courses.desc: Botanical aspects including morphology and domestication will precede lectures covering flower development and energy budget concepts. Impact of physiological variables such as photosynthesis translocation, mineral nutrition, and water relations on fruit ripening and composition will be covered.

courses.title: World Viticulture
courses.desc: Study of the diversity of viticulture, both geographical and historical. History of grape growing and its spread throughout the world will be covered, along with discussions of current viticultural practices in different parts of the world, including California.

courses.title: Soils in Viticulture
courses.prereqs: (CHE 002B or CHE 002BH);  BIS 002A;  (PHY 001A,  PHY 001B (can be concurrent)) or PHY 007A (can be concurrent);  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Landscape distribution, physical and chemical processes in viticultural soils. Site evaluation procedures, best soil management practices, vineyard fertilization, and soil health monitoring.

courses.title: Soils in Viticulture
courses.desc: Landscape distribution, physical and chemical processes in viticultural soils. Site evaluation procedures, best soil management practices, vineyard fertilization, and soil health monitoring.

courses.title: Fermented Foods
courses.prereqs: BIS 103;  MIC 102;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Physiology, biochemistry, and genetics of microorganisms important in food fermentations. How microorganisms are used in fermentations and how raw materials are converted into finished fermented foods and beverages.

courses.title: Raisin & Table Grape Production
courses.desc: Overview of the raisin and table grape industries in California and other production areas of the world. Cultural practices associated with raisin and table grape production will also be discussed.

courses.title: Grapevine Pests, Diseases & Disorders
courses.desc: Various pests and diseases of vineyards throughout California. Pest/disease identification and control methods (to include sampling techniques) also will be discussed. Integrated management approach to pest control methods will be emphasized.

courses.title: Analysis of Musts & Wines
courses.prereqs: CHE 002C;  PLS 021;  (CHE 008B or CHE 118B or CHE 128B).
courses.desc: Fundamental principles of analytical chemistry as they relate to specific methods used in winemaking.

courses.title: Wine Production
courses.prereqs: VEN 003;  VEN 123 (can be concurrent);  (BIS 102 or BIS 105).
courses.desc: Principles and practices of making standard types of wines, with special reference to grape varieties used and methods of vinification.

courses.title: Wine Types & Sensory Evaluation
courses.desc: Principles of sensory evaluation and application to wines. Factors influencing wine flavor, data from sensory analysis of model solutions.

courses.title: Wine Stability
courses.desc: Principles of equilibria and rates of physical and chemical reactions in wines; treatment of unstable components in wines by adsorption, ion exchange, refrigeration, filtration, and membrane processes; and protein, polysaccharide, tartrate, oxidative and color stabilities.

courses.title: Wine Microbiology
courses.prereqs: (VEN 123,  VEN 124,  MIC 102,  MIC 103L);  VEN 125, VEN 126 recommended.
courses.desc: Nature, development, physiology, biochemistry and control of yeasts and bacteria involved in the making, aging and spoilage of wine.

courses.title: Wine Technology & Winery Systems
courses.prereqs: PLS 021;  MAT 016A;  MAT 016B;  ((PHY 001A,  PHY 001B) or PHY 007A).
courses.desc: Process technologies and process systems that are used in modern commercial wineries. Lectures, demonstrations, problem solving sessions, and possible field trips. Includes grape preparation and fermentation equipment; post-fermentation processing equipment; winery utilities, cleaning systems, and waste treatment.

courses.title: Distilled Beverage Technology
courses.desc:
Distillation principles and practices; production technology of brandy,
whiskey, rum, vodka, gin, and other distilled beverages; characteristics of raw materials, fermentation, distillation, and aging.

courses.title: Introduction to Scientific Methods
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Processes involved in conducting scientific research. Topics covered will include conducting literature review, formulating hypotheses, and analyzing and reporting results. Students will complete an annotated bibliography and complete a written and oral research proposal.

courses.title: Sensometrics
courses.prereqs: FST 117;  ((VEN 125,  VEN 125L) or (FST 107A or FST 107B));  Or equivalent to FTS 117.
courses.desc: Experimental design and statistical analysis, including multivariate analysis, for both sensory and instrumental data in enology and food-related studies.

courses.title: Sustainable Vineyard Development
courses.prereqs: (VEN 101A,  VEN 101B,  VEN 101C);  (VEN 115 or VEN 118);  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Application of plant, meteorological, soil, water, GIS, and economic sciences to sustainable vineyard development. Preparation of a comprehensive study to determine the viticultural and economic feasibility of a given site for raisin, table, or wine grape production.

courses.title: Field & GIS Evaluation of Soils
courses.prereqs: PLS 120;  (PLS 205 or PLS 206);  (SSC 100 or SSC 105 or SSC 107);  VEN 101C;  Consent of Instructor.  ABT 180 is recommended.
courses.desc: Principles and practices used to evaluate agricultural soils in the field, including soil pits, soil cores, electrical conductivity meters, ground penetrating radar, geomorphology and surface terrain analysis. Use of geographic information sciences, soil databases, digital elevation models and geostatistics.

courses.title: Natural Products of Wine
courses.prereqs: VEN 123;  VEN 124;  and Consent of Instructor.  Or natural products background.
courses.desc: Structure, occurrence, and changes due to wine production to the natural products found in wine. Chemicals with a sensory impact will be emphasized, including flavonoids and other phenolics, terpenes and norisoprenoids, pyrazines, oak volatiles and other wine constituents.

courses.title: Instrumental Analysis of Must & Wine
courses.prereqs: VEN 123 or FST 103;  ((BIS 102 and BIS 103) or BIS 105), (CHE 107B or CHE 115) recommended.
courses.desc: Theory and practice of instrumental analysis of wines and musts.  mphasis on the principles of analytical techniques (e.g., CE, GC, HPLC, Mass Spectrometry) and factors determining correct choice of instrumental method.

courses.title: Advances in the Science of Winemaking
courses.prereqs: VEN 125;  VEN 126;  or Consent of Instructor.  Graduate standing.
courses.desc: Selected topics in the science and technology of winemaking. Topics will be drawn from current research of participating enology and viticulture faculty. Critical analysis of the technical content of published material will be emphasized.

courses.title: Advanced Sensory Analysis of Wines
courses.prereqs: ((VEN 124,  VEN 125) or FST 107);  AMR 120;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Sensory descriptive analysis experiments will be designed and conducted using standard sensory science methods.Data will be analyzed by analyses of variance, principal component analyses and generalized Procrustes analysis to evaluate the judges performance and interpret the significance of the results.

courses.title: Winery Design
courses.prereqs: VEN 124;  VEN 135;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Design of wineries. Includes process calculations, equipment selection, process layout and building choice and siting. Project scheduling, capital costs, and ten-year cash flow analysis for the winery. One field trip required.

courses.title: Advanced Viticulture
courses.prereqs: VEN 110;  VEN 116;  VEN 124;  VEN 125;  VEN 210 recommended.
courses.desc: Critical evaluation of scientific and popular literature on selected topics of current interest that relate viticulture to fruit or wine sensory attributes or quality.

courses.title: Current Topics in Neurotoxicology
courses.prereqs: Core courses in one of the following graduate programs: Pharmacology & Toxicology (PTX), Agricultural & Environmental Chemistry (AGC), Biochemistry & Molecular Biology (BMB), Cell & Developmental Biology (CDB), Immunology (IMM), Molecular Cellular & Integrative Physiology (MCP) or Neuroscience (NSC).
courses.desc: General principles of neurotoxicology, the cell and molecular mechanisms and health impacts of specific neurotoxicants and the contribution of neurotoxic compounds to complex neurodevelopmental disorders and neurodegenerative diseases.

courses.title: Metabolism of Toxicants & Drugs
courses.prereqs: PTX 201;  PTX 202;  PTX 203;  General biochemistry or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Significance/chemical pathways of toxicants and drug metabolism, enzymology and molecular aspects of P450 and flavin monooxygenases, hydrolases and phase 2 transferases and experimental approaches for metabolism studies.

courses.title: Toxicology of the Respiratory System
courses.prereqs: PTX 201;  PTX 202;  PTX 203;  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Survey of structure and function of the respiratory system, the pathophysiology of major lung diseases, the interactions of toxicants with the lung and response of this organ to injury.

courses.title: Pharmacokinetics & Biopharmaceuticals
courses.desc: In-depth study of pharmacokinetics, including the fundamentals of pharmacokinetics, how to design a pharmacokinetic study and how to use both compartmental and non-compartmental analysis to interpret the data.

courses.title: Knights Landing One Health Center
courses.desc: Internship at Knights Landing One Health Center (KLOHC) for undergraduate pre-veterinary student. Application of veterinary and One Health concepts to their work at the center.

courses.title: Infectious Disease in Ecology & Conservation
courses.prereqs: BIS 002A;  BIS 002B;  BIS 002C;  or equivalent. EVE 100 is recommended.
courses.desc: Introduction to the dynamics and control of infectious disease in wildlife, including zoonotic diseases and those threatening endangered species. Basic epidemiological models and application to field data. Scientists' role in developing disease control policies.

courses.title: Evaluation & Use of Diagnostic Tests
courses.prereqs: MPM 205 or EPI 205;  Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Clinical and epidemiologic properties and application of diagnostic tests for disease, with emphasis on selecting tests; validating, evaluating, and interpreting new tests individually and in aggregate; determining cutoff values; and developing testing strategies.

courses.title: Gun Violence
courses.desc: Gun violence, viewed from the perspectives of criminology and public health. Topics include personal and societal contributing factors and critical assessment of potential solutions.

courses.title: Washington Center Research Seminar
courses.desc: Core academic component of Washington Program. Topics coordinated with internships. Research draws on resources uniquely available in Washington, DC. Supervised preparation of extensive paper.

courses.title: Wildlife Ecology & Conservation
courses.desc: Introduction to the ecology and conservation of vertebrates. Complexity and severity of world problems in conserving biological diversity.

courses.title: Natural History of California's Wild Vertebrates
courses.desc: Examination of the natural history of California's wild vertebrates (fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals), including their biogeography, systematics, ecology and conservation status.

courses.title: Introduction to Conservation Biology
courses.desc: Introduction to conservation biology including both biological and social issues related to the loss of species and habitats. Intended for students with no background in biological sciences.

courses.title: Field Methods in Wildlife, Fish, & Conservation Biology
courses.prereqs: EVE 101 (can be concurrent) or ESP 100 (can be concurrent);  (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C);  and Consent of Instructor.  Or equivalent course of EVE 101 or ESP 100 (can be taken concurrently).
courses.desc: Introduction to field methods for monitoring and studying wild vertebrates and their habitats, with an emphasis on ecology and conservation. Required weekend field trips.

courses.title: Field Research in Wildlife Ecology
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  One upper division course in each of ecology, statistics, and either ornithology, mammalogy, or herpetology.
courses.desc: Field research in ecology of wild vertebrates in terrestrial environments; formulation of testable hypotheses, study design, introduction to research methodology, oral and written presentation of results.  Limited enrollment.

courses.title: Field Research in Wildlife Ecology: Laboratory
courses.prereqs: WFC 101 (can be concurrent);  and Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Field research in ecology of wild vertebrates in terrestrial environments; testing ecological hypotheses through field research, application of research methodology, supervised independent research projects. Held between Labor Day and fall quarter.

courses.title: Field Studies in Fish Biology
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Upper division course in each of ecology, aquatic biology, fish biology, and statistics.
courses.desc: Emphasis on theory of quantitative fish capture methods and design of individual research projects on ecology, behavior, physiology or population biology of fishes.

courses.title: Applied Statistics for Wildlife Research
courses.prereqs: (MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B);  (WFC 010 or WFC 050);  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Introduction to basic statistical concepts and methods as tools for fish and wildlife research. Application of general guiding principles of developing research questions and projects, basic probability theory, statistical estimation (correlation, regression, ANOVA, Chi-square test) and hypothesis testing. Introduction of some specialized analytical techniques, such as population dynamics modeling and time series analysis.

courses.title: Biology & Conservation of Wild Mammals
courses.prereqs: (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C);  (EVE 101 (can be concurrent) or ESP 100 (can be concurrent));  Or equivalent course to ESP 100 or EVE 101.
courses.desc: Origins, evolution, diversification, and geographical and ecological distributions of mammals. Morphological, physiological, reproductive, and behavioral adaptations of mammals to their environment.

courses.title: Biology & Conservation of Wild Birds
courses.prereqs: BIS 002A;  BIS 002B;  BIS 002C;  Upper division ecology course recommended.
courses.desc: Phylogeny, distribution, migration, reproduction, population dynamics, behavior and physiological ecology of wild birds. Emphasis on adaptations to environments, species interactions, management, and conservation.

courses.title: Biology & Conservation of Fishes
courses.prereqs: BIS 002A;  BIS 002B;  BIS 002C;  Upper division ecology course recommended.
courses.desc: Evolution, ecology, and conservation of marine and freshwater fishes.

courses.title: Physiology of Fishes
courses.prereqs: Upper division courses in nutrition and physiology or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Comparative physiology, growth, reproduction, behavior, and energy relations of fishes.

courses.title: Population Dynamics & Estimation
courses.prereqs: (MAT 016A,  MAT 016B);  (STA 013 or STA 013Y);  (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C);  Or the equivalent of STA 013; an upper division course in ecology.
courses.desc: Description of bird, mammal and fish population dynamics, modeling philosophy, techniques for estimation of animal abundance (e.g., mark-recapture, change-inratio, etc.), mathematical models of populations (e.g., Leslie matrix, logistic, dynamic pool, stockrecruitment); case histories.

courses.title: Sampling Animal Populations
courses.prereqs: (STA 100 or PLS 120);  (EVE 101 or ESP 100);  or equivalent; upper division standing.
courses.desc: Introduction to major statistical modeling approaches for estimating animal population parameters, including: sample counts, distance sampling, repeated point counts (N-mixture modeling), capture-mark-recapture for closed and open populations, static and dynamic occupancy modeling, and richness estimation. Methods are embedded in the context of obtaining reliable estimates of abundance, survival, occurrence and other ecological parameters for management and conservation.

courses.title: Tropical Ecology & Conservation
courses.desc: Ecology and natural history of the tropics. Challenges and opportunities associated with tropical conservation. Design and communicate course-based research project.

courses.title: Physiological Ecology of Wildlife
courses.prereqs: EVE 101 or ESP 100;  (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C);  Or equivalent course to ESP 100.
courses.desc: Principles of physiological ecology, emphasizing vertebrates. Ecological, evolutionary, and behavioral perspectives on physiological mechanisms used by animals to adapt to their environment, including consideration of climate-change and other threats to biodiversity. Tropical, temperate, and polar ecosystems are highlighted.

courses.title: Herpetology
courses.prereqs: BIS 002A;  BIS 002B;  BIS 002C;  Upper division ecology course recommended.
courses.desc: Evolution and ecology of the world’s diverse reptiles and amphibians. Emphasis on adaptations to environments, species interactions, management, and conservation.

courses.title: Ecology of Waterfowl & Game Birds
courses.prereqs: WFC 111;  or Consent of Instructor.  WFC 111L strongly recommended.
courses.desc: Detailed examination of distribution, behavior, population dynamics, and management of waterfowl and upland game birds.

courses.title: Behavioral Ecology
courses.prereqs: EVE 101 or ESP 100 (can be concurrent);  (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C);  Or equivalent course.
courses.desc: Basic theories underlying the functional and evolutionary significance of behavior, and the role of ecological constraints. Supporting empirical evidence taken mainly from studies of wild vertebrates.

courses.title: Marine Conservation Science
courses.desc: Key differences between marine and terrestrial ecosystems, major stressors of marine ecosystems (e.g., fisheries, pollution, bioinvasions, climate change and habitat destruction) and their consequences. Laws and agencies responsible for addressing problems, and the policies used.

courses.title: Urban Wildlife Ecology
courses.prereqs: BIS 002A;  BIS 002B;  BIS 002C;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Introduction to the behavior, ecology, and evolution of wild animals in urban environments. Effects of urbanization on disease, fitness, and dynamics of animal populations. Conservation and conflict management efforts in urban settings.

courses.title: Wildlife Ecology
courses.desc: Ecology of wild vertebrates, including habitat selection, spatial organization, demography, population dynamics, competition, predation, herbivory, energetics, and community dynamics, set in the context of human-caused degradation of environments in North America.

courses.title: Ecology of Human-Wildlife Conflicts
courses.desc: Ecological approaches to managing wild vertebrates that come into conflict with agriculture, public health, or the conservation of biodiversity.

courses.title: Wildlife Ecotoxicology
courses.prereqs: Introductory courses in organic chemistry, ecology, and physiology, or consent of instructor; ETX 101 recommended.
courses.desc: Various forms of environmental pollution in relation to fish and wildlife, the effects and mechanisms of pollutants, effects on individuals and systems, laboratory and field ecotoxicology, examples/case histories, philosophical/management considerations.

courses.title: Conservation Biology
courses.prereqs: (EVE 101 (can be concurrent) or ESP 100 (can be concurrent));  (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C);  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Introduction to conservation biology and background to the biological issues and controversies surrounding loss of species and habitats.

courses.title: Habitat Conservation & Restoration
courses.prereqs: EVE 101 or ESP 100;  Or the equivalent of ESP 100 or EVE 101; WFC 154 and ENH 160 recommended.
courses.desc: Analysis of the characteristics of wildlife and fish habitats, the conservation of habitats, and restoration.

courses.title: Plant Geography
courses.prereqs: ESP 100 or EVE 101;  PLB 102 or PLB 108 strongly recommended.
courses.desc: Survey of the geographical distribution of vegetation types and habitats, with consideration of the environmental and historical factors that determine these patterns. Conservation and management approaches. Analytical field and lab techniques introduced.

courses.title: Coastal Ecosystems
courses.prereqs: EVE 101;  course work in organismal biology, physical geography, and geology recommended.
courses.desc: Overview of coastal ecosystems, physical and biological elements and processes, and coastal zone dynamics, including sandy, rocky and muddy shorelines, estuaries, dunes and coastal watersheds. Discussion of the role of historical factors and conservation, restoration, and management approaches.

courses.title: Infectious Disease in Ecology & Conservation
courses.prereqs: EVE 101 or ESP 100 or VET 409;  Or the equivalent.
courses.desc: Introduction to the dynamics and control of infectious disease in wildlife, including zoonotic diseases and those threatening endangered species. Basic epidemiological models and their applications. Role of scientists in developing disease control policies.

courses.title: Animal Coloration
courses.desc: Evolutionary and ecological significance of coloration in mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish, cephalopods, crustaceans, spiders, insects, humans as well as color in fashion, plants and the military. Topics include history, protective coloration, warning coloration, mimicry, sexual dichromatism and color change.

courses.title: Climate Change Ecology
courses.prereqs: BIS 002B;  (EVE 101 or ESP 100);  or Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Ecological responses to current and expected future climate change, across levels of biological organization from individuals to ecosystems.

courses.title: Museum Science
courses.prereqs: Consent of Instructor.  Upper division standing.
courses.desc: Principles and methods required to preserve and present biological specimens for research, teaching collections, and museums.

courses.title: Conservation Biology & Animal Behavior
courses.prereqs: ECL 208 or ANB 221;  and Consent of Instructor.
courses.desc: Influences of concepts of animal behavior (functional, evolutionary, developmental, mechanistic, and methodological issues) on conservation biology theory and practice.

courses.title: Advanced Physiological Ecology of Wildlife
courses.desc: Advanced principles of physiological ecology. Ecological, evolutionary and behavioral perspectives on physiological mechanisms used by animals to adapt to their environment in the context of climate change and other threats to biodiversity. Primary literature will form the basis of discussion.

courses.title: Advanced Population Dynamics
courses.prereqs: Graduate standing; advanced course in ecology (e.g., EVE 101), population dynamics (e.g., WFC 122), and one year of calculus; familiarity with matrix algebra and partial differential equations recommended.
courses.desc: Logical basis for population models, evaluation of simple ecological models, current population models with age, size, and stage structure, theoretical basis for management and exemplary case histories. Emphasis on development and use of realistic population models in ecological research.

courses.title: Cultural Representations of Gender
courses.desc: Interdisciplinary investigation of how specific cultures represent gender difference. Examine a variety of cultural forms and phenomena including film, television, literature, music, popular movements, and institutions.

courses.title: Gender & Global Cinema
courses.desc: Role gender plays in film history/culture in various geographical contexts and in aspects of contemporary globalization. Films from nations such as China, Colombia, Cuba, Ethiopia, India, Iran, Korea, New Zealand, and the U.S.

courses.title: Introduction to Critical Gender Studies
courses.desc: Introduction to interdisciplinary, critical gender studies. Addresses the emergence of women’s, gender and feminist studies internationally, its links to women’s movements, and its influence within the various arts, humanities and social science disciplines.

courses.title: Feminist Critiques of Western Thought
courses.desc: Critical introduction to major traditions of social thinking in the West from a feminist perspective.

courses.title: Theory & History of Sexualities
courses.desc: Key issues in the social construction, organization, and reproduction of sexualities such as the intersection of sexual identity with gender, race, ethnicity, and class, and the relation between movements for sexual liberation and the regulation of the body.

courses.title: Special Topics in Critical Gender Studies
courses.desc: In-depth examination of a women and gender studies topic related to the research interest of the instructor.

courses.title: Gender & Post Colonialism
courses.desc: Explores changing configurations of race, gender, sexuality, class and implications for governmentality in one or more colonial or postcolonial regimes in one or more societies.

courses.title: Introduction to Feminist Theory
courses.prereqs: WMS 050 recommended or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Introduction to the emergence of feminist theory and to key concepts in feminist theorizing. Examination of past and current debates over sexuality, race, identity politics, and the social construction of womens experience.

courses.title: Feminist Research
courses.desc: Introduction to feminist applications and transformations of traditional disciplinary research practices;  initial training in methodologies for feminist interdisciplinary work.

courses.title: Globalization & Politics of Family Change
courses.desc: Political/cultural changes, conflicts, and economic disparities that have led to greater mobility and dispersal of families. Transnationalism on gender relations, sexualities, and the meaning of family.

courses.title: Critical Food Studies
courses.desc: Production and consumption of food at the intersections of gender, race, ethnicity, nation, and body. Individual and familial experiences as part of larger economic and political structures in the U.S. and globally.

courses.title: Contemporary Debates in Western Feminist Theory
courses.desc: Interpretations of poststructuralist, postmodern, and postcolonial thought from a critical feminist perspective; includes methods of applying theory to concrete social/cultural problems of gender, race, sexuality, class.

courses.title: Critical Fashion Studies
courses.desc: Feminist cultural studies of style-fashion-dress through transnational circuits, personal subjectivities. Fashion as means of gender oppression and liberation. Histories and discourses of  masculinities and femininities. Clothing works on global assembly line. Use of dress in construction/regulation of identities.

courses.title: Feminist Cultural Studies
courses.desc: Histories, theories, and practices of feminist traditions within Cultural Studies.

courses.title: Gender & Law
courses.desc: Exploration of womens legal rights in historical and contemporary context, discussing a variety of legal issues and applicable feminist theories. Topics include constitutional equal protection, discrimination in employment and education, sexual orientation discrimination, and the regulation of abortion.

courses.title: Women's Movements in Transnational Perspective
courses.desc: Transnational perspectives on 20th- and 21st-century women’s movements in Western, colonial and post-colonial contexts, examining movement’s forms and political orientations and relationships between women’s movements and other forces for change.

courses.title: Gender, War & Peace
courses.desc: Applies a critical gender perspective to militarism as manifest in contexts of military rule, war, conflict, peacebuilding and security post-conflict. Addresses the changing configurations of gender and sexuality in military institutions and militarized economies and cultures from an interdisciplinary perspective.

courses.title: Science, Gender, & Social Justice
courses.desc: Critical reading and reflection on the history of Western science, scientific institutions and the changing role of science in relation to inequalities of class, race, gender and sexuality, and global struggles for equality and justice.

courses.title: Masculinities
courses.desc: Cultural, economic, and political forces which shape historical and contemporary masculinities. Impact of race, class, ability, nation and sexuality on experiences and cultural representations of masculinity.

courses.title: Women, "Race" & Sexuality in Postcolonial Cinema
courses.desc: Feminist analysis of race, sexuality and class in the representation of women in commercial and/or independent films.

courses.title: Feminist Film Theory & Criticism
courses.desc: Historical overview of and contemporary issues in feminist film theory, including representation, spectatorship, and cultural production. Film stars, women filmmakers, and the intersections of gender, race, sexuality, and class in films and their audiences.

courses.title: Topics in Gender & Cinematic Representation
courses.desc: Examination of a specific topic within the broad rubric of gender and cinema. Possible topics include Latinas in Hollywood; gender, nation, cinema; and gender and film genre. Topics vary.

courses.title: Feminist Media Production
courses.prereqs: (CTS 020 or CDM 020);  or two WMS courses.
courses.desc: Media production as a mode of cultural criticism, furthering feminist/ social justice activist goals. Fundamentals of camera, editing and distribution via a social engagement model. Study and hands-on response to key historic and contemporary feminist and social justice media discourses.

courses.title: Queer Studies
courses.prereqs: WMS 070 recommended or consent of instructor.
courses.desc: Study of queer sexualities, identities, theories, practices. Alternative sexualities as historical, social, and cultural constructions in intersections with race, gender, class, nationality. Interdisciplinary exploration of sexual liberation and the regulation of sexuality through history, theory and expressive cultural forms.

courses.title: Body Politics
courses.desc: The body as a site where status inequalities are formed and resisted. Self-making through bodywork, history of gendered and racial meanings of the body, and analysis of normalizing discourses and practices.

courses.title: Gender & Experience of Race
courses.desc: Exploration of the co-construction of “race” and gender in comparative national historical contexts and contemporary lived experience. Study of intersections of race and gender in identities and how institutions, labor migration, social movements and consumption shape racialized gendered identities.

courses.title: Autobiography, Narrative, Memoir
courses.desc: Life narrative writings by women. Transgressive voices exploring issues of race, class, and sexuality, women's silence and marginalization. Theories of autobiography, autoethnography and memoir included.

courses.title: Women Writers & the Transnational Imaginary: The Arab World
courses.desc: Writings by women from diverse regions and cultures, understood in their cultural, socio-economic, and historical contexts, with each course offering a focus on women’s writing in specific geographic/national locations and their diasporas: The Arab World.

courses.title: Women Writers & the Transnational Imaginary: Asia
courses.desc: Writings by women from diverse regions and cultures, understood in their cultural, socio-economic, and historical contexts, with each course offering a focus on women’s writing in specific geographic/national locations and their diasporas: Asia.

courses.title: Women Writers & the Transnational Imaginary: The Caribbean
courses.desc: Writings by women from diverse regions and cultures, understood in their cultural, socio-economic, and historical contexts, with each course offering a focus on women’s writing in specific geographic/national locations and their diasporas: The Caribbean.

courses.title: Women Writers & the Transnational Imaginary: Africa
courses.desc: Writings by women from diverse regions and cultures, understood in their cultural, socio-economic, and historical contexts, with each course offering a focus on women’s writing in specific geographic/national locations and their diasporas: Africa.

courses.title: Women Writers & the Transnational Imaginary: Diasporic Women Writers in Europe
courses.desc: Writings by women from diverse regions and cultures, understood in their cultural, socio-economic, and historical contexts, with each course offering a focus on women’s writing in specific geographic/national locations and their diasporas: Diasporic Women Writers in Europe.

courses.title: Transnationalism & Writing by Women of Color
courses.desc: Writings by women of color in a transnational framework, understood in their cultural, socio-economic, and historical contexts. The interrelation among gender, writing, nationalism, and transnationalism with focus on women's writing in specific geographic/national locations and their diasporas: Topics on Women Writers of Color.

courses.title: Literature as Aesthetics of Resistance
courses.desc: Literature by women and other marginal groups which embody dissent and subversion as a means of challenging the status quo and to affect social transformation.

courses.title: Women of Color Writing in the United States
courses.desc: Literature, especially novels, written by contemporary women of color in the United States, understood in their socio-economic, cultural and historical contexts.

courses.title: Globalization, Gender & Culture
courses.desc: Critical gender analysis of globalization as a process of interconnected cultural, social and economic transformations inflected by gender, nation, class and race/ethnicity. Critical self-reflection and social observation skills.

courses.title: Gender in the Arab World
courses.desc: Examination of the history, culture, and social/political/economic dynamics of gender relations and gendering in the Arab world.

courses.title: Women & Islamic Discourses
courses.desc: Introduction to debate/discourses about women and Islam. Transformations in debate/discourses in colonial and postcolonial periods in the Middle East & South Asia. Comparative study of debate/discourses on family, work, law, sexuality, religion, comportment, human rights, feminist and religious movements.

courses.title: Gender & Public Policy
courses.desc: Role of gender in the creation of social policies, especially with respect to issues brought into the policy arena by contemporary feminism.

courses.title: Special Topics in Critical Gender Studies
courses.desc: In-depth examination of a women's studies topic related to the research interests of the instructor.

courses.title: Special Topics in Feminist Theory & Research
courses.desc: Explores in depth a topic in feminist theory and research related to the research interests of the instructor.
